HEADLINE: HOUSE PROUD;
It Was a Dark and Stormy Rewrite . . .

BYLINE: By JULIE MICHAELS 

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
JONATHAN HARR is a homebody. His world by day and most nights -- is a book-lined study at the front of a turn-of-the-century Victorian house in this college town. In his study, Mr. Harr spent eight years writing "A Civil Action," a nonfiction blockbuster that has sold a million copies since its publication in 1995. The story of an ambitious lawyer with a passion for social justice, Mr. Harr's book follows a lawsuit against two companies accused of dumping toxic wastes and causing leukemia in children in Woburn, Mass.
A meticulous reporter with a novelist's gift for narrative, the author fashioned a legal thriller out of an enormously complex case. Even John Grisham, master of the genre, has called the book, published by Random House, "the most compelling chronicle of litigation" he has ever read. 
 Hollywood agreed. Mr. Harr sold the film rights to Robert Redford and the Walt Disney Company for $1.25 million. The film, starring John Travolta, is to open on Christmas Day. For Mr. Harr and his wife, Diane, the windfall was a happy ending to years of struggle. His $80,000 advance petered out long before the manuscript was completed. To get by, they relied on Mrs. Harr's salary as a part-time art teacher. Their one buffer against hard times was their house.
Within walking distance of Northampton's trendy downtown, the house sits on a sleepy, tree-lined street, its wraparound porch reminiscent of an Andy Hardy movie. The couple bought the place for $86,000 in 1981. But with interest rates at 17 percent, they could afford it only by converting the upstairs into two rentals.
"I hated being a landlord," Mr. Harr, 49, recalled during a late-summer lunch at his house. "We had only one thermostat, which meant we paid for the heat. I'd lie in bed at night, hear the furnace turn over and listen to my money going up the chimney."
As Mr. Harr struggled with his book, he never dreamed of having a best seller, much less a movie sale. He hoped "A Civil Action" would earn enough for a new roof.
"When you go from $2,500 in the bank to $1.25 million, a strange delirium sets in," he said, reaching down to pet his creaky basset hound, McPhee (named for the nonfiction master John McPhee). Finally they asked their tenants to leave, then moved out themselves, for six months of renovation.
The couple had two priorities: Mr. Harr's office and the kitchen. Although south-facing, the office was darkened by the overhanging porch. During endless months of reading and annotating court documents -- stacked up, they'd have stood as tall as a three-story building -- he had longed for light. "I look back," he said, "and it seems to me it was always winter, always dark. I felt I had lived eight years in a cave."
When he wasn't in his cave, Mr. Harr was in the kitchen. Both Harrs are passionate cooks, as evidenced by a garden heavy with ripe tomatoes and the chilled orange-and-carrot soup Mrs. Harr had made for lunch.
In preliminary interviews with architects, the kitchen expanded and contracted, the study moved upstairs and down. But it wasn't until the Harrs met Tom Douglas, of the Northampton firm bearing his name, that they found someone who shared their vision.
"It was a great house," Mr. Douglas said, "but the interior was chopped up into a bunch of small, dark rooms." By moving a staircase and consolidating some rooms, the architect was able to open up the downstairs area. An addition at the rear -- what Mrs. Harr calls the "Victorian ranch" wing -- was rebuilt with a guest bedroom, a bath and an expanded dining room.
Mr. Douglas left the study at the front of the house. He solved the light problem by linking the room via an open arch to the former living room, now a library. The area is flooded by light from a bay window.
"Initially, I envisioned a more formal room, with a library table and chairs," Mr. Douglas said. But Mr. Harr's work habits required a couch. He does his best thinking -- and his best worrying -- lying down.
Like any struggling writer, Mr. Harr worried constantly about money. Midway through the book, broke and mired in rewriting, he considered applying for a job at a Burger King. That goes a long way toward explaining his Depression-style spending habits. But he couldn't resist splurging on the new kitchen.
Anchored by a 48-inch professional Viking stove and a Sub-Zero refrigerator, it is designed to accommodate two cooks working side by side. One wall is lined with pale maple cabinets, specially designed by Lance Hodes of Haydenville (Mass.) Woodworking and Design. The black counter tops are made of Ashfield schist, a local slate.
But some costs Mr. Harr could not countenance. For the kitchen, Mr. Douglas chose a handsome German faucet by Grohe but didn't note that it listed for $600. Mr. Harr rejected it. "But it haunted me," the architect said with a laugh. "At every meeting that followed, Jonathan always managed to bring up the Grohe faucet."
Mrs. Harr cheerfully conceded that she learned early on not to miss meetings with the architect. One time, Mr. Harr eliminated a shower in the master bath and counters of crow's-foot schist, a spectacular black slate with pale flecks that mimic avian footprints. "I made him put them back," she said.
Mr. Douglas confessed that his greatest concern was Tracy Kidder, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, who is Mr. Harr's best friend and Northampton neighbor. Mr. Kidder wrote "House," an account of the design and construction of a house in nearby Amherst -- and the disputes and misunderstandings that occurred as it went up. "Any architect would be nervous if he knew the guy who wrote 'House' was scrutinizing his drawings," Mr. Douglas said.
He need not have worried. The Harrs, who spent $300,000 on the project, said they are delighted. Over lunch, the couple spoke of their old house -- its faulty wiring, its old furnace -- the way one would speak of an old friend. They bickered good-naturedly over who saw it first and just how much they charged in rents. Finally, Mr. Harr escaped to walk McPhee, while Mrs. Harr offered an upstairs tour.
The larger apartment has become a second guest room and the master bedroom suite, with its fancy counter tops and walk-in shower. The second apartment became Mrs. Harr's studio. Then she opened a door to reveal that apartment's old kitchen.
"We decided we'd keep it," she said, ever the pragmatist. "Jonathan wants to write another book, and you never know -- if we need the income, we can always rent it out."

Wine racks run under a 10-foot island.; WINTER'S PAST -- The study, left, where Mr. Harr wrote his blockbuster is now filled with light. Right, bay windows run the length of the dining room, once a tiny nook. (Photographs by Lionel Delevingne for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TURF;
Mortgage Debate: Wait Or Seize the Moment?

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
HOW loooooooow can they go?
With the rates for many mortgages almost a percentage point below where they were a year ago, prospective co-op and condominium buyers in Manhattan are asking their mortgage brokers whether they should take the plunge or wait until the stock market -- or interest rates -- take another dive. 
 The answer depends on whom you talk to. The heads of New York City's two biggest mortgage brokerages -- Skyscraper Mortgage and Manhattan Mortgage -- give intriguingly different advice.
Neil Bader, the chief executive of Skyscraper Mortgage, said he tells clients who don't have to buy now to "hold off for six months." Mr. Bader, who wrote $750 million in mortgages last year, predicts that real estate prices in Manhattan will soften further -- financial parlance for "go down" -- and that mortgage interest rates will also decrease.
Since the Dow Jones industrial average's 512-point plunge on Aug. 31, Mr. Bader has been besieged with calls from nervous buyers. His purchase business -- as opposed to the refinancing of existing mortgages to take advantage of the low rates -- is down 35 percent from what it was in September 1997, he said.
Meanwhile, his chief competitor, Melissa Cohn, the president of Manhattan Mortgage, said that the number of customers applying through her company for a new mortgage, not a refinance, has stayed almost the same. What has changed are the percentages those new mortgages represent. In September 1997, new mortgage applications made up 76 percent of the company's $800 million-a-year business. This September, new buyers made up 59 percent. The number of refinancings almost doubled -- from 24 percent in September 1997 to 41 percent last month.
Ms. Cohn is advising buyers to seize the moment.
"It's impossible to predict the future," she said. "First, the apartment you love may not be there in six months. Second, nothing says that prices -- after one month of softening -- may not turn around and start going up again. And third, interest rates could go up."
The discrepancy between the Skyscraper figures, which show a significant drop in applications to buy, and those from Manhattan Mortgage, which show about the same number of applications, can be readily explained. Skyscraper, Mr. Bader said, owes 80 percent of its business to Wall Street -- brokers, bankers and lawyers. Only 40 percent of Manhattan Mortgage's business comes from Wall Street, Ms. Cohn said.
"The people closest to Wall Street -- the high-flying folks -- may not be coming into the marketplace," said Keith Gumbinger, a vice president with HSH Associates, of Butler, N.J., a financial publisher that surveys lenders across the country. "Whereas people not connected with it, more middle-market folks, just don't notice any difference."
For those who have decided to buy, Mr. Bader, Ms. Cohn and other mortgage brokers surveyed this week offered the following advice:
If you're wondering whether to go for a 30-year fixed mortgage or one of the tailor-made 5-, 7- or 10-year adjustable mortgages -- in which the interest rate remains fixed for the first 5, 7 or 10 years and then adjusts relative to the prevailing rates -- consider this. Current 30-year fixed-mortgage interest rates, which were around 6.69 percent yesterday, according to HSH, are the lowest in three decades. So, if you're a bit of a gambler, or if you know you're going to live in your new house for, say, exactly 10 years, you'll pay less per month with a 10-year adjustable.
Match the product to the time frame, brokers say. They agree that if you need a $300,000 mortgage, you'll pay $120 less a month in the first decade of a 10-year adjustable than for a 30-year fixed.
But with the rates for 30-year fixed loans so low, some buyers may prefer to pay the extra and relax. After all, over the next 30 years, rates will almost certainly go up. (Remember when mortgages hit 16 percent during the Carter Administration?)
"It may be that with all the uncertainty, you feel most comfortable by jumping into a 30-year fixed," Mr. Gumbinger of HSH said. "It provides the most stability, but you'll have to pay for it."

HEADLINE: G.M. to Open Doors of On-Line National Showroom

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
THE burgeoning Internet has often been compared with the automobile industry in the early days of mass production. Now the big auto makers want to take more of their business on line.
The General Motors Corporation intends to become the first auto maker to offer nationwide Internet shopping for the cars and trucks sitting on participating dealers' lots. 
 The company announced this week that GM Buy Power (www. gmbuypower.com), a Web site, would start operating in the first quarter of 1999, enabling customers to do everything over the Internet except actually buy and take delivery of a vehicle, which must still be done at a dealership.
The on-line customer will be able to schedule a test drive, ask the dealer to hold or locate a specific vehicle, find out the dealer's best price on a selected vehicle and apply for pre-approved financing from the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. The Web site will list all vehicles in inventory at dealers participating in the service, with the list updated daily.
Unlike such other on-line buying services as Autobytel and Microsoft's Carpoint, GM Buy Power will not limit consumers to shopping a specific geographic area, giving them a wider choice, a spokesman for G.M. said.
G.M. dealers will not pay a monthly subscription fee to participate in the service and, for the first nine months of 1999, G.M. will not charge dealers an enrollment fee. Other services require a monthly fee in return for limiting the number of dealers in an area who can participate.
All G.M. dealers can be part of GM Buy Power if they agree to certain customer standards; install required computer hardware, which costs about $1,000, and send a dealership manager through training.
G.M. research shows that customers want the time needed to buy a vehicle at a dealership to be an hour to an hour and a half instead of the usual three to five hours, said Ron Sobrero, the Chevrolet general sales and service manager who is a leader of the national roll-out of the site.
The Internet is becoming too popular with car shoppers for auto manufacturers to ignore.
Nearly 25 percent of vehicle shoppers search the Internet for information before buying, a number that is likely to rise to 50 to 60 percent in 2000, according to a recent study by J. D. Power and Associates of Agoura Hills, Calif.
G.M.'s decision to take the on-line shopping service nationwide follows a successful test started in October in four Western states: California, Oregon, Washington and Idaho. In the test, the Buy Power site received more than 670,000 visits in its first 10 months, with users spending an average of 11 minutes there, making it one of G.M.'s most active sites. More than 60 percent of the dealers in the region participated in the service, and consumers made more than 300,000 on-line searches for GM Buy Power dealers.
Both Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation plan to upgrade their Web sites (www2.Ford. com) and (www2.Chryslercorp. com) to offer similar listings of dealer inventory and the ability to find out a dealer's best price. Both currently offer model specifications (but not listings of specific vehicles) and the ability to get a quote from a dealer on a car or truck via phone or E-mail.

HEADLINE: Germany's Futile Look Back

BYLINE: By Norbert Walter; Norbert Walter is chief economist of the Deutsche Bank Group.

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
Everyone is attributing Helmut Kohl's defeat in the German elections to one decisive factor: that, after 16 years, the people here wanted a change. In fact, the opposite is true: the voters in the world's third-largest economy essentially expressed their desire to leave things unchanged.
In Gerhard Schroder, the Social Democratic victor, they have chosen a leader who has nurtured a happy-go-lucky isolationism, allowing them to hold on to all those cherished notions of the German welfare state. After all, if they really looked across their borders, they would discover that many Europeans have sobered up and changed their ways. 
 In his campaign, Mr. Schroder vowed to "modernize" Germany. Yet he has already announced that some of the very modest cuts the Kohl Government had sought in the welfare system would be revoked. Succumbing to redistributionist policies generous even by German standards is surely no way to "modernize." Nor can the unemployment problem be solved by continuing the huge subsidies that prop up old-line industries like coal and steel.
Holding on to the illusions of the past only means that Germany will waste more time on the road to reform. But reform is inevitable, as Mr. Schroder surely understands.
When push comes to shove, one can ultimately count on the new Chancellor to be a pragmatist. His Government will eventually come around to discovering what virtually everybody else, including Britain's reformed Labor Party, has already learned. In the long run, the only way to solve the scourge of unemployment is to bring wage costs in line with international levels. As long as German industrial workers, with their generous benefits, cost up to 80 percent more than their American counterparts, unemployment will not decline dramatically.
I assume it will take a year or two for the new Government to find its proper step. In the meantime, the world can judge Mr. Schroder's seriousness -- or perhaps even his ability to speed up this timetable -- with two important tests. The first is whether he announces that some of the policies he had promised are too expensive to be carried out because of the deficit left behind by the previous Government. That is what Bill Clinton and Lionel Jospin, the French Prime Minister, did after they were first elected. If Mr. Schroder does not resort to this old trick, he can count on having a much harder time reining in his parliamentary troops.
The second big test is whether the Chancellor-elect will succeed in integrating Oskar Lafontaine, the Social Democrats' powerful chairman, into his Cabinet as Finance Minister. If Mr. Lafontaine takes the post, as many expect, Mr. Schroder can be relieved that his main political competitor will have effectively become a member of the inside team. But if Mr. Lafontaine does not join the Government, trouble lies ahead. Unlike Tony Blair, Mr. Schroder is not clearly in control of his party, and Mr. Lafontaine is influential enough to undermine any reformist tendencies. His economic instincts are, for the most part, similar to those of the old-line British Laborites, who saw the state as the overriding factor in the economy.
Fortunately, even if Mr. Schroder fails both of these early tests, there is yet another check to keep Germany from going overboard. Today, most European Union countries are governed by social democrats. In the past, such a political landscape translated into a push for more public spending. But these days, thanks to the disciplinary forces of the European Monetary Union, that tendency is being reined in. The German budget for next year is already set, and it will meet the deficit limit set by the European Union. The new Government can shuffle money around a bit, but it cannot exceed the spending levels.
The monetary union exerts an enormous amount of peer pressure. If Germany's Social Democrats are inclined to overdo it on social spending, the finance ministers and prime ministers of the other European countries, most of them left-leaning, will probably come down hard on them. After undergoing painful belt-tightening themselves, the Europeans won't want to see the benefits of their sacrifices squandered. And the Germans, who have been the enforcers of fiscal discipline in Europe, will not want to become the objects of that enforcement themselves. Such are the disciplinary wonders of the new Europe.

HEADLINE: Clinton Putting Off Visits to India and Pakistan

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The White House said today that President Clinton had put off a visit to India and Pakistan, whose tests of nuclear devices in May set off alarm around the world.
"The President has decided to postpone his visit to India and Pakistan, which had been under review, which also means he will not be making a separate visit to Bangladesh," Michael D. McCurry, the President's spokesman, said at today's White House briefing. 
 He said the President would go ahead with plans to attend a meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Conference in Malaysia in mid-November. While he did not say what new countries might be put on the itinerary now that India and Pakistan are off it, other officials said South Korea and Japan might be added.
A year ago, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to visit India and Pakistan this fall "if all goes well." But in May, India exploded five nuclear devices. The United States imposed sanctions on India and warned Pakistan, India's longtime enemy, not to set off nuclear devices of its own. But Pakistan did, incurring sanctions.
The most severe sanctions against both countries have been lifted, and last week India and Pakistan pledged at the United Nations to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, which would prohibit nuclear testing.
But details of their participation in the treaty remain to be worked out. Mr. McCurry said today that the atmosphere was still not conducive to a Presidential visit, although he expressed pleasure that India and Pakistan had announced resumption of diplomatic talks.
"At the same time, the issues that we have been discussing with both Governments are complex and we believe will require more time to be addressed to our mutual satisfaction," Mr. McCurry said.
He said Mr. Clinton "is still eager to make the visit when we have had further significant progress with our respective security concerns."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Home Sales Down Again; Economic Indicators Flat

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Sales of new single-family homes fell in August for the second consecutive month, a sign that the lowest mortgage rates in more than three decades might not be enough to give the housing market, and the economy, a lift in coming months. Separately, a measure of future economic activity held steady during August.
The Commerce Department said today that home sales dropped 4.4 percent in August from July, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 838,000 units. During July, sales had declined 4.9 percent from June's record sales level. 
 In a separate report, the Conference Board said the index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in August after having risen half a percent in July. That suggested the economy would keep expanding "through at least early 1999," the Conference Board, a private research organization, said.
"Domestically, the general health of the economy is pretty strong," Dan Seto, an economist at Nikko Securities Company International in New York, said. Although the economy is not likely to maintain its growth rate of the first half, when it expanded at a 3.7 percent annual rate, "we could easily get by with a 2 percent" rate in the second half, he said.
The two economic reports were released one day after the Federal Reserve cut the overnight bank lending rate to 5.25 percent from 5.5 percent in an effort to keep the financial turmoil elsewhere in the world from doing too much harm to the American economy.
The level of home sales in August was the lowest since March. All of the weakness was in the South, where sales fell almost 14 percent, the biggest drop in three years. The Northeast, Midwest and West all registered single-digit gains.
The stagnant index of leading indicators sent a mixed signal. While the Conference Board said the report pointed to a continuation of the economy's expansion, which is nearly eight years old, the index has registered only one increase in the last four months. In contrast, the index rose in every month but one between July 1997 and April of this year.
Of the index's 10 components, five made a positive contribution in August, four were negative and one was unchanged. The biggest gain for August's index came from an increase in the money supply. The largest negative contributor was the slumping stock market.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Canada Drops CurrencyTrigger

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 30

 BODY:
The Bank of Canada has abandoned its policy of regular, predictable intervention in currency markets in defense of the Canadian dollar in favor of a more discretionary approach, bank officials said today.
The decision by the Canadian central bank and the Department of Finance marks the formal abandonment of the bank's policy of intervening in currency markets whenever the United States dollar moved 70 basis points against the Canadian dollar in either direction from the previous day's official close. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 The policy, first adopted by the bank in April 1995, was intended to smooth out volatility in Canadian dollar trading.
An official statement on the change said it was intended to increase the effectiveness and "signaling impact" of intervention.
In conformance with the change, the central bank stood on the sidelines this morning as the Canadian dollar tumbled through what would have been the central bank's normal intervention trigger.

HEADLINE: Possible I.M.F. Bailout Stirs Brazilians' Bitter Memories of 80's

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 30

 BODY:
With the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting about to start in Washington, with officials' weighing the cost and wisdom of bailing out Brazil from its deepening economic crisis, the prospect of a rescue package, however urgent, is stirring bitter memories among a cross-section of Brazilians.
Although Brazilian officials have been negotiating the size and conditions of possible aid for weeks, and the I.M.F. said today in Washington that it was negotiating a substantial aid package, the issue is so sensitive that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, hoping to be re-elected on Sunday, has not announced a formal request to the fund for assistance. 
 That has not stopped Mr. Cardoso's main opponent, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, of the left-of-center Workers's Party, from attacking Mr. Cardoso as a slave of foreign bankers. In the free air time that candidates receive, the Workers' Party shows Mr. Cardoso with head bowed as an announcer discusses the sacrifices that foreign lenders demand.
Mr. da Silva has called the administration's attempts to negotiate an accord with the fund a crime and said it would "tighten one more knot on the neck around Brazilians."
A cartoon in Jornal do Brasil, the newspaper, struck the same theme, showing a drowning man being thrown a noose.
The outcome, due after the elections, will depend on the winner and the course of negotiations with the monetary fund. Talks with the United States and the fund have focused on a loan package most likely to exceed $30 billion.
Brazil had a bruising experience with the fund in the 80's, and the effects linger. A new accord, even attached to billions of dollars, is widely seen an admission of the Government's failure to put its house in order and a humiliating surrender of sovereignty over economic policy.
The Government in has recent years made once unimaginable strides in cutting inflation, from 3,000 percent a year four years ago to 3 percent this year. But its budget deficit has ballooned, to 7.2 percent of the gross national product, and a broad measure of the flow of goods and services, the current account, is running a deficit close to $35 billion.
Deficits are not new. But the shortage of credit for emerging markets has pushed Brazil to the brink of crisis. Since the Russian crisis began last month, foreign reserves have shrunk, from $70 billion to $42 billion, despite moves to protect the currency by doubling interest rates.
Brazil today is different from the country that defaulted on its foreign debt in 1981. It is six economic plans later. Many of the officials who lashed out at the monetary fund for imposing stiff conditions for aid 10 years ago are struggling to hold firm to stability and have answered the crisis with pledges to cut entitlements and other costs.
But among ordinary Brazilians, the I.M.F. is associated, if not faulted, for a punishing recession through the 1980's and with issuing spending limits that Brazil failed to meet.
"There was the idea that by freezing prices and other gimmicks you could get somewhere," said Sebastian Edwards, a professor of international economics at the University of California at Los Angeles who wrote "Crisis and Reform in Latin America" (Oxford University Press, 1996).
Although it signed 11 agreements with the monetary fund throughout the 80's, Professor Edwards said, Brazil insisted that because of its size and importance, it should not be subject to the same conditions as other nations in trouble.

HEADLINE: Red Ink No More;
With Deficits Gone, Benefits of Surplus Are Debated

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
For the better part of two decades, economists and elected officials promised that all kinds of good things would happen if the Federal Government stopped running huge budget deficits.
Today the Government closed the books on its fiscal year, and for the first time since 1969 the budget will show a surplus, which President Clinton said should be about $70 billion when all the calculations are completed in a few weeks. That is slightly higher than the $63 billion projected in August by the Congressional Budget Office. 
 So where's the payoff?
To some degree, the answer is straightforward: Interest rates are lower than they would be otherwise, a development that has helped push unemployment down and the stock market up throughout much of this decade. That shift has also helped establish the United States as an anchor of stability in a world now at risk from the deepening global financial crisis.
But even now, some economists and analysts think the benefits from fiscal prudence have been overstated, and some wonder whether the projected surpluses will materialize if the economy should slip into recession. There is still a debate about how much the strong economy reflects the nation's improved fiscal condition and how much the improved fiscal condition is a result of the strong economy.
There is also some lingering doubt, especially among liberal Democrats, about whether the fiscal belt-tightening will prove a good deal for low- and moderate-income people in the long run, or whether it primarily benefited Wall Street and the wealthy.
Moreover, there is no consensus yet about what to do with coming surpluses, which the Congressional Budget Office estimated will total $1.55 trillion over the next decade. The debate over tax cuts, additional spending, reducing the national debt and strengthening entitlement programs is only the beginning.
Indeed, there is a growing battle over whether the Government should consider itself to be in surplus at all, since nearly all of the excess revenues in coming years come from payroll taxes supposed to be earmarked for the Social Security trust fund.
The dawn of the surplus era passed all but unnoticed today in the financial markets, which have long since factored in the anticipated good news. Meanwhile, in Washington, it was a day for celebration and contention, with both Democrats and Republicans claiming credit for the turnaround while laying out their own priorities for the future.
Mr. Clinton reiterated his position that the surplus be kept in reserve until Congress and the Administration settle on a plan to shore up Social Security for the coming retirement of the baby-boom generation. Republicans kept up their demands that a chunk of the surplus be allocated to tax cuts so that it is not used for increased spending, and said that Mr. Clinton had already raided the surplus by proposing as much as $17 billion in emergency spending next year for domestic and military programs that fall outside the normal budget process.
Beyond the political posturing, there is agreement among many economists that fiscal rectitude, when combined with unexpectedly high tax receipts stemming in part from the rapid run-up in the stock market, helped to push down interest rates. That happened because the Government's borrowing requirements declined, and because the absence of fiscal stimulus convinced investors and the Federal Reserve that inflation was less of a threat.
Just how much lower rates are than they would have been in the absence of fiscal improvement is largely a matter of guesswork, given the myriad of interrelated factors that influence rates.
But there is little question that lower rates have been a key factor in keeping the economy growing since 1991 and in generating new jobs at a healthy pace while stimulating business investment in productivity-enhancing machinery and computers. As a result, many analysts say, the United States is facing a period of deepening global economic crisis with considerable strength and resilience, a far cry from its position a decade ago when it was frequently judged to be in economic decline.
"The strength of the economy that we're all enjoying now is in no small part attributable to the efforts we've made to eliminate the deficit," said Robert D. Reischauer, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office who is now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, the research group. "We can be buffeted by the winds from Asia and the waves from Latin America, and still our economy chugs along."
In the long run, moreover, moving from deficits to surpluses provides the United States with greater flexibility in economic and social policy, from cutting taxes to increasing spending and coping with the strains that will result from an aging population.
"All of our policy for years was driven by nickel-and-diming the deficit rather than asking what's the right policy," said Van Doorn Ooms, a former chief economist for the House Budget Committee who is now with the Committee for Economic Development, a business-sponsored research group.
"If we maintain our heads and approach this sensibly, it's much easier now to take on issues like Social Security and Medicare," he said.
Still, there have been challenges to the prevailing fiscal orthodoxy from both the left and the right.
To begin with, many liberals have long been uncomfortable with the notion that balancing the budget was more important than financing social programs. To some Democrats, the emphasis on eliminating the deficit remains little more than cover for Republicans who want to shrink the size and influence of the Federal Government. But they also acknowledge real benefits from fiscal prudence, particularly the Federal Reserve's willingness to cut interest rates early in the Clinton Administration and its increased tolerance for extremely low unemployment rates even as growth has remained strong.
"Those cuts in real interest rates were very important in propelling the economy forward," said Robert B. Reich, who was Labor Secretary during Mr. Clinton's first term. "On the other hand, deficit reduction meant cuts in domestic discretionary programs, especially those for the less well off. And the President was unable to do anything close to the $50 billion a year in education, training and research and development investments that he had built his 1992 campaign around."
Whether the sacrifices turn out to be worthwhile will depend on how well the economy holds up the next time the business cycle turns down and on how the country chooses to use the coming surpluses, Mr. Reich said.
"If they're turned into tax cuts that are mostly for people in the top 20 percent of income or wealth, then many of the sacrifices made by those in the bottom half, in terms of programs lost or investments not made, will have been for very little," Mr. Reich said. "If the surpluses are turned into investments in the productive capacities of people in the bottom half -- education, job retraining, an expanded earned-income tax credit, for example -- then the payoff may be quite substantial."
John F. Cogan, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution and a former Reagan Administration budget official, questioned the premise that eliminating the deficit -- or more precisely, imposing higher taxes and restraining spending -- had been the key to the economy's strong performance.
"The causality is working in the other direction here," Mr. Cogan said. "The reason we have a budget surplus is not so much because we have had fiscal restraint -- although we have had more fiscal restraint in recent years -- but because of a healthy economy."
Mr. Cogan said the surpluses provided the nation with an opportunity to change its tax system, strengthen Social Security or reduce the $5.5 trillion national debt.
"Having said that, the surpluses can also represent a large problem," Mr. Cogan said. "Along with surpluses come, inevitably, the pressure to spend more, and we're already seeing the manifestation of that pressure.'
The assumption that the elimination of the deficit has brought tangible economic benefits is not universally accepted, either.
"Yes, we seem to be moving away from chaos and toward stability," Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant in New York, wrote recently in Challenge magazine. "It should be good news. And yet the payoff we were promised from reducing the budget deficit remains unfulfilled."
Mr. Bernstein argued that the trade deficit, which some economists had predicted would fall in tandem with the budget deficit, remained stubbornly high, even before the Asian crisis sent it even higher. And he made a case that interest rates, adjusted for inflation, have actually remained high despite the fiscal improvement.
The idea that the trade and budget deficits were inextricably linked may have been questionable from the start, since trade is subject to political and business influences as well as fiscal change. And given the tangle of complicated factors that determine interest rates, it is difficult to say what would have happened to rates had the nation not balanced its budget.
But Mr. Bernstein also made a point that would resonate with many economists in a world subject to rapid economic change: that it is hazardous to assume that changing one element in the country's economic mix could be counted on to have a certain result.
"The advocates of the mainstream hypothesis fell into error because they forgot one of the primary lessons of macroeconomics," Mr. Bernstein wrote. "Partial equilibrium -- moving one variable while holding all else constant -- is an interesting but a hazardous basis for prediction."
As a case in point, Mr. Bernstein cites savings rates. While deficits declined, reducing what economists call public dissaving, the savings rate in the private sector was falling.
"The profligate private sector, and a swelling stream of both domestic and foreign investment in the United States," Mr. Bernstein said, "thwarted the result that the mainstream had assured us was in the cards."

Graph: "Three Decades of Red Ink"
After 28 years in which the Federal Government spent more than it took in, the annual budget is now in surplus.
 
Oil Shocks -- In 1973 and again in 1979, oil exporters raise the price of crude oil, setting in motion both economic stagnation and inflation.
 
Vietnam War -- After a 1968 tax increase, the costs of the latter stages of the war add to the deficit.
 
Medicare/Medicaid -- Entitlement programs become an increasingly heavy Government burden as health care costs soar in the 70's and 80's.
 
Reagan Budget -- Starting in 1981, the President lowers taxes while sharply increasing military spending.
 
Interest Rates -- Paul Volker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, starts raising interest rates in 1979 to quell inflation, resulting in the worst recession since World War II.
 
Bush Budget -- Agreement Government cuts spending and raises taxes in 1990, but recession dilutes impact.
 
Clinton Budget -- In 1993 the administration pushes a package through Congress that increases taxes and holds the line on spending.
 
President Clinton yesterday discusses the first budget surplus in a generation.
 
(Sources: Congressional Budget Office; Brookings Institute)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Reality Finally CatchesUp With the High-Flying Blue-Chip Stocks

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Even after many lesser stocks had faded, America's blue chips sailed into the third quarter seemingly headed for yet another year of improbably outsize gains. On July 17 the Dow Jones industrial average reached 9,337.97, with commentators still talking of the just-right "Goldilocks economy" and mulling over the existence of a possible "new era."
That turned out to be the pinnacle. Before long, the blue chips joined the rest of the stock market in a general slide as an array of negatives came together at once. Yesterday the Dow dropped 237.90 points, dragging the popular index back into minus territory for 1998. 
 "The big consumer stocks are the ones that took the beating," said Rao Chalasani, investment strategist at Everen Securities in Chicago, summing up the worst quarter for the stock market in eight years. "Finally things started catching up to them."
Laszlo Birinyi, consultant on trading strategy to Deutsche Bank Securities, said: "It was like a New Year's Eve party that ended at 11 o'clock. People were still dancing when the music stopped."
Asian problems flared again, Russian leadership grew shakier, the hoped-for gentle deceleration of the United States economy suddenly threatened an acute profit squeeze and President Clinton's grip on the White House came into serious doubt.
Weeks of tumbling prices preceded a gut-wrenching drop on the final day of August, a 512.61-point reality check that was the second-biggest point loss on record. After this, the Dow and the rest of the market regained some footing before sagging again at quarter's end.
There was little that escaped the third-quarter carnage. The 30-stock Dow industrials dropped 12.39 percent during the July-September period, the worst since its 14.86 percent decline in the third quarter of 1990.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 10.30 percent and the Nasdaq market index -- bolstered by a few technology giants -- eked out a gain of 61-hundredths of 1 percent.
The legacy of this summer's swoon remains. Nervousness and volatility now mark most trading sessions. The specter of an overseas meltdown, profit erosion and other worries are beginning to be reflected in the American economy in the form of lower capital spending, diminished consumer confidence and more caution among lenders.
Numerous market leaders have warned recently of profit shortfalls, further battering their shares. Coca-Cola, for example, lost 32.6 percent of its share value during the last three months. American Express lost 31.8 percent; Sears, Roebuck, 27.6 percent, and Walt Disney and J. P. Morgan, 27.7 percent each.
"Find another time in recent stock market history when the thinking shifted so dramatically," said Byron R. Wien, chief United States strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "This is a major change in attitude -- and it probably isn't over yet."
Not surprisingly, the shift was reflected in statements -- and this week in action -- by the Federal Reserve, where officials kept reappraising the balance of economic and financial risks and found that concern about unsustainably rapid growth and revived inflation had given way to their opposites. On Tuesday the Fed cut the target rate for short-term interest rates, the first reduction in nearly three years.
In a single quarter, observed Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, "you've seen Fed policy go from potentially restrictive to neutral to ease" as it became increasingly worried about exposure to foreign economic and financial storms.
Among the Dow components, the biggest loss was 38.1 percent by the Travelers Group, which succumbed to the general implosion of financial shares and the large foreign exposure of Citicorp, its merger partner. Citicorp finished the quarter at 93, barely half its April peak of 182.
As always, however, there were exceptions -- stocks that powered through the downdraft, indeed attracting some money pulled from those that stumbled.
Dell Computer, for example, soared 41.7 percent to close at $65.75, a performance that topped the company's 37 percent surge during the spring when its market value surpassed that of General Motors. I.B.M., not that long ago mired in the category of fallen star, climbed 11.5 percent over the summer, the second-best Dow performer, following a 10.5 percent second-quarter gain.
The top Dow stock among its eight quarterly gainers was Philip Morris, up 17 percent, as the legal cloud over tobacco issues lifted a bit and some skittish investors, mindful of the company's strong food and Miller beer businesses, turned defensive.
Stocks of two other major brewers, Anheuser-Busch and Coors, had strong summers before surrendering some gains in the quarter's final week.
Utilities, another defensive sector that benefits from falling interest rates as well, bucked the down trend, too. The Dow Jones utility average rose 4.4 percent for the quarter, with Peco Energy up 25.3 percent and Con Edison up 13.2 percent.
Health-related issues also showed resilience. Johnson & Johnson climbed 5.7 percent, and Long's Drug soared 39.2 percent as the second-best gainer among the S.& P. 500. Amoco, which British Petroleum is buying, jumped 29 percent to top a generally stable energy group as depressed oil prices edged higher.
Some analysts took some comfort in scattered strength among cyclical stocks because their continued slump could have pointed toward recession. International Paper, for example, was the third-strongest Dow stock during the quarter, rising 8.4 percent, while Alcoa was right behind with a gain of 7.7 percent.
"Maybe the domestic economy is healthier than we anticipated," Mr. Birinyi said.

HEADLINE: Iraq Stiffens Defiance to U.N. Demands for Spot Arms Checks

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Iraq today hardened its defiance of Security Council demands that it allow spot arms inspections to resume. At the same time it publicly staked its hopes of ending sanctions by calling on Secretary General Kofi Annan to take over a major review of Baghdad's stalemated relations with the United Nations.
Behind the scenes Iraqi officials are working diplomatic circles to try to reopen Security Council splits as Baghdad moves into a critical period in its relations with the organization, which is now united in demanding Iraqi cooperation before any concessions are made. 
 Calling the effects of the embargo on Iraq, "tantamount to internationally proscribed acts of genocide," Foreign Minister Mohammed Said al-Sahaf of Iraq told the General Assembly in a speech that an across-the-board look at more than eight years of sanctions could break the impasse.
But he appeared to assume that Iraq could expect the broad review -- different from periodic reviews of sanctions, which have now been suspended -- before making concessions.
On Aug. 5, Iraq stopped on-site inspections by arms monitors, prompting the Security Council resolution that freezes the regular 60-day reviews but leaving open the chance to look at the bigger picture if -- and after -- Iraq falls back into line.
"There is no reason for Iraq to believe that it can renegotiate the resolution and thereby change the sequence of events," said Peter Burleigh, the acting United States representative. In an interview today Mr. Burleigh said that he knew of no one who was prepared to make that case for Baghdad.
The United States is the only permanent Security Council member to refuse to meet this week with Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister and a liaison aide with the United Nations on sanctions. Mr. Aziz has met envoys from Britain, China, France and Russia.
The British, who have been strongest supporters of the United States on Iraq, take over the rotating presidency of the Council on Thursday for the month of October.
Next week the United Nations Special Commission, or Unscom, and the International Atomic Energy Agency are due to present major reports to the Council amid reports that Iraq has continued to try to assemble parts for a range of prohibited weapons in the country through purchases abroad or in cooperative efforts with friendly nations like Sudan.
At the independent Nuclear Control Institute in Washington, the research director, Steven Dolley, said today that in nuclear weapons Iraq might be "just a Russian smuggler away" from being able to build a bomb with illegally obtained material. Large stockpiles of natural uranium also remain in Iraq.
Large questions also surround chemical and biological weapons programs, Unscom arms inspectors say.
Some Security Council members say that all questions about all possible weapons can never be answered and that the Council should begin closing files wherever possible as an incentive to Iraq. The diplomats say it was a mistake not to have closed the nuclear file in July, when it came up for review.
Restitution is being paid to victims of the Iraqi campaign against Kuwait through the United Nations Compensation Commission in Geneva, which has been given one-third of all money earned on limited Iraqi oil sales through the program that is intended to counter the problems that Iraqis face because of sanctions.
Today in Geneva, where the Compensation Commission once languished for lack of money before the "oil for food" program, the panel announced today that it had paid $1.9 billion in claims.
Iraq and some United Nations officials have been critical of the Security Council decision to take off the first 30 percent off oil sales for compensation rather than allowing it all to go to food, medicine and other urgent civilian needs.
Today in Baghdad, Denis Halliday, who resigned as head of the program in Iraq and is leaving the United Nations, called the results of the oil sales "a shot of oxygen for Iraq and the people of Iraq." He said that the country had received more than seven million tons of food since March 1997.
But Mr. Halliday, who is to meet 40 members of the United States Congress next week to assess the effects of the sanctions, said he was uncomfortable with what he called the incompatibility of tough sanctions' inflicting suffering on one hand and relief aid on the other, both coming from the United Nations.
"I think nobody anticipated the duration of these sanctions," he said, "and therefore the human cost that they represent in terms of child mortality, infant mortality, chronic and acute malnutrition, and the collapse of many of the most positive aspects of Iraq's society."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Big Amount Withdrawn From Equity Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Investors made net withdrawals of $11.2 billion from equity mutual funds in August, the biggest outflow on record and the first month in eight years that more money flowed out of stock funds than went in, according to industry statistics released yesterday.
The Investment Company Institute, a trade group, confirmed yesterday what many fund companies had reported anecdotally since the tumultuous final days of August, when the stock market fell 19 percent below its July peak. Two independent trackers of mutual fund flows, AMG Data Services and Trim Tabs Financial Services, also reported earlier this month that stock funds experienced net withdrawals in August. 
 For the mutual fund industry, the withdrawals ended an extended streak during which the fund industry had expanded enormously. In September 1990, the last month when investors made net withdrawals from stock funds, those funds had $227 billion in assets, well below the $308 billion in bond funds.
Last year alone, stock funds received as much in new investments as they had total assets in 1990 -- $227 billion. And even with the August withdrawals, assets of stock funds had grown to nearly $2.4 trillion, more than double the $1.1 trillion invested in bond and hybrid funds. In the first seven months of this year, stock funds took in, on average, $20 billion a month in new investments.
In September, however, investors appeared to have returned to their old ways. With the worst of the volatility of late August and early September beginning to subside, mutual fund companies have again begun to see money flowing in, analysts said.
Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, based in Santa Rosa, Calif., estimates that in September, stock funds took in net new investments of $19.3 billion. AMG, based in Arcata, Calif., also reported that stock funds had received positive cash flows last month, although the amount is uncertain because a significant number of fund companies report their cash flows to AMG once a month.
In addition, some leading mutual fund companies, such as Fidelity Investments and T. Rowe Price AssociatesInc., said investors put money in stock funds during September after redeeming money in August.
As investors fled from stock funds in August, they sought out the relative safety of bond funds and other more conservative investments. The trade group said fixed-income funds added $5.82 billion in net new investments in August, compared with net new investments of $6.84 billionin July. Hybrid funds, which spread their assets among stocks, bonds and cash investments, had an outflow of $887.5 million in August, after adding $1.07 billion in July.
Money market funds also proved a sought-after haven for investors, according to the data released yesterday. The institute said that money market funds received a record $50.94 billion in net new investments in August, compared with $24.93 billion in July.
Equity fund managers also raised the amount of cash on hand in their portfolios in August, to 6 percent of assets, on average, from 5.2 percent in July.
As the major stock market indexes headed lower in August, mutual fund managers were said by traders at several large Wall Street firms to be heavy sellers of stocks. That selling might have been in anticipation of possible waves of redemptions from investors alarmed by a rapidly declining stock market.
One reason equity fund managers might have been forced to sell was that they have been steadily slicing away at the amount of spare cash in their portfolios over the last three years. The July percentage of assets in cash was down from 7 percent two years ago and nearly 13 percent in the fall of 1990, before stocks and stock funds went on their eight-year tear.
The recent streak is not the longest period of consecutive months of positive cash flow ever recorded, however. For more than 15 years, from October 1954 through May 1970 -- a stretch that coincided with a strong bull market in stocks -- investors similarly made monthly deposits into equity mutual funds, according to the Investment Company Institute.
In all likelihood, that streak was even longer. Before October 1954, the Investment Company Institute tracked fund flows on a quarterly basis, rather than monthly; stock funds recorded positive quarterly net flows of cash dating back to the first quarter of 1944.
Mutual fund shareholders have also gone through extended periods of disillusionment with equity funds. In the eight years from November 1971 through October 1979, which includes the bear market of 1973-74, investors each month took more money out of stock funds than they put in.
The data for monthly fund flows reported by the Investment Company Institute measure new sales of funds less reinvested dividends and withdrawals, or redemptions, plus the net amount of money switched between stock funds and other types of mutual funds, mainly those investing in bonds or money markets.

HEADLINE: Farm Prices Fell in September, U.S. Says

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Prices received by United States farmers for their crops and livestock were down 8.4 percent in September compared with the month last year, according to the Agriculture Department.
The All Farm Products Index, which reflects prices for a mix of commodities, had a September reading of 98, compared with 101 in August and 107 in September 1997, the department said in its monthly agricultural prices report. 
 The news will not come as a surprise to United States farmers, who have seen prices drop this year as huge worldwide crops and meat production and the decline of export demand from Asia, the top foreign market for United States farm products, weigh heavily on income.
Congress is currently working on a package to help United States farmers during the price crisis.
Wheat prices slid to their lowest level since August 1987, the department said. Wheat prices during September reached an average $2.37 a bushel, down 2 cents from the previous month and $1.29 lower than the same month last year.
The average corn price at $1.76 a bushel was the lowest since December 1987. The September corn price was down 14 cents from August and 76 cents from September 1997, the Agriculture Department said.

HEADLINE: White House to Increase Efforts To Help Fight Software Piracy

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore will announce today a stepped-up program intended to help combat software piracy worldwide.
The effort, which was applauded by industry executives yesterday, has two main elements. First, the White House will issue an executive order that directs all Federal agencies to insure that the Government and its contractors do not buy or use pirated software. And the White House is also directing the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshevsky, to press foreign governments to embark on similar programs. 
 "By making sure its own house is in order, this puts the United States Government in a stronger position to make the anti-piracy message overseas," said Brad Smith, general counsel for international affairs at the Microsoft Corporation, the largest software company.
The nation's software industry is thriving, having grown at seven times the rate of the economy over all during the 1990's. But software piracy is a growing concern for the industry, especially as foreign nations close the gap with the United States in computer use.
An estimated 27 percent of the software used in the United States has been illegally copied, violating copyright laws, estimates the Business Software Alliance, a trade group. In countries like China and Russia, however, the piracy rates are estimated at more than 90 percent. Even in nations like Taiwan and Spain, the piracy rates are roughly 60 percent. The Government announcement will show that the software industry is raising its voice in Washington and it is being heard.
"This is a big deal from our perspective and having the White House weigh in certainly strengthens the message the industry has been making for some time," said Eric Schmidt, chairman of Novell Inc., a networking software company in San Jose, Calif.

HEADLINE: Germany's New Leader Gives France Reassurances About Ties

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 30

 BODY:
He will not become Chancellor until after the new German Parliament is sworn in and he can form a coalition Government, maybe at the end of October, Gerhard Schroder said today, but that did not stop the French from hanging on his every word for signs that he might love them less than he loves the British.
Making his first foray abroad since Sunday's election, Mr. Schroder reassured President Jacques Chirac, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and French journalists today that he wanted to strengthen Germany's relations with France every bit as much as those with Britain, for the greater good of Europe. 
 And he made music to Mr. Chirac's ears by agreeing with him on the need for better regulation of global capital flows to head off world recession. France will press that demand at coming meetings in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and finance ministers of leading industrial democracies.
Though that and much else Mr. Schroder said today does not yet amount to official policy, as French officials said they realized, they were happy with what they heard.
Standing side by side with President Jacques Chirac in the courtyard of Elysee Palace, where heads of state and Government are received though he is neither, Mr. Schroder said, "The President and I are of one opinion on the necessity of regulating capital flows and financial markets better than in the past."
At a news conference at the German Embassy later, he added, "We need more coordination in international economic policy, especially for uncontrolled capital flows that can bring whole economies under pressure."
The French had been unsettled by earlier statements by Mr. Schroder that he wanted to build his European policy not only on close ties with France but on a trilateral basis that would also include Britain.
French officials said Mr. Chirac had raised the urgent issue of the need for a coordinated position of the NATO alliance on how to stop Yugoslav Army attacks on civilians in Kosovo, a province of Serbia.
France and Britain sponsored a resolution on Kosovo that the United Nations Security Council adopted last week, warning Yugoslavia to stop the attacks, and French officials said their view now was that this resolution provided sufficient authority for the alliance to carry out threats of bombing Yugoslav forces.
Mr. Schroder said his party's position agreed that a Council resolution was needed before NATO could act.
Mr. Schroder, a Social Democrat, had lunch at the German Embassy with the conservative Mr. Chirac and then spent the afternoon with Prime Minister Jospin, a Socialist, and key French ministers.
After the meetings, French officials said their leaders had agreed with the Chancellor-elect that jobs and the social consequences of economic policy ought to rank high in European priorities after years of reducing deficits, at German insistence, to prepare the Continent for a common currency that will be introduced in 11 countries in January.
Mr. Schroder agreed with Mr. Chirac to set up joint working groups to find ways of invigorating French-German relations and of working out a common position on how to modify the cumbersome institutions of the 15-nation European Union.
Visibly reassured after finishing off his lunch with Mr. Schroder with Cuban cigars, Mr. Chirac told him he should feel at home at Elysee Palace.
Both said they believed that strengthening relations with Britain was no threat to any third country.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Volume of New Issues Slows Sharply

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Wall Street's core business -- the underwriting of stocks and bonds -- slowed significantly in the third quarter after relatively smooth growth in recent years.
Securities firms and banks issued $392.6 billion of bonds and stocks in the three months ended Sept. 30 amid much more volatile markets, greater caution among American investors and issuers of securities, and the swoon in the stock market that began in mid-July as global economic problems spread -- particularly in Japan, other Asian countries and Russia. 
 The volume was up 5 percent from the quarter a year earlier. But the pace of underwriting has slowed sharply from the first six months of this year, when banks and securities firms raised almost $1 trillion as companies issued bonds and shares at record rates in the most buoyant securities markets in a generation.
The ranking of the firms most active in managing securities issues for the third quarter was led by Merrill Lynch & Company, which raised $59 billion, followed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, Salomon Smith Barney, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Lehman Brothers.
Wall Street executives who have had a run of good markets in recent years were buffeted by this summer's more difficult markets.
"It was tough," said Steven D. Black, vice chairman and chief operating officer of Salomon Smith Barney, the brokerage subsidiary of the Travelers Group. "The longer the quarter went, the worse it got. September will show up as one of the worst months in terms of equity issue business.
"No matter what you did, you felt you were trying to catch a falling knife," Mr. Black said. "If you were an issuer, why go into the market with all the uncertainty? You're better off just to sit and wait."
Some see some improvement in the equity markets in recent weeks. "July globally was an unbelievably good market," said Mark Hantho, a managing director in equity capital markets at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, "In August the brakes were firmly applied, almost nothing was working in the market. But in September, the market was slowly emerging on a very selective basis," with some big companies gradually coming back to the markets.
The summer difficulties have taken a toll on even the best companies. "In a market crack like we have had, good and bad names suffer," said Vincent T. Pica, group president of the capital finance group at Prudential Securities.
The bond markets practically froze over after Russia defaulted on some obligations in mid-August.
The securities industry went "from printing about $7 billion a week of investment-grade debt to zero," in August, and has only begun to revive in recent weeks, said Kevin M. Kelly, the managing director at Goldman, Sachs in charge of new bond issue business. Last week, he said, the industry had continued its recovery, issuing about $5 billion of investment-grade debt. Recent debt issue activity, he noted, involved blue-chip borrowers almost exclusively. "We have quite a long way to go before we can get to covering the gamut of issuers."
Mergers and acquisitions also slowed markedly in the third quarter, as raising money for acquisitions became more difficult and company managers grew more cautious. There were $327.7 billion of mergers and acquisitions announced in the third quarter, according to preliminary figures compiled yesterday by the Securities Data Company of Newark. That represents a decline of more than 50 percent from $701 billion of mergers in the second quarter of this year, although it still represents a considerable increase from $192 billion of such transactions in last year's third quarter.
The decline in the volume of new securities issues was particularly pronounced in more speculative markets, such as those for initial public offerings and high-yield bonds. The industry managed 69 initial public offerings, raising $5.3 billion in the third quarter of this year, down substantially from the 158 such issues that raised $10.4 billion in last year's third quarter.
Wall Street issued $20.6 billion of high-yield bonds, in the third quarter, yet in the first six months of the year the securities industry issued more than $100 billion of such securities, which are also known as junk bonds. "It went from records to wreckage," said Richard J. Peterson, a spokesman for Securities Data.
Many on Wall Street are pessimistic about the prospects for underwriting. "I don't think it's going to change till you get some kind of leveling-off process from these wild swings," Mr. Black of Salomon Smith Barney said. "Individual stocks and industries moving all over the place."
Mr. Pica of Prudential said: "There's still a fair amount of uncertainty out there. Traditionally, October is a tough month."

HEADLINE: Congress to Debate Greater Oversight of Hedge Funds

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
As the financiers who rescued Long-Term Capital Management try to salvage what is left of the hedge fund, Congress will debate whether these secretive, risky investment funds that cater to the very rich should be subject to greater scrutiny.
The House Banking Committee will take up the issue Thursday at a hearing where Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve; William McDonough, the president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank; securities officials, and top financial regulators will testify. 
 Long-Term Capital nearly collapsed last week from an enormous amount of bad bets with borrowed money in turbulent global markets. A group of big banks and brokerage houses, fearful that a collapse would further destabilize the markets, rescued the fund with a $3.6 billion package of loans.
For as long as hedge funds have been around, since the late 1960's, Congress and regulators have struggled over how to properly supervise investment funds that can cause financial damage but are organized in ways that escape securities laws and minimize the information they must disclose.
For that reason, future attempts to bring about greater governmental oversight of hedge funds might become mired in the same tangled issues, politics and complicated details that have kept regulators away.
At present, lawmakers are long on concern but short on specific ideas. Following other hedge fund calamities, whether the 1992 Salomon Brothers "squeeze" on the Government securities market using hedge funds or the 1994 collapse of the $600 million Askin Capital Management hedge fund, hearings, reports, studies and recommendations have flowed from Washington.
The results have been mild tweaks in existing regulations even as the industry has expanded to about 4,500 domestic and offshore funds with nearly $300 billion in assets.
At the same time, the types of financial transactions done by hedge funds have become more complicated and could present greater global risks.
"Hedge funds have been allowed to exist in a regulatory black hole," said Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat and member of the House Banking Committee. "Hedge funds are defined by what they are not. They are not mutual funds. They are not banks. They are not brokers. They are constructed in ways in which the wealthiest people in America can invest and do it without any regulation. And this creates huge problems since hedge funds have acted so irresponsibly as to threaten a global financial collapse."
So far, Mr. Greenspan has dismissed the need for more oversight, saying that hedge funds are "strongly regulated by those who lend the money," mainly banks and Wall Street firms. But even Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who is not scheduled to testify, has admitted the free market may have faltered. In response to Mr. Greenspan's comment, Mr. Rubin said, "That assumes the creditors are careful."
Part of the difficulty of regulating hedge funds is the slipperiness about what a hedge fund is. No precise legal definition exists. The term "hedge fund" is not even used in Federal securities law. Generally, though, hedge funds in the United States are private partnerships of wealthy, sophisticated investors that buy and sell stocks, bonds, commodities and more exotic derivative securities, using sophisticated strategies to make bets on their direction.
Offshore hedge funds are usually mutual funds with headquarters in a tax-haven country, with some structured so that they can accept American customers.
As early as 1992, a joint report on hedge funds by the Treasury, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Fed concluded that "regulators have little access to information about these entities and their day-to-day activities" and warned of the "potential of these funds, due to their size, active market presence and use of leverage, to cause market disruptions." Hedge funds are generally not subject to S.E.C. oversight because they are private. They do not have to register with the S.E.C. as broker-dealers and provide disclosure because they fall under a "trader" exemption because hedge funds trade for themselves.
Hedge funds escape oversight, too, from the Investment Company Act of 1940, which regulates mutual funds, because, again, hedge funds do not make public offerings. As a result, hedge funds are exempt from regulations on disclosure, fees and borrowing.
Conversely, hedge funds face indirect regulation since they do business with regulated entities, banks and brokers. Moreover, since 1992, when efforts at hedge fund regulation began, leading hedge fund managers have learned to play the Washington game and have effectively avoided closer Government scrutiny through adroit lobbying and heavy campaign contributions.
Hedge fund managers were especially active in 1994, when a Democrat-controlled House Banking Committee considered Federal hedge fund oversight, and three leading managers, including Julian Robertson of Tiger Management, contributed $550,000 in soft money to Republicans. When Republicans took over Congress in 1994, a "Large Trader Reporting System" for hedge funds seriously considered by the Democrats died quickly.
The main regulatory question raised by the Long-Term Capital episode was why banking regulators never saw early warning flags that would have indicated banks had extended too much credit to an already overly indebted fund. Banks lending to Long-Term Capital are regulated primarily by the Federal Reserve and by the State of New York.
"Someone was asleep at the switch," said Paul N. Roth, vice chairman of the American Bar Association's task force on hedge funds. "It's not like the banks making these loans don't have sufficient regulatory oversight. There is sufficient regulation in place, but it's a question of whether the people were paying attention to this."
Bert Ely, head of an Alexandria, Va., bank consulting firm, said the focus of regulatory concern in Long-Term Capital should have been over threats to the safety and soundness of the banking system.
"Long-Term Capital would have never been able to grow and have the leverage it had, if it had not been lent the money," Mr. Ely said.
One question securities regulators will be examining is whether brokerage firms' loans to Long-Term Capital were made through their broker-dealer operations, which are regulated by the S.E.C., or by their corporate holding companies, which are not.
Despite concern about what happened at Long-Term Capital, even advocates of more scrutiny profess some cynicism.
"It's like going back to the savings and loan crisis, which caused us so much grief," said Thomas E. Petri, a Wisconsin Republican, who advocates higher bank premiums for higher-risk activities. "Anything the Government comes up with, you will find some really smart people to manipulate it."

HEADLINE: Eugene L. McCabe, 61, Founder Of Harlem Community Hospital

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
Eugene L. McCabe, a management consultant who founded and was president of North General Hospital, a thriving, minority-operated community hospital in Harlem, died there yesterday. He was 61.
The cause was breast cancer, his family said. 
 "He was indefatigable in putting it together," said Mario M. Cuomo, who, as Governor, approved many of the grants and loans to build North General. "His strength was his will and his total commitment."
North General, a 200-bed hospital on 121st Street and Madison Avenue, is the only minority-operated hospital in the state. Most of its trustees are black. The hospital specializes in treatment for diabetes, cancer and hypertension, which occur widely among low-income blacks. It recently built 300 units of condominium housing for low- and middle-income residents of Harlem.
"It is a wonderful hospital," said Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. "And Gene did it through sheer dogged persistence and sharp business acumen."
When another specialized hospital moved out of Harlem in the late 1970's, Mr. McCabe, along with Randolph Guggenheimer, a lawyer, developed the idea for North General: a community hospital to serve the impoverished, medically deprived area.
"It became his passion, his life work," said Livingston S. Francis, chairman of the board of North General.
Mr. Cuomo, who described the hospital's creation as "a miracle," said it took all of Mr. McCabe's persuasive powers to talk him and others into approving the necessary loans. At the time, many small community hospitals, overwhelmed with the unexpected demands of AIDS patients and crack addicts, were being closed. "It didn't make financial sense," Mr. Cuomo said. "But he made a case for that hospital. He was always entreating. He was never offensively pushy, but he was insistent."
As a result of Mr. McCabe's entreaties in Albany, Washington and New York City, the state appropriated $150 million to build the hospital. From the start, it was rooted in the community. At one early point, the union asked the hospital workers to continue working despite a missed pay period, Mrs. Gugggenheimer said. With the help of banks, local businesses and politicians, it pulled through several financial crises.
As president of the new hospital, Mr. McCabe drew on the resources of the staff in unexpected ways, Mr. Francis said. Nurses helped choose color schemes, and engineers installed lighting and laid floors -- tasks that would ordinarily be done by outside workers. The process was repeated seven years ago, when North General moved into its current facility, a modern brick building on 121st Street and Madison Avenue, with a bright interior decorated with art selected by staff members.
"That hospital," Mr. Cuomo said, "was his."
Mr. McCabe, who grew up in New Haven, graduated from Southern Connecticut State University.
He is survived by his wife, the former Elsie Crum, who is the president of the Museum for African Art in SoHo; their 1-year-old twins, Eugene and Erin, and a son, Kevin, from a previous marriage.
