HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Saudi Prince Meets Chiefs Of Big Oil; Talks Cordial

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
A quarter-century after Saudi Arabia nationalized its oil industry and put narrow limits on investment by Western oil companies, the heir to the Saudi throne, Crown Prince Abdullah, has asked top executives of seven major United States oil companies how his financially pressed country should be developing its vast oil and natural gas reserves.
Whether the Saudis are now prepared to shift policy and open their vast oil reserves and refining industry to investment by American companies remains unclear, according to several participants in a private meeting held on Saturday in McLean, Va., at the residence of the Saudi Ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar bin Sultan. 
 But a person who attended the meeting, Nat Kern, president of Foreign Report, a Washington consulting company to the oil industry that also publishes a newsletter, said in an interview that there was an openness by the Crown Prince and by Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister.
He related that they were saying, "Tell us what things would be beneficial for us." And when the oil executives held a general discussion of ideas for exploration and production, the Saudis nodded in agreement. "There were no taboos," he said. "They were open-minded. Before, they were closed-minded."
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said that both sides realized they needed each other, more than in the past and that this would lead to more cooperation. Mr. Richardson added that he would visit Saudi Arabia in December, the first time an Energy Secretary has been there in six years.
Attending the meeting were top executives of Mobil, Exxon, Texaco, Chevron, Atlantic Richfield, Conoco and Phillips Petroleum. The Washington Post reported the meeting yesterday.
Since nationalization, Saudi Aramco, the state oil company, has produced and refined most of the oil. Production namounts to eight million barrels a day, and Saudi Arabia is the world's largest exporter.
Mobil, the biggest American investor in Saudi Arabia, and some other companies have been allowed to develop the likes of petrochemical and lubricant plants, but Saudi Arabia has kept foreign companies from bringing the vast fields into production and out of basic refining.
Yesterday, Lucio A. Noto, chairman and chief executive of Mobil, said in a statement that the meeting was "about the sharing of ideas." He added that the discussions were not specific on whether the exploration and production of oilfields or the refining industry would be involved.
Lower oil prices have severely cut into the revenue of Saudi Arabia, which has been running huge budget deficits, even though its proved reserves of 260 billion barrels are the world's largest.
Some neighbors, like Kuwait, have been courting Western oil companies and attracting big investments. Iran, which is off limits to American companies, has been seeking to open its industry to European companies.
Daniel Yergin, chairman of Cambridge Energy Associates, a consulting group based in Boston, said that with lower oil prices the Saudis could be seeking partners so they would not have to absorb all the risk.
"There are benefits in sharing the risk with other companies," he said.

HEADLINE: FISCAL YEAR ENDS WITH U.S. SURPLUS, FIRST IN 3 DECADES

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
President Clinton announced today that the Government was ending the fiscal year with a budget surplus of about $70 billion, the first since 1969 and the largest on record. "It is a landmark achievement," he said.
"Tonight at midnight," the President declared in a ceremony here as the clock ticked toward the close of the 1998 fiscal year, "America puts an end to three decades of deficits and launches a new era of balanced budgets and surpluses." 
 But the President's celebration of the surplus did little to mask an untidy budget process that is unfolding on Capitol Hill and must be resolved in the next nine days, before Congress leaves town for the fall election campaigns.
Indeed, the surplus is contributing to the untidiness: both the Administration and Congressional Republicans have found the emergence of an extra pot of $70 billion or so -- the exact size will not be known until the Government makes a final accounting in a couple of weeks -- too tempting to ignore, especially in an election year. House Republicans would use part of the surplus to finance a tax cut, while the Administration has proposed billion of dollars in new spending.
Although a new fiscal year begins on Thursday, Congress has finished work on only 2 of the 13 spending bills needed to keep the Government running beyond tonight. As a result, Congress and the President have agreed to a stopgap measure to finance most of the Government through Oct. 9, a device used in 8 of the last 10 years to buy the two sides more time to resolve their differences.
Enthusiasm over the surplus has been tempered by the international markets' growing turmoil, which has made it unclear how long the United States can expect to sustain its own economic growth. In fact, whether the annual surpluses projected for the next decade will materialize if the nation slips into recession is just one of the questions being debated by wary economists. Page C1.
The availability of a surplus, anticipated for months, once seemed to offer the nation the opportunity for a philosophical debate over its direction in a new era of plenty. But that debate has been truncated in the last several weeks by the drive on Capitol Hill to impeach the President over the Lewinsky scandal, and the budget process, surplus and all, has been all but lost in the shuffle.
Beyond that, Congress, reflecting a rift within the Republican Party, has not even passed a budget resolution this year. Instead, it is using last year's agreement, which does not project a surplus until 2002, as its spending guide.
"Here we are starting a new fiscal year, and the road map is still in dispute," Representative David Minge, a Minnesota Democrat who is a member of the House Budget Committee, said incredulously.
In place of a broader debate in the era of surplus is the horse-trading and philosophical standoffs over abortion issues that have characterized the endgame of every recent budget season.
The only consensus as the session draws to a close is "to spend money and get out of town," said a discouraged Representative Tom Coburn, a conservative Republican from Oklahoma who wants Congress and the President to stay within the spending limits to which both agreed in the budget-balancing agreement last year.
Mr. Clinton has said for months, and reiterated today, that he wants to save all of the surplus to bolster the Social Security system for retiring baby boomers. At the same time, however, the Administration is seeking to spend $17 billion for "emergencies" that it did not calculate in its budget. These emergencies include peacekeeping in Bosnia, addressing the year 2000 computer bug, improving security at United States embassies around the world and providing disaster relief to American farmers.
Republicans say the Administration is dipping into the surplus to pay for these efforts. But Linda Ricci, a spokeswoman for the White House Office of Management and Budget, said that under budget rules, a lifting of spending limits to pay for emergencies was permitted and that the surplus was not being tapped. Republicans say this is a distinction without a real difference.
"When you spend the money, you reduce the surplus," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Senate Budget Committee and has strongly opposed the effort by House Republicans to spend part of the surplus on a tax cut. The House passed an $80 billion tax cut last week, but the Senate appears ready to kill it; if not, the President has promised a veto.
If anything, the projected surplus has deepened the rift within the Republican Party, separating further the deficit hawks devoted to staying within spending limits from the supply-side tax-cutters who say lower taxes would spur growth.
In any event, Republicans appear prepared to go along with most of the President's requests and spend at least $13 billion on the emergency programs. This despite some grousing over the apparently elastic definition of "emergency," which provides for events like the year 2000 computer glitch and the Bosnia mission, both of them issues for some time.
The President today soft-pedaled his recent criticism of Congress but did urge Republicans to safeguard the surplus until Social Security was made secure.
"If we squander this surplus," he said, "and start spending a little here, a little there, a little yonder on the tax cuts, just because we are a few weeks before an election, before we take care of this, what are we going to do when times get tough?"
With his ceremony today, the President was able to assume credit for the surplus, and he gave credit as well to Congressional Democrats who voted for his tax increase in 1993. This annoyed Republicans, who resent Mr. Clinton's ability to take credit that they feel belongs to them.
"President Clinton's trying to make everybody assume that just because he raised taxes in 1993, he balanced the budget," said the Senate Republican whip, Don Nickles of Oklahoma. Reflecting a longstanding gripe that Republicans have with Mr. Clinton, Senator Nickles added, "The President today even took credit for welfare reform, which he vetoed twice."
The increasingly sour atmosphere has only further hampered a budget process that was already largely stalled. Mr. Clinton's own proposals for child care and education programs were predicated on revenue from a tobacco bill that went nowhere. And the Administration has appeared so preoccupied with fending off the impeachment efforts that it has not seriously pushed a budget agenda. Nor have the Republicans stated clearly what issues they are prepared to hold firm on when they do finally negotiate with the Administration.

HEADLINE: Northwest Farms and Industry Pinched by Asia's Fiscal Crisis

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: KAHLOTUS, Wash.

 BODY:
The huge piles of golden grain that rise like sand dunes along the banks of the Columbia and Snake Rivers are a beautiful sight, but to the wheat farmers of the Pacific Northwest, they are a sign of deep trouble. In a normal year, 90 percent of the region's wheat crop is exported to Asia, but this is not a normal year.
Hammered by a sharp fall-off in demand because of Asia's economic crisis, the region's farmers are faced with one of their biggest stockpiles -- 340 million bushels, enough to fill a line of hopper rail cars stretching from Seattle to Chicago. The price of wheat has dropped to a 21-year low, but even then, as Lonny Lightfoot, manager of the Port Wallula Barge Terminal explains, "There's just no selling it." 
 In central Washington, the heart of an apple industry that is by far the largest of any state's, growers are forecasting a record harvest this autumn. But the growers are so alarmed by the drop in Asian demand -- Thailand, Malaysia, China and Indonesia all bought 50 percent to 85 percent fewer apples from Washington over the last year -- that they recently voted to levy a 15-cent-a-box "promotional assessment" on themselves for an advertising campaign. The goal is to get Americans to eat an extra apple a day.
Here in what is by many measures the most trade-dependent region of the country, Asia's economic problems are clearly hitting home, starkly illustrating the domestic downside of a crisis that in other parts of the United States may still seem like an across-the-world abstraction, or perhaps even a welcome opportunity in the form of ever-cheaper imports.
Nor is the Pacific Northwest's sag in exports to Asia limited to wheat or apples. Sales to Asia of computers, semiconductors and software are all down sharply, and "a lot of that stuff's more perishable than the food," said Jeff Seely, president of the Netstock Direct Corporation, an Internet services company in Bellevue, Wash., speaking only partly in jest.
And the region's biggest employer, the Boeing Company in Seattle, has been hit by the worrisome news from Asia, which typically buys about a third of its planes and which was long seen as Boeing's big growth market. In recent weeks alone, China froze all of its airplane orders and delayed some deliveries, while the flag airline of the Philippines went out of business.
Even a cursory survey of industries here indicates the ways that the strong American dollar can do harm at home. And while the Northwest's overall economy remains strong, Asia's difficulties have led some government officials to project a noticeable slowdown in growth.
In Washington, for instance, the state's top economist, Chang Mook Sohn, recently cited Asian problems in revising his estimates for growth. He lowered projected job growth in the next two years to 1.5 percent (it was 4.1 percent in 1997), and he lowered estimates for the state's tax revenue in that period by almost $200 million.
Washington's unemployment rate, 4.7 percent in August compared with 4.5 percent nationwide, has been sable over the last year and only slightly above the national average.
At the Port of Seattle, imports increased 37 percent in the first six months of 1998, compared with that period last year, while exports dropped 24 percent, an imbalance many experts find troubling.
"Trade is crucial to the economy in this part of the country, and anything that happens in Asia affects us very quickly and very deeply," said Patricia Davis, a port commissioner and president of the Washington Council on International Trade.
"There are signs of a real downward spiral," Ms. Davis added, ticking off statistics on the decline in current state exports to 10 Asian countries -- 48 percent in crops, 38 percent in apparel, 54 percent in lumber and wood, 22 percent in computers and industrial equipment.
Nowhere is the pain felt more keenly than in the farmlands here in eastern Washington, where the interconnectedness of world economies is illustrated by the detailed knowledge local farmers have of the ups and downs of the Thai baht, the Japanese yen or the Indonesian rupiah.
These farmers are long accustomed to the vagaries of the weather, but the uncertainty of Asia's economy seems almost more vexing.
"It's very frustrating," said Gary Galbreath, 58, who planted 4,200 acres of wheat this year. "Here it seems like you're cutting a pretty nice crop and Mother Nature is smiling on you, but then you go to market and you're not making any money at all."
The local price for wheat recently dropped to $2.24 a bushel -- it was as high as $5.20 two years ago -- and most farmers estimate that they need to make $3.25 to $3.50 a bushel to turn a profit. The price drop is pushed not only by bumper crops here and in Canada, but also by the promise of a big crop in Australia.
"It's a tough situation all over," said Jonathan Schlueter, executive vice president of the Pacific Northwest Grain and Feed Association in Portland, Ore. "Farmers know they have a good crop, they know they have the quality foreign buyers want, and yet the buyers are waiting for the markets to go down. And it gets cheaper the longer they wait."
Properly covered and aerated, the grain can last for years, but with all elevators in the area at capacity, wheat is piling up along the rivers and in unlikely settings, like the broad lawn of a go-cart track in St. John. But the stockpiles are ominous in themselves: As the supply grows, prices are likelier to stay low, so that another bountiful crop next year may only add to the problem.
Farmers here say they can generally ride out one bad year but what is worrisome about the Asian crisis is that no one knows when it will lift.
"If prices stay like this another year or two, you're going to see a crisis around here," said Vern Regennitter, general manager of the Ritzville Warehouse Company, a grain elevator operator in Ritzville. "A lot of people are going to be in a world of hurt."
In conversations with residents at places like Ritzville's branch of the Wheatland Bank or the Wheat and Barley, a diner in nearby Colfax, the worries that Asia's crisis could drag down American farms are palpable.
"Farmers in general have to deal with the weather, and we're accustomed to taking the bad with the good, but you really get to wondering if this thing in Asia is the big one," said Al Curtis, a St. John wheat farmer whose summary of his harvest resembles a grim haiku:
"Excellent yield, terrible price, no profit."
What is also clear is that many farmers are increasingly angry over the trade embargoes that the United States has imposed on many nations around the world. Many here believe that they might have faced ruin if Congress had not temporarily lifted a ban on food sales to India and Pakistan. The ban was imposed after the two countries tested nuclear weapons in May.
"They're not going to turn around and launch a nuclear missile filled with grain at us," said State Representative Mark Schoesler, a Republican and a Ritzville farmer. "If we take their money and they take our grain, I don't think that's going to hurt anybody. I can't think of any country we've turned around because of food sanctions anyway. Castro's still Castro, Saddam's still Saddam, and we're not making those sales."
Recently, in a broad reflection of such discontent, the leaders of groups representing wheat, grain, barley, pea and lentil growers in the Northwest signed a petition calling for elimination of all sanctions on American food exports except in cases of "compelling national emergency" or a declaration of war.
Apple growers are also deeply worried by Asia's problems. Indonesia, which bought 4.1 million boxes of Washington apples in the 1996-97 season, the most of any Asian nation except Taiwan, bought just 670,000 boxes in the last season. A box weighs about 42 pounds.
American consumption of apples has flattened in recent years at about 21 pounds annually per person, compared with 35 pounds in Canada and 50 pounds in some European countries, said Jim Thomas, of the Washington State Apple Commission in Wenatchee.
Hence the new marketing campaign, which comes amid a projected record harvest of 103 million boxes in a state that typically grows nearly two-thirds of all the nation's apples.
"We have to compete for all those stomachs out there," Mr. Thomas said. "We're competing against Frito-Lay and all those people who are spending millions of dollars to try to come up with what we already are -- fat-free stuff, sodium-free, etc."
The $23 million advertising campaign is not exactly huge -- Mr. Thomas estimates that is the amount spent to market a Snickers candy bar -- but it is a start. "It gets us into the ball game," he said.
For the moment, the computer industry's problems in selling to Asia have been generally offset by continued strong sales to Europe, Canada and Mexico. William T. Archey, president of the American Electronics Association, the largest high-technology trade group in the country, said that he could not break down specific figures for sales from the Northwest, but he noted that the region had a heavy and growing concentration of computer companies, including Microsoft, and that many companies here had been specifically trying to increase sales in Asia.
Over all, Mr. Archey said, sales to Asia of computer equipment and software in the first six months of this year fell to $28.7 billion from $32.5 billion in the same period of 1997. That 12 percent decline is even greater if sales to China are factored out, he said.
"The issue that I think is the most important, and only the prophets can deal with it, is when this is all going to turn around," Mr. Archey said. "I think the most optimistic expectation at this point is another two years."
Especially in the farm region, Northwesterners are trying to treat the Asian problems with some stoicism.
"There's an old saying," said Pearson Burke, a grain merchandiser and commodities broker at the Ritzville Warehouse. "Low prices cure low prices and high prices cure high prices."
But as Mr. Burke offered a visitor a tour of his company, including an elevator full of wheat in a million-bushel pile stretching more than half the length of a football field and 80 feet high, he said the forces at work in this crisis felt far more remote than those brought on by nature.
"There are a lot of things a farmer can't control, including the weather," he said. "But this is something else entirely. The most skilled farmer here can't control what's going on in the economy half a world away."

HEADLINE: On Eve of Key Meeting, I.M.F. Paints a Gloomy Global Picture

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
In an unusually pessimistic report, the International Monetary Fund said today that it now expects the Russian economy to contract by 6 percent this year and next, and Japan to sink into its deepest recession since the end of World War II.
The report, issued a day before finance ministers from around the world arrive here for annual meetings of the World Bank and the I.M.F., also drastically scales back estimates of how fast other economies will grow. It urges 90 percent of the world's central banks to cut interest rates in an effort to spur growth and calls for greater cuts in the United States. The Federal Reserve announced its first cut in three years -- a modest quarter-percent off one of its key short-term rates. 
 Usually the I.M.F. puts the very best spin on bad news. Repeatedly it said the Asian crisis -- and then its contagion effects around the world -- was abating. Today, instead, it warned that "Chances of any significant improvement in 1999 have also diminished and the risks of a deeper, wider and more prolonged downturn have escalated."
Another notable change in this report was the call for interest rate cuts. Just months ago the I.M.F. was prescribing high interest rates in Thailand, Korea, Indonesia and then Russia, confident that once their currencies were stabilized there would be a chance to cut rates again and resume growth. But now the I.M.F. -- and the United States Treasury, which deeply influences the fund -- regard the choking off of growth as the greatest risk.
The news about Russia came as the World Bank, in another blow to the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin, suggested that it might have to cancel $6 billion in planned aid for the country. The money was promised in July, before Russia let its ruble devalue and forced out virtually all of its economic reformers. Since then the I.M.F. has suspended its aid, which was part of the same package, which totaled $17 billion.
"Whether or not a total of $6 billion for the 18-month period makes sense is, I think, debatable at this point," Johannes Linn, World Bank vice president for Europe and Central Asia, told a news conference today.
In Moscow earlier today, Russia's former top tax collector urged the I.M.F. not to make further loans to Russia because the Government's commitment to economic reform is shaky and that aid could do more harm than good. Instead, Boris G. Fyodorov said, the Group of Seven industrialized nations should present Russia with a list of 10 steps to build a market economy and make sure they are carried out before handing over billions of dollars in new loans and aid.
The reluctance by the I.M.F. to restart aid until Russia begins to cut taxes and avoid printing money so fast that it brings back hyperinflation has led many in Moscow to believe they may not see any more cash from the fund for months, and perhaps longer. But the World Bank, which focuses on poverty, was always considered a surer bet by the Russians, more concerned about keeping Russia's fraying social safety net together. Now that, too, seems threatened.
In its report today the I.M.F. predicted that world growth would be limited to 2 percent this year. That is a huge step backward: A year ago, before its last annual meeting in Hong Kong, the Fund forecast that the global economy would expand by 4.3 percent this year.
Japan's slowdown is perhaps the most worrisome news. The fund predicted that the world's second largest economy would shrink by 2.5 percent this year. Until recently, most economists have guessed that Japan's growth would be zero to negative one percent.
Japan's growth is critical because it serves as the engine for other Asian economies. But the downturn in Japan is so severe that the country's banks have stopped lending -- causing a credit crunch that is freezing economies in the region.
The I.M.F.'s revised figures also show that five of Asia's most critical economies will be deep in recession this year: Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines and South Korea. Indonesia's downturn will be the worst, and rice shortages there are increasingly severe. China, the I.M.F. said, will grow at 5.5 percent, making it the healthiest major economy in the region.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Plunges 237.90; Long Bond Yields 4.97%
Investors turned from stocks and into bonds, pushing long-term Government yields below 5 percent for the first time in more than 30 years, reflecting worries about the economic crisis abroad and financial problems at home.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 237.90 points, or 2.9 percent, to 7,842.62, but prices of Treasury securities rose, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond down to 4.97 percent. Page A1. 

Outflows at Equity Mutual Funds
Investors made net withdrawals of $11.2 billion from equity mutual funds in August, the biggest outflow on record and the first month in eight years that more money flowed out of stock funds than went in. Bond and money market funds posted net gains. C6.
 
I.M.F. Sees Contraction in Russia
The Russian economy will contract by 6 percent this year and next, and Japan will sink into its deepest recession since the end of World War II, the I.M.F. predicted in an unusually pessimistic report. A18.
 
Bankers Trust in Hedge Funds
Bankers Trust disclosed that it had about $1 billion in exposure to hedge funds, but added that about 99 percent of that exposure was collateralized with cash or Treasury bills. Nevertheless, its stock, closing at $59, was down about 3 percent for the day and was well below its 52-week high of $136.4375, which was reached in April. C2.
 
The banks and Wall Street firms that rescued Long-Term Capital Management named six bankers to supervise the hedge fund's huge investment portfolio. C2.
 
Big Banks Cut Prime Rate
Chase Manhattan, Citicorp, Nationsbank and some other big banks lowered their prime rates by a quarter-point, to 8.25 percent, a day after the Federal Reserve cut its target rate for overnight loans between banks. C6.
 
Limits Favored on Option Plans
A New York Stock Exchange task force will recommend tightening loopholes in a recent controversial ruling on plans to issue stock options without shareholder approval. C6.
 
Home Sales Fell 4.4% in August
Sales of new single-family homes fell 4.4 percent in August. Separately, the Conference Board said the index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in August. C7.
 
Saudi Prince Consults U.S. Oilmen
A quarter century after Saudi Arabia nationalized its oil industry, limiting Western investment, Crown Prince Abdullah ibn Abdulaziz, left, has opened discussions about development of his country's vast oil and gas reserves with top executives of seven major American oil companies. With oil prices falling, the Saudi budget is in deficit. C4.
 
Sony and Toyota Plan Data Service
Sony and Toyota are teaming up with a relative unknown, Internet Initiatives Japan, to develop a data transmission service for Japanese business in direct competition with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone. C4.
 
Complaints Over Foreign Steel
Seeking Federal relief, a coalition of 12 American steel companies and two unions accused Japan, Russia and Brazil of selling steel in the United States at unfairly low prices and imperiling the domestic industry. C4.
 
A Crisis for Northwestern Farmers
Huge piles of golden grain rise like sand dunes along the banks of the Columbia and Snake Rivers. Normally 90 percent of the crop from the Pacific Northwest goes to Asia. Now, because of the economic crisis, Northwestern farmers are unable to sell their grain. A1.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Big Banks Cut Prime Rate

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, Citicorp, the Nationsbank Corporation and some other big United States banks lowered the rate at which they lend money to their best customers to 8.25 percent yesterday, from 8.50 percent, a day after the Federal Reserve cut its target rate for overnight loans between banks. 
 The BankAmerica Corporation and the First Chicago NBD Corporation also cut their prime rates to 8.25 percent. And other United States banks are expected to cut their prime rates. On Tuesday, Norwest Bank Minnesota, the largest banking affiliate of the Norwest Corporation, lowered its prime rate to 8.25 percent, from 8.50 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Despite Cut in Rates, Stocks Fall As Investors Choose U.S. Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Worries about containing the economic crisis abroad and fears of financial problems at home prompted investors to sell stocks and buy bonds yesterday, pushing long-term Government yields below 5 percent for the first time in more than 30 years.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 237.90 points, or 2.9 percent, to 7,842.62, but prices of Treasury securities rose, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond down to 4.97 percent, a rate that most of those working on Wall Street have never seen in their professional lives. 
 While the bond market has rallied spectacularly since the stock market peaked in mid-July, the third quarter was the worst for the Dow in eight years, down 12.4 percent for the three months. Shares of financial services companies and makers of consumer products were among the hardest hit in the quarter. Page C1.
At the close yesterday, the Dow was down 16 percent since its peak and just 303 points from its 1998 low on Aug. 31. The only good news was that the Dow overcame the odds last month. Historically, September is the worst month for the Dow. But the Dow rose 4 percent last month.
Yesterday, the day after the Federal Reserve cut its short-term interest rate target one-quarter point in an effort to prevent the financial crisis abroad from derailing the American economy, all the news seemed to point to things getting worse, not better.
More companies offered warnings that their earnings would come in below forecasts, adding to the gloom that has analysts predicting that earnings will decline in the third quarter for the first time since the fourth quarter of 1991.
There was speculation about the collapse of another hedge fund on the heels of last week's rescue of Long-Term Capital Management, which needed an infusion of $3.6 billion from Wall Street's major brokerage firms and banks to stay afloat. While the fund denied the rumor, the fact that such rumors spread so easily these days is a sign of negative investor sentiment. The rumor helped drag down shares of banks and brokerage firms, which have been among the hardest hit in the stock market decline since mid-July.
And even the news of declining interest rates was not all that positive. "The current rally is based on growing expectations of negative economic developments," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company. Robert V. DiClemente, the chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney, added, "This is not the way we would have liked bonds to go through 5 percent."
In addition, while lower interest rates will help home buyers and consumers, the downward rush in Government yields has left the rates on other debt, like that of corporations, much higher as investors have chosen the safety of Government-backed bonds over even those of companies with good credit ratings.
Mr. DiClemente said that overall credit was already tightening as the cost of corporate borrowing had risen and banks were becoming more averse to risk. As the Fed cuts interest rates, he said, "there is no assurance that financial conditions will be easier."
The drop in interest rates was apparently a key contributor to the losses at Long-Term Capital, meaning that further declines could mean harder times for it and other hedge funds that bet that Treasury yields would not fall this far this fast.
It is also probably contributing to losses for many Wall Street firms for the same reason.
While the decline in Treasury rates may be hurting firms on Wall Street, many analysts say the Fed did not cut rates enough on Wednesday to send a reassuring signal to other countries that the American economy will continue to grow and be a market for their exports.
"I think this is a time when you have to take pre-emptive action," said Nicholas P. Sargen, the global market strategist for J. P. Morgan's private clients. In his view, it is clear that the global economic crisis is now impinging enough on the American economy to offset any inflationary threat from an interest rate cut that encourages growth.
The price on the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction from the yield, jumped 1 29/32, to 108 4/32. The yield of 4.97 percent was down from 5.09 percent on Tuesday and is off three-quarters of a percentage point since the Dow hits its peak on July 17. The yield on the 10-year note, which is a benchmark for home mortgages, dropped to 4.41 percent, from 4.56 percent on Tuesday, its lowest since the end of 1965.
In the stock market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 32.01 points, or 3 percent, to 1,017.01, while the Nasdaq index dropped 40.21 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,693.84. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks dropped 2.21 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to 363.59.
"When you see bond prices go up this much and stock prices go down this much, the message is clear," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "Investors are becoming much more worried about the economy and earnings than they had been."
Among the companies issuing third-quarter earnings warnings yesterday or after the market closed on Tuesday were RJR Nabisco Holdings, which cited declining sales in Russia and other republics of the former Soviet Union; Arch Coal, the second-largest American coal producer, which said maintenance costs were reducing profits, and Healthsouth, which runs outpatient surgery clinics and said it might have to revise its earnings forecast because of price pressure from managed-care companies. These announcements came a day after Goodyear Tire and Rubber, Viacom and CBS all fell because of earnings concerns.
In addition, there were signals from Europe that earnings are under pressure there. Benetton Group, the Italian clothing retailer, said earnings fell 14 percent in the first half of the year in part because of reduced sales in Asia.
According to I.B.E.S. International, which monitors analysts' earnings forecasts, profits for the companies in the S.& P. 500 will fall by 2.2 percent in the third quarter.
Bank and brokerage stocks fell again yesterday. Chase Manhattan fell 1 7/8, to 43 1/8, and Citicorp fell 4 3/4, to 93.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 120 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
South Korea Cuts A Key Interest Rate

BYLINE: Bridge News 

 BODY:
South Korea's central bank cut its key interest rate yesterday by a full percentage point in an effort to ease the credit squeeze that is hurting many South Korean companies. The Bank of Korea lowered its overnight call rate, the rate it charges commercial banks for overnight loans, to 7 percent from 8 percent. 
 The Bank of Korea said the quarter-point rate cut by the United States Federal Reserve on Tuesday had eased concerns that lower rates in Korea would prompt investors to move funds out of the country and into American investments. The International Monetary Fund is forecasting that the South Korea economy will shrink by 7 percent in 1998 -- its sharpest decline in more than four decades.

INTERNATIONAL A3-19
 
Security Council to Meet On Massacres in Kosovo
The United Nations Security Council scheduled an emergency meeting for today to consider how to respond to massacres of ethnic Albanians by Serbian forces in Kosovo. Diplomats condemned the attacks, as NATO completed planning for possible air strikes. A1 

Investigators were trying to get a wounded survivor of a mass killing out of Serbia to testify at a war crimes tribunal. A1
 
Iraq Further Defies U.N.
Iraq hardened its defiance of Security Council demands that it allow spot arms inspections to resume. But it also publicly staked its hopes of ending sanctions by calling on Secretary General Kofi Annan to take over a major review of Baghdad's relations with the United Nations. A3
 
24 Injured in Hebron Blast
The army said 13 Israeli soldiers and 11 Palestinian passers-by were wounded when a Palestinian hurled grenades at an Israeli patrol post in the divided city of Hebron. A3
 
Pessimism From the I.M.F.
The International Monetary Fund said it expected the Russian economy to contract by 6 percent this year and next, and Japan to sink into its deepest recession since World War II. The report also drastically scaled back estimates of how fast other economies would grow. A18
 
Clinton Puts Off Trip
President Clinton will put off a visit to India and Pakistan, which each set off nuclear devices in May. Last week, both countries pledged to sign a treaty barring further testing, but the White House said the political climate was still not suited for a Presidential visit. A12
 
New Charge in Terror Case
Federal prosecutors charged an associate of Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile suspected in the embassy bombings in Africa, with taking part in a conspiracy to attack American military installations abroad. A11
 
Denials of Abuse in Malaysia
Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad suggested that his jailed former deputy, Anwar Ibrahim, might have punched himself in order to accuse the police of beating him. A8
 
Schroder Reassures French
Gerhard Schroder, right, who is to become Chancellor of Germany, reassured President Jacques Chirac, left, and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin during a visit to Paris that he wanted to strengthen relations with France as much as with Britain. A17
 
Violent Protest in Peru
Hundreds of protesters broke through the gates of the presidential palace in Lima, storming the grounds and shattering windows before they were forced out by the police and soldiers. The clashes followed a peaceful demonstration by about 5,000 people against President Alberto K. Fujimori, who was inside the palace, but was undisturbed, officials said. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A20-29
 
Rare Surplus Prompts Debate on How to Spend It
President Clinton said the Government was ending the fiscal year with a budget surplus of $70 billion, the first since 1969 and the largest on record. But there is no agreement between the White House and Congress on what to do with the money. A1
 
Rules for Impeachment Inquiry
Through proxies, President Clinton and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, exchanged accusations of conflicting standards in the Watergate and Lewinsky inquiries. A28
 
A poll said that up to 30 percent of teen-agers had watched part of President Clinton's grand jury testimony and 21 percent had read at least part of the Starr report. A28
 
Democratic Donor Indicted

Land Trusts Booming in West
Land trusts, a land conservation movement, are growing the fastest in the Rockies and the Southwest, according to a survey. Nationwide in the last decade, the private conservation groups permanently protected from development acreage nearly equal in size to Connecticut. A20
 
Victims Get $24 Million
Los Angeles County has paid nearly $24 million to 36 people found to have been wrongly arrested and in some cases beaten by sheriff's deputies at a bridal shower in 1989. A21
 
2 Types of Guardrail Banned
The Federal Highway Administration is banning further installation of two common types of rippled-metal guardrail along Government-financed highways after tests showed that the guardrails caused full-sized pickup trucks to roll over. A29
 
Winds Diminish, but Not Rain
Georges, now a tropical depression, continued to drench the South, sending rivers over banks as it moved north and east across Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, where flood watches were in effect. A24

City Says Jail Health Care Is Difficult to Monitor

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HOECHST AND KOHLBERG KRAVIS RETHINK HERBERTS DEAL

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Hoechst A.G., the European drug maker, said yesterday that it was still in talks with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company on the price of the Herberts paint unit, which Kohlberg Kravis has agreed in principle to buy. Hoechst suggested that Kohlberg Kravis, the largest buyout firm in the United States, was pushing to pay less than the 3 billion marks ($1.79 billion) announced last month for Herberts, which makes paints for the European auto industry. Since then, chemical companies' shares have plunged on concern that recession in several markets will dampen worldwide growth and depress commodity prices. The continuing talks were reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SILICON VALLEY GROUP TO CUT 300 JOBS AS SALES DECLINE

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Facing continued weakness in the semiconductor business, Silicon Valley Group said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by about 11 percent, or 300 employees, in the next few months. The company, a maker of wafer processing equipment that had tried to control costs through a hiring freeze and unpaid days off for its workers, also cut 700 jobs in July. Silicon Valley Group, of San Jose, Calif., said it expected sales in its fourth quarter to fall 10 percent to 15 percent from the previous quarter and sales for the first half of the 1999 fiscal year to be 10 percent to 15 percent below those of the second half of the current fiscal year. Silicon Valley shares fell $1.0625, to $8.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
American Banana To Stay in the Bronx

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
American Banana Company will remain in the Bronx and expand its operations with assistance from the city's Industrial Development Agency, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.
The fresh-fruit distributor has outgrown its Bronx warehouse in Hunts Point and was considering relocating to Jersey City. Instead, the company will buy a 40,000-square-foot building at 250 Coster Street in Hunts Point. 
 The company will install loading docks and modern banana-ripening equipment, including 16 specially equipped ripening and refrigeration rooms. The estimated cost of the project is more than $3 million. American Banana has 25 employees at its warehouse and plans to add 15.
"American Banana was one of the first vendors at the Hunts Point Market," Mr. Giuliani said. "Now this 52-year-old, family-run company is continuing in its pioneering tradition by modernizing its operations. The Hunts Point Market is a tremendous asset to the Bronx, and the city applauds companies like American Banana that continue to bring jobs and revenue into the community and deliver high-quality service."
Through the development agency's Industrial Incentive Program, American Banana will receive tax incentives in the form of a mortgage recording tax waiver, a land tax abatement, stabilization of building taxes and a sales tax exemption, for a net value of $546,051. American Banana will also apply to the Energy Cost Savings Program and seek benefits from the Hunts Point Economic Development Zone.
American Banana will also receive a sales tax exemption on hard construction costs for renovations. Because the site is within the Hunts Point Economic Development Zone, the company is eligible for full land tax abatement annually for 25 years. NICK RAVO

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 38; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4704 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums 

 * "BAULE: AFRICAN ART/WESTERN EYES," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Jan. 3). Once again this exemplary museum proves that connoisseurship and anthropology do not make strange bedfellows. This assembly of 135 breathtaking objects includes elegant portrait masks, spirit spouse figures, feared and fearful animal masks and objects for everyday use. Supplemented by an unorthodox but effective use of dioramas and videotapes, they illuminate nearly every aspect of Baule life -- private and public, religious and secular -- and belief systems without stepping on the viewer's visual pleasure. The show has been organized by Susan M. Vogel, the museum's founding and former director, who has spent three decades studying the Baule, who live on the Ivory Coast; it forms a rare, sharply delineated cultural portrait. Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.; Saturdays, noon to 8 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 * "BONNARD," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Oct. 13). Don't miss this exhibition. Americans still don't appreciate Pierre Bonnard enough. He doesn't fit comfortably into the history of modernism, so he tends to be regarded as an anachronism, an Impressionist after Impressionism was dead. But his best art deserves to be ranked with Matisse's and Picasso's, and if you doubt this, spend time in the last rooms of the show. It ends with the paintings of Bonnard's wife, Marthe, in the bath -- mysterious elegies of love -- and with his self-portraits, which are unequaled, and that's not forgetting Rembrandt, van Gogh or anyone else. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. (pay what you wish after 4:30 P.M.). Admission: $12.50; $9.50 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
 * "THE CEASELESS CENTURY: 300 YEARS OF 18TH-CENTURY COSTUME," Costume Institute, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Nov. 29). The theme of this scintillating show is the continuing impact on fashion of the elegant, extravagant 18th century, when aristocratic taste prevailed and luxury knew no bounds. Even in our Minimalist modern age a yearning for unabashed finery keeps breaking out, the show proposes, and it compares some magnificent examples of 18th-century style with 19th- and 20th-century counterparts. Echoes of the wasp waists, buttressed busts with deep decolletage, flaring hips and elaborate surface adornment beloved by those in the 18th century reappear in the 19th century in a gown made by Elise, dressmaker to the Princess of Wales, for example, and in the 20th century in clothes by designers like Worth, Lanvin, Christian Lacroix, Hubert de Givenchy and Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel. The examples, from the Met's collection, are strikingly handsome, and the presentation has panache. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Admission: $8; $4, students and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
 * "WALKER EVANS: SIMPLE SECRETS," photographs from the collection of Marian and Benjamin A. Hill, International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, (212) 768-4682 (through Nov. 29). The personal vision, technical perfection and headlong momentum of Evans's astoundingly prolific career is outlined in these 89 photographs, drawn from a private collection. They span from Evans's early, nearly abstract images of New York architecture, influenced by the European avant-garde, to his Polaroids of graffiti made in his final years. In between are the great images from the mid-1930's, when Evans captured the psychic and physical reality of American life, while also making finely textured pictures whose every centimeter contributed to a visual whole as intense and as important to American art as any of Jackson Pollock's drip paintings. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Fridays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $6; $4, students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * "FROM VAN EYCK TO BRUEGEL," Early Netherlandish Paintings, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 3). A patch of heaven has touched down in Manhattan. This dream of a show is exactly what it says it is: a display of more than a hundred 15th- and 16th-century Flemish paintings representing the bulk of the Met's impressive holdings. Long-hidden pieces have been pulled from storage; familiar works brought together from throughout the museum. And the big news is also old news: the unrivaled genius of the Netherlandish artists, and the inventive vitality of a culture that saw the natural and the supernatural worlds as mirror images. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).
 
 * "INSIDE OUT: NEW CHINESE ART," Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742, and P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Jan. 3). Art in China has changed dramatically in the last few decades and this big, stimulating, two-location show gives a sense of vanguard developments on the post-Mao mainland, in Taiwan and Hong Kong, and among expatriate Chinese artists in the West. The work ranges from video to Western-inspired Pop painting, from spectacular, room-filling installations to ink scrolls. The messages are complex and contradictory: myth, humor, pessimism and nostalgia rub shoulders, often in a single work. There are ups and downs in this tip-of-the-iceberg showcase, but it's a benchmark event. Asia Society: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays to 8 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. P.S. 1: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission to both is $4; $2, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
 * MARK ROTHKO, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Nov. 29). "Only that subject matter is valid which is tragic and timeless," was Rothko's famous remark, but his art, though resonant, has always remained obstinately vague. The best rooms in this handsome survey include pictures from the early 50's in which the colors all seem to be ecstatic and springlike: chartreuse, pink, peach, orange, saffron, lavender and white, layered in veils with the quality of breath on a pane of glass. There's a sense of rhapsodic abandonment on Rothko's part to some exquisite and mysterious new discovery. It's a feeling akin to fresh love. If there is a religious dimension here it involves the intensity of the esthetic experience, which in Rothko's ambitious terms may have constituted a failure. Important artists often don't achieve the goals they set for themselves, but they achieve something else, which they may not appreciate. Hours: Wednesdays, and Fridays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. (free after 6 P.M.) Admission: $9; $7, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 BOB THOMPSON, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Jan. 3). This radiant exhibition of 100 works from 1959 to 1966 traces the brief headlong career of Thompson (1937-1966), a black American artist and one of the rising stars of the early 1960's. Thompson lived hard and died young, and was also tremendously productive. Trips to Europe fired his enthusiasm for the Old Masters, whose religious and mythological themes and compositions he modernized with flat bright color. These reds, blues and yellows also functioned metaphorically, implying a multiracial world alternately pastoral or violent in mood. Thompson died too early to achieve greatness, and as the middle third of the exhibition demonstrates, his paintings could be simultaneously formulaic and hesitant. But there are several remarkable works here, especially his small paintings and studies. And the biggest painting, "Garden of Music" (1960), may be his masterpiece. A group portrait including Thompson's friends Ornette Coleman and John Coltrane and other jazz musicians, it is set in a bright-dark abbreviated landscape and has the enigmatic power of a Gauguin or Munch expanded to the scale of Pollock. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
 Galleries: Uptown
 
 SIMON LEE, Sculpture Center, 167 East 69th Street, (212) 879-3500 (through Oct. 17). Mr. Lee, who has done a lot of outdoor, site-specific work, here presents an installation consisting of large glass panels on which dust has been sifted in vague patterns and a revolving light that causes shadows of the dust patterns to be cast on the gallery walls. The shadows are too pale and amorphous to be as visually compelling as you want them to be (Ken Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
 MEL CHIN, ARLAN HUANG, BING LEE, China 2000 Fine Art, 5 East 57th Street, (212) 588-1198 (through Oct. 24). A fresh arrival on 57th Street, this gallery has been conceived with the good idea of exhibiting traditional and contemporary work together. The low-key inaugural show makes a promising case for the project. The work by three mid-career artists on display in one room sets up subtle connections with the scholar's objects and painted scrolls handsomely installed in another (Cotter).
 
 SHARON HORVATH, "Rome Series and Other Works," Tibor de Nagy Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 262-5050 (through Oct. 10). Maps are the basis of Sharon Horvath's work, but not your basic Rand McNally variety. A trio of big, dense and convoluted maplike compositions influenced by medieval renderings of Rome form the set piece of this show. They combine architectural elements, labyrinthine street patterns, mathematical symbols and a host of imaginary icons, the whole suggesting an ambitious topology of the mind. There are simpler works here, too, like "Heaven and Sea," in which a large potato-colored cloud represents the celestial; and the sea as something of a free-form navigational aid. Other works have a bizarre but appealing rebuslike imagery that demands a cryptographer to decipher it. The show is aerated by Ms. Horvath's imaginative draftsmanship, which seems to make mystical contact with the unseen as well as the visible (Glueck).
 
 JASON MARTIN, Robert Miller Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 980-5454 (through Oct. 10). These paintings, whose lusciously monochromatic surfaces are striated with a comb-like tool, are smart, economical, optically jazzy and pedigreed to the hilt. Their no-hands process relates most obviously to Pollock, their dancing optical wave patterns to Bridget Riley, their surfaces (aluminum, stainless steel, Plexiglas) to Robert Ryman. But it is mostly for naught. Not only do they suffer from tacky retro-chic, they seem machinemade. They have the thin, brief dazzle of a Slinky toy making its way down the stairs (Smith).
 
 KENNETH NOLAND, "Circles," Andre Emmerich Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-0124 (through Oct. 17). Forty years ago, Mr. Noland's stained, concentric circle paintings made him a force in avant-garde painting. Now, after working through all sorts of other geometric permutations, he's come full circle. His new, targetlike pictures are small and have thick, shiny acrylic paint, mechanically generated rings and a wide variety of pleasing color combinations. It's certainly unintentional, but these confections look a lot like kitsch (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
 JAYASHREE CHAKRAVARTY, Drawing Room, 40 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through Oct. 22). This 42-year-old painter from India is making her New York solo debut with a show of beautiful, formally inventive paintings done on scrolls of paper that twist down from the gallery ceiling. The subject is urban: windows, street signs and figures, wrapped in smoggy clouds of hatch lines and swirling strokes. The energy is high and sweet, with the sensation-packed verve of a first morning's walk through the streets of a strange city (Cotter).
 
 MILES COOLIDGE, Casey Kaplan Gallery, 48 Greene Street, (212) 226-6131 (through Oct. 10). Mr. Coolidge continues his investigation of real and pictorial scale with color photographs that document the agribusinesses of California's Central Valley in long, thin, but thrillingly expansive slices. The layered views of fields, roads and buildings render actual size ambiguous, as if it might all be a scale model. They also make one think of 19th-century paintings of the untouched American West, the oppressive Americanness of the Conceptual photographs of Dan Graham and Ed Ruscha and the three-dimensional desolate landscapes of Michael Ashkin. They suggest the American heartland as seen through the artillery slot of a bunker. Call it the paranoid sublime (Smith).
 
 PEGGY CYPHERS, Donahue/Sosinski, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 226-1111 (through Oct. 10). Sandy-textured, subtly colored semi-abstract paintings in which hieroglyphs, loosely improvised patterns, dripped strands of glue and passages of staining are layered over screen-printed bird or insect illustrations. Some of these meditations on natural history are overworked to the point of muddiness; the best have an airy poetry (Johnson).
 
 CADENCE GIERSBACH, "Plastic Replicating Garden," Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, (212) 343-7300 (through Oct. 17). Smart, shiny, eight-foot-tall folding screens, each panel of which is upholstered in stuffed white vinyl on which the artist has painted atomized, black-and-yellow copies of distorted photographs of English topiary gardens, creating a kind of radioactive Pointillism. Though hideous to look at, the layering of cultural signifiers is conceptually dizzying (Johnson).
 
 JIM HODGES, CRG Gallery, 93 Grand Street, (212) 966-4360 (through Oct. 10). This reticent show about fragmentation and time includes a mural made of carefully pieced-together mirror shards and a wall drawing depicting two lovers as interlocking patterns of concentric circles, like the growth rings of trees. Most moving, though, is a self-portrait: dozens of shirts layered inside one another in sizes from adult male to baby. Each shirt is tailored from materials suggesting a different time or event in the artist's life (Cotter).
 
 RICHARD KALINA, Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-1012 (through Oct. 10). Lively collages on canvas in which photocopied botanical illustrations, painted stripes and cut-out shapes of things like airplanes, pipes and telephones are densely layered in grid-based compositions. They're visually enthralling if not heavily meaningful (Johnson).
 
 ALIX LAMBERT, Curt Marcus Gallery, 578 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 226-3200 (through Oct. 10). Ms. Lambert is a multitasking conceptual artist who has no qualms about mixing art and life. The main work in this show is a series of large-scale photos of tattoos that the artist executed on the bodies of intrepid friends. In each case, she asked the subject to produce the design, and the results amount to a gallery of portraits, indelibly recording whims, passions, private jokes and obsessions (Cotter).
 
 SOL LeWITT, Pace Wildenstein, 142 Greene Street, (212) 431-9224 (through Oct. 10). For years the simple procedures of Mr. LeWitt's wall drawings have landed them in the vicinity of other artists' work, deflating the notion of originality by suggesting distant cousins of Matisse, Malevich and Frank Stella. Now, in a series of undulating lines and shapes rendered in bright colors and booming scale, Matisse is joined by Keith Haring and Victor Vasarely. The results are among the most optically vibrant works of Mr. LeWitt's long career, invigorating eye-candy, sugar-free and made with all natural ingredients (Smith).
 
 SANTI MOIX, Paul Kasmin, 74 Grand Street, (212) 219-3219 (through Oct.10). In each of the funky, richly sensual paintings of Mr. Moix, a Barcelonan who now lives in New York, agglomerations of blobby, mud- or flesh-colored forms appear against expansive blue fields, suggesting a wedding of the visceral body and the expansive mind (Johnson).
 
 CHARLINE VON HEYL, Friedrich Petzel, 26 Wooster Street, (212) 334-9466 (through Oct. 10). Colorful, gestural but dry abstract paintings by a German artist who recently moved to New York. Ms. Von Heyl's works involve much painterly process, combining staining, smearing, layering, drawing and mark-making; they come out looking well-designed but flat and disaffected, as though the artist believed there was nothing left for painting but the rearrangement of cliches (Johnson).
 
 ALLAN WEXLER, Ronald Feldman, 31 Mercer Street, (212) 226-3232 (through Oct. 10) Proceeding with relentlessly inventive logic, Mr. Wexler, who was trained as an architect, systematically develops formal variations on the archetypal house and the straight-backed chair. In paper, cardboard, fabric or wood, he unfolds, flattens, deconstructs, turns inside out and otherwise transforms the basic object in so many different ways you begin to feel metaphysically dizzy (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
 JOHN AHEARN, Alexander and Bonin, 132 10th Avenue, near 18th Street, (212) 367-7474 (through Oct. 24). Mr. Ahearn, who is famous for his portrait busts of people in low-income neighborhoods, cast from life, has not had a gallery show since 1991. This one, including thinly painted portraits of children, two life-size studies for a public commission and a series of unpainted reliefs of multiple pairs of hands, offers little in the way of provocative new developments (Johnson).
 
 ANDREA BELAG, Bill Maynes, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 741-3318 (through Oct. 10). Abstract stripe and plaid paintings in which wide, watery swaths of sweet color ranging from near black plums to luminous transparencies of orange cross the canvas horizontally and vertically, overlapping in places. Ms. Belag, a mid-career New Yorker, works with relaxed confidence; you only want to see her push her color into less predictably palatable territory (Johnson).
 
 BARBARA GALLUCCI, "Carpet Bottle Flock & Shine," Derek Eller Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 206-6411 (through Oct. 10). Mock kitsch sculptures in the form of big, flat but thick flower images, assembled from puzzlelike parts made of tacky carpet remnants, polished copper and Formica; also, some odd, mirror-glass bottles. Ms. Gallucci's works are amusing and have material presence but they need to be more over the top (Johnson).
 
 KLAUS LUTZ, De Chiara/Stewart, 521 West 26th Street, (212) 967-6007 (through Oct. 10). Mr. Lutz is a Swiss-born experimental filmmaker and performance artist. Here he has orchestrated an enjoyable, Rube Goldbergesque installation in which his jerky, home-made looking films of a little man moving about in the deep, illusory spaces of abstract paintings are projected onto three big, white weather balloons (Johnson).
 
 "SCULPTURE," Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105 (through Oct. 10). An exceptionally handsome show of five vintage and recent Minimalist and Post Minimalist works. The conceptual ironies of a set of Gerrit Rietveld side tables reincarnated 50 percent bigger than the originals by Sherrie Levine play off the pristine geometries of works by Donald Judd, Sol LeWitt, Tony Smith and Jackie Winsor (Johnson).
 
 JASON SIMON, Pat Hearn Gallery, 530 West 22d Street, (212) 727-7366 (through Oct. 24). An installation that looks like the aftermath of a disaster at a rock concert. Two giant black speaker horns appear to have come unmoored from the ceiling and crashed to the floor, where they sit among broken chairs and scattered food containers quietly playing ambient sounds of a deserted arena. Could this be the end of the society of the spectacle? (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
 MAYA LIN, "Topologies," Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through Oct. 31). Ms. Lin is best known for her powerfully understated public monuments, notably the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington. This show focuses on her less familiar studio work and does much to clarify the themes that have shaped her work, from the merging of nature and science to the subliminal play of Asian thought. The show's three largest sculptures cohere into a mountain-sea-moon landscape, crystalline in its simplicity but resonant with implications of change (Cotter).
 
 "PERSONAL TOUCH," Art in General, 79 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-0473 (through Nov. 7). Except for Amy Sillman's gouaches, there is little of the hands-on personal touch in this show. Rather, it's a mixed bag of quirky, high-concept work, including Sora Kim's brown office for "Unlimited Concept Company Cleaning Department"; funny, body-oriented videos by Jozef Robakowski, like "My Foot Is Painful"; rich photographs of low-rent family relations by Tracey Baran; a red rubber text by Meg Belichick and a banner bearing Jenny Holzeresque admonitions by Ryszard Wasko (Johnson).
 
Last Chance "AHAB'S WIFE," Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, Staten Island, (718) 448-2500 (through Sunday). The intriguing title of this six-artist exhibition was inspired by a reference in Herman Melville's "Moby-Dick." Only Ellen Driscoll explores the possibilities of the theme directly in murky, expressionistic works on paper, enigmatic sculptures and props for a performance to be presented Thursday through Sept. 20. The painter Janet Gillespie offers finely made, surreal paintings of the ocean; Arden Scott fashions elegantly abstracted boat sculptures. Ahab's wife remains disappointingly unrealized as a character or a metaphor. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $2 (Johnson).
 
 "ROBERT COLESCOTT: RECENT PAINTINGS," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Sunday). Nineteen paintings by Mr. Colescott that represented the United States at the Venice Biennale last year. His raucous pictures swarm with cartoon characters who act out wildly scrambled blackface burlesques of race, sex, violence and death. Nothing if not contradictory, his paintings are also beautiful, smart and poetic. Though raw, they have a lush, painterly sensuality, and though bumptious, they speak to complex philosophical matters through metaphorically loaded images. Hours and admission: See above Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2 (Johnson).
 
 "DAVID GOLDBLATT: PHOTOGRAPHS FROM SOUTH AFRICA," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Tuesday). This exhibition of 46 photographs of South Africa under apartheid is a dispassionate inventory of churches, monuments, shantytowns, apartment houses, graveyards, toilet seats, billboards, hedges and house trimmings. Mr. Goldblatt practices social iconography, photographing ordinary objects packed with historical and sociological meaning. He was drawn "to the quiet and commonplace, where nothing 'happened' and yet all was contained and immanent." But all is not contained and immanent in these images. Many of the pictures cry out for explanation, and their cry is answered with a torrent of text. Sometimes the words help, turning uninflected pictures into illustrations of the twisted social relations and hideous inequalities of apartheid. Sometimes, though, the text is just a tidal wave of words in which the crucial information drowns. Hours and admission: See above (Sarah Boxer).
 
 BILL JENSEN AND LEONARDO DREW, Mary Boone Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through tomorrow). These two solo shows go in opposite directions. Mr. Jensen, long known for small organic abstractions, seems to be paring down and loosening up his work, testing how little he can get away with and still have a painting. Except for the vaguely nautical, poetically nocturnal painting "A Few Small Nips," the canvases here are mostly beautiful traces of the artist's involvement, or good starts. In contrast, Mr. Drew's latest rust-covered reliefs and sculptures, despite their found-object patinas, seem over-worked. They achieve toxic levels of artifice, like a stage set whose effects are meant to be read from a distance and thus seem overwrought when viewed more closely (Smith).
 
 JOHN MORRIS, D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22d Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-9460 (through tomorrow). Mr. Morris burrows so deeply into familiar territory -- ultra-fine, quasi-abstract drawing -- that he finds a bit of turf to call his own. His first solo show consists of about 200 small, obsessively perfect images made with various combinations of crayon, wax, graphite, ink and ballpoint pen; they are displayed unframed in tight formation on two big tables. Luminous and mysterious, the motifs range suggestively from the cellular to the architectural, from the decorative to the Tantric, and pulsate with a life that in more Romantic times might be called universal (Smith).
 
 LIISA ROBERTS, "Blind Side," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Sunday). Borrowing a little too much from "Wavelength," the 1967 avant-garde film classic by Michael Snow, this young American artist has created a well-thought-out film installation involving twin life-size images of a formal sitting room through whose windows day changes to night and back again in about six minutes. The viewer's reflection and shadow provide the figurative element as the room disappears and reappears, and the windows, looking out on a bustling city, suddenly resemble little film screens. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
 ALEKSANDR RODCHENKO, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Tuesday). By turns illuminating, tragic and chilling, this fascinating exhibition details the work of an artist who spent much of his career on the cutting edge of art and history, a position that did not leave him unscathed. For a few short years in the early 1920's, Russian Constructivism was an artistic revolution in step with a political one, and Rodchenko was its most diversely innovative representative. He made paintings and sculptures that presaged Minimalism and photographs and graphic designs that were similarly ahead of their time, while also serving the needs of the new Soviet state. With Stalin, that state brutally switched its allegiance to Socialist Realism, dismissing, imprisoning and sometimes killing avant-garde artists or requiring humiliating "reconstructions." This was the path chosen by Rodchenko, as attested by the photojournalistic images that give this exhibition such a sad conclusion. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
 GEORGE SEGAL, Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Sunday). This retrospective presents Mr. Segal as something more than just the Pop artist he's been labeled; it shows him to be a humanist of expansive vision able to address difficult historical topics like the Holocaust or deep religious subjects like the biblical story of Abraham and Ishmael. But the works that look best are the mournful tableaux of white plaster figures fitted into diners, subway cars or telephone booths, which made him famous in the 1960's. Only three or four of these stark theaters of modern angst are included in this 42-work retrospective. Hours: Closed today and tomorrow; Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5:45 P.M. Admission: $7; $5 for students and the elderly; children under 12 free (Johnson)

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART;
Calder Works On the Move

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
The Calder Foundation is the latest suitor to make a play for 2 Columbus Circle in Manhattan, that white marble building with the slender arches and round holes that Edward Durell Stone designed to be the Gallery of Modern Art in 1965.
Alexander S. C. Rower, a grandson of the artist Alexander Calder and the director of the foundation, said he believed it was time to move the operation from its headquarters in Woodstock, N.Y., to Manhattan. He has spent the last six months looking at sites large enough to house a Calder museum as well as the foundation's archives and library. 
 Though 2 Columbus Circle would be an ideal spot, the fate of the city-owned building appears uncertain. In July 1996, the city asked for sealed bids from interested buyers. But three months later, after the deadline for bids, no selection was made.
"We were waiting to see who would be selected to develop the Coliseum site," said Charles Millard, president of New York City's Economic Development Corporation, referring to a building on the west side of Columbus Circle. "We wanted a selection that would be compatible. The real estate market has changed and we're evaluating the situation. None of the bidders have been rejected."
Although Mr. Millard declined to name the bidders, the Dahesh Museum, which specializes in 19th-century European art, has made public its interest in the building.
"It would be a wonderful addition to the city to have a Calder museum," said Randall Bourscheidt, president of the Alliance for the Arts, an advocacy organization in Manhattan. "Calder had a strong identification with New York and quite a following here."
Mr. Rower said he had been working with Schuyler G. Chapin, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, to find a city-owned building that would be suitable for the Calder Foundation. "We've been looking everywhere from Battery Park City to Chelsea, TriBeCa, the West Village and a few sites in midtown," he said. He confirmed that 2 Columbus Circle was on his wish list, even though the foundation began to consider it after the bidding had been closed.
"We've asked to be able to put in a bid anyway, but the city hasn't gotten back to us yet," Mr. Rower said. "Schuyler Chapin thought we should go for it." A spokeswoman in Mr. Chapin's office said the commissioner declined to comment.
The foundation has large holdings, with some works owned by family members and others by foundation supporters. The art includes about 300 sculptures, 55 monumental outdoor works and more than 3,000 works on paper, many not publicly seen since 1943. The foundation was a large lender to the exhibition "Alexander Calder: 1898-1976," which opened in March at the National Gallery of Art in Washington and is now at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. The foundation also has extensive archives, with more than 100,000 documents.
"We've spent the last 11 years working on the artist's catalogue raisonne and have 16,000 works documented," Mr. Rower said. Though he was not sure when the catalogue would be published, he said it would be about 35 volumes. "It will be an encyclopedia," he said.
 
Hermitage West
 The State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, may be short on cash, but not on vision. The latest of its many plans is to transform a home for the elderly in Amsterdam into a satellite of the Hermitage. The building, the 17th-century Amstelhof Nursing Home on the Amstel River, belongs to a church, which wants to sell it to a buyer that would make it into a cultural center.
Why not a Russian cultural center in Amsterdam, asked Mikhail B. Piotrovsky, director of the Hermitage. "It would have permanent exhibition space to show two shows a year, one that would be up for a year and the other for six months," Dr. Piotrovsky said. "We would also like to exhibit works from other Russian museums."
Besides giving the Hermitage another site for showing its vast collections, Dr. Piotrovsky said, an Amsterdam location would make it easier for people to see the museum's treasures. It could also become a good source of much-needed revenue. "I'm very optimistic about the project," he said. "We're beginning to do feasibility studies."

Welcome, Please Stay
The long-awaited Berger Collection of British art is opening at the Denver Art Museum on Oct. 10. Originally the exhibition, which includes more than 200 works by artists like Reynolds, Gainsborough, Constable and Sir Alfred Munnings, was to have gone on view last November, when the museum reopened its European and American galleries after a seven-year facelift. But the collection was too big for the space. So now the museum has stored part of its permanent collection to make room for the British art.
Formed in just three years by William M. B. Berger, founder of the Denver-based Berger Group of mutual funds, the collection takes up about 10,000 square feet, the entire seventh floor of the museum. It will be on display for six months. The works span 600 years and, in addition to paintings, include the Bute Book of Hours and a Nottingham alabaster altarpiece.
Some experts say the Berger Collection was assembled too quickly to have the depth of the Yale Center for British Art or the Huntington Library Art Collections and Botanical Gardens in San Marino, Calif. But Mr. Berger defends his collection, saying that "even the Tate can't boast of having 600 years of British art."
The museum hopes the collection will never leave. "I think whenever a museum is able to host a show like this, it hopes to get the collection," said Lewis I. Sharp, director of the Denver Art Museum. "Our European holdings are small, so for this institution it would be a great gift."
Mr. Berger isn't so sure: "I tell the museum, you put up the gallery first and then we'll see what happens."
