HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Big Swiss Bank Is Shaken Up By Hedge Fund

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
As more fallout from the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management L.P. cascaded over Europe today, the chairman and three high-ranking officers of UBS A.G. of Switzerland resigned -- the most visible casualties to date of dealings with the United States hedge fund.
The departure of Mathis Cabiallavetta and the senior officers was designed to restore some confidence in UBS, which became Europe's biggest bank after the merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation in June. 
 But the announcement at an early morning news conference in Zurich did little to reverse a weeklong slide in bank stocks. Shares of UBS closed at 285 Swiss francs ($210) -- up 10 francs from their close on Thursday but less than half their high of 657 Swiss francs in July. At one point, the shares dipped to 258 francs.
Falling bank shares have led a sharp decline in European stocks in general that continued today as investors sensed they were no longer immune to roiling markets from Asia to Wall Street.
Even the Bank of Italy, Italy's central bank, acknowledged on Thursday that it had invested $250 million in Long-Term Capital -- an extraordinary investment for a central bank, particularly because some of Long-Term Capital's arcane trading was based on the likely behavior of Italian Government bonds. Questions about the Bank of Italy's investment multiplied when Reuters quoted a Bank of Italy foreign-exchange official, Pierantonio Ciampicali, as saying the central bank had been unaware Long-Term Capital was a hedge fund when it had first invested in the risky American firm.
European banks, including Dresdner Bank, Germany's second biggest, have so far acknowledged about $1.1 billion in losses from the Long-Term Capital debacle -- the most at UBS -- at a time when Europe's banking industry seems headed for a sobering downturn.
ING Barings, the investment and corporate banking division of ING Groep in the Netherlands, said on Thursday, for instance, that it was cutting 1,200 of 9,000 jobs.
In London, J. P. Morgan analysts downgraded three European banks, including Dresdner and UBS, on Thursday, warning "there may be further negative surprises for the market as we peer deeper into a number of the black holes which have emerged recently."
At UBS, Alex Krauer, who has temporarily replaced Mr. Cabiallavetta, 53, told reporters today that the bank's problem "is not a financial crisis, rather a crisis of confidence." He said the bank's exposure to Long-Term Capital arose from poor judgment and "an improper assessment of the situation" rather than negligence.
Pressed to say whether any of the departed executives had held personal stakes in Long-Term Capital, UBS officials said that there was no evidence of this but that an internal audit was still under way.
UBS announced last week that it would write off $685 million because of losses connected to Long-Term Capital.
The resignations were a surprise partly because they came so soon after the the merger of Union Bank and Swiss Bank created UBS in late June. The combination had been trumpeted as a milestone in Swiss banking history, but the alliance has been dogged by pressures from American Jewish and political organizations in the so-called Nazi gold affair, falling markets and what now seems a remarkable gap in the bank's internal ability to calculate the risk of its investments.
Marcel Ospel, the chief executive of UBS, said at the news conference in Zurich today that as late as August the bank's most senior managers were aware of losses totaling only $50 million from dealings with Long-Term Capital because of the way the transactions had been recorded.
As markets began to collapse in July, he said, "we were talking about a large accrued position with major risks spread over different books."
In a statement, UBS said: "The evaluation and the ongoing management of risk positions were not carried out to the standards expected."
Apart from Mr. Cabiallavetta, the responsibility fell on three other bank officers: Felix Fischer, chief risk officer; Werner Bonadurer, the joint chief operating officer at the Warburg Dillon Read investment banking arm, and Andrew Siciliano, the head of rates at Warburg Dillon.
"The conviction that I am doing the right thing for my bank has prompted me to take this step," Mr. Cabiallavetta said in a statement.
The bank's inability to detect the risks has left many in Switzerland questioning its professionalism, and Mr. Ospel was pressed to acknowledge that the bank was considering bringing in foreign directors with greater market expertise to bolster its all-Swiss board.
Swiss regulators have also opened an inquiry into the bank's losses. "We will have to ask ourselves how a bank can enter such a huge engagement with a single hedge fund," Daniel Zuberbuehler, head of the Federal Banking Commission, said in a published interview this week. "We also need to know why there was no red light coming on earlier."
UBS is one of the institutions that helped assemble a $3.6 billion rescue package for Long-Term Capital in return for a 90 percent stake in the hedge fund, clearly hoping to recover some losses while averting broader market chaos. Chastened by the experience, UBS forswore further ventures into high-risk investment.
"Given the developments in the international financial markets, in the future UBS will -- within the framework of its defined strategies -- focus even more intensively on those areas of business likely to generate sustainable earnings with a justifiable level of risk," the company said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Job Growth Turned Slack In September

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Job creation fell in September to the lowest rate in more than two years, the Labor Department reported yesterday -- the most persuasive evidence yet that the financial crisis abroad is slowing the booming American economy.
The Labor Department said the unemployment rate edged up only slightly, to 4.6 percent, from 4.5 percent in August. But payrolls expanded by just 69,000 jobs, a fraction of the 309,000 jobs created in August or the roughly 200,000 that had been expected by forecasters. 
 Total hours worked dipped, suggesting that production and income were leveling out, and hourly pay barely inched up.
The Labor Department's monthly employment report is considered the most substantial assessment of the economy's health. Coming on top of other signs of weakness -- falling exports, slowing retail sales and weaker business investment -- the data reinforced a view among economists that the eight-year-old expansion was being crimped by the economic problems that began afflicting Asia last year and have since spread.
"It's a warning sign of slower economic growth ahead," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
The department also reported that em ployment growth had been stronger in July and weaker in August than first reported, underscoring that the slowdown has been steep. Excluding the gyrations caused by the General Motors strikes, gains in employment shrank from 270,000 jobs in July to 160,000 in August to the very modest September gain.
"The revisions don't change our sense of where we are," said Katherine Abraham, the Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "But they make the decline in job growth more marked."
A fraying at the edges of what was until recently a vibrant labor market has already been reflected in a retreat in consumer confidence in the last few weeks from record highs. The University of Michigan, which tallies a widely followed index of consumer confidence, reported yesterday that the index slipped to 100.9 in September from 104.4 in August.
To be sure, the American labor market still remains healthy by any historical measure. The change in the overall unemployment rate, for example, reflected a shift of a few hundredths of a percentage point that was then magnified by rounding. Unemployment among most demographic groups -- at the lowest levels in 25 or 30 years -- has not budged. And the percentage of Americans working actually rebounded to a near-record of 64.1 percent.
"These are still signs of a very strong labor market," said Alan Krueger, a labor economist at Princeton University. "Most people who want jobs are still able to find them."
But the snapshot of the labor market confirmed that the risks facing the economy have shifted toward much slower growth, maybe even recession.
Signs of cooling were widespread. Factory payrolls continued to shrink in September, dropping by 16,000 jobs and bringing the total number of manufacturing jobs lost this year to 114,000. With exports to Asia and Latin America plunging, imports soaring and production flat or contracting, the makers of electrical equipment, machinery and other industrial products have been forced to lay off workers.
The weakness in manufacturing is likely to persist. Orders for long-lasting goods were up over all by nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, but excluding aircraft and automobiles (which were bolstered by the end of the G.M. strikes), orders declined 1.2 percent.
Construction in September contracted by 20,000 jobs, not just in residential building but also in heavy construction like roads and bridges. That is the first decline this year other than those that reflected the vagaries of weather and seasonal adjustment. It is also a sharp contrast to the average monthly gains of around 24,000.
Most striking, however, was a sharp slowdown in hiring in the sprawling service sector. Services added just 105,000 jobs in September, compared with the average of 215,000 a month since the start of the year. Particularly noteworthy was that the head count at temporary-help suppliers, a leading indicator of future permanent hiring, dropped sharply, by 44,000. Temporary hiring had been zigging up and down all summer, but the September number was farther off the average than any of those shifts.
Wage inflation, too, seems to be cooling with the labor market. The trend in hourly pay, which seemed to be picking up in the first half of the year, now seems to be leveling out or even slowing. Hourly pay was up just 4 percent from a year earlier, compared with a rise of 4.3 percent from May 1997 to May 1998.
Despite the overall pattern of cooling off, hiring did pick up in a number of industries, including wholesale and retail trade, computer services, management consulting and financial services. The brightest spot: the amusement industry, which includes theme parks, bowling alleys, movie theaters and video parlors, all places where Americans can leave their worries at the door.

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
Kennelly's Star-Crossed Campaign Spurs Search for Reasons

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 2

 BODY:
For Barbara B. Kennelly, the Democratic Congresswoman trying to unseat Gov. John G. Rowland, the indignities are becoming an almost everyday event.
Earlier this week, she held a noon rally in Hartford, her hometown, and the audience consisted mostly of bored-looking construction workers shepherded by union leaders from a nearby site. Last week, she spoke to a group of 200 business people in Danbury, and the audience had no questions. In the last week, two of the groups that most dependably endorse Democrats, the Connecticut Education Association and the Connecticut National Abortion Rights Action League, decided not to make a choice in the race. And on Thursday, a new poll by Quinnipiac College showed her 44 percentage points behind the incumbent among likely voters. 
 Things are so bad, in fact, that in Mrs. Kennelly's home district, the poll showed the Governor leading by 27 points. And now, Mrs. Kennelly, the stately scion of a political family that ruled the state for decades, faces the very real possibility that her 23-year political career will end in a comedy of errors.
"This is beyond a landslide -- we're looking at blowout proportions," said Douglas J. Schwartz, the poll's director. "Every issue and every group is moving Rowland's way. It's a wind that's catching everything and blowing it in his direction."
Mrs. Kennelly, who gave up her House seat to run for governor, professes to be mystified about the devastating trajectory of a campaign that once looked so promising. Perhaps, because her name recognition helped her in early polls, the campaign looked more promising than it ever was. But certainly no one anticipated she would be in this kind of trouble. Why not? To many experts, one answer may lie in her political upbringing.
Political operatives in the state say the campaign of Mrs. Kennelly, 62, reflects that of an old-style politician who has never embraced the tools and demands of a modern campaign. In fact, they suggest, her approach to politics seems to reflect more the attitudes of her father, John M. Bailey, a longtime state Democratic chairman, who spent party conventions in the green room behind the stage, where politicians would go to pay court. In addition, they say, she has not had tough re-election races during her 16 years in the House of Representatives, and she has thrived in the deal-cutting culture of the Ways and Means Committee.
These days, the tool kit of the successful challenger's campaign includes a simple message repeated endlessly, an elbows-out style, an agility with sound bites, a ferocious pace and a faith in the potentially decisive impact of television advertising.
By nature or necessity, Mrs. Kennelly appears to have gone forth with a shortage or lack of each.
"She doesn't know how to excite this generation," said Peter K. Breit, professor emeritus of government at the University of Hartford. "She's very much her father's daughter, but Connecticut is no longer her father's state. People today see that era as arid and nonresponsive."
But the biggest problem with her campaign may be her opponent. Governor Rowland has remained popular and well financed in a year when incumbents everywhere are enjoying high approval ratings, largely because of the strong economy. Take that environment, stir in a lackluster campaign, and the consensus of a wide range of Democrats and Republicans in the state boils down to: There was little she could do, and she did not do it.
Signs of trouble were evident from the beginning. Mrs. Kennelly had been reluctant to enter the race, but Democratic leaders seized on a poll -- conducted by the University of Connecticut in June 1997 -- that showed her four points ahead of Mr. Rowland, and they talked her into running. She warmed slowly to the race and did not immediately poke at what Democratic leaders considered Mr. Rowland's vulnerabilities, which included his record on education and the environment. He used last winter's session of the Legislature to record achievements in both areas, and she was left to accuse him of stealing her issues.
An early brochure for Mrs. Kennelly featured snapshots of her with prominent politicians -- including the late Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. -- an indication that she might be trying to rely too much on reputation, not on ideas for the future. Republicans called the flier "The Dead Democrats."
A series of four debates that begins Monday gives Mrs. Kennelly one more chance to make a case against Governor Rowland. She has seemed to take little advantage of recent joint appearances with Mr. Rowland, however, declining to criticize him directly. Further, her pitch does not always come across as well honed. Speaking to the business audience last week, for example, Mrs. Kennelly said she planned to enforce environmental laws more rigorously, but did not mention her tax-cut plan.
Mrs. Kennelly clearly does not relish the give-and-take of the campaign trail. Most politicians are reluctant to leave the eye of a television camera. But with reporters surrounding her after her Danbury appearance, she saw the Governor arrive and urged reporters to go talk to him. Served a fat pitch by a reporter looking for a quote about her new hope on the day she began her television advertising, she replied: "Fine. I feel just fine. How do you feel?"
William A. McEachern, a political economist at the University of Connecticut, said: "She just wasn't ready for prime time, the rough-and-tumble of a statewide race. She's better speaking from the well of the House than on the street, and she was trying to run in good times with no memorable issue."
Even Republicans are agog at the decisiveness of her collapse. "She has gone from coronation to catastrophe in just a year," said Kevin F. Rennie, a Hartford lawyer and a former State Senator.
In the Quinnipiac poll released Thursday, 61 percent of the registered voters who were surveyed said they were for Mr. Rowland, 28 percent were for Mrs. Kennelly, and 8 percent were undecided. Quinnipiac polled 1,070 registered voters between Sept. 23 and 28. The margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points. Among the respondents considered by the pollster to be the most likely to vote, the gap was even wider, 69 percent to 25 percent.
A comparison with Quinnipiac's previous Connecticut poll, taken in June, showed that the more Mrs. Kennelly campaigned, the lower her numbers fell. "As the campaign has worn on, she has gone from an overall positive evaluation to a mixed one," Mr. Schwartz, the poll's director, said. When she finally began her television advertising last week, the poll numbers stayed static. Mrs. Kennelly had hoped to impress voters with her concern about education and health care, but those who were polled said Mr. Rowland would do a better job in both areas.
After the poll results were released on Thursday, Mr. Rowland had to struggle to keep a straight face as he talked with reporters outside his office. He said he respected Mrs. Kennelly's "long and distinguished career," and warned against complacency among Republican voters, even though he said he was doing "fairly well."
Mrs. Kennelly's campaign said the poll numbers did not necessarily mean that her brand of politics was outmoded. "Barbara Kennelly is not about theater," said her spokesman, Kevin Lembo. "Barbara Kennelly is about substance."
Eating lunch between campaign stops several weeks ago, Mrs. Kennelly was recounting her glory days as a Hartford City Councilwoman. Recalling the crush of media attention that followed her every pronouncement about her investigation into a roof collapse, Mrs. Kennelly triumphantly turned to an aide and said, "That was when I was a good speaker."

HEADLINE: At Russian Post Office, Check Isn't in the Mail

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 2

 BODY:
In a season of crashing banks, plunging rubles, bouncing paychecks, failing crops and rotating governments, maybe it is not the ultimate insult. But the nation that bore Tolstoy and Chekhov and still regards a well-written letter as a labor of love is buckling a little this week, because it can no longer wish good health to Baba Anya in Omsk.
The Post Office is broke. 
 In 60 of the country's 89 state-like regions, more than 1,000 mail cars have been sidetracked, many stuffed with up to 18 tons of letters, newspapers and parcels. The state Railway Ministry refuses to carry more mail until the Post Office makes good on some 210 million rubles in old bills -- about $13 million in today's dollars, or $35 million in dollars six weeks ago.
Air mail, which amounts to one of every four or five letters, was also suspended at one of Moscow's major airports until this week, when the Post Office coughed up five million rubles for old bills. A second airport is still demanding three million rubles for past-due debts.
So much mail is backed up that post offices in Moscow and elsewhere have simply stopped accepting out-of-town mail, except for areas that can be easily reached by truck. Delivery schedules have fallen weeks, and perhaps months, behind.
"The situation is really extraordinary," said Vladimir V. Sherekhov, the deputy chief of mail service administration in the Government's Communications Committee. "We've never had anything like this before."
Maybe the Post Office has been lucky. Extraordinary is the rule elsewhere in Russia.
Until today, the lower house of Parliament was preparing to sue the Government for failure to provide soap, heat, toilet paper and copy-machine paper in the legislature's monumental downtown offices. It turned out that politicians had exhausted their funds by cutting short their recess and returning to address the nation's economic crisis.
Earlier in the week, officials said Russia's Arctic shipping routes may close next month because half the nation's icebreakers are in disrepair and there is no money to fix them. The oldest of the ships is so ancient that its nickname is Granny.
Such anecdotal evidence that Russia is losing its wheels, like one of its old, ill-maintained Volga sedans, is everywhere. But oddly, real signs of public distress are not all that common, perhaps because the system rarely seems to shed a part as big as a postal system.
If America's Postal Service is increasingly a pipeline for sweepstakes notices and bills, the Russian Post Office still holds a special place in the national conversation. Russians still write letters to each other, frequently and fervently, and many in remote regions get their news through the mail.
Millions use the mails to ship canned goods and other provisions to needy relatives and friends in faraway areas, an especially vital service in winter. And in the last few years, the Post Office has become a vehicle for a growing mail-order trade in books, clothes and other catalogue items not readily available outside big cities.
Exactly why all this has rumbled to a halt is in some dispute. What is clear is that the Post Office and the Railway Ministry both suffer from what ails every Russian venture, private and public alike: nobody pays his bills.
The state Railway Ministry complains that it is continually stiffed by customers who believe the railroads are honor-bound to carry freight whether they are paid or not. The Government has decreed nearly 40 categories of freight which the railroads must carry for next to nothing.
Among the biggest deadbeats are the "power ministries" -- the military and interior departments -- which did not pay during Soviet times and feel little need to pay now.
"It's a psychology formed during the socialist period," said Tatiana L. Pashkova, the deputy spokeswoman for the ministry, "and the same situation exists with the Post Office. We've been in dispute for a very long time. Always we try to understand their differences. But we can't carry cargo for free."
No kidding, says the Post Office: It, too, is owed 200 million rubles by Government agencies, and is barred from raising rates even though freight costs are outstripping revenues. Moreover, the Post Office is also required by the Government to carry some forms of mail, such as pension checks, at reduced rates.
Officials at the state Communications Department say they also suspect an ulterior motive in the railroads' actions: a struggle to dominate the thriving mail-order business.
"Here's competition between us and the railroads for the delivery of parcels, and I think decisions made by the railroads are mainly explained by this competition," Mr. Sherekhov said. "They blame us for carrying some commercial cargoes instead of mail."
The Railway Ministry's spokeswoman, Ms. Pashkova, said such "commercial cargoes" are indeed a problem, but only because the railroads know that the Post Office has already gotten cash to transport the packages. The railroads are still waiting for their share of that money, she said.
In the meantime, the situation has come to a boil. In late September, the railroads cut mail service in and out of Moscow, effectively decapitating the postal system and forcing officials to draft a fleet of trucks to move letters in and out of the city.
Hundreds of empty and full rail cars have clogged some local yards to the point where moving cars into position for unloading has become difficult. At last count, 39 loaded cars were awaiting service at one yard. And customers are getting angry.
"We've gotten all kinds of complaints," said Viktor Salikov, a deputy in the Communications Department's mail shipping center. "People are even coming to us, searching for mail that was sent weeks ago."

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROPOSES I.M.F. ACT EARLIER TO PREVENT CRISES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton today proposed changing the strategy of the International Monetary Fund so it can act earlier to help countries ward off economic crisis, rather than waiting until disaster strikes, when bailouts are more expensive and painful.
Mr. Clinton's proposal came after a week of turmoil in world financial markets and growing fears that the I.M.F.'s severe shortage of money is paralyzing its ability to calm investors, who are pulling billions of dollars out of emerging-market countries. 
 The plan would work, however, only if all member nations provide their full contribution to the I.M.F., starting with the United States. Congress has not approved the $18 billion American share.
The plan does not call for new money to the I.M.F. Rather, it would allow the fund to spend some of that money differently.
The move is motivated, Mr. Clinton said, by mounting evidence that the financial turmoil is threatening the United States.
But details of the plan were left deliberately vague today, largely so that Europe and Japan could debate and perhaps alter it at a meeting on Saturday of finance ministers and central bankers from the world's largest industrial economies. Their meeting will immediately precede a far larger annual meeting of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, sessions that this year are focused on how to stop the global economic turmoil that many fear could set off a worldwide recession.
Mr. Clinton announced the plan this morning in a statement he read just before heading off to two political fund-raisers, a hasty presentation that suggested that the idea had been put together quickly. He said the American proposal would "provide contingent finance to help countries ward off global financial contagion."
Later in the day, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin -- who developed the plan over the last week with the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan -- described the idea as a line of credit that the I.M.F. could offer to countries that are basically economically sound, but are vulnerable to investor panic.
Though Mr. Rubin would not identify any specific countries, the plan might apply to places like Brazil, which despite taking bold measures to reform its economy has still been shaken by nervous investors pulling out their cash because they fear that it could be the next place hit by economic turmoil.
The hope, American officials said, is that the mere presence of the "standby credit" -- akin to a guarantee from a rich relative that a newcomer to town will be able to pay the rent -- will calm investors.
"The idea is to create a precautionary credit line that wouldn't be dispersed unless it is really needed," a senior Treasury official said.
Experts in international finance generally applauded the plan because it appears to be aimed at solving one of the I.M.F.'s greatest shortcomings: Right now it provides major aid to countries only after they are deep in trouble, and then usually with conditions -- chiefly austerity and high interest rates to bolster their currency -- that can trigger unemployment, recession and political backlash.
But politically, the proposal may run into several problems.
The plan would bring no new money into the I.M.F., whose coffers are badly depleted. It would only change the way the fund spends the money given by its 182 member nations.
And right now, Mr. Clinton's commitment to provide $18 billion in new money to the I.M.F. is still stuck in Congress, after being overwhelmingly approved in the Senate and overwhelmingly rejected in the House. A conference committee is expected to decide in the next 10 days or so, but other countries will not contribute their shares -- for a total of $90 to $100 billion in new money -- until the United States acts.
This puts Mr. Rubin in a particularly precarious position at the meeting on Saturday. He must press a plan that is bound to be met with some suspicion by Europe and Japan, at a time that the United States is not providing its share of the financing.
Mr. Clinton alluded to this quandary today during his brief speech on the South Lawn, just two hours before the House Judiciary Committee released thousands of pages of grand jury testimony and other evidence in the Lewinsky matter. The President said, "In the few working days it has left this year, the most important thing Congress can do to protect our farmers, our ranchers, our businesses and our workers, is to secure full funding for the International Monetary Fund."
This is the third time in two weeks that Mr. Clinton has spoken at length on the global financial crisis, after months of near-silence. His political aides say it is time for the President to show a strong American commitment to calming the chaos. And, they add, it may well be good politics by focusing on the economy while Congress seems consumed by its investigations.
The Administration refused to set any amount for this new line of credit for countries in economic danger, saying that will be part of the discussions in the next several days.
Regardless of its size, the new plan may help the White House sell I.M.F. financing in Congress by arguing that it would make the fund more agile and more sensitive to countries' domestic problems. But a fierce critic of the I.M.F. financing, Dick Armey, the House majority leader, said he was unimpressed.
"We need to recognize that it was the Clinton Administration's own policies that accelerated the financial collapse overseas that is threatening the U.S. economy today," Mr. Armey said in a statement this afternoon.
"If the President will not -- or, as yet another consequence of his diminished leadership, cannot -- bring about real changes in international financial institutions, then Congress must supply leadership in his place," he said, insisting that all I.M.F. loans should have a one-year limit and that the fund be prevented from imposing multi-year economic reform plans.
The theory behind the new approach is that the I.M.F. can do more to contain economic contagion, and do it less expensively, if its acts well in advance of a crisis. But announcing the goal and designing the instrument are very different. Mr. Rubin said at a news conference today that investors might feel more confident if they saw that a country had resources to fall back on if they got in trouble, thus diminishing the likelihood of defaulting on its debt.
That, of course, was the theory behind the first bailout of South Korea late last fall. The money proved insufficient, however, and a second infusion was required. It was also the theory behind providing $40 billion in commitments, including $3 billion in American backup financing, to Indonesia. But the political chaos in Jakarta was so great that no amount of money from the I.M.F. could stem the flight of capital from the country.
Still, the American proposal could help emerging-market countries that have essentially sound economies and have enacted real economic reforms but are still caught up in what Mr. Rubin today called the "herd mentality" that has led investors to pull out their money.

HEADLINE: Job Creation Slowed By Foreign Turmoil

 BODY:
The United States economy produced jobs at the lowest rate in more than two years during September, the Labor Department reported. Economists called it the most persuasive evidence yet that the financial crisis abroad is slowing the domestic economy. 
 The Labor Department said the unemployment rate edged up only slightly, to 4.6 percent, from 4.5 percent in August. But payrolls expanded by just 69,000 jobs, a fraction of the roughly 200,000 that had been expected by forecasters.
 Business Day, page C1.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HALLIBURTON TAKES ACTION TO SAVE ABOUT $250 MILLION

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Halliburton Company said yesterday that it would eliminate about 5,250 jobs and close about 400 offices worldwide as part of its plan to save about $250 million a year from its acquisition of Dresser Industries and to reduce expenses as lower oil prices cut into its business. The job cuts are in addition to about 2,000 workers the company has already eliminated because of low oil prices. The cuts reduce the work force of the Dallas-based company by about 7 percent.

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF THE PRESIDENT: THE OVERVIEW;
Panel Releases Conversations Taped by Tripp

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The House Judiciary Committee today released the final mass of evidence in its consideration of impeachment charges against President Clinton, offering a pungent store of furtive tapes and grand jury delvings into Mr. Clinton's intimate relationship with a White House intern.
The release of the 4,600 pages of heavily edited testimony and transcripts featured Linda R. Tripp's 20 hours of secret voice recordings of the intern, Monica S. Lewinsky -- the seedbed tapes of the seven-month criminal investigation into the misbehavior with Ms. Lewinsky that Mr. Clinton denied before the nation for seven months. 
 The White House, braced for an all-out impeachment struggle with the Republican-controlled Congress, denounced this third release of evidence accumulated by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, as "the clearest indication that this is a partisan process designed for partisan gain," and one far afield from the constitutional requirement for impeachment.
To make that point, the President's lawyers submitted an argument for the House's consideration that reached back 200 years into the history of sex and politics and cited as precedent Congress's early refusal to impeach Alexander Hamilton, the Secretary of the Treasury, after he paid off a blackmailer who threatened to disclose Hamilton's sexual peccadilloes. The 105th Congress should be no less tolerant in the case of Mr. Clinton's behavior, the 30-page brief argued.
The document release ranged from tiny details in the Tripp-Lewinsky confidences to hard combat in the grand jury room between prosecutors and the dozens of Clinton supporters subpoenaed as the President found himself targeted.
"Tell the grand jury all the conversations you had with the President of the United States about Monica Lewinsky since January 12, 1998 -- how's that?" one prosecutor demanded of Bruce R. Lindsey, the deputy White House counsel. Mr. Lindsey, the President's closest, most tight-lipped confidante, stolidly refused to answer.
While devoid of major new disclosures, the new material details the wide net thrown by Mr. Starr in trying to make the case to Congress that the President should be impeached because he allegedly committed perjury and tampered with witnesses in his effort to keep the Lewinsky affair private.
Mr. Clinton, on a fund-raising visit to Cleveland, observed that everyone has to live with the consequences of mistakes in life. "Most of us don't have to live with it in quite such a public way," he said as donors laughed and the new disclosures flooded the nation.
The densely packed three-volume release, including the testimony of dozens of the President's staff members and political associates, was laced with second-hand accountings of the President's personal life and glimpses of the White House's extensive attempts to foil Mr. Starr in his mission. The material was the prelude to the committee's public meeting next Monday, when the Republican majority is widely expected to recommend a formal House impeachment inquiry.
The new evidence hardly settled the impeachment question as Mr. Clinton's critics and defenders each claimed material supporting their contentions. But the voluminous material confirmed the White House scandal as a heated farrago of personal, legal and political clashes that has put Mr. Clinton's incumbency at risk. The welter of documentation includes these:
*The repeated attempts of Mrs. Tripp, Ms. Lewinsky's erstwhile friend, to use her mentoring role to coach the younger woman -- even using the collective "we" in strategizing at some points. "I think you should say, 'Well, I really need to speak to the big creep,' " Mrs. Tripp advised in one taped exchange, referring to the Ms. Lewinsky's nickname for the President.
*The possibility of gleaning the Tripp-Lewinsky tapes for exculpatory material as much as indicting comments. In the one tape-recording that Mrs. Tripp made secretly for Mr. Starr last January, she asked Ms. Lewinsky a key question in the prosecutors' attempt to discover evidence of Presidential perjury: "What is the definition of sex?" On the tape, Ms. Lewinsky replied, "Intercourse." Echoing Mr. Clinton's later defense to the grand jury and the nation, she added: "I never had intercourse. I did not have a sexual relationship."
*The repeated grand jury questioning in which the recollections of the President's secretary, Betty Currie, who facilitated Ms. Lewinsky's Oval Office visits, grew less and less distinct. "My memory is a little better -- but not much," she told the jury after a consultation with her lawyer.
*The urgent dawning in the White House last Jan. 17, after the President was deposed in the Paula Jones sexual misconduct civil suit, that Mr. Starr was hotly pursuing Ms. Lewinsky as a witness in some larger criminal inquiry directed against the President. "Do you think you can reach Monica, see what's happening?" Mr. Clinton asked Mrs. Currie after his deposition. After tracking down Ms. Lewinsky, the secretary said the normally loquacious intern hung up the phone after declaring, "I can't talk to you."
*The combativeness of the President's loyalists in the face of Starr prosecutors. "I'm just not going to answer that," the President's close friend, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., snapped when asked whether he was misled by Mr. Clinton's distinctions about sexual conduct. "You seem to have the problem with oral sex," he told the prosecutor. "I don't."
Already split along partisans lines even before voting its own inquiry, the committee now has a wealth of submissions from Mr. Starr, including Ms. Lewinsky's testimony admitting to oral sex with the President, and Mr. Clinton's own four hours of grand jury testimony broadcast to the nation last month. In that testimony, the President criticized Mr. Starr's inquiry as little more than a politically driven "parsing of the definition of sex."
Mr. Clinton maintains that because his behavior with Ms. Lewinsky involved oral sex and not intercourse, he did not commit perjury in his Jones lawsuit deposition last January, when he denied a sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky. After confirming a relationship before the grand jury, the President also told the nation on Aug. 17, contending that his earlier denials were legally accurate though generally misleading.
The document release disclosed the grand jury testimony of a panoply of witnesses, from some of the highest Presidential counsels to Secret Service agents who guard the President. There were exceptions, notably the testimony of Kathleen Willey, a White House volunteer who said Mr. Clinton had once groped her sexually. Mr. Starr previously said his office was continuing to look into possible obstruction of justice in the reaction to her charge by unnamed Clinton defenders.
Armies of lawyers and news workers gleaned the latest disclosures into the weekend, setting the stage for the Judiciary Committee's opening hearing on Monday. In particular, they studied the President's initial handling of the crisis as it broke last January, the Democrats' insistence that the evidence is more exculpatory than indicting and, above all, the interplay between Mrs. Tripp and Ms. Lewinsky -- with the intern remaining clueless until the end about her friend's duplicity. "You are a wise, savvy woman, and I truly value your opinions," she told Mrs. Tripp last November.
Mr. Jordan, the President's golfing buddy who helped look for a job for Ms. Lewinsky when she was being subpoenaed in the Jones lawsuit, testified that two days after his deposition Mr. Clinton was in an "incredulous state" about the Drudge Report on the Internet. The cyber gossip gave the first public hint of Mr. Starr's searching into the deposition and the President's personal affairs as he sought evidence of obstruction of justice.
"It's not true," Mr. Clinton declared of the Lewinsky matter, according to Mr. Jordan. With the new Starr threat emerging, Mr. Jordan had lunch with Mr. Lindsey.
"It was clear that there was a problem, and what to do about the problem we did not get into," Mr. Jordan testified.
The President, meanwhile, had already been talking to Mrs. Currie soon after his return from the deposition, and asked a series of questions that prosecutors consider witness-coaching but that the President insists was innocent. Before that point, even as Mr. Clinton was being deposed on Jan. 17, John Podesta, the President's deputy chief of staff, had heard the first rumors of Mr. Starr's possible entry into the affair -- "linking for the first time, in my mind, Monica Lewinsky to the Paula Jones matter," Mr. Podesta testified.
As the sense of crisis grew, Mr. Jordan repeatedly telephoned Ms. Lewinsky, to no avail. He got to know her during the job-hunting help he had offered her. Summarizing the young woman for the grand jury, Mr. Jordan recalled, "I was listening to a bobby-soxer who was mesmerized by Frank Sinatra."
The President telephoned Mr. Jordan in the early morning of Jan. 21, when the first newspaper disclosures were breaking about Mr. Starr's new inquiry.
"There's a story out," the President said, according to Mr. Jordan. "I'm concerned about it. And the story is about Monica Lewinsky and myself."
Mr. Clinton "just sort of emoted about his circumstances," Mr. Jordan said. In turn, he testified, he advised the President: "Not to worry about it. Tell the First Lady. Deal with it later in the morning."
The President's lawyers said the latest release of documents bolster their charges that Mr. Starr twisted the evidence he gained in his investigation to build an impeachment referral to Congress.
Gregory Craig, the special counsel to the President, said a close reading of the thousands of fresh pages show that Mr. Starr engaged in "a pattern of evidentiary manipulation and misdirection" in his report to the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. Craig, who was recently added to the White House staff to direct Mr. Clinton's response to the impeachment inquiry, said Mr. Starr purposely failed to discuss evidence favorable to the President "and intentionally omitted direct exculpatory testimony, paraphrased unambiguous statements to obscure their plain meaning and systematically resolved conflicting testimony in its favor."
The principal evidence of that, Mr. Craig said, was that Mr. Starr's initial "narrative" -- a list of detailed charges presented to Congress -- did not contain some of the information that was finally released today, well after the initial sensation over Mr. Starr's impeachment recommendation last month. The President's lawyers cited Mrs. Currie's testimony that it was she and not Mr. Clinton who was responsible for trying to get Ms. Lewinsky a job.
The President's lawyers sent a letter today to Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, outlining their objections and arguing that neither private sexual conduct nor the perjury alleged by the President's critics met the constitutional test of impeachment.
The White House's protests and references to the new material pointed once more toward a defense that Mrs. Tripp acted as an agent provocateur for the President's political opponents in her conversations and tapings of Ms. Lewinsky.
The release of the text, but not the sound, of the taped conversations, presents considerable excerpts from the long and winding feat of eavesdropping carried out by Mrs. Tripp on Ms. Lewinsky as she railed about her affair with Mr. Clinton.
"I don't think there's a detail she left out," Mrs. Tripp testified to the grand jury, as if from exhaustion.
The tapes present Mrs. Tripp's behavior as ranging the gamut. "I hate what he has done to you," she told Ms. Lewinsky in denouncing the President at one point. But at another moment, her mission in endlessly hearing about Ms. Lewinsky's version of her life and times exasperated Mrs. Tripp.
In an E-mail message last Oct. 27, she complained to Ms. Lewinsky about her constant "ranting and raving" over the affair. "Share this sick situation with one of your friends, because, frankly, I'm past nauseated about the whole thing," Mrs. Tripp snapped. (She obviously reconsidered, for she taped on into the New Year, and finally for Mr. Starr.)
Ms. Lewinsky replied, "That's fine," while urging that none of their confidences ever be broken.
In her own grand jury testimony, Mrs. Tripp denied being a secret agent for Mr. Starr and other Republican critics of the President. "My idea was never to manufacture evidence," she asserted. "In fact, I had never even thought about the independent counsel in my wildest dreams. My idea was I'm going to arm myself with records so when I'm in a position to speak under oath, I can do so truthfully."
For her part, Ms. Lewinsky often sounds self-absorbed and frustrated. "I think people call me 'the stalker,' " she lamented. "I think that's what they say. Oh my God, that gets me so mad. I hate that," she said, as Ms. Tripp quietly taped the tale of the President and the intern.

HEADLINE: New Curbs Set For Pakistan And India

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 2

 BODY:
While Congress debates a temporary waiver of sanctions imposed on India and Pakistan because of their nuclear tests in May, the Clinton Administration is getting ready to release a long list of companies and government institutions in those countries that Americans will be barred from doing business with if the sanctions stay in place.
Experts say that the list, required under an amendment punishing nations that test to develop nuclear weapons, is due out soon and could not come at a worse time for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan and Atal Behari Vajpayee of India. 
 Both men pledged last week in speeches to the United Nations that they would sign the nuclear test ban treaty within the coming year although both do not have solid support for the move at home.
In India and Pakistan, where the nuclear tests met with jubilation, there have been second thoughts about the consequences of those tests, which altered the strategic map of Asia and increased the number of countries with nuclear weapons for the first time in 30 years.
The American sanctions that followed -- covering loans, credits, credit guarantees, military and munitions exports -- were felt worse initially by Pakistan, which was already under Congressional restrictions, but India did not escape the effect, which will worsen if links to American trade and investment are disrupted. Even with a waiver, bars will remain on deals with Indian and Pakistani nuclear institutions. The United States earlier waived some restrictions on agricultural sales.
The hope of the two Prime Ministers had apparently been to convince people that signing the 1996 test ban treaty would bring benefits -- at the very least the lifting of sanctions. The publication of a list of prohibited business partners, however coincidental, could negate that argument.
Administration officials say that they have no option, since the drawing up of the list was required by Congress under the 1994 Glenn Amendment, named for its author, Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio. Officials call it an "entities list" because it is a mixed bag of targets, including government institutions, military units, government-owned companies and private firms doing business with the nuclear establishment in either country.
About a dozen Indian and Pakistani companies and fewer than 20 Government departments in India and 15 in Pakistan are involved, officials said, but dozens more subdivisions are also listed, bringing the list to 100 or more names. The most severe restrictions cover government organizations involved in nuclear or missile activities.
Karl F. Inderfurth, Assistant Secretary of State for South Asia, said that the impending release of the list did not in any way reflect disappointment with the statements made by the two leaders, although Administration officials said at the time the pledges were made that Washington also wanted to see progress in other disarmament areas.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 4, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A headline yesterday about Indian and Pakistan companies and government institutions with which Americans will be barred from doing business misstated United States policy toward those countries. The ban assumes that current sanctions imposed after those countries tested nuclear devices in May remain in place. No new sanctions are planned.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Secret America

BYLINE: By Sam Tanenhaus; Sam Tanenhaus, an editor at The Times's Op-Ed page and the author of "Whittaker Chambers," is writing a biography of William F. Buckley Jr.

 BODY:

SECRECY
 The American Experience.
 By Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
 Introduction by Richard Gid Powers.
 262 pp. New Haven:
 Yale University Press. $22.50. 
 Just because the United States won the cold war doesn't mean our Government did everything right. On the contrary, as one of the most zealous cold war Presidents, Ronald Reagan, delicately put it when acknowledging the criminal excesses of the Iran-contra scandal, "mistakes were made." Indeed they were. The Central Intelligence Agency, in particular, was a command center of malfeasance in the 1980's. Under its Director, William Casey, the C.I.A. fed the White House exaggerated reports of Soviet military and economic strength and kept Congress in the dark, illegally at times, about various covert operations. Meanwhile, a mole within the agency, Aldrich Ames, was peddling secrets to the Kremlin, with the result that at least 12 prized overseas "assets" were killed.
 It would be unfair to pin all this on Reagan. What happened on his watch was simply the culmination of a long history of deceptions thrust on official Washington by official Washington. "Secrecy" is Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's withering account of the Government's bottomless appetite for "intelligence" -- that is, for collecting, concealing, suppressing and manipulating it. It is a dismaying tale, though Moynihan has told it with uncommon liveliness and a mordant wit. For example, he and his colleagues on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee received a briefing on Bosnia in 1993. Before the spokesman for the C.I.A. began, he raised a question: "Is everybody here cleared?" Moynihan writes: "One asked oneself: cleared for what? Premature Chetnik sympathies? Latent Titoist tendencies? We had no secrets about the Balkans. But this was now Government routine."
 Yet this book is not primarily an insider's account of the Government in action. It is, more ambitiously, a historical assessment of the "culture of secrecy," particularly in the area of foreign policy.
 In a thoughtful and wide-ranging introduction to "Secrecy," the historian Richard Gid Powers, himself an authority on the subject, reminds us that Moynihan, "the quintessential liberal anti-Communist," is uniquely qualified to survey this terrain, since in 1993 he introduced legislation for a bipartisan study of the problem of Government secrecy. He was chairman of the resulting commission, which "interviewed more than 96 agencies, corporations and organizations and more than 300 individuals," including "some of the country's best-known historians, policy analysts and journalists," as well as "convicted spies" serving time in Federal prisons. What he learned, Powers tells us, augmented his already formidable distrust of official intelligence. In the 1970's, Moynihan had been among the few in government who openly questioned Washington's dogged insistence that the Soviet Union was steadily gaining in "military, political and economic strength" when any visitor could see that the people there "had no clothes, not to mention no shoes, butter, meat, living space, heat, telephones or toilet paper."
 How did the shapers of our foreign policy arrive at this state of educated ignorance? Through a fateful conjunction of secrecy and bureaucracy, Moynihan says, that dates all the way back to 1917, when President Woodrow Wilson dragged a reluctant nation into World War I and thereupon began, with missionary grimness, to crush all dissent. Wilson pushed the Espionage Act of 1917 through Congress, and then the Sedition Act of 1918. Thus did the apostle of forthrightness in international relations -- "open covenants . . . openly arrived at" -- leave successive generations to wrestle with the three-headed demon of conspiracy, loyalty and secrecy. As Moynihan notes: "In time there would be a Federal Bureau of Investigation to keep track of conspiracy at home, a Central Intelligence Agency to keep tabs abroad, an espionage statute and loyalty boards to root out disloyalty or subversion. And all of this would be maintained, and the national security would be secured, through elaborate regimes of secrecy."
 The next step came in the 1930's, when the United States was confronted with the rise of totalitarian powers abroad, both fascist and Communist. The latter, in particular, functioned as an international conspiracy, complete with underground spy networks and multiple front groups, and seemed to require counterconspiratorial remedies. Many of these were concocted by J. Edgar Hoover, who began compiling dossiers on subversives, real and imagined. In his enthusiasm he did not always distinguish Soviet operatives from, say, members of the now-forgotten League of Women Shoppers.
 Convenient elisions of this kind helped sow the bitter discords of the cold war, the era in which Government secrecy assumed its most treacherous proportions. A malign precedent was established with the handling of the Venona decrypts, interceptions of ingeniously coded cables relayed to Moscow by Soviet agents posted in the United States. In 1943, the National Security Agency captured a batch of these communiques and began the long, painstaking decoding process that eventually yielded the names of Americans who were spying for the Kremlin. By 1947 there was ample evidence that a Soviet spy network was flourishing inside the United States. It made sense that President Truman should be put on notice.
 Yet there was a complication. In 1946, J. Edgar Hoover had warned Truman that Communists had infiltrated the Government, but the evidence he adduced was weak -- a dubious list of names and gossipy allegations -- and Truman had scoffed. The Venona documents offered, at last, hard facts. "Now then," Moynihan asks, "did the Director of the F.B.I., who had been quite prepared the year before to rush to the President a report of an all but fictional 'enormous Soviet espionage ring in Washington,' inform the President of the possibly less than enormous but real Communist spying when real evidence became available?" The answer was no.
 It was not all Hoover's fault. The decision was made by Gen. Omar Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who classified the Venona material as Army "property." Unlike Hoover, who hated Truman, Bradley liked and admired him. But his loyalty to the President was overcome by the bureaucratic imperative to hoard these valuable nuggets. As a result, in the early, critical stages of the cold war, the President had no firsthand knowledge of Soviet infiltration. "It gives one pause," Moynihan remarks, "to think now that all Truman ever 'learned' about Communist espionage came from the hearings of the House Un-American Activities Committee, the speeches of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the like." Almost as bad, millions of Americans would remain convinced for years to come that domestic Soviet spying was the phantasmal invention of Hoover, HUAC and McCarthy.
 But there is more to this depressing story than Moynihan reports. In 1945 Mackenzie King, the Prime Minister of Canada, had traveled to the White House bearing a transcript of statements made by Igor Gouzenko, a Russian who had defected while employed in the Soviet Embassy in Ottawa and then gave a thorough rundown of a North American spy ring. Gouzenko identified a number of agents by profession only. He had no names. But Hoover was able to connect the dots and present a clear enough picture to Truman's Under Secretary of State, Dean Acheson, in a private meeting. Acheson, a New Dealer and no fan of Hoover, did not take the report seriously and so let the matter drop, although it offered stark confirmation that two senior Administration officials, Alger Hiss and Harry Dexter White, were Soviet agents. Secrecy, then, was not the whole problem. Partisanship and personal feeling entered into the equation too.
 Beyond this, it may well be that more, not less, secrecy would have calmed the furies of those fraught years. Surely it was the public nature of the Hiss and Rosenberg spy trials that inflamed the nation, whereas comparatively secret prosecutions of the atomic spies Klaus Fuchs and Alan Nunn May caused far less furor in Britain. The contrast was clear, too, in subsequent spy scandals. The British Government cleaned up its intelligence agencies by means of quiet purges that created scarcely a ripple of interest, while the highly visible Red hunts superintended so clamorously by Joseph McCarthy left a permanent wound on the nation's political life. Openness, too, exacts a toll.
 Still, it is hard to quarrel with Moynihan's characterization of cold war secrecy as injuriously "all-consuming." For this reason it is surprising that he says so little about the Vietnam War. No President was served worse by experts than Lyndon Johnson, whose policy advisers and field generals, brandishing data that no outsiders were permitted to examine, used the absurd numerology of body counts to weave a fictional narrative of battlefield triumphs. Here, again, secrecy did not operate alone, for what motivated these experts to deceive the Commander in Chief was their determination to halt Communist expansion, and what persuaded Johnson to go along was, in large part, his fear of appearing "soft" on Communism.
 On the other hand, Moynihan's argument is thoroughly borne out in the case of Johnson's successor, Richard Nixon, whose passion for secrecy really was all-consuming. His undoing began, Moynihan observes, with the publication of the Pentagon Papers. Nixon persuaded himself that those documents were vital to national security and so set in motion the retributive machinery that ultimately led to his resignation.
 "Secrecy" carries the story forward to the period of Moynihan's own struggles with a C.I.A. grown lazy and fat over the years. Formed in 1947 as an information-gathering agency, it soon lunged into covert actions, supported by a hugely inflated budget that by 1990 was five times as large as the State Department's. Moynihan, who has repeatedly called for the agency's dismantling, points out that doubts about the C.I.A.'s performance arose as early as the 1950's.
 He also argues that there is no reason that information gathered secretly should be any more effective than that accumulated by open study. He cites the example of the egregious report on "Deterrence and Survival in the Nuclear Age." Prepared by a panel of the President's Science Advisory Committee in 1957, and forwarded to President Eisenhower weeks after the launching of Sputnik, the report envisaged a Soviet Union ineluctably on course to overtake the United States economically and militarily by the end of the century. This nonsense helped spawn the fiction of a "missile gap." Nonetheless, the report remained, in all its patent error, classified Top Secret until 1973.
 By then the damage was done. Misreading the Soviet Union had become de rigueur for policy experts. American analysts diligently ignored the truth about our rival superpower: its dysfunctional economy, its political spoils system rotten with corruption, its republics seething with ethnic hatreds, its satellite countries in rebellion. Our leaders insistently portrayed this creaking shambles of an empire as an indestructible colossus. When the truth overtook us in 1989, the custodians of the free world were suddenly clueless.
 Moynihan's account of all this is engaging and informed. But the question remains: Would it really have helped if the veil of secrecy had been lifted and if outside experts had been given a chance to assess the Government's slanted evidence? After all, dissenting voices were raised time and again, and from within the Beltway. George Kennan, the architect of Soviet containment, had seen as early as 1947 that, as Moynihan puts it, "Soviet Communism contained its own seeds of destruction." But his warnings went unheeded. So did Moynihan's 30 years later, when he adduced indisputable facts to show that the Soviet Union was in extremis. The trouble, as he pointed out in 1991, was that "our analysts had internalized a Soviet view of the world." Yes, secrecy was to blame. But so was an ideology so rigid that it had been transmuted into blind faith.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 13; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2119 words

HEADLINE: FALL AND WINTER CRUISES;
The Romance of the Seas

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL; EDWIN McDOWELL, a business reporter for The Times, covers the travel industry.

 BODY:
THROUGH most of the first eight months of this year, almost everything seemed to be coming up roses for the cruise industry. The year-end passenger count is likely to surpass last year's 5.05 million total, and the industry forecast of 7 million passengers by the year 2000 seemed well on target. Even the arrival in Florida two days ago of the Grand Princess, the world's biggest cruise liner, which departs on its initial Caribbean cruise today, did not give rise to the usual laments that the industry cannot absorb so many berths. 
 But the stock market slide that turned into a plunge on Aug. 31, and the financial roller-coaster ride that followed, sent the euphoria packing. For they served as reminders that cruises are especially vulnerable to penny-pinching during tight economic times, when many potential passengers opt instead for day trips, vacations visiting family or friends, or staying home altogether.
Hurricane Georges caused few canceled cruises in the Carribean and the Gulf of Mexico, though a number of cruise lines had to juggle itineraries, dates and time of departure, even the port of departure. Barring unforeseen storms, or greater than expected damage to ports, cruise lines said they expected to be operating on normal schedules by last week. But they recommend that passengers who have booked a cruise contact their travel agent, the cruise line or the line's Web site for any last-minute changes.
 Still, while widespread optimism about the economic outlook has been replaced by widespread caution, the industry is reasonably confident that several national trends and its own innovations will cushion any but the worst shocks.
For example, while vacations are undeniably susceptible to economic downturns, more Americans have come to regard them as a veritable birthright. Americans took 862 million pleasure trips last year, according to the Travel Industry Association, 43 percent more than in 1987. And cruises, at an average cost of about $175 per adult per day, including meals and entertainment -- with children free or at a reduced rate -- compare favorably with resort hotels, ski vacations or a week or two at the beach.
Furthermore, the popularity of two- to five-day cruises, the industry's fastest-growing segment, mirrors the national trend toward shorter, more frequent vacations, to accommodate working couples. As a result, younger people are increasingly choosing a cruise for one of those shorter vacations. According to the Cruise Lines International Association, the percentage of travelers over 60 has dropped to 28 percent this year from 44 percent in 1986 and the median age has fallen from 52 to 50 in that same period; Carnival said that for the last decade 35 percent of its 1.7 million passengers have been under 35.
Another sign of cruising's growing popularity among younger people is that weddings at sea are no longer an anomaly but an established phenomenon, offered on ships large and small. The Grand Princess says it has the first chapel at sea, the Hearts and Minds Wedding Chapel, which seats 36 and can be used for marriages and renewing vows. Chapels are all but certain on some of the 20 or more new ships expected to go into service through the year 2001.
Carnival alone said that it will have married 2,000 couples this year, during shipboard services on embarkation day in any of its year-round home ports, plus Vancouver during the summer season. Also available are on-island ceremonies during port calls in Catalina Island, San Juan and St. Thomas, as well as shipboard services while its vessels are docked or anchored at Grand Cayman and Barbados. To keep up with demand, two months ago Carnival added on-island ceremonies in Ocho Rios, Jamaica; Key West, Fla. (at a private beach), and Nassau, the Bahamas (in a flower-covered gazebo at the Radisson Beach Hotel or on an adjacent private beach).
Wedding packages average about $500 but can easily cost $1,500, depending on options. Most are likely to include an official civil ceremony, flowers, champagne, photographs, wedding cake and transportation to and from the island location. Most also include prerecorded wedding music, but American Hawaii's packages include live ukulele music, as well as flower leis and a floral headpiece for the bride.
"A lot of the people getting married on ships are getting married for the second time, and just don't want to spend a fortune on another wedding," said Shaunah Majcher, vice president of Royal Pacific Occasions, a Vancouver company that coordinates weddings throughout the world for Holland America. One of its more unusual wedding sites, Ms. Majcher said, is atop Herbert Glacier, a short helicopter flight from Juneau, Alaska.
Cruise weddings vary with cruise line, although the lines require that bride and bridegroom sail on the cruise. Also, according to Ms. Majcher, on most ships captains do not perform wedding ceremonies, couples cannot usually be married while at sea, and most wedding ceremonies are civil rather than religious services.
Children are another growing cruise sector. The industry puts their numbers at only 15 percent, but in the case of Carnival, the industry leader, that is expected to translate into about 200,000 children this year. And the percentage of children is obviously far higher during school vacations and on Disney Cruise Line, which was designed with families in mind.
Citing the fate of the all-family ship American Adventure, which folded in 1994 after nine months of operation, industry officials still question the wisdom of an all-family ship or cruise line, except for Disney, whose cruises are sold as part of a land-sea package with Disney World. But they consider family cruises with children an important untapped market.
That is why this year Princess lowered from 12 months to 6 months the age at which children can accompany their parents or guardians to the Caribbean and Alaska. That is also why, during holidays or in the summer, most ships have a range of programs for kids 2 to 17, as well as trained counselors, baby sitters, children's menus, toddler's play areas, teen clubs, wading pools, karaoke contests and pizza parties. Premier's Big Red Boat not only has Looney Tunes characters aboard but also serves Bugs Bunny-shaped waffles for breakfast.
All Carnival ships have a children's wading pool, while its Celebration and Ecstasy have water slides for children who can swim and are at least 3 feet 10 inches. The Grand Princess not only has two-level children's and teen centers, for teen-agers it also has a disco, Jacuzzi and a motion-based simulator that provides a variety of thrill rides.
One of the newest trends afloat is educational activities for children, including Hawaiian language and hula lessons on American Hawaii Cruises, Italian language lessons on Costa Cruise Lines and learning the art of clowning aboard Norwegian Cruise Line. Royal Caribbean has a video arcade as well as children's books in the ship library and movies for children on cabin televisions. On Celebrity Cruises, children can participate in summer stock theater, from operating lighting equipment to performing in shows.
Activities for adults are on the rise, too. Theme cruises, which Norwegian Cruise Line claims to have pioneered in the early 1980's, continue to grow in number and popularity. Norwegian is offering its 16th annual Floating Jazz Festival on two weeklong Caribbean cruises aboard the Norway departing Miami on Oct. 24 and Oct. 31; other sailings will feature country music (Nov. 14), big bands (Nov. 21) and blues (Dec. 12).
Holland America's Westerdam will operate 22 seven-day theme cruises this fall and next year from Fort Lauderdale to the eastern Caribbean. These include a tribute to Frank Sinatra departing Dec. 12 (Sinatra's birthday), and big bands Nov. 14 and 21, Jan. 9 and March 6. The Oct. 24 departure will celebrate Oktoberfest, with beer tastings and oompah and polka music. Bingo's the game on the Nov. 7, Jan. 2 and March 27 cruises, and the Super Bowl will be broadcast live on Jan. 31. That cruise will feature Pro Bowl and Hall of Fame football players.
American Hawaii Cruises' Independence will have marine naturalists aboard all 14 seven-day round-trip whale-watching cruises departing Honolulu every Saturday from Jan. 2 through April 3.
Crystal Cruises themes will range from the cerebral to the gustatory. Writers, artists and editors of The New Yorker magazine will appear on each segment of the Crystal Symphony's 99-day voyage from Los Angeles to Lisbon, beginning Jan. 18. And all eight 12-day San Francisco to Alaska cruises next summer will feature "great chefs of San Francisco." Royal Olympic's Stella Solaris will celebrate theater and cabaret on its 13-day cruise departing from Rio de Janeiro to Manaus, Brazil, and on its 13-day cruise departing from Manaus to Fort Lauderdale. The Royal Viking Sun will offer a murder mystery cruise during its 14-day crossing (May 21) from Miami to Barcelona in which passengers act the role of sleuth and try to collar a killer on the loose among them.
Radisson Seven Seas Cruises is offering six golf cruises through February, during which passengers can play on two to four golf courses per cruise. The first, 10 nights, departing Oct. 15, sails from Rome to Madeira. The Nov. 23 cruise is seven-nights round trip to and from San Juan, Puerto Rico; Nov. 30, seven nights from San Juan to Puerto Limon, Costa Rica; Dec. 7, eight nights from Puerto Limon to Fort Lauderdale; Jan. 17, nine nights from Puerto Caldera, Costa Rica, to Fort Lauderdale, and Feb. 2, 10 nights from Fort Lauderdale to Puerto Caldera.
The reason for the popularity of theme cruises, according to James G. Godsman, president of Cruise Lines International Association, is that they they can fit into busy schedules and "give vacationers the chance to try a new hobby or rekindle interest in an old one, against a backdrop of ever-changing destinations."
Meanwhile, the cruise industry is expanding to new ports of call -- adding variety to itineraries -- and to new home ports. Holland America will use San Diego as a home port for the first time in 1999, when the Statendam makes five 16-day round trips to Hawaii, the first two of which depart March 29 and April 14. Its Nieuw Amsterdam will return to Tampa, Fla., in December 1999 for a series of five 14-day cruises to the southern Caribbean, plus two seven-day holiday cruises. Carnival's Sensation will relocate to Tampa this December for weekly western Caribbean cruises, beginning Dec. 20.
 
CARNIVAL, with the biggest fleet in the industry (12 ships currently, with 2 more scheduled for delivery next year), will be busy on several new fronts in 1999. Its Fascination will operate from Newport News, Va., and Charleston, S.C., with a mix of one-night Cruises to Nowhere and Bahamas trips. Next fall, Carnival's Inspiration will sail a somewhat similar itinerary.
Significantly, the Fascination and Inspiration can each carry 2,040-passengers, suggesting that Carnival has high expectations for them in their new surroundings. When Carnival returns to New York next summer, for its first sailings from the city in five years, it will do so with the Triumph, set for delivery in mid-July. At 2,758 passengers and 102,000 tons, it will be the biggest cruise ship ever to operate from New York.
Cruise ships are vulnerable not only to economic swings but to safety failures as well, despite the industry's exemplary safety record. A survey last June by Wirthlin Worldwide, a research and consulting company in McLean, Va., found that 14 percent of Americans in a nationwide telephone poll of a thousand adults said they intended to spend at least one night on a cruise ship during the coming year. But that plummeted to 7 percent the next month, following the fire aboard the Carnival Ecstasy shortly after it left Miami.
Political change has affected the Wind Star, which will be repositioned in November from the Mediterranean to Costa Rica instead of Southeast Asia as planned. It had been scheduled to operate for five months in Indonesia, according to Richard D. Meadows, vice president of marketing and sales for Windstar Cruises, but unrest in the region -- prompting State Department travel advisories -- hampered the company's ability to market the cruises.
"Our Indonesian itineraries from Bali to Singapore were an integral part of our year-round Southeast Asia program," Mr. Meadows added. "Without these itineraries we think it will be difficult to operate profitably in Southeast Asia on a year-round basis and have decided to move the ship in a different direction."
