SECTION: Section 6; Page 51; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 7453 words

HEADLINE: The Crude Face of Global Capitalism

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Goldberg; Jeffrey Goldberg is a contributing writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
Azerbaijan is a former soviet republic located in a disagreeable spot just south of Russia and just north of Iran. It is known for nothing except oil, and the smell of that oil is inescapable, even inside the cabin of an arthritic helicopter desperately trying to gain altitude for a trip across the Caspian Sea.
The helicopter, a rusting Soviet Mi-8, seems unable to move forward, which is problematic, because we are already hovering 25 feet above the ground. Our destination, an offshore pumping complex known as Oily Rocks, sits 15 miles away. Azerbaijan Airlines inherited the helicopter from Aeroflot but did not, apparently, inherit spare parts. 
 One of these helicopters recently crashed into an oil platform, initially prompting the president of Azerbaijan's state oil company to turn down my request for a lift. "It would be very embarrassing if foreigners were killed on the way to Oily Rocks," Natig Aliev told me. But I told Aliev I couldn't leave Azerbaijan without seeing Oily Rocks, one of the world's largest offshore oil complexes, a place that would certainly rank as Azerbaijan's greatest tourist attraction if Azerbaijan had tourists. And so the accommodating Aliev lifted the ban, for an afternoon.
After hanging in the air for two minutes, the pilot sets the helicopter back down. Big yellow rings of sweat stain his shirt. He tosses off the last man to climb aboard, and returns to his seat. This time we're off, a single 150-pound oil worker making all the difference.
As we gain altitude, the Apsheron Peninsula spreads out before us. The ground below is brown and cracked dry in the heat. Crippled oil pumps dot the landscape all the way back to the capital city, Baku, which is built on vast reservoirs of oil and gas and is crowded with ornate buildings that date back to the first great oil rush here, more than a century ago.
We fly out over the pale blue Caspian, which is spidered with mean black slicks of oil. Which makes me think of. . . caviar. Just how safe can Caspian beluga be, if the sturgeon swim in light crude?
And then, there it is: Oily Rocks, a Stalinist fabulation of broken-down oil platforms and causeways that stretch past the horizon. Crosshatched streets, 125 miles of them, rest on pylons sunk into the seabed. We touch down on a weedy landing pad and are met by a school bus that will carry us down the causeways that link one platform to another. The state oil company has sent a senior executive, Baba Musayev, to be my official minder. He is a man of about 50, rough-hewed, with rotting teeth and arms tanned the color of plums. There is no place like Oily Rocks in the entire world, he says, and this is true: in the West, oil platforms are built freestanding. "But in the Soviet Union," Musayev says, "steel was cheap and there was a lot of it, so the Soviet mentality said that everything should be linked by road."
Oily Rocks is crumbling; truck-size chunks of it are falling into the sea, and everything is orange with rust. One-third of the 600 wells are inoperative, and miles and miles of causeway have broken apart. The Caspian is rising, and water now laps the second stories of many buildings, even those that house oil workers. These eight-story apartment buildings are a remarkable sight: only the Soviet Union could build slum housing in the middle of the sea.
"We realized that we couldn't sustain this when the market economy came along," Musayev tells me, curling his lip when he says "market economy." We are eating lunch in the cafeteria, fresh greens, white cheese and boiled chicken, served by dour, henna-haired women. A photograph of Azerbaijan's president, Heydar Aliyev, watches us from the wall. It is impossible to avoid Aliyev's image -- or his influence -- anywhere in Azerbaijan.
"Capitalism is only interested in revenue, not in engineering," Musayev continues. And yet he wants to join the market economy he so distrusts. He has already applied for jobs with four Western oil companies. He earns $80 a month, and knows that even drivers for Amoco and Unocal make three or four times that amount.
The Americans are already aboard Oily Rocks, in a limited way. We drive past a yellow-painted facility that shines in the hammering sun. It is a gas-compression facility just built by Pennzoil. "No smoking around here," Musayev says, tossing his cigarette. "American rules."
American rules may soon apply to all of Oily Rocks. The complex, like everything in Azerbaijan, is for sale. The Government is looking for a partner, a Western oil company, that will modernize this mess. It will surely find one, because Baku is overflowing with oilmen. The city stands at the center of the first great oil rush of the 21st century, an oil rush of great consequence for Washington and Moscow, and for a dozen capitals in between.
Scholars who believe that history ended with the collapse of Communism should visit Baku, because in Baku, nothing is settled. Who could predict the future of a country that many in Moscow -- volatile, feverish Moscow -- believe shouldn't be a country at all, but instead a province of a reanimated Russian empire? In Teheran, Azerbaijan is seen as an unforgivable contradiction: a secular Shiite state, a country ripe for Islamization. In 10 years' time, Azerbaijan could be an Islamic state, or a neo-Communist state, or a capitalist democracy, or a capitalist autocracy, or even part of Russia.
Azerbaijan gained its freedom in 1991, but soon lost 15 percent of its territory to Armenia, which humiliated it in a vicious war. Azerbaijanis were killing each other too; the country seemed ungovernable, a failed-state-in-the-making of warlords and gangsters. But in 1993, Heydar Aliyev came back to Baku. He was the former Communist Party boss of Azerbaijan who had gone into self-imposed rural exile, but returned to Baku and exploited the chaos there. His bloodless coup brought a temporary stability.
He also brought with him an idea that insured his country's independence. There has always been oil in Azerbaijan. Centuries ago, the Zoroastrians built their fire temples in the hills of Baku, worshiping the flames that burst from the gas-filled earth. More than 100 years ago, the Nobel brothers and the Rothschilds built fortunes on Baku oil. Then the Soviets came, and closed off Azerbaijan's oil reserves to the West.
It took an ex-K.G.B. general and former Politburo member to open them up again. For Aliyev, oil wasn't only a commodity; it was freedom.
"Oil is our strategy, it is our defense, it is our independence," Aliyev's foreign-policy adviser, Vafa Gulizade, told me. "Iran is dreaming dreams of Azerbaijan, and if the Russians were strong, they would colonize Azerbaijan. But they can't because Aliyev invited the whole world in to watch."
By 1994, the world's major oil companies, with Aliyev's encouragement, were busy developing Azerbaijan's neglected oil wealth. Aliyev's theory was that flag follows trade, and the theory is proving correct: Aliyev has become Washington's man, and Azerbaijan's oil has become an issue of great strategic importance for the United States.
Azerbaijan sits atop as much as 20 billion barrels of oil, which makes its reserves smaller than Kuwait's but about the same size as Nigeria's, from which the United States imports nearly 5 percent of its oil. Azerbaijan may also become the conduit for even more oil and natural gas that will flow from Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan, on the east side of the Caspian. All told, the Caspian region could be the source of as much as 200 billion barrels of oil. For America, the stakes are enormous.
"The Caspian region will hopefully save us from total dependence
on Middle East oil," says Bill Richardson, the Secretary of Energy and the Administration's point man on the Caspian oil rush. For the oil com-
panies, the opening of the Caspian means access to tens of billions of dollars of oil. Already, Western companies have signed oil contracts totaling $40 billion in Azerbaijan; more than 1,000 American oilmen are making Baku their base, part of an expatriate community numbering at least 4,000. Profits at this early stage, though, are still theoretical, and some companies are having a lousy time of it; a consortium including Pennzoil, for instance, recently spent a great deal of money drilling in the Caspian and came up with no oil.
Aliyev has ladled out much of his oil already, entering his state company into 12 development projects with foreign oil companies, but there is still plenty of oil left to be found. In the race to capture it, the Americans hold the early lead, with the British close behind and the French, Germans, Norwegians, Japanese and Italians all trailing. Even the Russian oil company Lukoil has a presence. Baku is a United Nations of oil, and the jockeying for the most lucrative oil fields is intense. But no more intense than the jockeying between Russia and America, which find themselves in a subterranean and unacknowledged war for primacy in an especially dangerous corner of the earth.
"We have difficulty convincing the Russians that we're not trying to edge them out," Richardson says. "They see the area as their sovereign, virgin territory."
One reason the Americans might have difficulty convincing the Russians that they're not being edged out is because they are being edged out: President Aliyev has already cut favorable deals with American oil companies at the expense of Russian ones. Which is why the Russians don't like it when the Americans start talking about pipelines. The next best thing to controlling the source of the oil is controlling its flow. Some of Azerbaijan's oil already flows north to Russia through a small pipeline; another small pipeline is being built to Georgia. But an international consortium of oil companies is scheduled to recommend a route for a main export pipeline later this month that could eventually move one million barrels of oil daily. Russia wants the pipeline to run through its territory but the United States wants it to run west, through Georgia and into Turkey, a NATO ally. Iran, too, would like to have a pipeline, but that won't happen as long as the United States says it won't happen.
The competition for all this oil means that Baku is filled with intrigue and the fear of instability. Last month, Aliyev's police and opposition demonstrators fought street skirmishes in advance of the national election to be held next week. President Aliyev has been the object of three, or four, or five assassination attempts in the last several years (his intelligence chief counted six for me, though two sounded more like wishful thinking than executable plots), and his ally to the west, Georgia's Eduard Shevardnadze, is also a semiregular target of assassins. It is believed throughout the Caucasus that the assassins are dispatched by Russian nationalists who have not accepted the death of their empire. Russia's current meltdown has only heightened the fear in Baku and Tbilisi, Georgia's capital, that Russian hard-liners will be trying even more enthusiastically to pull Azerbaijan and Georgia back into Moscow's orbit.
Assassins are only occasional visitors to Baku, but the city is rampant with ham-handed Russian spies, as well as Turkish gangsters (known for their proud display of chest hair), black-eyed Chechen revolutionaries, paranoid American diplomats, fanatical Iranian terrorists and financial speculators of various nationalities, drawn to Baku because it is a frontier of global capitalism.
Before I left for Baku, I was inundated with propaganda from the oil companies and from Azerbaijan's lobbyists in Washington, assuring me that Azerbaijan is a lighthouse of stability, a pro-American redoubt and a place ready to do business in the community of Western nations. Most of all, they said, it is a place whose shining future, under the leadership of Heydar Aliyev, is assured.
Whether or not that's true, Baku is a fine place to watch the future of capitalism unfold. The Caspian oil rush is a reminder that not all commerce in the future will be carried out antiseptically over the Internet, that the ethereal talk of globalization means little to men who have to drill for oil and then physically move that oil across dangerous territory. Here, the old verities apply. At least in this corner of the globe, 21st-century capitalism looks very much like 19th-century capitalism. Baku is a city of the artfully delivered bribe and the brute shakedown, of florid corruption and baroque greed.
The helicopter manages to return us safely ashore, and a rickety van collects us for the return trip to town.
Baku today is a run-down city in need of a thorough dusting, but there are signs of new wealth: construction cranes fill the sky and satellite dishes sprout from apartment windows. Of course, the oil money is still just a trickle, and the people of Azerbaijan, two-thirds of whom live in poverty, are said to be unmoved by the Government's promises to lift living standards. Out in the countryside, far from the oil fields, almost a million refugees from the disastrous war with Armenia scratch by in abandoned rail cars and corrugated tin huts. But a paper-thin layer of Baku society is housing itself in limestone palaces built high above the sea.
I am let out at the Hyatt Regency, which is where the new rich come to play, and where the oilmen congregate. Downtown, by the sea, are the expatriate bars, filled with platform workers and marginal players. Poolside at the Hyatt, though, is where deals get done, and where, I was to learn, spies do their spying.
I return to my room to wash the sheen of oil off me, but I'm interrupted by a knock at the door. It is a man in uniform who announces, "The Minister of Defense would like to see you."
Things like this happen in Baku.
"When?" I ask.
"The car is waiting," he says.
We are driven to the defense headquarters, the onetime home of the Soviet Army's southern flank commander.
I am led up a marble staircase and into the Minister's suite. A relief map of the Caucasus, the Middle East and Central Asia stretches the entire length of the wall. The map is a graphic reminder of just how perilous his neighborhood is.
The Minister, Safar Abiyev, is in uniform and greets me coolly. "How did you enjoy Oily Rocks?" he asks, though I hadn't mentioned my visit to him.
He says he's heard I've been asking questions about Iranians and Armenians and he thinks there are some things I should know. This is hardly unusual -- every one in Baku seems to know what everyone else is asking about.
We talk for a moment at his desk, on which sit 12 telephones. Then he orders me to the map.
"Here," he says, using a pointer to locate the Armenian capital, Yerevan. "Here is the location of the Armenian nuclear power plant. They are shipping nuclear fuel from here" -- he traces a line across the map -- "to here." He points to Teheran. The Azerbaijanis believe the Armenians capable of nearly anything. They would blame
Armenia for the collapse of the Japanese economy if they thought the charge would stick. It is true that Armenia cooperates with Iran, but Abiyev would offer no particulars about nuclear cooperation, and American security officials couldn't shore up his accusation.
Standing at the map, I point Abiyev to another line, the one running from Baku to Tbilisi. It is the path where a small oil pipeline is under construction, the same path the main pipeline will most likely follow. The route runs close to Armenia, and to Azerbaijani territory occupied by the forces of Nagorno-Karabakh, the Armenian stronghold in the middle of Azerbaijan. There is much concern among oilmen that Azerbaijan won't be able to protect the pipelines from the Armenians, who so far have derived no benefit from the oil boom.
It is important, of course, that the Government of Azerbaijan -- and the Governments of Georgia and Turkey, too -- assure the oil companies that the pipeline will be secure. "I don't think they will be capable of cutting the pipeline off," Abiyev says, referring to the Armenians. "We could stop them." And with that, the Defense Minister signals that the command interview is over. He rises, presents me with his best wishes and a lovely decorative rug.
i T is not the rug I would have chosen. The rug I really admire is hanging in a saunalike waiting room in the old K.G.B. headquarters. President Aliyev's image is woven into its center, but the weaver fattened Aliyev's face and darkened his eyebrows, making him look like Brezhnev.
I have time to admire the subtlety of the weave because the Minister of National Security, Namik Abbasov, keeps me in his sweltering, moldy waiting room for a half hour. It seems almost too obvious, but I think he likes to make his visitors sweat before he sees them.
The door opens, and I am invited inside. Abbasov is built like a block of ice: he is a man of serious poundage, and his hair is cropped short. A former K.G.B. colonel, he now directs Azerbaijan's intelligence apparatus.
Abbasov's office is decorated simply, and there only eight telephones on his desk, which makes him, by one method of calculation, four telephones less important than the Minister of Defense.
Before the interview can begin, Abbasov is interrupted by a telephone call from the President, who wants to know why the American Embassy here just warned its citizens to beware of "anti-U.S. elements" in Azerbaijan. This warning is a matter of some importance to Azerbaijan, because much here depends on the Americans and their money; the hundreds of American oilmen in Baku must be kept safe and unworried.
After he hangs up, Abbasov says he has no idea why such a warning would be issued. He asks me if I feel safe in Baku. I answer yes -- after all, authoritarian rulers like Aliyev certainly do know how to keep the streets quiet -- and this gives Abbasov an idea. "Maybe you'll go on Azerbaijan television and say this," he says. I panic at the thought of flacking for Aliyev, but we are interrupted by the ringing of yet another of Abbasov's phones, and the subject is dropped. As it turns out, Abbasov consults with Azerbaijani TV daily, to help shape its coverage.
A democracy Azerbaijan is not, but it is, reliably, a friend of America's, and this is the point Abbasov makes at length. His country is crawling with spies who do not have America's interests -- or Azerbaijan's interests -- at heart. What worries Abbasov right now is cooperation between Moscow and Teheran. Last March, he says, an Iranian truck carrying steel for use in the construction of ballistic missiles was stopped at Astara, a town on the Azerbaijan-Iran border. Abbasov tells the story:
"We got information from Russian territory that there was a cargo of radioactive material moving to Astara. I am not prepared to tell you whom we got the information from. With this information we stopped the truck and confiscated the material. The Russian Government is denying the existence of the cargo, but I know that the cargo was loaded in and around Moscow. We called our American counterparts, and samples of the seized material are now in America. The driver was arrested, but he didn't know anything. Would you like the license-plate number of the truck?"
He tells me the license-plate number. I'm not sure what I'll do with it, but I write it down in a serious manner. "This is the first time we captured such material," Abbasov says. "There was a previous incident in '96. There was a boat on the Caspian. Radiation was detected, but we reacted late and couldn't intercept before the boat entered Iranian waters."
I ask him if he felt the Americans were grateful for the interception of the truck. "Yes, of course," he answers, "but we are doing this for ourselves. Their missiles couldn't reach America, but they could reach Azerbaijan."
There is another sort of spy, Abbasov tells me later, that he doesn't worry about as much. These spies also want a piece of Azerbaijan, but these are the pieces that Azerbaijan is eager to sell. These are the industrial spies, who work on their countries' business interests, trying to learn which oil company is up and which is down.
"Every intelligence organization is attempting to get the upper hand for their oil interests," he says. "It is a natural process. We wouldn't apprehend these officers because it is a natural thing they are doing."
Where are they doing this spying?
"In Baku."
At the Hyatt?
"We see a lot of suspicious people around the Hyatt," he says.
I invite him for a drink by the pool.
"Oh, I never go to the Hyatt," he says, smiling.
Twilight one weekday by the pool at the Hyatt, and the tables are filling up. I am sitting with one of the owners of the hotel, an Iranian exile named Parviz Amir-Parviz -- "everyone calls me Parv" -- who is educating me on the subject of corruption. He is a voluble entrepreneur, the biggest taxpayer in Azerbaijan and President Aliyev's tutor on the subject of capitalism. He is also known to pay out the occasional bribe.
"I don't pay bribes to ministers," he explains to me. "When I send my guys to the various ministries, I tell them, bribe the low-level guys. Bribe this guy 10 bucks, bribe that guy 20 bucks. But not the ministers. Bribes were the basis of the Soviet system. You can't change the place overnight."
Parviz is lucky in that he is publicly associated with the President. He is generally avoided by the shakedown men drawn to foreign businessmen like flies to fruit. "The President never told anyone, 'Protect this hotel, protect Parviz.' But remember, he comes here once, twice, four times a month for receptions and parties. The officials see that, and so they don't come here for the shakedown."
What about Aliyev? Is he a shakedown artist, too?
"No way," he says. "The old man's not dirty himself -- when you're the Shah, why do you need money?"
Parviz has faith that Aliyev is clean enough -- and tough enough -- to fix Azerbaijan's problems.
"Yeah, he's a dictator, but so what? It's like with Pinochet. He fixed the economy, made the streets safe, made sure everyone had bread to eat. Now they say that Pinochet was dirty, that children are missing. Well, sometimes children have to go missing when you're cleaning up a country."
We are seated under an umbrella facing the pool. It is dinnertime, and the secret business of Baku is being conducted before our eyes. "See those guys," Parviz says, pointing to a group of severe-looking men talking softly among themselves. "They're from the I.M.F. They just came back from the President, telling him to kick all the corrupt guys out, shrink the work force. But the President knows he can't do that. I've talked to the old man, and he says if he does that, he'll have anarchy. Imagine 10,000 cops out of work. These guys will go out and form political parties and create chaos."
One table over, the Israeli Ambassador entertains a group of businessmen, an armed security agent sitting nearby -- it drives Iran mad to see an Israeli ambassador in this Shiite country. At other tables ringing the pool sit the men from Amoco and the men from the French oil company, Total. Though as many as two-thirds of Azerbaijan's oil fields have already been divvied up, there are still fields to be bought, and oil-company geologists are searching land and sea for hidden deposits. This is what the spies are after -- who's drilling where, who's finding what and who's striking the best deals with Aliyev's Government.
It is an exciting night at the Hyatt, because the man who created the most successful consortium for Aliyev, a man jokingly known as Terry of the Caucasus, is back in town, and poolside. Terry Adams is a legendary figure, a Welsh giant -- he stands a head and a half taller than most Azerbaijanis -- who once worked for British Petroleum. In this place where connections are everything, Adams's name seems to open every door.
Rob Sobhani, an American oil consultant, has joined us at our table. He is an American of Iranian descent who has unparalleled access to Baku's ruling elite. He's eyeing the men from Total, the French company that does a great deal of business in Teheran. Washington, of course, says that oilmen who are eager to do business with Iran -- including Terry Adams and the men from Total -- are not acting in the West's best interests.
"Watch the guys from Total," he whispers. "There they go." The Total executives line up to greet Adams, practically kissing his ring. Adams, like most oilmen, believes that America's unilateral ban on trade with Iran is illogical. If it wasn't for that ban, the main export pipeline from Baku could be built at cheap cost through Iran and to the Persian Gulf. "On a map, Iran looks like one of the easier ways to get it out," Adams tells me later, a half-smile on his face.
Just then, a strange-looking character with a cell phone and a handlebar mustache walks by.
I ask who he is, and am told he is from the Minaret Group, an international finance company owned by a man named Viktor Kozeny, a Czech who is not particularly welcome in his own country. Kozeny buys up privatization vouchers, the shares in state-owned companies distributed to the citizens in post-Communist states. There is a good deal of suspicion about Minaret's activities -- Abbasov, the Azerbaijani intelligence chief, told me that he has "serious doubts about what Minaret is doing here -- they're a real threat."
Parviz tells me he has no problem with men like Kozeny. "Everybody's a speculator here," he says. "Anything that is speculative is scary. Nothing is institutionalized, nothing is regulated. That's just the sort of place it is. But there's a lot of money to be made here."
Unless you're not connected. There is a terrible price to pay if you have no connections. It is preferably paid with a large number of $100 bills, several businessmen whispered to me.
In my search for someone who could explain just how things work, one diplomat in the capital told me to ask a simple question: Why is there no mafia in Azerbaijan?
It's a good question. In many of the countries of the former Soviet Union -- Russia chief among them -- the mafia presence is obvious. In Tbilisi, I went one night to a mafia hangout, a jazz club in the basement of a refugee hotel that seemed a Georgian version of a Chicago speakeasy: mobsters in black, guns bulging at their waistbands, and women who could only be described as mafia molls, lipsticked and haughty.
But in Baku, I couldn't find the equivalent. There's the Mozaic disco, by the waterfront, where I watched a Turkish gangster talking on his cell phone while pressing his hips up against his standoffish Russian girlfriend, but the Mozaic hardly resembles a Gambino family nightclub.
So where's the mob?
For the answer, I turned to an expert, a leader of the Chechen mafia. Chechnya, the breakaway Russian republic, sits north of Azerbaijan. The slight and frightening man I had arranged to meet, Khozh-Ahmed Noukhaev, is typical of the sort of person who washes up in Baku, someone entranced by the transformative power of oil money. Over tea in the darkened bar of the Europe Hotel, he tells me about his own transformation. Ten years ago, he was a shakedown artist in Moscow; today he is president of something called the Caucasus Common Market, which he claims will build a trading league to concentrate the power of the Caucasus states and make them independent of Moscow. Oh, and make money, too.
His deputy, a Polish Catholic-turned-Sufi Muslim, says Noukhaev is keen to sell his services to the oil companies. He can protect their oil like no else, he says. Noukhaev's past suggests why.
"The Chechen mafia is different from any other mafia," Noukhaev tells me. It is late and the bartender would like to go home, but he does not care to disrupt Noukhaev, who has two bodyguards. Noukhaev is dressed in black and carries a gold-tipped cane; he was wounded during the Russian siege of Grozny, the Chechen capital.
"My business was to protect Chechen businessmen from Russian businessmen," he says. "At first, I had to suggest this protection with rough actions. I would put it to Russian businessmen to take Chechen partners. This would help Chechen businesses to grow, but it also helped the Russian businessmen, because now they had an extra partner."
I asked him if he killed people in the course of business. "I don't know of any cases in which I killed people," he replied. For many years in prison I had to defend myself, but killing isn't killing if you're protecting yourself."
It seemed like an obvious question, so I asked him: Why doesn't he offer his services to Western companies struggling against corruption in Baku?
It could be a growth industry, the protection of Western businessmen. Azerbaijan is the intersection where Soviet efficiency and Ottoman integrity meet, and doing business here can try the soul, the bank account and the patience of the Western ambassadors who regularly intercede on behalf of their countrymen's business interests.
Not all businessmen, of course, feel their pockets being picked. Aliyev protects the most important foreign investors -- the oil companies -- from the sort of petty corruption that infects most of Azerbaijani society: the traffic stop that turns into a demand for cash, the customs official who needs money for his sick mother, and by the way, you didn't need us to release your shipment this year, did you?
"The President personally hears the oil companies' complaints," Vafa Gulizade, Aliyev's foreign-policy adviser, told me. But even the oil companies find themselves handing out "scholarships" and "consultancies" at a generous clip. And the sons of the country's leaders often end up in the employ of American oil companies.
But this is nothing compared with what those outside the oil industry feel. Those who sell financial services or consumer products operate without direct Presidential protection, and suffer for it. In my search for a Westerner who could explain the way business is really done, I kept stumbling across the name Glogowski. But Glogowski -- Antos Glogowski, a British financier -- had made himself scarce from Baku. The climate wasn't right for him just then. Only later did I track him down -- in Palm Beach.
Glogowski is the president of AJG Investments, a firm that, like Minaret, buys privatization vouchers. He was doing a good job of it, too, until the day in May when agents of the Azerbaijan Interior Ministry raided his offices, seizing $30 million worth of vouchers and threatening his employees with arrest.
"I'm not sure why this happened," he told me. "We are operating legally in Azerbaijan, so this came as a surprise."
I had heard in Baku that for a price of $500,000, Interior Ministry agents were willing to return Glogowski's vouchers, but he wouldn't comment on that. "AJG has taken the decision to resolve this by legal means only," he said carefully.
After months of pleading with Aliyev's privatization czars, Glogowski got back his vouchers, but says he's still got problems in Baku. "What you're seeing played out in Azerbaijan is the new school versus the old school," he says. "The new school wants to make it a friendly environment for foreign investment. The old school has other priorities. We're caught in the crossfire."
For problems like Glogowski's, Noukhaev suggests to me before we finally leave the bar, the methods of the Chechen mafia are no solution.
"What is happening to them is a kind of crime that I cannot stop using our methods," he says. "When corruption comes from the state, I can't protect foreign businesses from that. Not when the state is the mafia."
This does not necessarily mean that Heydar Aliyev is the Caucasus version of John Gotti. He is much smarter, for one thing. Those interested in seeing Aliyev remain in power -- the American Government included -- do not see Aliyev as a thief. His ally in Tbilisi, Eduard Shevardnadze, calls Aliyev "one of the pioneers in the fight against corruption in the Soviet Union," which is the opposite of the truth, but Shevardnadze's life depends in part on Aliyev also staying alive and in power.
Before reimagining himself as an Azerbaijani nationalist, Aliyev was the leading Azerbaijani Communist and the fourth-ranking leader in the Soviet Union during the Brezhnev era. Aliyev was an elaborate flatterer, showering Brezhnev with gifts. Brezhnev's demise -- and Gorbachev's rise -- meant Aliyev's end too. Aliyev, like many regional Communist bosses, had a reputation for ostentatious corruption -- and Gorbachev's men, eager to rid themselves of leaders whom David Remnick, in his book "Lenin's Tomb," calls "mafia sultans," capitalized on this reputation to good effect. Aliyev was a broken man in the last days of the empire.
But then came the second act. Aliyev managed to pull himself out of the dustbin of history, brush himself off and assume the Presidency of an independent and chaotic Azerbaijan. He promised to end his country's war with Armenia and he did; he promised to restore law and order to Baku's deadly streets and he did. He was able to do this because ex-K.G.B. generals understand how to seize and maintain control. "He's a real cool cat," says an admiring Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former Carter Administration national security adviser who now advises Amoco on Caspian issues.
Next week, Aliyev is up for re-election -- which is an inexact term, since he didn't wait for the people's approval before assuming power in 1993. The following year, he "legitimized" his rule in an election that saw him win 99 percent of the vote.
"I'm always telling him not to campaign too hard, because if he gets more than 65 or 70 percent of the vote, the Americans might think it's suspicious," Gulizade, the foreign-policy adviser, tells me over dinner one night in a Turkish restaurant. The restaurant is part of an "entertainment center" built for the idle children of the new rich. It includes an indoor swimming pool and a computerized bowling alley. As we walk in, we pass a woman dressed in a manner that would get her stoned in Teheran. "Call girls and bowling," Gulizade says whimsically. "All under one roof."
In Soviet times, Gulizade was a senior diplomat; he made his mark running the air bridge that resupplied the Egyptians during the Yom Kippur War. That, of course, was then. Now: "I've always admired the Jews," he says. As Aliyev's foreign-policy adviser, he is charged with maintaining good relations with the West, including Israel. Six months ago, in fact, he had bypass surgery in Israel, and tonight we are celebrating the half-year mark with vodka and caviar. "Vodka is the one good thing the Russians gave us," he says. Gulizade is a raconteur, and he tells me about President Aliyev: "President Aliyev is very much like President Clinton. When President Aliyev was younger, he had the same problem Clinton had, with women. But Aliyev was a K.G.B. general, so he knew how to run a conspiracy to keep things silent."
Late in the evening, we leave the entertainment center. Gulizade is at the wheel, unsteadily. Baku is quiet. Since President Aliyev's morality campaign began in February, many of the city's nightspots have been shuttered. "These casinos and bars weren't in keeping with traditional Azerbaijan culture, so the President closed them," he says. "You know, though, you can still get anything in Baku. It's just underground."
Later, I asked a diplomat if the casinos were really shut down to protect Azerbaijani honor. Of course not, he said. The story going around Baku is that they were shut down to keep the President's relatives from losing money to the Turkish mafia, which had a piece of the casinos. But that story was wrong, the diplomat said. The real reason is this: "If you're planning to overthrow a government in this region, you've got to spread money around to the plotters. The secret police are everywhere, and this money would be noticed. But if these plotters just happen to win the money in the casino, well, then, that's luck. Shut the casinos, and you shut off the revolution."
It is impossible to know if this is true, because, like most everything in Baku, only one man knows why Heydar Aliyev does what he does, and that's Heydar Aliyev.
For the man who is the maestro of the Caspian oil rush, Aliyev has a suspiciously modest office. It sits high up in the building that houses the Presidential Apparat, overlooking Baku harbor. The carpets are curling, and it is as dimly lighted as an Intourist hotel.
As I wait for my interview with Aliyev, which will be videotaped by the presidential videographer for possible showing on the evening news -- which is essentially All Aliyev, All the Time -- I scan the shelves in his outer office for reading material. Most of the books celebrate the perspicacity of Heydar Aliyev. One is a hardcover published by the Government to commemorate Aliyev's visit to America last year. Like the other oil chieftains of the post-Soviet states that ring the Caspian, Aliyev was treated to the high honor of an official Washington visit. The book is 415 pages long and contained, when I stopped counting, 143 photographs of Aliyev. It also featured a photograph of a rug woven in the image of Chelsea Clinton which was presented to her father.
I am finally escorted into the meeting room, where I am shown the best place to stand in order to greet the President properly. It is quietly suggested that I flatter the President at the outset of the interview, as he is fond of sycophancy.
He comes in, hits his mark and shakes my hand while looking into the camera. We settle in around an oversize table. He is 75 years old, a natty dresser, perfectly shaven and expertly manicured. He wears the satisfied look of a man who has outlasted many enemies. But some of his enemies are persistent, and I ask him why so many people want him dead.
"The people who want to see my demise are those who want to come to power by force," he says. "Of course, in many cases, these attempts grow from other countries."
Aliyev catalogues for me his frequent close calls: "I escaped death several times. They've even tried to shoot down my airplane with a rocket. In August of '93, a young Turkish student was going to assassinate me with a sniper rifle. In March of '95, the special forces of the Interior Ministry tried to take power by force. They also planned to kill me. Later they tried to blow up the bridge on the way to the airport in order to kill me, but we stopped this."
He is imperturbable, and this extends to his behavior during the interview. It is quite obvious that his staff lives in fear of him; his translator quakes when relaying unflattering questions, though Aliyev has surely heard them before. Such as: How can an ex-K.G.B. general lead his country to Western-style democracy?
"It is true that I was a general of the K.G.B., and I am proud that, as an Azerbaijani, I gained the post of K.G.B. general," he tells me. "But a person always gets better."
How do you respond to the accusation that Azerbaijan is brimming over with corruption that might threaten the future of your country?
Smoothly, of course: "Corruption is very characteristic of the countries of the former Soviet Union," he says. "But you have corruption in your country. In America, though, you have kind of legalized it. Maybe when we reach the same level as the United States, then we can officially make corruption legal."
What sort of corruption do you see in America?
"I ask Congressmen why they have such close relations with Armenia, and they say that the Armenian Diaspora gives them a lot of money. Is that corruption or not?"
The Azerbaijanis are bitter about Armenian power in Washington, and it is true that the Armenian lobby has pulled off a neat trick: Armenia occupies Azerbaijani territory, and yet it is Azerbaijan that, by Congressional fiat, cannot receive direct American aid. Aliyev perorates on the subject for a while, until we are a safe distance from my original question. He is unwilling to discuss corruption this close to the election.
I ask Aliyev if I can tag along as he campaigns. He gives me a surprised look, as if to suggest that a sultan need not campaign. He tells me he does not get out much these days, but when he does, "thousands of people gather to applaud me."
The conversation turns to the subject of democracy, and, like all autocrats, he pleads for time. "No one was born a democrat in this country, including myself," he says. "This is not your country. Maybe if we establish conditions of democracy, my grandson will have democracy."
Anyway, it is stability, not democracy, that interests the oil companies. I ask Aliyev whether the Armenians or the Russians might sabotage his pipeline. "The pipeline is not just Azerbaijan's pipeline," he says, smiling at his cleverness. "It will be built by Western companies, and their Governments will have an interest in keeping the pipeline safe."
Aliyev gives the impression of calm, which has assured the West that Azerbaijan is in capable hands. But a 75-year-old man who is the frequent target of assassins and has no obvious successor may not be the surest bet. His country is surrounded by enemies, his army is weak and there is no ironclad guarantee that the oil beneath his sea will ever make it to the West. A drive to Tbilisi that tracks the "early oil" pipeline proves that.
The front-line commander, an acne-scarred lieutenant, is wearing flip-flops where his boots should be. I've driven with my translator to a tiny village on the border with Armenia, 200 miles west of Baku, and this unimpressive officer has put an end to our trip. Drive 20 yards farther, he says, and you'll be shot -- by them, not us.
For several hours, we have been following the western pipeline route. The early-oil pipeline, now under construction, will run near here, just skirting Armenia as it makes its way out of Azerbaijan and into Georgia. Armenian extremists have made noises about interrupting the flow of oil out of Azerbaijan, and since the Armenians have a far more effective army than the Azerbaijanis, these threats are not taken as idle.
I ask the lieutenant where the Armenians are, and he points to an electrical tower about 100 yards away. "There," he says. "And there," pointing to a hill behind a half-destroyed house. I ask if we could walk up to the barbed-wire emplacement that marks the end of the road. "If they see you," he says, "they'll definitely shoot."
The forces of Armenia and Azerbaijan, technically in the fifth year of a cease-fire, manage to shoot across the line virtually every day. But it is very quiet on this road when we arrive. There are a few civilians about, and the braying of a donkey is the loudest noise we hear.
I ask the lieutenant if he believes the Armenians are capable of seizing the land through which the early-oil pipeline will run. He looks confused. "I don't know about a pipeline."
The pipeline, the one they're building a few kilometers from here.
"I don't know anything about it," he says. "How will this affect our conflict with the Armenians?"
The lieutenant watches me write down his answers in my notebook. "You write with your left hand," he says. "I've never seen that." Neither have any of his men.
Just then, shots are fired over the hill. We hustle behind a concrete wall. I ask the lieutenant if he's going to order his men to shoot back.
"No. If we do that, the Armenians will shoot until tomorrow morning," he says, defeated.
It is not a very heartening performance, particularly if you're an oilman whose career depends not only on finding crude beneath the Caspian Sea but also on moving it safely and cheaply across hundreds of miles of unstable territory. Even in an era of high-tech capitalism, there aren't many shortcuts in the oil business. But here, in a place America hopes will help solve its Persian Gulf problem, the fragility of the oil business is particularly apparent. Success depends on the cooperation, or at least the acquiescence, of Russians and Chechens, Iranians and Armenians, and the fortunes of an aging autocrat and a dispirited lieutenant who has no idea how important oil is to his country.
As we drive out of range of Armenian snipers, we pass a bus shelter that has painted on it a portrait of Heydar Aliyev. The slogan underneath reads, "Together to the Future," and I think that the future is not nearly as hopeful as Heydar Aliyev believes it will be, and not nearly as secure as the oil companies -- and Washington -- need it to be.

PUB-DATE: October 4, 1998

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 3; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1417 words

HEADLINE: Q&A/Dr. Zelle Andrews;
A Champion of Rights on Three Fronts

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
FEMINIST, gay rights advocate, elderly American -- are just three of many epitaphs that Dr. Zelle Andrews carries, just three of the groups on whose behalf she fights. Dr. Andrews, a resident of New Rochelle, former president of the New York State Chapter of the National Organization for Women, was recently named Woman of the Year by the Women's Equality Day Committee, a coalition of various county organizations that works on behalf of women.
Dr. Andrews, who has her doctorate in history, is the County Executive's liaison to the gay and lesbian community. 
 When Dr. Andrews travels to meetings around the United States, many of those she encounters find it incredible that it is a job, originally part time, that was created by a Republican-Conservative, former County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, in 1994. It is now a full-time job in the administration of the current County Executive, Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Dr. Andrews:
Q. Is Westchester a tolerant place, relatively speaking, for gays and lesbians?
A. Clearly. We are so fortunate here, it's unbelievable. I go to national conferences and people ask what I do and I tell them and they're shocked; you are paid to do this? I think that Andy O'Rourke did a very courageous thing. He does, after all, have a very conservative constituency whose interests he needed to pay attention to. I also think in other parts of the country, particularly in the South and Southwest, he might not have been able to get away with it. Long before he did this he had taken an active role in AIDS issues. He has come around to being pro-choice, though it took him some time.
Having said all that, it's really a mixed bag for gays here in Westchester. We don't have a sexual orientation nondiscrimination bill. We don't have domestic partner health benefits, although provision for this is in a proposed contract with the county government's largest employees unions. These are things that really make a difference. Other counties have a sexual orientation nondiscrimination law.
Q. What are the duties of your office?
A. I have a responsibility to bring to the lesbian and gay community information about the services that are available through the county and ways in which they, as taxpaying citizens, can take advantage of them. I also have a responsibility to bring to county agencies the needs of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community to make sure that in the delivery of those services they are included.
Let me give you some idea of what we're dealing with. We have a population of almost 900,000 people in Westchester. Approximately 650,000 of those are older than 18. We really don't know how many gay people are out there, because you can't find these folks unless they're ready to tell. But let's use Dr. Kinsey's estimate of 10 percent -- some people believe this is an underestimate, some an overestimate -- that would mean there would be more than 60,000 gay and lesbian people in the county older than 18. And of those 650,000 who are older than 18, 170,000 are older than 65. This is a group of people I'm particularly interested in since I'm over 65. That means there are 17,000 gays and lesbians who are over 65. So you have a tremendous group of people who have reason to need county services, particularly from the County Office for the Aging, the Departments of Social Services and Health and others. All the hospitals need to know that they have gay and lesbian clients, and businesses need to know. We have a major center of international corporations here and national corporations, some of whom have active gay and lesbian caucuses. Many of them do not.
Q. You are a feminist; you are gay. Sometimes the women's movement has had trouble with the two causes being linked. What is you reaction?
A. That's not my primary concern. My major concern is that many women, mature and young, do not get feminism. There is such a horrendous backlash. There are still people my age and younger who say, I'm not a feminist, but. . . . And then they'll spiel off all the things that they do believe in which are precisely what feminism has been advocating since Day 1. There is a real lack of understanding about what feminism is and what it is not. It's going to take us a long time. Feminism is a very profound set of revolutionary notions that completely disrupts every established relationship from the economic to the political to the personal to the global.
The issue of feminism and gay rights got settled a long time ago as far as I'm concerned way back in the late 1960's -- for about five or six years, maybe longer -- when Betty Friedan and others were talking with NOW about the "lavender menace," and the Manhattan chapter made life very uncomfortable for certain openly gay feminists. Those women castigated NOW for being homophobic and unwelcoming of lesbians, and in those early days there was a lot of discomfort. I wasn't aware at the time I was gay, but we were booing Betty off the platform. And NOW has been at the forefront for decades about the connection between the control of women and using lesbianism to control us. If you deviate in any way from a very prescribed, very traditional feminine role, then you must be a lesbian. So we began to work out an understanding of how that kind of stereotyping was damaging all women. From that came an acceptance from the active feminist community.
Q. What made you a feminist?
A. No. 1 was a very strong mother, who was born before her time. She was right in between the end of the first wave of feminism and the second wave and valiantly carried on in her own life as best she could her own ideals of the importance of all kinds of social-justice issues. My father was also involved in political issues. He was the head of what was a hospital for the chronically ill, aged and infirm in the days when disability issues were totally hidden in the 1930's and 1940's. My mother was also an early conservationist. They were both very committed to their Christian faith as well, and as far as they were concerned this was part and parcel of the social justice message that they got through Christianity.
But that's not what turned me on to feminism. It just set me up to be receptive. What really turned me on was that when I got married I happened to marry my boss at Harvard Business School and was told by the dean in advance that this wasn't going to be a problem, that we had different kinds of jobs. But when we came home from our wedding trip, there was a letter it the mail saying, Sorry, she's out of here. I felt like we had been betrayed. I had no way of figuring out what to do with myself. It was horrible; it was absolutely horrible. I had lost my job because I was a woman and had gotten married.
Q. How long were you married?
A. I'm still married, and it's perfectly all right for you to say that. I left the relationship in 1977. But my husband and I have been on good terms: we're kind of like brother and sister. And he has always been very supportive of my efforts and activities.
Q. Was coming out hard?
A. Oh, terrible. It was prolonged; it was painful. We're talking somewhere in my mid-30's, which was fairly late.
It was a result of my exposure to this issue through my active work in NOW. I went from co-founding the Honolulu chapter back in 1968, to being on the Hawaii State Commission on the Status of Women. And then when I moved back to the mainland I got involved in the Southern Westchester Chapter and moved up through the ranks, became president of the Westchester chapter, then president of the state organization and then on the national board.
I was totally immersed.
Q. You did not realize you were gay?
A. I had no idea. And then little by little, little by little, I began to connect the dots about myself. I began to see the pattern and say, this was me. Coming out was very episodic. It took me about 10 years to be able to be out in certain venues. Fortunately, in that regard, my parents were dead, so I didn't have the excruciating issue of telling my parents. My parents would have been horrified. First, I began telling some people in private. I would say it wasn't until I became co-chairman of the Loft around 1992 that I was willing to go public as a gay person. And nowadays, the minute I say what I do I out myself. Sometimes I sort of gauge the situation. If I'm not sure, I just say I work for the County Executive.

HEADLINE: A New Battle Plan to Fight Pollution

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WHO is at fault? It is a question often asked after an environmental spill or another type of accident. Should a faceless corporation be required to pay a fine that it can easily afford and then pass along the cost to its customers? Or should the blame be placed elsewhere -- say on a company vice president who turned a blind eye to violations or an employee who threw the wrong switch?
This summer, after 122 million gallons of unchlorinated sewage rushed into the Hudson River from the Yonkers Joint Treatment Works, fouling sections of the giant waterway and causing two beaches to close, the superintendent of the plant was charged by the District Attorney's Office with a criminal offense -- a knowing violation of a state pollutant discharge elimination system permit, which is a felony. 
 The superintendent, Kenneth Grauer, a 25-year employee of the county, faces up to four years in jail, if convicted. But his lawyer claims that his client has become the scapegoat of a system that must place the blame somewhere.
The arrest of Mr. Grauer, 49, in August by District Attorney Jeanine Pirro's Environmental Crimes Bureau marks a new trend in recent years: holding people criminally responsible for environmental violations. The complaint contends that even though Mr. Grauer was alerted to the failure of the plant's chlorination system on July 13, he did not take steps to limit the discharge until the next day. For now, he is suspended without pay until the charges are resolved.
His case is not unusual. Throughout the United States, not only are corporations paying heavy fines but company executives and employees who are found responsible for crimes against the environment are also facing time behind bars.
"Companies are just low-hanging fruit," said Earl E. Devaney, director of criminal enforcement in the forensics and training division of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. "It's time to pierce the corporate veil and go for the individual."
Mr. Devaney said that large companies can often absorb even heavy penalties but that when corporate executives, plant supervisors and other employees are arrested, the charges serve as a greater deterrent to future crimes. "It's one thing to have fines levied on your company," he said. "It's considered to be the cost of doing business, but it's another thing to have to tell your pals at the country club that you're going to the slammer for 15 years."
Take, for example, the case of George E. Betts, president of Lam Pine, a company in LaGrande, Ore., who was sentenced on May 18 in Federal District Court in Boise, Idaho, to pay $163,177 to the protection agency's superfund. The court also sentenced Mr. Betts to six months in prison. He was convicted of being involved in the illegal transportation of more than 230 55-gallon drums of paint and solvent wastes to another plant he owned in Payette, Idaho.
"I rejected the notion that these were just good people doing bad things," said Mr. Devaney, a former special agent in charge of fraud for the Secret Service. "They had the same motivations as other white-collar criminals -- lying, stealing and cheating. They knew the violations were crimes, and they went and did it anyway." Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the director of the Environmental Litigation Clinic at Pace University in White Plains, said Congress "has passed all these wonderful environmental laws since 1970" but the public will not benefit unless the Government continues to take a hard line with polluters. The Clean Water Act was adopted 26 years ago.
On May 21, 1997, in Federal District Court in Anchorage, Edward Hanousek, a supervisor for the White Pass & Yukon Railroad, was sentenced to serve six months in prison and six months in a halfway house and also to pay a $5,000 fine for his Clean Water Act conviction for the negligent discharge of oil from a company pipeline in Skagway, Alaska, in October 1994. He has since appealed the verdict. The discharge was the result of an accident that occurred during the illegal removal of rock from United States Forest Service land. The case was investigated by the protection agency's criminal investigation division.
In Westchester, the County Attorney, Alan D. Scheinkman, said he approved of such enforcement actions, saying that they "put employees on notice that they will be held responsible for their actions."
In the Westchester case, Mr. Grauer was one of three employees suspended in connection with the incident, which occurred on July 13 and 14. No charges have been filed against the other two employees. The County Executive's office has conducted an investigation into the actions of Mr. Grauer, who reportedly did not alert senior officials or use backup procedures to treat the water. For four hours, waste water that had not been disinfected flowed into the Hudson at the rate of nearly four million gallons an hour. The release of the waste water prompted county health officials to order the beach at Croton Point Park and another in Sleepy Hollow -- Philipse Manor Beach -- closed for two days.
Commissioner Howard N. Adel of the County Health Department, said he was heartened that the county was taking action against polluters. "It's very reassuring that our department's concerns are reflected in the county's policies," Dr. Adel said.
The chlorine-pumping system at the Yonkers plant broke down twice in two days, but even the second time, County Executive Andrew J. Spano said, no one notified top officials. "We have strict procedures in place for this," he said at the time. "It just baffles me why they didn't tell anybody."
Mr. Grauer's lawyer, David M. Rosoff, said last week that the county was brandishing its get-tough policy at his client's expense. "They're attempting to make an example of Mr. Grauer," the lawyer said. "Whatever environmental problems occurred, they weren't a result of criminal negligence on his part."
Mr. Rosoff described the District Attorney and the County Executive as overzealous. But Mr. Spano said his office and the District Attorney were not targeting workers in general but rather "an individual who did not carry out his responsibility and consequently jeopardized the people of Westchester."
Mrs. Pirro said the charges against Mr. Grauer did not represent a new policy but rather a continuation of a course set in motion in 1994, when her office established its Environmental Crimes Bureau. "From the onset," she said, "this office has held both individuals and corporations criminally liable for pollution."
For example, in 1996, Mrs. Pirro charged seven owners of dry cleaning establishments with criminal offenses in a 32-count indictment brought before Justice Kenneth H. Lange of State Supreme Court in White Plains. The top charge, first-degree, unlawful dealing in hazardous waste, carried a maximum penalty of four years in prison and a fine of $100,000. All of the defendants were found guilty of paying undercover agents (officials from the State Department of Environmental Conservation who were posing as illegal hazardous waste haulers) to transport their illegal waste. They were fined, sentenced to probation and required to perform community service.
The State Department of Environmental Conservation does not handle criminal offenses, referring cases like the Westchester dry cleaners to a district attorney, Gary F. Sheffer, a spokesman for the department, said.
That is why in the case of the July spill at the Yonkers sewage treatment plant, the state fined the county only for administrative violations of permits, and Mrs. Pirro proceeded with the criminal charges against Mr. Grauer. Answering the state charges, the county agreed in August to pay the Department of Environmental Conservation $600,000 in penalties for violations in Yonkers and other plants, Frank V. Bifera, general counsel for the department, said.
Mr. Bifera said that even though his department does not prosecute offenders, it nevertheless tries to hold individuals responsible when appropriate. In the case of two oil firms in the last year, the state successfully filed administrative, but not criminal, charges against the individual owners and levied heavy fines.
"Sometimes it's a matter of an individual trying to get ahead in a company," Mr. Bifera said. "Sometimes he or she is trying to cover up incompetence or just acting recklessly."
Judson W. Starr, a former chief of the Federal Justice Department's environmental crimes section and now a lawyer with Venable, a law firm in Washington, said the latest policies "imposed great powers" on some corporate executives like senior vice presidents in charge of the safety and health of the environment. "They were little heard from before," he said. "Now companies are becoming more sensitive to the fact that there are extreme risks in violating environmental laws."
But John Cronin, the Hudson Riverkeeper, said that while governments talked a good game about getting tough with environmental polluters, officials were often inconsistent. "Too often, politics gets in the way," he said. "When the economy is bad, they don't want to do anything to interfere and make it get worse. When times are good, they don't want to rock the boat.
"I'm glad to hear they're talking about taking a stronger stance, but I'm skeptical."

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
Could Glen Cove Be Replacing Nashville?

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER 

 BODY:
IN the recording world, there's New York, Los Angeles and Nashville. And then there's Glen Cove. "It's the best kept secret in the world "' said Richie Cannata, co-owner of the Cove City Sound Studio, one of a trio of recording studios that works with major artists in the North Shore town.
"It's not a secret in the industry," he said. "Do we care about having kids outside the door looking for Celine Dion? We don't want that." Perhaps because, on this particular day, she isn't there. But her voice is. Cove City is tracking and mixing an album of Ms. Dion singing Christmas songs and making a soundtrack of featured songs from the television series "Touched by an Angel." 
 To record the vocals, the studio sent a producer and engineer to the chanteuse in Miami. Mr. Cannata, who grew up in Garden City South and lives in Glen Cove, now plays for the Beach Boys. The musician played saxophone and keyboards for Billy Joel for eight years, then worked with Elton John, Roseanne Cash and Rita Coolidge. He was performing with Styx 13 years ago when he purchased the building that became his Glen Cove headquarters. Intent on bringing the humanities into town, he created Long Island's largest recording studio.
His partner, Ric Wake, is Ms. Dion's producer. Hence, a room full of platinum and gold albums. And lots of musical notes. Three years ago, Mr. Cannata recalled, Billy Joel worked on "River of Dreams" at the studio. Other Long Island-bred artists, like Taylor Dayne, LL Cool J and Mariah Carey, have recorded there. Ms. Dion made two previous albums at the studio. Howard Stern used the facility to record the soundtrack for "Private Parts," the movie.
Diana Ross came by last year. John Sekada was in recently doing a mix. Natalie Cole, Whitney Houston, Donny Osmond, Barry Manilow, Darryl Hall and Phoebe Snow all sang incognito at the studio, which is tucked behind the Metropolitan catering hall.
Last month, the studio completed two tracks with a 1998 Grammy winner, Tricia Yearwood.
They are mixing a track for Mya, the rhythm and blues artist. And making a CD for a 15-year-old in the neighborhood who plays the flute. In a converted turn-of-the-century soda bottling plant around the corner, Sissel, a Norwegian vocalist who recorded the motion picture Titanic soundtrack with Ms. Dion, is recording her first American album.
"We call it studio row," said Perry Margouleff, 38, sometime songwriter and owner of Pie Studios, a five-year-old vintage analog recording hall. Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones recorded part of the group's "Bridges to Babylon" album there last November, Mr. Margouleff said, then took a speedboat home to Westport, Conn., at 2 A.M. Joan Osborne, Cyndi Lauper, the Hooters, Cheap Trick and Jackson Browne were happy with limousines.
"There's Motown, the Detroit sound," said Fred Guarino, engineer and owner of Tiki Recording Studio, the first of the studios. Tiki moved from Mr. Guarino's garage to an abandoned local tavern in 1983.
"It's kind of funny to say the Glen Cove sound," he said. "Something sort of developed here accidentally. There was no cultural development or formalized method. It's a cottage industry, but real work has come from this area. It's not just home studios."
Mr. Guarino's digital sound machine combines corporate and rock recording and attracts more local bands than the two other studios. But Peter Allen, Debbie Gibson, Brian Setzer, Kenny Rogers and Al Jarreau have also used his recording rooms.
Initially, Mr. Margouleff said, stars balk at coming to Glen Cove. When they realize they can go across the street for ice cream without being bothered by fans, they like it.
"The city's too expensive and too dirty," Mr. Margouleff said. "Traditionally, the areas where you can have a commercial space suitable for making noise and having a recording studio are not the more pleasant areas in New York. People come here, they make barbecues and hang out outdoors. They can leave the front door open. Artists can come and really do their thing and not feel that someone else is eavesdropping or nosing in on what they are doing."
The goal, Mr. Margouleff said, is discovering the next hot star.
"That's the pot at the end of the rainbow," he said. "Most of the time when I'm scouting and looking for talent, I'm doing it in the city."
 
Indian Rhythms
Using the studio at Cove City recently were the legendary Thunder Bird Sisters from the Shinnecock Reservation near Southampton.
"We perform several times a year," said the Rev. Dr. Holly Haile Davis, 38, the group's lead guitarist.
She was crocheting as she listened to a playback of "In the Spirit of Crazy Horse." "We've been singing since 1973," she said. "It was about time for us to make a CD." And, along with a blue blanket, a music video. Organizing the group, which has performed nationally and internationally, was Eddie Brigati, co-producer of the CD and lead singer from the Rascals, known for such 60's hits as "Beautiful Morning," Groovin'," "People Gotta Be Free" and "Good Lovin'."
Music, explained Mr. Brigati, was a way for the group of Indian performers to tell the Shinnecock story and vent their community concerns.
"That's how it worked for the Rascals," he recalled. "A lot of it was inspired by the hostile environment of the time -- the Vietnam war, riots in the streets, the beginning of the atomic age. The power of music supercedes any obstacle. A guy like me could say something and it could be taken around the world."
The singing sisters -- and brother, mother and cousins -- came to Glen Cove, Mr. Brigati said, because there are no recording studios on the East End.
"All the celebrities just come out there to rest," he said. Instead, they want the celebrities -- who have built homes all around their territory -- to listen to their CD, which will be released this month.
"We haven't gotten past the house that went up in 1640," said Dr. Davis. "Three hundred and fifty years later you have an Indian community that is also entirely outside the loop of Hamptons society.
"The fact that the American Indian people still live today is a miracle in itself," she said. "Physical genocide, cultural genocide, spiritual genocide -- we are victims of many levels of violence including economic violence. The fact that we are alive in 1998 is not because our neighbors want us to be. It's a test of our endurance."
Inside the studio, Elizabeth Haile, daughter of Chief Thunderbird, matriarch of the clan and teacher at the Hayground School in Bridgehampton, was working on the video.
"Music is medicine," said Ms. Haile. "You get to express yourself, happy or sad, you get to wrap the issues that are important to you in music."
In between takes, the group, whose message to their children and grandchildren is to preserve their heritage and live in harmony with their neighbors, snacked on bagels and cream cheese.
 
Science Loses to Art
Hawking his handblown glass pieces in the second-floor gift shop at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn recently was Rodman Gilder Miller. A cell biologist specialized in neuroanatomy, Dr. Miller gave up science for art six years ago. Not surprising, considering his family tree. Dr. Miller's great-grandfather was Louis Comfort Tiffany.
"My interest in glass was tempered," said Dr. Miller, who flew in from Seattle for the opening of the "Louis Comfort Tiffany and Stanford White and Their Circle" exhibition at the museum, toting a suitcase filled with his own creations.
"My great-grandfather was the master of glass," he said. The one-of-a-kind sapphire and amethyst-shaded vases and wall pockets "remind one of a human body," Dr. Miller said, "but it's not too much in your face."
Pointing out a $160 white vase that looked like ladies' lingerie, Dr. Miller noted that although he was born 10 years after Tiffany died, his artwork -- and use of sensuous, even voluptuous organic forms -- is strikingly similar to that of his ancestor, one of the most influential arbiters of style of the Gilded Age.
"It's in my blood," he said. "I was exposed to it since I was knee high to a grasshopper. I'm sure it's had some effect. Nature, nurture. One way or another, it's in there."

HEADLINE: Global Warming Study of East End Sparks Debate on Sea Rise

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
THOSE living on the coast are in trouble," George Abar said after watching Southampton Beach being washed away in a hurricane.
It was only a computer-generated video, prepared by Mr. Abar's organization, the National Environmental Trust in Washington, to illustrate what could happen if global warming causes a three-foot rise in sea levels. When combined with a 10-foot storm surge from a Category Two hurricane, like the one that struck the Gulf Coast last week and others that have hit Long Island several times in this century, Southampton Beach would be all but destroyed. 
 Mr. Abar said his organization prepared the video to "try to take abstract notions and make them compelling. As they say, a picture is worth a thousand words."
According to a scenario accepted by many (but by no means all) scientists, a three-foot sea-level rise would not occur for at least a century. But the National Environmental Trust, a Washington-based private group, argues that to avoid future catastrophe, action must be taken now to reduce emissions of so-called greenhouse gases, produced mostly by burning fossil fuels. Many climatologists fear that these gases will raise global temperatures, causing a partial melting of the polar icecaps and raising sea levels worldwide.
"Some sea-level rise is inevitable because of pollution now in our atmosphere," Mr. Abar said. "The question is, are we going to respond to these changes?"
Mr. Abar said he would like to see the United States adopt the agreement reached last year by 160 nations in Kyoto, Japan, in which the major industrialized nations are required by the years 2008 to 2012 to cut greenhouse gas emissions by an average of 5.2 percent below 1990 levels. Adoption of the treaty by the United States is stalled in Congress by critics who argue that the cost of compliance outweighs the uncertain benefits.
Mr. Abar said Southampton was chosen for this study because of its high profile and concentration of expensive beachfront real estate. But the 29-page report accompanying the video made clear that the impact of rising sea levels would be felt Island-wide.
In 100 years, it said, the South Fork could be split into at least three sections; Jones Beach, Fire Island, the Hamptons beaches and Pikes Beach could all be under water; the coastlines in Bayville, Asharoken, Huntington Bay and the Great South Bay could be littered with the ruins of docks, seawalls and homes, and countless inland backyards in places like Middle Island and Yaphank could be at greater risk of flooding because of a rising water table.
"Global warming," the report said, "threatens to spell the end of much of what we know Long Island has to offer, washing it away by rising seas and destroying for the future the Island's historic past."
The video was created using an overlay of detailed pictures from the National Aerial Photography Program and elevation data from the United States Geological Survey. Using the elevation data of Southampton Beach, the computer digitally replaced land with water.
Other factors, including changes in patterns of tidal scouring and other forms of erosion, were not taken into account, and Mr. Abar warned that the computer-generated images should not be used to predict the fate of any single piece of property. As presented by the report, however, the overall trend seemed ominous.
Others were skeptical of the report. Candace Crandall, a policy research associate with the Science and Environmental Policy Project of Fairfax, Va., assailed the study, describing the National Environmental Trust as "a propaganda mill, not a research organization."
"They are out to promote global warming as a scare across the country," she said. "That's what they are doing, so I take all of what they are saying with a grain of salt."
Ms. Crandall said that the estimate of a three-foot rise in sea level is based on the worst-case scenario presented in a 1996 report by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. This was the panel's third report on the issue in this decade, she said, and each one forecast a smaller rise in temperature and sea level.
"The problem is shrinking into nothing," she said. "I'm seeing more and more scientists who are acknowledging that there is considerable dispute" about the impact of global warming.
Her group's research, Ms. Crandall said, appears to indicate that global warming is occurring, but that it will increase evaporation, which will fall as snow and ice on polar areas and thereby lower the sea level. "There seems to be an indication that the evaporation-precipitation factor may be the greater effect," she said.
But Vivien M. Gornitz, a climate expert who joined Mr. Abar at a briefing on the study, said there is no doubt that global warming will push the sea level higher by a "couple of inches in 30 years. In the worst-case scenario, it would increase by eight inches. Major floods that used to occur every 100 years could occur once every 30 years."
Dr. Gornitz asserted that what is needed is better coordination between agencies in developing coastal policy.
"What is going on on Long Island is absolute chaos in terms of coastal management," said Dr. Gornitz, a scientist at Columbia University's Center for Climate Systems Research and NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies. "There is no management whatsoever. Whoever has the most political and economic clout gets his way."
Such conflict was evident early this year when neighbors objected to the erection of a 175-foot steel bulkhead in front of the home of Ronald and Isobel Konecky in Bridgehampton. Southampton Town called the work illegal. When the town later held a public hearing on a proposed six-month moratorium against the erection of bulkheads, more than 100 people showed up to protest.
The Konecky case flared just a week after a reported $1 million erosion-control project failed to protect the oceanfront home of their neighbor, William Rudin. The project had consisted of oversized sandbags that were placed in a semicircle in front of the Rudin house.
One of the consultants on the project blamed vandalism -- a knife slash in one of the sandbags -- for leaving the system vulnerable to an Atlantic storm the night of Jan. 28.
But Robert S. DeLuca, president of the Group for the South Fork, scoffed at that assertion, saying: "If you can bring down a million-dollar structure with a pocket knife, you probably shouldn't have built it in the first place."
Mr. DeLuca, who also attended the National Environmental Trust's briefing last week, said there are $10 billion worth of second home investments on the East End. But even those who do not own beachfront property use the beach, he said, and "if the beach disappears from erosion, it will be a less attractive area to live."
The National Environmental Trust study said the "state's coastal economy is its lifeblood. Anti-environmental rhetoric is filled with assertions about how much it will cost to stop global warming. This report speculates on what it will cost to lose our natural resources."
The report said that in 1996, tourism on the Island, much of it shore-related, employed about 152,000 people, 14 percent of the Island's jobs. Chief among the lures of Southampton, it said, is the town's sandy, white beach, more than 20 miles long.
"Unfortunately," it said, "that beach is eroding at an average of 1.7 feet per year and is facing extinction from the very forces that created it, plus something else: the melting of polar glaciers and the hydrologic thermal expansion brought on by global warming."
Southampton Town and Southampton Village are now both developing coastal studies, and Mr. DeLuca said he will press to have global warming included as a factor in long-term planning on the South Fork.
Mr. DeLuca said his organization advocates the development of a post-storm recovery plan to determine how and what should be built along the beachfront. And he said there should be a buyout program for those who have lost 80 percent of their homes to soil erosion and the sea.
Mr. Abar offered one lesson to shorefront homebuyers: "Don't take a 30-year mortgage on a home that may be gone in 30 years."
