HEADLINE: County Won't Take Part in a Sales Tax Waiver

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
CONVINCED that property taxes would have to be increased substantially if it did otherwise, Westchester County has decided not to take part in a state plan to waive all sales tax on some apparel for a fourth trial week in January.
The vote of the Board of Legislators suggests a high probability that the county will not permanently exempt certain clothing and footwear from the county's portion of the sales tax. The county portion ranges from 1.5 percent to 2.5 percent, depending on whether local jurisdictions impose their own sales tax. Some of the county's sales tax revenues are redistributed to towns, villages and school districts, so the county government's action affects those entities, too. 
 "It is very obvious to us that opting in would cause us to increase the property tax in all municipalities in Westchester County," County Executive Andrew J. Spano said. "It would severely hurt our cities at a time we are trying to keep our taxes low for the people of Westchester County. It doesn't make sense."
The cities of Mount Vernon, Yonkers and New Rochelle each collect their own sales tax of 2.5 percent and the city of White Plains a 2 percent tax. These municipalities have also decided not to take part in the tax-free clothing week, from Jan. 17 through 24.
This means that during that week, the only reduction in sales tax that shoppers in Westchester will have is the elimination of the state's 4 percent sales tax and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's 0.25 percent sales tax on clothing and footwear purchases of less than $500. The permanent exemption on the state and M.T.A. sales tax will apply on purchases of less than $110 beginning Dec. 1, 1999.
The county government and the cities have until late next year to make a definitive decision on whether to take part in the permanent exemption.
If Mr. Spano has his way, the answer will be no -- unless the state government agrees to reimburse the county for the lost revenue, projected to be $14.2 million to $18.7 million in its first full year, 2000, just on the county level. Under these projections -- made in a report prepared by the Westchester County Association, an influential business organization -- White Plains, Yonkers, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon would collectively lose a projected $10.2 million to $13.4 million in sales tax revenues, and Peekskill, Rye City, all towns, villages and school districts would lose $2.7 million to $3.6 million.
Likewise, the answer will be no from the four cities if their top officials, two Republicans, two Democrats, have their way. The mayors of these cities and other local government officials from around the county joined Mr. Spano at a news conference recently in which they, too, said that sales tax relief could only lead to higher property taxes.
"We live our life around this sales tax, and without it it would be disastrous to the city of White Plains and the county of Westchester," Mayor Joseph M. Delfino of White Plains, a Republican, said. Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers, also a Republican, said his city had made great strides in overcoming its past financial woes and now had its "own plan for tax cutting," a plan that did not involve sales tax changes.
Also voicing views against the long-term and short-term exemption of clothing from the sales tax were Mayor Timothy C. Idoni of New Rochelle and Mayor Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon, both Democrats.
Resolutions against joining the sales tax exemption have also been passed by the Westchester Municipal Officials Association and most of its member municipalities and various school districts.
Bolstering the position of Mr. Spano and the others was the report prepared by the Westchester County Association, which analyzed in detail the effects the sales tax exemption could have in Westchester. Property tax increases would be substantial and would more than offset any sales tax savings, according to the report.
For example, the report said, a property owner in White Plains with assessed property at $14,540 (considered about average in that city) would pay between $218 to $286 more a year in property taxes to make up for the lost sales tax revenue. That homeowner would have to spend $6,228 to $8,171 a year on clothing purchases of less than $110 to come out even, the report said. Likewise, in Yonkers, a home assessed at $12,900 (again, an average assessment) would have an increase in property taxes of $137 to $181. That person would have to spend $3,425 to $4,525 on clothing to offset the increase, the report said.
Speaking on behalf of the Westchester County Association and the report they helped prepare, Thomas J. Spitznas, an economic consultant, and Theodore Puluso, a certified public accountant, said it was not feasible to think that the local governments could make up for the lost revenue by cutting from their budgets. "Most of the fat has already been cut," Mr. Spitznas said. Nor, they said, was there any proof that the reduced sales tax would bring increased retail business to the county.
He added that if the clothing exemption were allowed and if it did, as predicted, lead to increased property taxes, there would be further consequences. Increased property taxes, he said, would lead to higher rents for retailers, who would have to raise prices on their goods, thus eliminating any consumer savings from sales tax relief.
The Westchester government did take part in three earlier trials of the sales tax exemption on clothing, most recently in September. It is estimated that the county government would lose up to $1 million if it joins in the fourth trial.
The vote on whether to take part in the fourth and final trial week was 11 to 6, almost along party lines. The Board's nine Democrats were joined by two Yonkers Republicans -- Katherine S. Carsky and Bernice Spreckman -- in voting not to take part. Those favoring continued participation generally argued that the county could find enough fat in its budget to make up for the lost sales tax revenue.

LENGTH: 2109 words

HEADLINE: Nassau Coliseum's Biggest Brawl Ever Is Off the Ice

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE

 BODY:
DREAMS for the future of Long Island's only major sports franchise will be on the minds of fans when the New York Islanders return to the ice at the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum tonight.
But there may not be much to cheer about. The Islanders appear to have little chance at the Stanley Cup. Worse, the team's managers and their landlord, County Executive Thomas Gulotta, have called one another such nasty names in the last few weeks that any capacity for cooperation between the two sides may be lost forever. If not for a judge's order, the Islanders would not even be setting foot in the building. 
 It appears that Islander management got the worst of it in this hockey brawl with Nassau County, but future clashes seem inevitable. Over the long term, the greatest damage may be to the concept of the Nassau Hub, a retail and entertainment complex envisioned for central Nassau County.
The immediate issue, unfolding over the summer and now threatening to hang over the 1998-99 season, has been the safety of the Coliseum. The Islanders say the arena is a hazard; the county says it is not. But it is hard to avoid the suspicion that the Islanders' safety concerns are somehow related to their expressed desire for a renegotiation of their current lease and a new arena that could be built and ready for action in three years.
"All we want is to be able to compete on the same footing as the other teams around the country," said David Seldin, the president of New York Sports Ventures, which bought the Islanders in February for $195 million. "To survive we've got to attract more fans, and that means not only better players, but a state-of-the-art arena."
Mr. Seldin said the franchise was currently losing $11 million a year.
The team was prepared to play tonight's exhibition game against the Washington Capitals elsewhere had not State Supreme Court Judge Burton S. Joseph issued an order on Tuesday requiring that the Islanders adhere to their contract with the county and play all their scheduled home games at the Coliseum. To go elsewhere, the judge said, "would cause the county irreparable harm."
The judge also ruled that claims by the Islanders that the Coliseum was unsafe were unfounded. Justice Joseph said that engineers hired by Gary Bettman, commissioner of the National Hockey League, had conducted a thorough safety inspection of the 16,400-seat arena and reported to the court that there were was no structural threat to the fans or players.
Mr. Seldin said the team would obey the court's ruling and return to the Coliseum to play its scheduled games there. However, he said, the team would not return to its old offices in the Coliseum's basement; its headquarters are now in Jericho.
He said the Islanders also planned to continue to press a suit they filed in Federal district court in Brooklyn on Sept. 9 seeking $10 million in damages and charging that the county had permitted the 26-year-old Coliseum to fall into such a state of disrepair that it was no longer safe to play hockey. As a result, he said, the team, in effect, had been evicted.
The county and Spectacor Management Group, which was contracted by the the county to operate the Coliseum, fired back on Sept. 17 in State Supreme Court in Mineola, seeking a temporary restraining order barring the team from playing scheduled home and exhibition games any place but the Coliseum. The county decided to go to court after talks called by Mr. Gulotta failed to resolve the dispute.
Mr. Gulotta said the owners were using the safety issue as a ruse to gain a share of parking and concession fees at the Coliseum and to improve their position in negotiations to build a new Coliseum and to develop the 70 acres that surround the arena.
Mr. Gulotta has proposed building not only a new arena, but also converting the old Coliseum into a convention center and the construction of a new hotel and shops and office buildings. The sports complex would be linked by rail and jitney to Roosevelt Field and other shopping malls, office buildings, nearby colleges and universities and county, state and Federal office buildings.
The new Coliseum would be the jewel in the center of what Mr. Gulotta calls the Nassau Hub, which, if realized, would represent a monumental reminder of the Gulotta administration.
Mr. Gulotta said he was hopeful of attracting another big-sport franchise, perhaps a basketball team, and that the threat by the Islanders to leave not only damaged the county's image as a growing sports market but might also put upward pressure on interest rates on bonds and other financing instruments that would be issued to build the Hub.
As one official close to the talks put it, "It's all a matter of who controls slicing up the pie and gets the bigger piece, and no one is going to tell Tom Gulotta how to hold the knife."
While everyone involved, including the fans, want a new arena, the debate continues over how to pay for it and the rest of the Hub project. New York State has come up with $30 million toward the arena, which could cost between $200 million and $300 million. County taxpayers appear reluctant to make a contribution and Mr. Gulotta, mindful of voter abhorrence of higher taxes, says those interested, including the Islanders, should bring along their own capital.
The Coliseum, the oldest unrenovated arena in the National Hockey League, is not the only sporting arena that has been found wanting and in search of public and private capital. The new owners of the New Jersey Nets have made noises about leaving the Meadowlands Sports Complex to a proposed site in Newark. The Devils are also unhappy at the Meadowlands and have said they want to move to Hoboken.
In New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed a $1.3 billion stadium for the team on the West Side of Manhattan to house the restless George Steinbrenner and his Yankees, while the Bronx is offering a new $500 million complex to keep them at Yankee Stadium in the Bronx. In Queens, the Mets unveiled plans for a new domed stadium in April, and they hope to have the city pick up three-quarters of its $500 million price tag.
Mr. Seldin has noted that the U.S. Open tennis tournament was played at the one-year-old National Tennis Center in Queens, which cost $245 million to build. The city helped by issuing $150 million in tax-exempt bonds to build the center, but the United States Tennis Association makes the payments.
Similar creative financing will be required for a new Coliseum in Nassau. Sources close to the talks say the county has offered to put up a third of the money if the state and the Islanders also put up a third each. But Mr. Gulotta is said to want the Islanders to advance an additional one-third to cover the county's share, and then be repaid over a period of time.
But while everyone is dreaming about a new arena, the old concrete steel-reinforced structure that rocks when the Islanders score and the fans cheer and stamp their feet in unison, is showing its age. Many of the 64 columns that surround the arena and hold up the roof have small cracks, concrete is flaking away from six of the columns, and bulges are appearing at some locations around the midsection of the facade.
Engineers told Justice Joseph that such aging problems were considered commonplace in similar buildings, including most of the skyscrapers in New York City as well as the cement and marble State Supreme Court in Mineola, where the judge conducted his hearings over the last two weeks.
Lawyers for the New York Islanders argued heatedly before Justice Joseph with lawyers for Nassau County and Spectacor Management, which operates more than 30 arenas worldwide, over whether the arena was safe.
Kenneth L. Steinthal, the lawyer representing the Islanders, charged that the team suffered irreparable harm because the county refused to permit an independent safety evaluation of the Coliseum.
"There is no difference between this situation and the Iraqi arms inspection," he said. "The Iraqis don't want the U.N. to come in and investigate, and Nassau County won't permit an independent evaluation. We're not suggesting that the Coliseum be condemned and closed down, we just want to be assured that it is safe."
In response, Joseph J. Ortego, the lawyer for the county, argued that the Islanders had failed to tell the court why the arena was unsafe and accused the owners of being on "a fishing expedition" in an effort to find evidence for their Federal lawsuit.
"If the Coliseum is safe for the World Games, the Jehovah's Witnesses, Sesame Street and the circus, then give us at least a hint of why it is unsafe for the Islanders," Mr. Ortego said.
Mr. Ortego accused the Islanders of using the safety issue as a tactic to scare the public as a means to embarrass the county government into giving the Islanders a new contract.
Outside the courtroom, both sides pulled off their gloves and let loose with a barrage of ugly personal attacks in full-page ads in Newsday and on the Internet at www.coliseum-coverup.com. Mr. Seldin described the county and Spectacor Management as "criminal institutions" attempting to "conceal the truth from the public," while Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive, described the Islanders as "greedy" and "a pig at the trough."
Despite the vitriol, Mr. Gulotta, after Judge Joseph's ruling on Tuesday, urged Mr. Seldin and the owners of the Islanders, Howard Milstein and Steven Gluckstern, to return to the negotiating table to discuss the new arena and the Hub development. In a letter to the owners, he said he had directed the county's negotiator to resume "with all due haste, planning for a new multifaceted sports complex to meet the future needs of the Islanders and to develop the Hub in a manner consistent with the best interests of Nassau taxpayers."
Apparently responding to critics who charge the county has taken too long to act on plans for the new coliseum and the Hub, Mr. Gulotta said that the planning process would "resume immediately and adhere to a rigid timetable." He also wrote: "While I am hopeful that the Islanders' ownership will be a constructive part of this development plan, the county will not be deterred from formalizing a plan to present to the community."
In a tepid response to the Gulotta overture, Mr. Seldin said he hoped that it was "made in good faith" and that Mr. Gulotta himself would participate in the talks and "not let them get lost among subordinates." Meanwhile, Mr. Seldin continues to insist that the Islanders have no lease at the Coliseum and that "this will be established over the coming months in Federal court."
"The public and the press are now looking hard at the county and S.M.G.'s handling of the Coliseum," Mr. Seldin said. "It is sad that a judge had to force the county to have even a limited inspection."
He said the recent scrutiny forced by the Islanders had resulted in the correction of "numerous" safety problems and the identification of several other concerns.
"Crumbling concrete will be fixed and areas of potential danger around the outside of the Coliseum will be blockaded to protect visitors to the facility," he said. "With time, there will be more complete inspections and a more complete examination of all the evidence."
To entice fans to the arena, Mr. Seldin said the team was rolling back its ticket prices and had cut the service charge for tickets ordered by phone. For tonight's preseason game, he said, tickets would be free for season subscribers and $10 for everyone else, regardless of seating.
In addition, he said regular-season tickets for all October and November games would be available at a special discount in the 300-level seating areas of the Coliseum. All 300-level $19 tickets will be $ 10: $35 tickets will be $20 and $40 tickets will be $30.
Both sides claimed that Justice Joseph's ruling was a victory for the fans. But it was Justice Joseph who most strongly expressed concern for the fans in the courtroom. He went so far as to apologize to the fans, saying he was sorry he could not return their telephone calls to his law secretary asking the court what they should do with their tickets for the Islander's first scheduled exhibition game, on Sept. 25, which was canceled because of the continuing legal dispute.
"Their concern shows how this affects everyone, from the fans to the county's image across the country to interest rate," he said. "I always get very upset when a respected industry or any employer that is an integral part of the economy of Long Island, in effect, wants to pick up their marbles and leave."

LENGTH: 1553 words

HEADLINE: End to School Segregation, Voluntary Or Mandated?

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
WHETHER Connecticut should continue its plan of voluntary school desegregation or institute one with mandated timetables and goals and some kind of punishment for school districts that don't comply was debated in a court hearing last month.
The hearing, before Superior Court Judge Julia L. Aurigemma in Middletown, was a continuation of the Sheff v. O'Neill case, which has been responsible for school reform legislation since the state's Supreme Court ruled in July 1996 that the state's system of autonomous municipal school districts had resulted in unconstitutional de facto segregation for students in Hartford. 
 But lawyers for the plaintiffs, 17 Hartford schoolchildren when the lawsuit was filed in 1989, argued that the reforms enacted by the legislature and the Governor since the Supreme Court ruling have had little effect on the racial and ethnic isolation of the capitol city's schools.
In fact, they said, the racial make-up of Hartford's schools has even grown slightly more isolated since the Supreme Court decision. Black and Hispanic students made up 93 percent of Hartford's school enrollment in 1996, and now they are 94 percent, says Wesley W. Horton, one of the plaintiffs' attorneys.
The plaintiffs' lawyers and their expert witnesses claimed that the state's reliance on voluntary efforts had not met the court's order to remedy the problem, and could not be expected to in the future.
Witnesses for the state countered that tens of millions of extra dollars in state funding has been allocated for schools in districts with high proportions of minority students, preschool opportunities for low-income urban youngsters have been greatly expanded, and about a fifth of the state's public school students are now served by public school choice and inter-district educational programs, all in direct response to the Sheff decision.
They argued that historically, across the country, voluntary desegregation efforts have been more successful than mandated ones, and that given enough time the state's voluntary efforts will reduce Hartford's racial isolation.
The Supreme Court's decision left it up to the legislature and the governor to find a remedy, which lawyers from the State Attorney General's office, defending the state, said was exactly what was done. Judge Aurigemma asked the two sides to submit post-trial briefs by Dec. 4, and scheduled final oral arguments for Dec. 7. Her decision is not expected until early next year, but either way she rules is unlikely to settle the case.
If she rules in favor of the plaintiffs and decides to order a particular remedy, it would necessitate another hearing to determine exactly what remedy should be ordered, and the Attorney General's office would probably appeal such a decision.
If she rules in favor of the state, it gives the legislature and the governor more time to effect a remedy but doesn't preclude the plaintiffs from filing another show cause complaint in two or three years if they aren't satisfied with the state's progress.
Any ruling by Judge Aurigemma that contradicts the Supreme Court decision in the state's favor will likely bring an appeal by the plaintiffs to the Supreme Court.
The hearing was held during a curiously anemic political season in which education has been a frequent campaign theme for state candidates, for whom the Sheff decision has been a kind of invisible polar bear in the room, virtually unmentioned by Republicans or Democrats.
In December, the State Education Department will issue its first biennial report on progress toward reducing racial isolation in the cities. Then in January, the legislature will convene to consider new recommendations to respond to the Supreme Court's order.
The state's star witness in the hearing was the Education Commissioner, Theodore S. Sergi, who spent two days on the stand describing the state's response to the Sheff case.
In addition to Mr. Sergi, there were several expert witnesses who, armed with charts and graphs, analyzed the pros and cons of the state's voluntary approach and dueled over their research findings.
Mr. Sergi said he told how Gov. John G. Rowland appointed the Educational Improvement Panel -- a 22-member committee representing legislators, educators, civil rights leaders and others with an interest in the case -- to make recommendations on remedies to the legislature's 1997 session.
This school year, Mr. Sergi said, 100,000 of the state's 540,000 public school students will participate in inter-district educational programs with students from different socioeconomic backgrounds. The state also has 15 inter-district magnet schools and 16 charter schools serving 7,000 students, and an inter-district Open Choice program serving well over 800 students -- 540 from Hartford, 200 from New Haven and 100 from Bridgeport.
The e program, which some educators call Project Choice, is the continuation of Project Concern, a school choice program in Hartford that gave urban students the opportunity to attend schools in adjacent suburban towns. It was expanded to include New Haven and Bridgeport because the Sheff decision, though specifically about Hartford, has been interpreted as potentially applying to other cities as well.
Mr. Sergi also noted that the state appropriated more than $100 million for pre-school education, early reading programs, computers, school renovation and construction, and school library books for "priority districts," which is how the state terms those targeted for special economic aid due to income or racial and ethnic demographics.
"It's hard to say that that is not responsive," Mr. Sergi said. "It's a responsive beginning, but were not finished."
"The solution will not come in a courtroom, but in the classroom," said the Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal. "We hope the court will give the elected officials, the legislature and the governor the time to implement programs that are meaningful and effective."
As an expert witness, the state put on the stand a Boston University political science professor, Christine Rossell, who has analyzed hundreds of school district desegregation efforts across the country. She testified that her analysis shows that voluntary desegregation is more effective than court-mandated programs because it generates less "white flight."
Witnesses for the Sheff plaintiffs, Gary Orfield of Harvard University, Gary Nutriello of Columbia University Teachers College and Bill Gordon, a desegregation expert from North Carolina, presented evidence to support that side's claim that the state's remedies were ineffective.
Their argument was that only a few hundred of Hartford's 23,000 public school students were affected by the state's remedial efforts, and that without enforceable timetables and goals, no meaningful reduction in the racial isolation of the city's school pupils was possible.
They discounted the part-time inter-district educational programs, special programs open to both suburban and Hartford students, and all the state's response in the rest of the state as not applicable to the Sheff order of the Supreme Court. Part-time programs do not remedy full-time racial isolation, and programs in other cities do not affect Hartford students, they said.
"The whole thing the state's been doing the last three years is a drop in the bucket," said Mr. Horton.
Another Sheff lawyer, Philip Tegeler, of the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, said the Hartford component of the Open Choice Program only serves 524 students (Mr. Sergi put the number at 540), fewer than its predecessor, Project Concern, served before the Supreme Court ruling and only about half its size 10 years ago.
The plaintiffs' legal team presented guidelines it wants to see implemented by the state that include goals and timetables for measuring compliance and ways the state can enforce them.
Their guidelines also suggested methods for reducing racial isolation that would require suburban districts and the Hartford district to share each others' schools and force the hiring of more minority teachers for all schools.
"Our case is pretty simple," Mr. Tegeler said. "It boils down to the numbers. What has the state done for the students in the Hartford area, not for the state?"
The state has done a great deal for the students in Hartford, said Mr. Sergi. When Hartford's Board of Education was unable to address the problem of its high school's losing accreditation and a plan to turn schools over to a private company failed, the state took over the system, replacing the local board with a state-controlled board of trustees. Hartford also has the largest school choice plan and several magnet and charter schools, with more under development. "Hartford's certainly has been my highest priority the last two years," Mr. Sergi said.
Probably the most important step was when the legislature made reducing racial isolation an "educational interest" of the state. Mr. Sergi said this means no local district can ignore it.
The plaintiffs may have misgivings about the pace and voluntary nature of the state's response, but Mr. Sergi said the state will eventually achieve what the plaintiffs want. "The goals of the state and the plaintiffs are very similar," he said. "It's a question of how you get there."

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
Cleanup of Tainted Industrial Sites Gains Momentum

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
VACANT for six years, the single-story building at 4 Henderson Drive within a corporate park in West Caldwell is an industrial wreck, a victim of time and environmental concerns.
But this spring, a new owner plans to clean the 10.2-acre site of contaminates and renovate the 49,000-square-foot structure that occupies it into an office building. 
 The site, where electronic circuit boards were once made, contains trichloroethylene, a chlorinated solvent, which has seeped into the ground water.
In doing the cleanup, the owner, Aqua Terra Realty Holdings of Manhattan, will take advantage of a state law passed last winter that provides financial incentives and protection from liability to buyers who clean polluted industrial sites, also known as brownfields, and return them to productive use.
"Pre this legislation," said John B. Mariano Jr., a lawyer for Aqua Terra in the purchase of the site,"there was an open-ended invitation for legal fights" as well as the prospects of new cleanup orders and more costs. Now, there is at least more certainty to the process, said Mr. Mariano, a partner at the Florham Park law firm of Schwartz Simon Edelstein Celso & Kessler.
The Brownfields and Contaminated Site Redemption Act amends earlier laws in an ongoing effort in New Jersey, and the nation, to make the regulatory climate more flexible and offer more incentives to reuse land left from the state's industrial past. In the last 13 years, the state has overseen the cleanup of some 9,594 such sites, according to the Site Remediation Program, which is a part of the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
Some 10,000 contaminated properties -- including brownfields but not sites on state or Federal Superfund lists -- still exist in the state.
When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed the law on Jan. 6 she described it as "a powerful new tool" to bring economic activity to long-dormant brownfields.
Terri C. Smith, legislative analyst at the Site Remediation Program, stressed, however, that the law did not relieve original polluters from liability.
Although no sites have gone through a cleanup or redevelopment since the law was signed, one indication that the law has spurred additional interest, Ms. Smith said, is the increase in the number of agreements property owners have signed with her department to perform voluntary cleanups. From January to August, there were 1,342 such agreements signed, up from 1,122 agreements during the same time period last year. Some of last year's agreements are advancing to the next stage toward redevelopment.
The key provision of the law is that it protects buyers of tainted sites from private lawsuits related to past contamination problems if they agree to clean the properties according to state requirements. Essentially, the state requires different standards depending on the planned new use of the site, with a residential reuse requiring a higher level of remediation than commercial or industrial uses. The standards also permit alternative methods, including impermeable caps to stop wastes from seeping out, instead of requiring the removal of such industrial residue.
Once this site is remediated, the State Department of Environmental Protection will agree not to sue. The new law also exempts buyers from any new cleanup costs once state environmental officials approve the cleanup job.
THE financial sweeteners include matching state grants to small developers who utilize innovative technologies to remediate sites, as well as reimbursement for up to 75 percent of the cleanup cost. Projects must generate new tax revenue that exceeds the cost of the cleanup to qualify for the reimbursement incentive.
The law also liberalizes the exemption from property taxes that municipalities can grant to developers who reclaim industrial sites in environmental opportunity zones, designated by municipalities, to up to 15 years from 10 years -- the time permissible under state statutes.
The reuse of properties within zones was also expanded to include residential uses; previously, only commercial and industrial uses were permitted.
To highlight those points, Governor Whitman signed the law in front of the former Alcoa plant along River Road in Edgewater while wrecking crews worked to raze the building, where aluminum products were made from 1914 to 1965. Several attempts to redevelop the 10-acre site since then were unsuccessful and it sat vacant. Oils that contained PCB's, a toxic chemical, seeped into the walls and floors of the building, which was completely decontaminated and demolished a month and a half ago.
Next March, a two-building rental complex containing 408 apartments will begin rising on the site. The developer is Daibes Brothers of Edgewater.
Aqua Terra Realty is seeking a matching state grant for the technology it intends to use to clean the West Caldwell site. The company bought it last August from the Canada Life Assurance Company, which foreclosed on the property a few years earlier. Mark Javello, who along with Steven Ancona is a principal at Aqua Terra Realty, said the grant would cover the remediation costs, which preliminary estimates put at $300,000 to $500,000.
The company's affiliate, the Aqua Terra Environmental Corporation, is considering using a process called anaerobic biodegradation for the cleanup. It essentially uses the bacteria found in the soil to break down the trichloroethylene found on the site into benign substances.
"The technology grant will be a perk, but the bigger picture is that the state is saying that it is willing to work with us," Mr. Ancona said, adding that that could help speed the process, which is expected to take six to 18 months to complete.
No one, however, is calling the law a panacea. "It is more of an incremental step than a giant leap forward," said Keith E. Lynott, who heads the environmental law practice at McCarter & English, a Newark-based law firm. While the law provides safeguards from liability, Mr. Lynott said, it does not provide absolute immunity, so that cleanups still carry certain risks. For example, he said, the liability protection extends only to the purchased property but does not take into account contaminates migrating off-site to adjacent properties that may also be affected.
Mr. Javello, of Aqua Terra, said his company "will layer the protection from the state with additional insurance to avoid being blindsided."
STILL, many said, the law offers promise. "Its provisions are all factors that can help tip the scales in favor of remediating and redeveloping sites," said Ira Whitman, who heads an environmental consulting and engineering concern bearing his name in East Brunswick. "It makes the process less daunting and more feasible."
Agreeing with that assessment is Dean O. Lundahl, vice president of the Advance Group, a development company in Bedminster. "I'm not saying we will take on Superfund sites," he said, "but we are now looking at properties that earlier we may have walked away from."
Mr. Lundahl said his company would try to take advantage of the law for the redevelopment of a 15-acre site it owns along the waterfront in Trenton. The site, occupied by four office buildings totaling 400,000 square feet, had undergone a cleanup. But it is not known if the remaining undeveloped portion of the site needs further remediation, he said, noting that plans call for building two more office buildings, with 300,000 square feet, parking for 2,000 cars and 50,000 square feet of retail space.
Some private environmental groups, however, are worried that the law weakens cleanup controls and restricts public participation. "We have outstanding concerns about the inability of the law to allow community input into cleanup decisions," said Bill Wolf, policy director at the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club. "And it will undermine the urban redevelopment goals of the state."
Ms. Smith countered that, "The new law doesn't change anything regarding the way we do business, nor does it change any of the technical requirements concerning cleanups."
Alan J. Steinberg, executive vice president of the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission, added, "Our philosophy is that the needs of economic development and environmental protection are made to be complimentary under the law, not brought into conflict."
But Raymond A. Ferrara, president of the Omni Environmental Corporation, an environmental consulting concern in Princeton, said that, "above and beyond anything else, the recycling of brownfields is a development issue." For projects to work, he added, they still must have the right economics in place and a developer with the financial wherewithal.
Location is what drew Aqua Terra, which specializes in the recycling of environmentally distressed properties, to the West Caldwell site. Mr. Ancona said that it is within a corporate park, accessible to major roadways like Bloomfield and Passaic Avenues and has all the infrastructure in place to support a new use.
Mr. Javello added, "We also felt comfortable the site could be cleaned."
Once a tenant is identified, work on renovating the building will start. Completion of the project, estimated to cost $6 million, is expected by next summer.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Long Island;
Lowest Rates in 30 Years Fuel Higher Home Prices

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
AS both a seller and a buyer, Didi Farrell has an interesting perspective on house prices.
Feeling that their three-bedroom West Hempstead Cape Cod would be easy to sell in a strong housing market, she and her husband, Daniel, a New York City police officer, recently put it up for sale at $169,000. 
 They also say that low interest rates, which have dropped to a national average of 6.64 percent, a 30-year low, will help them take on a much higher mortgage.
The Farrells are moving forward with plans to buy a house with a dining room, den and four bedrooms so that they will have enough room for themselves and their two small sons, 3, and Christian, 21 months.
But because of the same strong housing market, the house they hope to buy, also in West Hempstead, is priced at $269,000 -- more than they had planned to spend.
It will mean stretching, Mrs. Farrell said. "We won't be able to put as much aside into our retirement account as we have been, there won't be as many dinners out and we'll be keeping things to a minimum for at least a year," she said. "But it puts us into the size house that we would like to be in."
Similar buying and selling decisions have been stoking the market despite the rise in house prices in the last year.
The median contract price in Nassau County in July 1997 was $180,000. A year later, it had risen to $195,300. In Suffolk, the price rose to $153,000 from $145,000.
Nevertheless, said Joseph E. Mottola, chief executive of the Long Island Board of Realtors, "I'm not getting any kind of sense that affordability is an issue -- people are not complaining about what they have to pay." He attributed that to "favorable interest rates, the availability of a variety of financing programs to fit everybody's needs and a general business optimism about being employed and doing well."
Andrew Thaw, a partner of Whitman Thaw and Associates, mortgage bankers in Melville, and the president of the New York Society of Mortgage Professionals, a trade group, noted that even if a house goes up $10,000, the monthly cost would be more than offset by a drop of one percentage point in interest rates, assuming a 10 percent down payment is made in both cases.
He explained that with a 10 percent down payment, a $150,000 house would require a $135,000 mortgage that at 8 percent interest over 30 years would cost $990.58 a month. A 10 percent down payment on a $160,000 house would require a $144,000 mortgage that at an interest rate of 7 percent would cost only $958.04 a month.
For first-time buyers, even the 10 percent down payment could be enough to knock them out of the market were it not for programs specifically aimed at them, said Lynn Law, a mortgage counselor with the Long Island Housing Partnership in Hauppauge, a nonprofit housing agency.
The State of New York Mortgage Agency has programs that allow first-time buyers to finance 100 percent of the cost of both a new and a resale house, said Joseph S. Rizzo, a mortgage representative for the Bank of New York Mortgage Company in Riverhead, which is a member of the housing partnership. Family income can be $90,000 or more, depending on the number of family members, Mr. Rizzo said.
As of Oct. 1, the Sonyma rate for a 30-year loan for up to $227,000, with 1 1/2 points, was 6.625 percent. A point is 1 percent of the mortgage amount.
Still, rising prices have forced many buyers to scale back on their dream house, compromising either on neighborhood or size.
An example of how prices have gone up in a year is a house she listed a year ago for $225,000 in Williston Park, said Evelyn Atanas, a Williston Park broker. The owners withdrew it from the market, recently put it back on and got $235,000, she said.
Neal and Anne Ressa, who are first-time buyers, started looking for a house a year ago before settling on one in Mineola, which they found through Atanas Realty.
LAST year, we couldn't find anything we particularly loved, but the same houses this year were $20,000 to $50,000 more," said Mr. Ressa, who is a salesman for a welding-supply company. Mrs. Ressa works for a department store as a personal shopper.
They wound up getting "a bargain," Mr. Ressa said -- a four-bedroom Cape Cod for $200,000. "We were the first people to see the house, and the owner was elderly and ready to sell," he said. Still, their dream had been to buy in Port Washington, where he grew up, he said. But in Port Washington, they would have had to pay at least $250,000 for a smaller house, he explained.
Brokers, especially those in Nassau, report there is very little left even in the $200,000 range. "I have buyers come in saying, 'I can spend up to $200,000,' which is an incredible amount of money especially if you're a young couple just starting out," said Renee Luft, a sales agent with the Century 21 Prevete real estate agency in Hicksville. "But for $200,000, you don't get very much anymore."
Even so, brokers say that buyers today are very knowledgeable and are not inclined to overpay. "Even in today's hot market, pricing is crucial," said Katy Anastasio, owner of Anastasio Associates, a Huntington real estate broker.
New-house prices are rising along with those of resale houses. Depending on the development, prices have risen $5,000 to $25,000 a house in the last year, said Marilyn Larsen of Great Neck, a marketing consultant to builders. "And there has been no resistance," she added, noting that she is able to lock in today's low interest rates for nine months until a house is delivered.
Builders say they are forced to raise prices because they face rising costs. "I don't raise prices frivolously," said Steven A. Klar, an East Meadow builder, "but when we project out for a longer period of time, I anticipate cost increases in insulation and other materials, and I have to consider the cost of holding land."
In his current development, Waterways at Moriches, he is building 274 units consisting of two-bedroom apartments and two-bedroom semiattached houses for people 55 or older. Prices for houses to be delivered in the spring have gone up $5,000 to $10,000 over those that went into contract in June for earlier delivery, Mr. Klar said. The new prices range from $175,000 for an apartment to $250,000 for a semiattached house.
At the Villages at Huntington, where McGovern-Barbash Associates of Babylon is building 248 houses, prices, which started at $295,000 to $340,000 two years ago, have risen to $330,000 to $425,000. The cost of materials and labor has also gone up, said Susan Barbash, one of the principals.
But buyers willing to move farther east into subdivisions just starting out can take advantage of preconstruction prices.
At a 72-house Yaphank development called Fairway Woods under construction by J. D. O. C. Construction of Yaphank, preconstruction prices range from $149,900 for a three-bedroom high ranch to $182,900 for a four-bedroom colonial.
But by Columbus Day, when models open, those prices will go up at least $5,000, said Mrs. Larsen of Great Neck, who is in charge of marketing. Since sales began six weeks ago, contracts have been signed on eight houses, she said.
Among her customers are John Jackson, a New York City police officer, and his wife, Nancy, an insurance claims representative. They have contracted to buy the $182,900 colonial, having just sold their three-bedroom, 1,100-square-foot Ronkonkoma ranch for $148,500.
Because they hope to lock in a 6.625 percent interest mortgage, their new house will cost them only $150 a month more, including taxes, Mrs. Jackson said. The reason is that on their Ronkonkoma house, their mortgage had an 8.5 percent interest rate, she said.
Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a business group, and director of the International Trade Research Institute at Long Island University-C. W. Post in Brookville, said that although the volatility in the stock market had not yet affected house prices, she anticipated a "leveling off" by winter or spring if the stock market kept falling.
Will that mean a sharp price drop? Dr. Kamer said she did not see that happening "because we haven't had the excesses of the 80's, when homes were really bought as an investment that was going to increase in value and not as a place to live."

HEADLINE: A Medical Center Works on Its Health

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
WHEN the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center opened in 1928, its towering promontories inspired comparison to Mount Shasta. Sixty years later, however, the mountain was turning into a molehill.
"Columbia, frankly, had gone through a 15-year period of trivial investment -- and it showed," said Dr. Herbert Pardes, dean of the faculty of medicine and vice president of the university for health sciences.
An architect familiar with some of the more antiquated areas of the old Presbyterian Hospital building was even more blunt. "It was frightening," he said, "to think that this was where people came to get well." 
 Since the late 1980's, however, $1.13 billion has been invested to construct or renovate 4.27 million square feet of space at the Washington Heights complex.
"What you see is an expression of the institution's taking the initiative to keep itself strong and to serve the community," Dr. Pardes said.
This year marks the opening of the New York State Psychiatric Institute, whose sleek curtain wall of bottle-green glass hugs the Henry Hudson Parkway; a new diabetes center and storefront clinic at St. Nicholas Avenue and 168th Street; a new pediatric intensive care unit at New York Presbyterian's Babies and Children's Hospital; an expansion of the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center in the Atchley Pavilion; a new research center for the New York Orthopaedic Hospital, and a new eye clinic.
None of these projects looks as if it would belong in a hard-edged, squared-off, white-tiled, fluorescent-bathed labyrinth. Openness -- even softness -- are key. Spaces are defined by curves, not corners. Expanses of glass replace opaque walls. Carpeting substitutes for linoleum. Woods (or wood-grained vinyl) supplant tiles. Luscious colors burst through the monochromatic landscape. And there is room to sit, to eat, to reflect or relax.
Something else is striking about these projects. They breach urban boundaries that seemed inviolable a decade ago, extending the medical center to the east side of Broadway and -- across two bridges -- to the west side of Riverside Drive. The center may also cross to the south side of 165th Street to build a hotel.
Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. believes the center has also grown more responsive to the district he represents. "They're doing things with the community," he said, "as opposed to for the community."
Nonetheless, there are daunting questions on the horizon. Will the merger nine months ago of the Presbyterian and New York Hospitals lead to a contraction uptown? Will managed care undermine the economics and logistics of such a large-scale enterprise?
Dr. David B. Skinner, vice chairman and chief executive of the New York Presbyterian Healthcare system, said contraction was "unlikely."
"Both campuses are full-service providers of care and they serve different constituencies," he said. He acknowledged the danger posed by managed-care programs to large, single, freestanding academic medical centers. "That is why we moved a long time ago to create a health-care system that has another 28 hospitals," he said.
Now part of that system, Presbyterian is itself the sum of once-independent units like the Babies and Orthopaedic hospitals. Presbyterian joined with Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1921 to build the medical center. The Psychiatric Institute, run by the New York State Office of Mental Health, is affiliated with the college.
The institute has produced what is surely the most striking recent addition to the center, a $79 million, six-story structure that is actually two buildings in one, divided by a soaring, prismatic atrium.
The south part is devoted to in-patient care, with 22 beds for upper Manhattan residents and 36 beds for research programs, and out-patient centers like an anxiety disorders clinic, a depression evaluation service and a children's day program. The north part is largely for laboratories.
The structure was designed to rise not much higher than the nearby cliffside so that it did not block views from the upland neighborhood. As a consequence, it is most familiar to highway motorists; not the usual case for a building in Manhattan.
"The facade facing the highway picks up on the speed of cars and the flow of the Hudson River," said Peter Pran, of the architectural firm N B B J in Seattle. While at the Ellerbe Becket firm in the early 1990's, Mr. Pran designed the institute, with Jill N. Lerner and Timothy Johnson.
The institute is still moving out of its 69-year-old, 20-story tower across Riverside Drive (where preserved brains can be found in glass jars on lab shelves).
But early reviews of the new building are encouraging. "The staff is thrilled," said Dr. John M. Oldham, the director of the institute, "because they now have a pleasant place for their patients."
The patients are even more thrilled, said Richard Herman, the administrator of the Washington Heights community service, which cares for 950 people from upper Manhattan, most of them impoverished, many of them immigrants. From the day rooms, patients enjoy unimpeded river views.
JUST the other day, Mr. Herman ran into Steven M. Papp, the deputy director for administration, shortly after Mr. Papp and Dr. Oldham were importuned by a patient who wanted to go home immediately. "That's a good sign," Mr. Herman said. "I thought when we first moved that no one would ever want to go home. Compared to where they live, this is like the Plaza."
Compared to the Plaza, of course, it's no Plaza. "We were cut and cut and cut," Mr. Pran said. "So much was cut on this building, that it survived at all is amazing."
Institute officials can point to features they fought to keep, as well as those that were sacrificed to a limited budget -- like the cafeteria, which was to occupy a notch in the building's facade overlooking the river. Until money can be found to complete it, the room will remain a raw shell.
Dr. Oldham held out for two bridges over Riverside Drive against considerable budgetary pressure to eliminate the one linking the institute to the Milstein Hospital Building. "This is our lifeline, our umbilical cord to our patients," he explained.
The new building is 330,000 square feet, compared to 240,000 square feet in the old tower. "Much of the increased space wasn't for expansion," Mr. Papp said. "It was to meet codes, mostly in patient care." This included the provision of day rooms, individual bedrooms and private bathrooms, as well as the elimination of dead-end corridors that required hourly fire watches.
Looking over a landscaped outdoor area south of the new building, Dr. Oldham said: "This is the first time we've ever had a yard for our patients. In our old building, we had rooftop cages, which were awful."
The choice of the site was not without controversy, however. Ms. Lerner, who is now at Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, said the community did not want the Psychiatric Institute to repeat the fortress-like, windowless facade that the Milstein building presents to Riverside Drive. "Their concern was that we activate the street," she said.
But the real battle was over the turf itself, which looked like parkland and had been mapped as such in 1966, although it was in fact owned by the university.
In effect, Columbia exchanged its land between Riverside Drive and the Henry Hudson Parkway for the old Psychiatric Institute building, which it will convert over the next four years into a new home for the Joseph L. Mailman School of Public Health.
Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said he had opposed construction west of Riverside Drive since his earliest days in city government. But he was also responsible for naming the spot Dead Dog Park during his previous term as Parks Commissioner after he came across a dog that he said had been "executed Santeria-style."
Community opposition to the project was placated somewhat by the promise of a pedestrian bridge to Fort Washington Park along the river. Mr. Farrell, who heads the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, said last week that construction of the long-awaited bridge might begin in 2000.
On the east side of the medical center another "park" -- this one of buildings -- is taking form. It is called the Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Park.
The first structure in the park was the $37 million Mary Woodard Lasker Biomedical Research Building of 1995, a speculative, multi-tenant, commercial laboratory at Broadway and 166th Street. Its 500-square-foot modules, meant to serve as "incubator" space for new companies, have lab benches and ventilating hoods. The average annual rent is $26 a square foot.
There are now 16 tenants, said William A. Polf, a deputy vice president of Columbia University, including V. I. Technologies, which specializes in blood cleansing.
From the public point of view, the building is best known for incorporating portions of the old Audubon Theater and Ballroom, where Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965.
Columbia once intended to raze the building. Under pressure from preservationists, however, the university agreed to retain the terra-cotta facade, which now functions as a decorative screen for the new building, and parts of the interior. In the entrance vestibule is a memorial to Malcolm X, bearing his Muslim name, El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz, the dates of his birth and death and the words "Knowledge" and "Courage."
A memorial to his widow, Dr. Betty Shabazz, who died after a fire last year, is to be established on the second floor, said Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, which controls the ballroom and adjacent space.
The architects were Davis Brody Bond, who also designed the second Audubon building, the $75 million Russ Berrie Medical Science Pavilion, a home for academic researchers constructed last year at St. Nicholas Avenue and 168th Street.
MR. BERRIE is the founder and chairman of Russ Berrie & Company of Oakland, N.J., makers of plush and beanbag animal figures, wind chimes, mugs, votive holders and picture frames.
As it happens, he is also diabetic. And he is a patient of Dr. Robin S. Goland, who had preached for years that diabetic patients needed a one-stop center where they could make rounds among all the medical specialists they needed to see.
"Nobody disagreed," she said, "but we didn't have the space or the resources." That is, until Mr. Berrie stepped forward last year with a $13.5 million gift to create the 14,000 square foot center. Dr. Goland is the director. It was designed by Architecture + Furniture and Davis Brody Bond.
The center, which is to open this month, will include what Dr. Goland calls an "interactive media wall," with information on the latest treatments and equipment. There are telephones and data ports in the waiting areas. Even more important, there is a pantry, so patients suffering from hypoglycemia can get something to eat.
The diabetes center also includes research laboratories. "Scientific investigators will ride the elevators with families that have just learned that their child is going to have to have shots for the rest of his life," Dr. Goland said. "That will lend a sense of immediacy to their work. And it will give patients a sense of hope."
Downstairs, on the ground floor of the Berrie Building, is a new clinic for a Columbia-Presbyterian group practice known as AIM, Associates in Internal Medicine, which serves northern Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood. Seventy percent of its clients are Hispanic, 20 percent are black.
"A storefront at 168th Street is the perfect space for making primary care physicians accessible to people in the community," said Dr. Steven Shea, director of the division of general medicine. "It's a real statement that we're here to stay."
Among the defining touches of the clinic, there are 35 chairs in the waiting area for 9 examining rooms -- a higher-than-usual ratio. "Hispanic patients don't go to the doctor alone," Dr. Shea said. "They bring their families to the clinic. So the number of chairs is a critical issue."
The clinic, which opened last month, was designed by Gran Sultan Associates. "We left in all the design extras in spite of the usual cash crunch," Dr. Shea said. These included wood veneer finishes in some areas, wall sconces and a curving cornice over the reception area. "Doing it nice was the single most important statement we could make to our patients," he said.
The third Audubon building, a $100 million project, will probably mix the research mission of the Berrie building to the north with the commercial mission of the Lasker building to the south. "We think we could have incubator facilities together with academic space very successfully," Mr. Polf said.
Audubon park surrounds a real park, Mitchel Square, a triangular patch cleaving Broadway from St. Nicholas Avenue.
Under a $4 million reconstruction, the once-ragged park is getting a new fence and paving, 21 trees and 1,500 flower bulbs. The project includes the conservation of the Washington Heights-Inwood War Memorial, a poignant sculptural grouping of three soldiers created in 1923 by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, who later founded the Whitney Museum of American Art.
"We wanted to show the city's participation with the biomedical center in the restoration of the area," Mr. Stern said.
Other city investments nearby include a $2.9 million renovation and expansion of the tuberculosis clinic at the Washington Heights District Health Center by the Department of Design and Construction, on behalf of the Health Department.
Though not formally part of the medical center, the district health center is attached to the core of original buildings where much renovation is taking place. (The core buildings replaced a ball park where the team that became the New York Yankees played from 1903 to 1912. A plaque in the courtyard marks the location of home plate.)
With the opening of the Milstein Hospital Building in 1989, many floors of the old Presbyterian Hospital tower emptied out.
In June, the Anne Youle Stein Center of New York Orthopaedic Hospital opened on the 11th floor. Paneled in expanses of blondish anigre wood, with mini-rotundas where corridors cross, the center might be mistaken for a law office -- at least until one came to the microsurgery and arthroscopy labs.
Integrated Design Group is the architect of the Stein Center and of renovations to the 14th floor of Presbyterian Hospital and the 13th floor of the Atchley Pavilion. "We're trying to remove all the things, like stainless-steel corner moldings, that scare you as a patient," said Barry Erenberg of Integrated. "It's an interesting project -- concealing a hospital within a hospital."
Pearwood walls and granite tiles greet visitors to the new medical oncology floor of the Herbert Irving cancer center, designed by Gwathmey Siegel & Associates. Flat-screen television monitors are mounted on the treatment cabinets in the day hospital, so patients can watch TV, with headphones, as they are getting infusions.
"We are always trying to make the facilities more comfortable and inviting," said Deborah J. Irving, director of the office of facilities development at New York Presbyterian's Columbia-Presbyterian campus (and no relation to Herbert Irving).
When the smallest patients awake after surgery, they literally see stars -- embossed in the ceiling tiles overhead. The visual theme of the new pediatric intensive care unit, on the ninth floor of Babies and Children's Hospital, is space travel.
FANCIFUL touches abound in the unit, which opened in June and was designed by Architecture + Furniture and the Spector Group. Color is splashed about with cheerful abandon. The floors, while vinyl, have a wood grain to look more like a bedroom at home. Desks and cabinets are made of oversized maple blocks.
One of the architects, Michael Spector, brought an intimate perspective to the project, since his grandson was once admitted to the old I.C.U. for open-heart surgery.
Unlike the cubicles of the old unit, the new rooms are open and airy, with glass walls and doors between them. "When children see other children who are almost in the same boat, and other children who are walking around, they support each other psychologically," Mr. Spector said.
As Dr. Howard Zucker, the pediatric director of the unit, walked through on a recent afternoon, he could see a 5-month-old girl recovering from heart surgery in the "Jupiter" room, a 6-month-old boy awaiting a liver transplant in "Orion" and a 16-year-old girl with leukemia in "Halley's Comet."
Family members are also accounted for in the design. Reclining chairs are provided in each child's room so that an adult can sleep only a few feet away. There are lockers and a shower. Small seating areas replace a large central space. "We created nooks so that you don't feel you're in a railroad station," Ms. Irving said.
"The feedback from parents has been very positive," Dr. Zucker said. "It's not the experience you want in life, but this is the best you can make it."
Looking to the future, Babies and Children's Hospital plans a $120 million, 11-story building to replace a parking lot at Broadway and 165th Street. The new structure will be connected to the existing hospital and contain 100 general medical-surgical beds, 40 neonatal intensive-care beds and 20 acute rehabilitation beds. Ground-breaking is expected next year. The architects are Ewing Cole Cherry Brott of Philadelphia and Davis Brody Bond. On completion of the new tower in 2001, the older hospital will be devoted mainly to out-patient departments.
"We really need to invest in out-patient services," said Cynthia N. Sparer, the executive director of the hospital. In cases involving cystic fibrosis and cancer, for example, she said, "Children still need to be admitted but hospitalizations are fewer and of shorter duration than in the past."
Farther west on 165th Street, a hotel may eventually be built, although planning is preliminary. "At any one time, we have hundreds of patients with relatives who want to stay near them," Dr. Pardes said.
There are other needs, too, as Mr. Polf found when he surveyed the staff on what the university could do to improve life at the medical center. One scientist answered simply: "Build a decent cafeteria."

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Property-Tax Rebates

 BODY:
Governor Whitman has proposed giving property-tax rebates whenever the state has a surplus. What do you think of the idea?
 
Save for Lean Years
New Jersey's surplus is the result of the conjunction of a good economy, low unemployment and low interest rates. It is unlikely that these conditions will continue indefinitely. It would be better for all of us if the surplus were "saved" for the day when the expenses of running our state, county and municipal responsibilities go up faster than our tax revenues.
 
JERRY STEIN
West Orange
 
It's Our Money 
 The surplus is all our money and should have already come back. Having a surplus means their calculations were wrong and we got overcharged. Are they collecting interest on our money?
 
BETTY A. SCHROECK
Clark
 
Presidential Aspirations
First, the only reason the Governor is doing anything about property taxes is to appease the right people before 2000, when she might take the leap and run for President.
If she were interested in providing tax relief, why not give back the revenues she stole from municipalities in her 30 percent income tax reduction?
 
ALBERT F. WORTH Jr.
Iselin
 
Education Fund
Let's put any budget surplus into a fund for education, since that's where most of our taxes go. I personally don't want a minuscule rebate. I'd rather have that money going into the schools.
 
SARAH MAJOR
Titusville
 
Relief for Some
I think Mrs. Whitman should give property tax relief to homeowners who have no children in public school.
 
DEE HILLMAN
Hillsborough
 
School Vouchers
The state income tax was supposed to help finance public education, and thus lower property taxes. Instead, the politicians and government bureaucrats discovered a new pot of money that they could spend. Education costs per pupil have tripled, adjusted for inflation, and test scores have fallen. A school voucher program would halt this crazy education inflation. This would bring down property taxes, by far the greatest factor in the high rates.
 
ALIETA ECK
Piscataway

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 9; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 719 words

HEADLINE: COMMUNITY;
Federal Grants Help Gown to Aid Town

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
The gap between universities and their adjoining neighborhoods is often wide, especially in cities. But as urban problems have intensified over the years, intruding at times on campus life, more and more schools have been rethinking their relationship to the greater society.
Against this backdrop, Rutgers University and Kean University were among 18 colleges and universities recently awarded Federal grants totaling $7 million for new partnerships. The local grants will aid neighborhoods near Rutgers's Newark campus and Kean's Elizabeth branch. 
 The grants, awarded late last month by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, are aimed at helping the schools direct their resources toward revitalizing low-income neighborhoods near their campuses and offering new opportunities to residents by, among other things, creating jobs, fostering new business and expanding home ownership.
. Rutgers, which received $399,998, will center efforts on the West Side Park section in Newark's Central Ward; Kean, with $399,129, on the Elizabethport section of Elizabeth.
The grants have been offered since 1992 as part of H.U.D.'s Community Outreach Partners Centers Initiative, said Stan Vosper, a department spokesman.
Even before the incentive program, Rutgers (with campuses in Newark and New Brunswick) and Kean (Union, Hillside and Elizabeth) had been working with neighborhood groups.
But such involvement was unusual, said Norman J. Glickman, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers, which will be a key player in the Rutgers initiative.
"Most universities don't take the stance this is important," Dr. Glickman said. "Research in physics or ancient Greece is more important.
Both universities prepared their proposals with input from their respective communities, and often the proposals build on existing programs.
"During some of the focus groups we had, one of the concerns of some community leaders was that Rutgers wanted to come in with its own ideas," said SanDonna Bryant, coordinator of the Newark Community Development Network, one of seven community groups that Rutgers will work with in the project.
But, she said, "It's not a case of Rutgers coming in and usurping the community but rather working with existing groups on activities to help the community."
The West Side Park neighborhood of Newark has about 20,000 residents with a median family income of $17,364, 20 percent less than Newark's and 60 percent below New Jersey's, according to Kathe Callahan, director of the new Newark Center for Families and Communities. Her agency will provide the social services part of the plan, including health services and job training.
Dr. Glickman's Center for Public Policy Research will oversee the technical aspects of the Rutgers effort in Newark, including housing and economic development. The plan calls developing a nurse-managed neighborhood health clinic, an after-school program and a 6echnical skills development center to help people find work. It would also help residents create affordable housing.
"We're here as a resource," said Ms. Callahan. "We're saying to the neighborhood, 'What is it you want to do and how can the university help you in achieving those goals?' "
When Kean University received word of the federal grant, it already had been working with Elizabethport community officials, drafting a social services plan for low-income housing.
The 16,000 residents of Elizabethport have a per capita income that is half of Elizabeth's as a whole and a third of Union County's, said Susan Lederman, executive director of Kean's Gateway Institute for Regional Development, a year-old agency that will lead Kean's program in Elizabethport.
Her agency will help residents create a network of day care centers and create several hundred day-care jobs. It will also give technical support to residents starting up small businesses and work to cut red tape to help residents develop some 1,700 parcels of land.
Dr. Lederman sees many benefits from such partnerships.
"By working cooperatively, we will be cutting down the division between town and gown," Dr. Lederman said. "But more important, we're using many of the neighborhood's existing ideas by working with residents. And we're joining together for a joint future."

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1379 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1999 Lexus LX 470 and 1999 Toyota Land Cruiser;
One Ready for the Woods; The Other, the Country Club

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
DID conspicuous consumption disappear with the 1980's? Not where large, expensive sport utilities are concerned. It seems that the bigger and more expensive the luxury sport utility, the better it sells.
Consider the Toyota Land Cruiser and its virtually identical cousin, the Lexus LX 470. Both of these full-sized sport utilities, priced from almost $47,000 to almost $59,000, were redesigned for the 1998 model year and introduced in April. They are unchanged for the 1999 model year. 
 Sales of the pricier LX 470 have unexpectedly exceeded those of the Land Cruiser in some months this year, but the Land Cruiser is predicted to close the year ahead of its cousin. Lexus is constrained in the number of LX 470's it can build because of limited availability of suspension components.
This comes at a time of unprecedented choices for the seemingly limited pool of consumers who can afford these vehicles. Still leading the charge is the wildly successful Lincoln Navigator, introduced in 1997. The Ford Motor Company has an even bigger sport utility in the works. Cadillac will soon introduce the Escalade, based on the Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon. Last spring GMC added an even more luxurious version of its Yukon, the Denali. The Suburban, sold by Chevrolet and GMC, remains a perennial favorite and the Range Rover -- the granddaddy of pricey utilities -- is holding its own.
Indeed, the phenomenal growth of the North American sport utility market shows no signs of slowing, and the sub-segment of the large, expensive, gas-guzzling types is demonstrating the most rapid rise in popularity.
Lexus introduced its first sport utility, the LX 450, in 1996 to keep its car buyers from moving into Range Rovers, Jeep Grand Cherokees and Suburbans. Based on the highly regarded Toyota Land Cruiser, the LX 450 added a formal grille and Lexus badging outside, butter-soft leather upholstery and rich wood trim inside, some additional equipment and $7,000 to the price tag. The formula remains largely the same this time around. The LX 470 -- the name change from the 450 connotes the more powerful 4.7-liter V8 engine -- and the new Land Cruiser still share the same basic architecture.
The two are by no means the biggest sport utilities available; those honors go to the Chevrolet and GMC Suburban. Even the gargantuan Lincoln Navigator is a foot longer than the LX 470 and Land Cruiser. The Toyota sport utilities also are shorter than the Cadillac Escalade, though Toyota has managed to add a third-row seat that Cadillac did not.
Compared with the Navigator and its bold, chrome-laden grille, the styling of the LX 470 and the Land Cruiser is understated. Their lines have been softened from those on the previous generation.
The most notable distinctions between the two are the LX 470's four-beam projector headlights, its side body cladding and running boards that match the body color.
Both have a high step into the cabin, but the LX 470 has an adjustable height control that the Land Cruiser does not. The system lowers the vehicle for easier entry, raises it for off-road driving or levels it for highway cruising.
Inside, both the LX 470 and the Land Cruiser are roomy and comfortable. The LX 470 comes standard with a third-row seat, providing reasonably comfortable accommodations for up to eight people. The third seat costs an extra $1,135 in the Land Cruiser.
The third seat is removable in both vehicles, though it is a two-person job. If you don't want to remove the seat but need extra room, the seat splits and the halves fold sideways out of the way. The second-row seats also fold and tilt forward for more cargo-carrying capability.
The difference in interior ambiance between the base Land Cruiser and the LX 470 is like that between the Toyota Camry and Lexus ES 300. Both have all the comfort and convenience you need but one provides more luxurious flair.
The LX 470 comes standard with creamy leather and elegant touches of genuine walnut wood trim; leather in the Land Cruiser is a $1,820 option. The Land Cruiser's instrument panel layout of rotary knobs and buttons is typical of a Toyota. Controls are logically placed, easy to operate and highly readable. The LX 470's instrument panel, equally functional, has the same holographic feel as that of the Lexus flagship, the LS 400 luxury sedan, and is stunning at night.
Both sport utilities are well-equipped with standard cruise control, three power outlets, power windows and locks and reclining second-row seats. The Land Cruiser is available with five major options -- rear air-conditioner, locking rear differential, leather, power moonroof and the third seat -- which, in total, add $5,000 to the nearly $47,000 price tag.
The LX 470, at $56,400, comes with virtually every standard feature imaginable, some of which are not available on the Land Cruiser. The only options are the power moonroof at $1,270 and the Nakamichi premium audio system at $1,200.
The most innovative feature in the LX 470 is the in-dash compact disk player that requires no CD changer. The player swallows up to six CD's, fed one at a time.
Other standard features in the LX 470 but not in the Land Cruiser include: power tilt and telescope memory steering column; memory for driver's seat and mirrors; rear-seat automatic climate control; Homelink garage and security gate opener, and self-dimming inside and outside mirrors.
As for safety features, both of the sport utilities come with standard dual front air bags, anti-lock brakes, daytime running lights and pretensioning seat belts. Neither vehicle is equipped with side air bags.
The biggest change in the LX 470 and Land Cruiser from the models they replace is under the hood. Their predecessors had been accused of being overpriced and underpowered with their V6 engines.
Both now are powered by a sophisticated and refined 4.7-liter dual overhead-cam V8 engine, a derivative of the LS 400's engine. It produces 230 horsepower and 320 foot-pounds of torque and is mated to an electronic four-speed automatic transmission. The utilities don't take top honors in horsepower -- the 1999 Navigator packs a whopping 300. Still, the Toyota utilities run strong, smooth and silent.
Similarly, the Land Cruiser and the LX 470, in particular, ride and handle like significantly smaller vehicles than their domestic competitors. But a test drive revealed a subtle difference in ride and handling between the two. The LX 470 is outfitted with its own suspension system, which is more sophisticated than that of the Land Cruiser and provides a ride more in the vein of a luxury sedan.
On a trip to northern Michigan, the tested LX 470 glided over the state's notoriously rough pavement without notice. The pleasant ride is reminiscent of the riding-on-a-cloud feeling of the LS 400 sedan. Even more impressive is the braking capability of the LX 470 and Land Cruiser. At more than 5,000 pounds, the two nearly match the braking of many 3,500-pound domestic sedans in testing by automotive enthusiast magazines.
The two also meet California's stringent low-emission standards, but both are gas hogs. Fuel economy -- an oxymoron in this instance -- is about 13 miles a gallon in the city and 16 on the highway.
Both the LX 470 and Land Cruiser, with its long history of traversing the African deserts, are extremely capable off-road. Each comes only with full-time four-wheel-drive; a low range is engaged by shifting a lever next to the transmission shifter. The Land Cruiser, with its more adventurous buyers, is more likely to explore off-road; still, the Lexus plowed through a foot of snow on an unpaved road without hesitation.
 The LX 470's extras come at a premium. While the Land Cruiser carries a base price of $46,898 (easily climbing to nearly $52,000 with all of the goodies), the Lexus starts at $56,400 and climbs to $58,870 fully loaded, making it the second-most-expensive sport utility, behind the Range Rover at about $65,000.
But the added features, the ultra-refined suspension, the exclusive Lexus nameplate and the pampering Lexus ownership experience are worth an extra $6,000 or so, aren't they? If one is consuming, why not do it conspicuously?
 
INSIDE TRACK: Very refined, very expensive.
