HEADLINE: Feud Eclipses Time of Glory For Leader Of Malaysia

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Among Asia's leaders, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was notable as a man with a bold vision: a physical and social transformation that would push this nation into the forefront of world affairs.
It almost came true. 
 In 17 years as Prime Minister, Dr. Mahathir, 72, who is a medical doctor, fostered an economic liberalization that led to some of the world's fastest rates of growth.
He drove Malaysians to be more productive, to embrace high technology and to begin major investments around the world. He created a national affirmative-action program that allowed the country's ethnic Chinese, Malays and Indians to share in improved living standards and a new sense of Malaysian identity and pride.
Nineteen ninety-eight was to have been Dr. Mahathir's year of triumph, perhaps paving the way for his retirement, with the inauguration of huge public works projects and impressive gatherings of foreign leaders and sportsmen.
But today, in a dizzying turnaround, Malaysia is on Asia's critical list, its economy teetering and its stability shaken by what seems to have been an entirely avoidable political cat fight.
Last month, Dr. Mahathir dismissed and arrested his deputy and heir apparent, Anwar Ibrahim, 51, accusing him of corruption and illegal sex acts. The move set off street demonstrations and aroused international condemnation, particularly from Mr. Anwar's many friends in foreign governments.
One of the region's most stable and prosperous nations is suddenly in an uproar.
It appears that, as in Indonesia, Thailand, Japan and South Korea, the pressures of economic collapse have spawned a political crisis. In all those nations, the result was a change in leadership. The question now is: Is Dr. Mahathir next?
The answer is far from clear. Unlike Indonesia, Malaysia has shown few signs of simmering discontent. The ouster of former President Suharto in Indonesia had been predicted by many people. Almost no one seems to have foreseen the eruption here.
Malaysia is not familiar with political demonstrations. Unlike Indonesians, Malaysians rarely riot. Many people here were puzzled and disturbed when they encountered water cannon and the riot police on the streets in recent weeks.
"What we're seeing is unprecedented," said Ambassador John R. Malott of the United States. "This has never happened in Malaysia, and nobody knows where it's going to go. You can write a lot of scenarios, but we are in totally uncharted waters."
Dr. Mahathir, the confident nation-builder, seems to be flailing as he watches his legacy crumble. An economy that had been growing at more than 8 percent a year for the last decade is now headed for a contraction of perhaps 6 percent.
Angry and frustrated, he closed Malaysia off to international financial markets one month ago, turning his back on the foreign investors whom he once embraced and who had fueled the rapid growth.
The move had the intended effect of bringing home the Malaysian currency, insulating it from the speculators whom Dr. Mahathir blames for the crisis and giving an adrenaline jolt to the now self-contained economy.
It is a move that seems in tune with a recent round of questioning of the economic orthodoxy of the International Monetary Fund. But few foreign economists expect it to work for long.
"Mahathir is attacking the fundamental beliefs of the free market, of capitalism, of Wall Street," a foreign diplomat said. "We are either watching economic theory being rewritten or reconfirmed -- and I don't think it's being rewritten."
The day after making his economic gamble, Dr. Mahathir set off the most severe political crisis of his tenure, dismissing Mr. Anwar, the man he had been grooming to be his successor.
Two weeks later, Mr. Anwar was arrested at his home and held incommunicado for 10 days, during which he says he was beaten by his jailers. Last week he was charged with 10 counts of corruption and sexual misconduct that could result in a prison term of up to 34 years.
The harshness of those moves unleashed a surge of largely unsuspected discontent that mobilized Mr. Anwar's motley fellow constituencies: liberal democrats, young professionals and politically assertive Muslims.
For the first time in decades, Malaysians by the thousands demonstrated in the streets and in mosques and were met with tear gas and water cannon. Many people were beaten and hundreds were detained, although most were later released.
People here whisper that Dr. Mahathir's days may now be numbered. But few venture a guess at what that number might be.

HEADLINE: Tottering Into the Spandex Era;
Bankrupt, Downtown Athletic Club Tries to Hold On

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Kevin C. Murphy counts himself as one of the Downtown Athletic Club's biggest fans, so he seemed a little embarrassed that he was the only person shooting hoops in the cavernous indoor basketball court before lunch one recent weekday.
It is hard to believe, he said, "but when I first joined the club, there was a waiting list and 4,000 members." 
 That was back in 1976, and since then the place itself has not changed much. An odd combination of gentlemen's club and gymnasium, it remains to this day one of the few spots in the city where a member can play a fierce game of squash, simmer in the steam room, take a cold plunge, shoot a round of billiards, eat a chicken pot pie and cap it all off with a Scotch and cigar at what may be New York's longest bar. (It is more than 70 feet long.)
But fewer and fewer people seem interested in doing all these things, at least under one roof. That helps explain how the Downtown Athletic Club, home of college football's Heisman Trophy, finds itself in dire straits.
Membership is dwindling, to under 1,300. The building, at 19 West Street near the tip of lower Manhattan, is crumbling. And the club's financial affairs are in utter disarray. (It is in bankruptcy and owes the city more than $3 million in back taxes.)
To pay off its back taxes without hocking the Heisman, the club is trying to find a way to use its other asset, its building, which dates from 1930.
But a series of nasty disputes has broken out, pitting members against one another, against a group of real estate developers who sought to buy and renovate the building, and, most recently, against the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, which wants to preserve the Art Deco exterior of the club's 35-story structure. That desire may stymie another developer's effort to upgrade the building and rescue the club.
Like so many New York battles, this one is over real estate. But it is also a fight for the soul of an old-fashioned institution that some people believe has outlived its time.
"We tried to work with them to allow the club and its heritage to go forward, to bring the facility into the 21st century so it could be enjoyed by a lot more people," said M. James Spitzer, the lawyer for the real estate developers who tried to buy the club's building and now hold the mortgage on it. But the members "all know each other -- the few that use it -- and don't want anyone else in there," Mr. Spitzer said.
The members don't see it quite that way. "Why shouldn't we keep something that has made important contributions to the city for 50 years?" asked William J. Dockery, who, as the club's new president, is quarterbacking its latest effort to stave off oblivion. The developers, Mr. Dockery contended, "want to change the entire fabric of the place, and make it like the Equinox or the Vertical, a froufrou club with several thousand members."
"Froufrou" is not a word anyone would use to describe the Downtown Athletic Club. Masculine, yes. Impressive, perhaps. Empty, often.
True, there is a jazzy floor full of stationary bikes and Stairmasters, where televisions are tuned to CNBC, music blares and mirrors glare, just as at most health clubs.
But that floor seems almost jarringly out of place in a building where time seems to have stopped decades ago. On the 18th floor is a big boxing ring, where the former heavyweight boxer Gerry Cooney gives lessons some afternoons -- and where some of the plaster has fallen from the high ceiling.
The 12th floor is given over to an Olympic-size swimming pool, with a balcony from which viewers can watch the slow strokes of the half-dozen swimmers below.
The top floors of the building, full of small rooms that members and outsiders can rent by the day, week or month, are generous with their harbor views but stingy with their bathrooms, which have stall showers, just like in college.
On the sixth floor, "The locker rooms are kind of grubby, but frankly, I don't care," said Byron Klapper, a bond-insurance executive who has been a club member for almost 20 years. He boasts that Ivan Boesky, one of Wall Street's most famous felons in the 1980's, once had the locker a few doors down.
On the fifth floor is the women's locker room, which can best be described as pink. The club was one of the first of Manhattan's men's clubs to admit women, which it did in the late 1970's. About 10 percent of the members are women.
This early effort to increase membership had mixed results, Mr. Murphy recalled. "One hundred women joined -- but 75 old-timers, the guys who like to smoke cigars and play dominoes, resigned," he said.
In general, change has come hard for the club. Luigi D'Angelo, who has worked there for 36 years, and now oversees the food service, said that the members who eat there would be disappointed if they could not get their corned beef and cabbage every Wednesday, followed by corned beef hash every Thursday.
Where else would the dining room include three billiard tables at one end? What other place has anything like the Heisman Room, a wood-paneled retreat covered with portraits of famous football players? What other place has the fabled trophy, a bronze statue of a football player stiff-arming his way to victory, a replica of which has been awarded to the best college player in the country every year since 1935? And if the carpet in the lobby where the Heisman Trophy stands is a little threadbare, so what?
Still, almost all private clubs in cities across the country ran into trouble in the early 1990's. "When Congress took away the club-dues tax deduction, that particularly hurt city clubs," said Elizabeth Hart, a vice president of the National Club Association in Washington. "Instead of sending six executives to join a club, companies might only send two."
The Downtown Athletic Club also faced special problems. Many of its members worked at stock brokerage firms and investment banks that merged out of existence or moved uptown. Shipping concerns started leaving lower Manhattan in favor of New Jersey, and law firms dispersed all over the city.
Oddly, perhaps, New Yorkers' increasing interest in healthy living also hurt the club. For one thing, a member who consumes a three-martini lunch is far more profitable for the club than a member who spends an hour playing pickup basketball.
For another, spandex-clad single people have increasingly preferred to go to clubs where they could meet other spandex-clad single people, places like health clubs. These usually cost far less that the athletic club's $1,800 annual membership.
In the early 1990's, the club's financial situation became increasingly desperate. First the club fell behind on its real estate taxes, then it had to pledge some of the revenues it gets from the Heisman Trophy to satisfy the bank that held its mortgage. By the end of 1996, things were so dire that the club's accountants expressed concern about whether it could stay in business.
Last year, the club's directors devised a plan to sell the club's building to developers led by Richard Born, a well-known hotelier who owns the Stanhope, and Steven Caspi, a Westchester developer. The developers planned to renovate the building, operate a hotel on the top floors, and lease space back to the club.
But the club's members voted against the plan. The club's lawyers said the deal was not good enough, financially. The developers' lawyers said a new board of directors at the club tried to scotch the deal because they feared losing control of their private preserve.
In any event, the developers did not give up. They sued the club to try to get it to go ahead with the deal. And last February, they bought the club's mortgage from the Bank of New York, after the club itself was unable to come up with the $5 million that the bank wanted.
That is when the club filed for bankruptcy protection, in part over worries that the developers might foreclose on the mortgage.
Throughout all this, many club members have remained blissfully unaware of the institution's peril. But others, like Mr. Dockery, were galvanized. He organized a slate of candidates for the board of directors who ran on a platform opposing any sale of the building and promising to fix the club's finances. The slate won. "I didn't want to get involved -- I was happy working on my hook shot," he said. "But I saw the club headed down the drain."
Elected in May, Mr. Dockery and his fellow directors began trying to clean up the club's rather chaotic accounting and operating practices in the hope of finding a new deal that would provide enough cash to pay off the city's $3 million tax lien.
By August, they thought they had found it. Centaur Properties tentatively agreed to lease the top floors of the building for close to $1 million a year, and spend more than $12 million to turn the dormlike rooms into suites that corporations could rent for long-term stays. Centaur would also pay the club $7 million in cash up front so that renters could use the club's athletic equipment; that money would let the club pay the city and spruce up its building.
Almost immediately, however, a snag arose. The city government had been warning the club for some time that it planned to consider designating the club's exterior as a landmark; now, it proposed holding a hearing on the matter.
This did not go over well with Centaur, which complained that such a designation would add at least $1 million to its costs and untold time to its development plans. In particular, the developer intends to punch holes in the exterior walls to put in air conditioners; much of the building's Art Deco detailing occurs under the windows, just where such holes would be likely to go.
Even if the Centaur plan goes forward, it is unclear whether the developers who hold the mortgage would be satisfied. They could declare the club in default if it does not meet certain financial targets -- even if it makes all its payments on time.
This plan "has zero chance of being successful," said the developers' lawyer, Mr. Spitzer. "Ultimately it isn't going to furnish them with the money they need to make it work."
Mr. Dockery disagrees, of course, and spent last week holding meetings with members to discuss the plan to save their club. All seemed receptive, he said, adding that he hopes to present a plan to the bankruptcy court early next month.
He has a lot of members rooting for him, including Robin Segal, who comes down from Greenwich Village to exercise at the club. "My family has been members here for years," she said, adding that this is a place her teen-age children learned to love sports.
"I hope they pull it off," she said of the plan. "It's a shame -- there's so much tradition here."
 
To Survive, Private Clubs Shed Old Ways
The decline of the Downtown Athletic Club has been mirrored at private clubs across New York City, many of which have been forced to close in recent years by changing fashions, economics and their own inefficiency.
"About four or five years ago, we drew up a list of 25 clubs that had gone out of business," said Dan Condon of Condon, O'Meara, McGinty and Donnelly, an accounting firm that specializes in clubs. "And there were only about 60 private clubs in New York in 1970."
Mr. Dutton and others said that the hardest hit have been clubs in lower Manhattan, an area that lost many businesses in the late 1980's, and smaller clubs that lack gyms or private rooms where members can stay overnight.
There are signs that things have bottomed out, Mr. Condon said: club membership is inching up again, by 2 percent to 3 percent in each of the last two years.
But that is too late for the City Midday, Drug and Chemical Club at 140 Broadway, which ceased operations in December 1997. The original City Midday Club was founded in 1901. "There was a decline in membership," said Leonard S. Dome, a lawyer who is overseeing the club's demise. "Life styles changed."
The clubs that have survived, Mr. Condon said, have done so by updating their menus, renovating their buildings and easing up on dress codes and old attitudes.
In the late 1980's, for example, the situation began to look rather grim at the Down Town Association, a club on Pine Street in lower Manhattan that dates from 1860. Membership had fallen from around 1,100 in the mid-1980's to below 500 in 1989.
But the current president, Mark R. Altherr, said the club had rebounded somewhat from those dark days. Today, membership has inched up to about 580. "We renovated the building," he said. "We brought in new management and upgraded the food."
 Alan K. Dutton, the president of the local chapter of the Club Managers Association of America and the general manager of the Yale Club, on Vanderbilt Avenue in midtown Manhattan, said that other clubs, too, were getting the message.
"They have been improving the rooms, adding fitness equipment and bringing in creative cuisine," he said. "The stuffy old club doesn't make it anymore."

HEADLINE: For the Good Book, A Good Sales Pitch

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
It was not a standard airplane banner that caught the eyes of sunbathers from Jones Beach to the Hamptons on the Labor Day weekend. Instead of hawking suntan lotion or happy hour drinks, the sign read: "Make a Friend in a Very High Place. Marble church.org."
That was the abbreviated version of a print and poster advertisement for the Marble Collegiate Church that also says: "Everyone knows it helps having friends in high places, and no one's higher than God. So stop by Marble this Sunday and make a powerful new friend. Or just strengthen your friendship with an old one." 
 God's messenger these days is as likely to be a Madison Avenue account executive as a missionary. Religious advertisements have become savvier, slicker and certainly wittier than the staid church announcements found on the religion pages of newspapers.
And they have turned up in the strangest places. In the past, church ads were generally found in magazines and newspapers and on radio broadcasts. Now, with the ascendance of a generation of clergy raised on television and video, the ads might also appear on the airborne streamer, the telephone kiosk, the construction site and the Web page.
"Folks are saying, 'If we want to reach out to people and we are not out pounding on doors, we must do something we haven't done before,' " said Roy Lloyd, the broadcast news director for the National Council of Churches, who also works in print media.
He continued: "People no longer join a church because that's where their family belonged, and denominational loyalty is a thing of the past. Today, people are looking for places that coincide with their values or challenge them in ways that are appealing. An impression built over time that mainline religion is dull and boring, and you have to give them a different perspective."
Marble Collegiate's current advertisements, which were introduced in summer resort publications like Hamptons magazine and Dan's Paper in the Hamptons and The Fire Island Tide, are now running in New York magazine, Time Out New York and The Village Voice, and are attached to boarded-up construction sites around the city. They will also go up on more than 30 telephone kiosks in December. And the airplane trailer is scheduled to make another overhead appearance on Oct. 18 at Giants Stadium, during a New York Giants-Arizona Cardinals game.
Among the five other messages in the campaign is one proclaiming: "You Don't Have to Be a Sinner To Attend Our Church. But It Helps."
That ad and others were meant to counteract the image of church as judge. "There is an enormous amount of bad feeling because of the sense that you are a sinner, you are wrong," said Dr. Arthur Caliandro, the senior minister of the church, which is at Fifth Avenue and 29th Street. "That is not what Marble is all about, nor, in fact, what true religion is about."
John Follis, president and creative director of Follis/N.Y., the church's ad agency, said: "In my 20 years in the business, I have worked on everything from Coca-Cola to infant thermometers, but never have I worked on a product that does absolutely everything and is free. Advertising Marble Church is essentially selling God."
If so, God is being sold elsewhere as well. Last fall, the Church of the Heavenly Rest, the majestic Episcopal house of worship at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street, began using similarly amusing ads and is now running two campaigns a year geared to subway poster display. A typical message: "Sex Doesn't Mean a Thing." In smaller type, it continues: "Neither does race, age, economic status, political affiliation. Or whether you believe in God. If you need help, you won't be turned down. You've got to start somewhere. Start now."
Paula Paluszek, a senior copywriter for Grey Advertising and a member of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, wrote the copy. "I didn't want them to even remotely look like church ads but to be constructively provocative," she said. "I wanted to combine a New York in-your-face challenge with a warm welcome and a promise of Christian hope." Actually, she said, she was inspired by Christ himself. "When he was working among the people, he spoke the vernacular of the time and there were compelling bold images in his parables," she said. "Some of his images were very graphic, and I took a cue from his style in a way."
New York is not alone in the phenomenon, which is being taken to an extreme in London, where Charles and Maurice Saatchi, the advertising tycoons, will open the Saatchi (named for their parents, not themselves) Synagogue this month. An ad has already appeared showing a piece of gefilte fish with the catch line, "At our new synagogue, this is the only thing which gets rammed down someone's throat."
Most religious institutions are not so brash. The Rev. James L. Burns, rector of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, had a simple goal when he broached the idea of the advertising campaign shortly after becoming its spiritual leader two years ago. "I was after two groups of people," he said, "people not affiliated with any particular church, who slog up the subway stairs each day and wonder, 'Is this all there is?' and parish members who might want to rethink what their church and their participation in it is about. When people come in who are new to the church, we ask, 'Did you see the ad?' and about 50 percent say, 'Oh, yeah.' Then we have a job delivering something worth staying for."
Still the church's goal was not primarily to bolster membership. "We are a fairly large church with 1,600 members and are in good financial shape," said the associate rector, the Rev. Steven E. Woolley. "We are not trying to bring in members for the sake of growth or to raise money. We are trying to feed the spiritual hunger, doing what God told us to do: proclaiming the good news."
Dr. Caliandro said he was disturbed by the waning assumption that church is a normal part of Sunday.
"Religious worship is no longer an expected part of what we do on Sunday," he said. Citing the lures of "staying home and washing the car, playing golf or reading the Sunday newspaper," he said, "30 years ago there would have been a fourth option. You might want to go and worship, but that is no longer in the thinking of people. In New York City, there is such intense competition for attention that religious institutions need to let people know they are there and have something to offer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marble Collegiate Church's current advertising campaign includes posters like this one at 32d Street and Second Avenue. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Postal Trucks Can Run on Ethanol, but Probably Won't

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Six years ago, with smoke from the burning oil wells of Kuwait barely cleared, Congress ordered the Federal Government to help wean America from gasoline, and decided that by 1998, half of all new Government vehicles should be able to run on an alternative fuel.
The Postal Service announced last month that to comply, it would buy 10,000 new delivery trucks that can run on ethanol or gasoline, and that the first would be delivered for use in the New York City region. 
 But while the vehicles can use ethanol, Postal Service officials say, they probably will not. That is because the nearest public ethanol station is in Indianapolis. In fact, there are only about 40 stations in the whole country that sell ethanol, according to vehicle manufacturers.
"The ethanol-capable vehicles will be all over," said a Postal Service spokeswoman, Sandra Harding. She said the vehicles would be sent wherever new trucks were needed, regardless of what fuels were available. "If they don't have ethanol available in certain areas, then the automobile will just run on gasoline," she said.
The first of the new postal vehicles, modified Ford Explorers with their steering wheels on the right so that letter carriers can easily reach mailboxes, will begin arriving in May. In New Jersey, Newark will get 100; Paterson, 53; Lakewood, 73, and Bellmawr, 50. Hicksville, on Long Island, will get 84.
State officials in New Jersey and New York said they knew of no public fueling site within their borders that sold ethanol.
Environmentalists, who have been urging the use of alternative fuels for years as a way to reduce dependence on oil and to lower auto emissions, are not happy about the outcome.
"There's an absurdity, an irrationality, having these vehicles and not having fuel for them," said Nevin Cohen, the director of research at Inform, a nonprofit environmental research group based in New York. The Federal Government, he said, had tried to be "fuel neutral," meaning that it backed a variety of alternatives to gasoline without choosing one over the others. But, he said, "This isn't fuel neutral; it's fuel nutty."
"Natural gas would have made more sense," said Mr. Cohen, who pointed out that United Parcel Service and other operators of large fleets use natural gas vehicles in the New York region. The Postal Service should send the new trucks to the Midwest, he said.
In fact, the Postal Service says that it runs 7,300 vehicles nationwide that use alternative fuels, some of them natural gas, but that some of those have to operate on gasoline because natural gas is not available. And buying a truck that can use natural gas (even if it does not) costs about $4,000 extra; buying one that can use ethanol (even if it does not) costs only about $200 extra.
Some Postal Service vehicles get their fuel from public gas pumps, but major post offices often have their own pumps. The Postal Service is resisting the idea that it should have ethanol or natural gas pumps for its own vehicles.
"We can't be a part-time utility company or a part-time oil company," said Wayne Corey, a vehicle maintenance manager with the Postal Service. "That's what those people are in business for."
Faced with the problem of meeting the 50 percent quota for vehicles that run on alternative fuels -- the quota rose to 75 percent in fiscal year 1999, which began on Oct. 1 -- the Postal Service had acted reasonably, Mr. Corey said.
The problem, he and others say, is that the continuing drop in the price of gasoline, combined with corporate streamlining by oil companies and others involved in the manufacture of vehicle fuels, has hindered the development of the alternative fuel market.
Natural gas, while cheaper than gasoline, has been handicapped by the need for expensive compressor stations and by the problem of squeezing the tanks into cars.
Ethanol, which is widely used in ordinary gasoline at blends of up to 10 percent, presents other problems. In places where it is publicly available, it is commonly sold as E-85, a blend that is 15 percent unleaded gasoline, but it costs 10 cents to 15 cents a gallon more than regular unleaded gasoline, even with various tax advantages.
Ford and Chrysler have adapted some of their vehicles for ethanol, because they get credits for doing so under the Corporate Average Fuel Economy law, as if their vehicles got better gas mileage. But it is likely that many of those vehicles will never see a drop of ethanol, either.
Ethanol's environmental and energy benefits are harder to demonstrate than those of natural gas, although the fuel is popular in Congress as a way to subsidize farmers, who grow the corn that is one of its main ingredients.
Mr. Corey pointed out that bringing in the ethanol-capable vehicles would improve air quality even if they never used ethanol, because they are new and meet the latest emission standards. They are replacing vehicles that are at least 10 years old, many of them ancient Jeeps.
David E. Rodgers, director of the Energy Department's office of technology utilization, said he was working with officials at the Postal Service to ship the new trucks to places where ethanol is available, even though the purchase contract with Ford specified where they would be delivered.
"The groups that procure vehicles are using systems they have had in place for 50 years," he said. "The groups that are promoting alternative fuels are usually in another part of the organization, and getting those groups to work together is a problem."
Dennis M. Baca, manager of environmental policy at the Postal Service, said that he was meeting with corn growers and ethanol manufacturers to try to increase the supply of fuel, and that the new vehicles, which will begin arriving in May, would be kept together to make it easier to supply ethanol to them.
When introducing a new fuel, Mr. Baca said, there has always been a question about which would come first, the fuel or the vehicles that use it. But he said he hoped the Government's commitment to the new trucks would encourage suppliers and other companies to try alternative fuels, too. "We are taking some risks," he said, "in hopes the rest of the country recognizes we all are better served by clean air."

HEADLINE: Brio Is Gone, but Brazil's Leader May Be Back

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 3

 BODY:
With their vast country struggling against economic collapse that could usher high inflation back in, and with a $30 billion rescue package in the balance, Brazilians are expected to re-elect President Fernando Henrique Cardoso on Sunday, rejecting the three-time candidate of the left, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.
But the euphoria of four years ago, when Mr. Cardoso rode to victory on a plan for ending inflation and modernizing the role of the state, has disappeared. The Real Plan, named for the new currency, the real, has been crippled by the Government's failure to rein in spending. This time Brazilians are bracing for a morning after marked by austerity, recession, joblessness and tax increases. 
 Jolted by the economic breakdowns in Asia and Russia, the Brazilian stock market has been stumbling through the year like a battered giant, crashing and resurging time and again, losing 41 percent of its value since January. About $30 billion in foreign reserves have fled Brazil for safer havens since Russia's market collapse in late August.
Until recently a prized market for direct foreign investment, Brazil is now feared as the country most likely to draw the storms of Asia to American shores. Foreign investors are watching Brazil closely, in the expectation that a triumphant President Cardoso will tackle reforms immediately. A $30 billion International Monetary Fund plan to salvage Brazil's faltering economy also depends on a Cardoso victory.
Though congressional seats and state houses in this nation of 160 million people are also at stake, attention is focusing almost entirely on the presidential race.
"This last year has brought a new uncertainty," said Antonio Carlos Alkimin, director of population studies at the Brazilian Institute for Geography and Statistics. "People are voting more against inflation and against a leftist government than with a sense of optimism over what will happen when Fernando Henrique wins."
So far the crisis is like a dark cloud hovering offshore. A Central Bank doubling of interest rates to stanch the outflow of dollars braked industrial expansion, and unemployment is the highest in 15 years. But deeper cuts in Government services, public sector layoffs, tax increases and other drastic measures are on hold until after the President's presumed re-election, as are the terms Brazil will have to meet for the I.M.F. bailout.
Polls predict that Mr. Cardoso, who won a constitutional amendment allowing presidents to run for re-election, will become the first Brazilian President to succeed himself. He is expected to take 47 percent of Sunday's vote, a large enough amount to avoid run-off elections on Oct. 25. His nearest rival, Mr. da Silva of the Workers Party, was projected to win 24 percent. Ciro Gomes, a former Finance Minister, is expected to take 9 percent of the vote. And an excitable surgeon known simply as Eneas, who calls for Brazil to build an atomic bomb, is expected to get 2 percent.
As the election approaches, the images and slogans of candidates across the political spectrum have been multiplying, their banners fluttering from trees and lampposts. In the twice-daily free television time that has become the centerpiece of political campaigns, the two leading candidates present visions of themselves and Brazil that could hardly be more at odds.
President Cardoso's television programs feature a determinedly upbeat country, with a chorus of smiling teen-agers singing the President's praises and exhorting voters to turn out for him. Though Mr. Cardoso used part of his air time to rebroadcast a speech he made warning of postelection fiscal adjustments, his message has been one of stability and prosperity.
"All of our efforts, all of our achievements, cannot end when we're only halfway there," the President said in his final broadcast on Thursday night. "In the middle of a world crisis, a country with so many resources and possibilities, a country with so much international support, which gains more respect abroad each day, whose people are serious and hard-working, has no reason to change direction."
The program for Mr. da Silva, who is universally known as Lula, features black-and-white footage of him marching against the military dictatorship that ended in 1985 and commiserating with the poor. A former president of the Metalworkers Union, Mr. da Silva left school to begin working at 15, and lost a finger operating a lathe.
This election, Mr. da Silva traded the berets and polo shirts of the past for suits and measured speech, but his ideas remain far to the left of Mr. Cardoso's. He opposes a deal with the I.M.F. and says Brazil's priority should be Brazilians' social needs.
"I've never accepted that a country as rich as ours should have so much inequality, so much misery," said Mr. da Silva. "The banks and the international speculators can wait."
Mr. Cardoso has also committed gaffes that have fed into the Workers Party's image of him as a leader removed from the problems of the masses.
During his administration's so-far-unsuccessful push to restructure social security benefits, Mr. Cardoso said people who wanted to retire early were "bums." Although the President later explained that he meant to attack professionals who retire after 20 or 25 years, millions of Brazilian pensioners who had begun their working lives as children felt themselves maligned.
Worse yet, word leaked that the 67-year-old President has himself been collecting a pension, currently at $4,300 a month, ever since Brazil's military dictatorship forced him to stop teaching at the University of Sao Paulo in 1969. Although the President could have returned to teaching 10 years later, he chose to keep the pension instead.
Sergio Amaral, the President's spokesman, said Mr. Cardoso saw no reason to give up the pension, since he had been "retired by an arbitrary act of the military Government, and he continued working for the country as politician and then President." He said Mr. Cardoso gave up a second pension he could have collected for having been a Senator.
And in an August speech at the Parque Royale slum outside Rio, the President stunned residents when he said: "There's no way to make everybody rich. I don't even know if it's worth the trouble, because the life of a rich person, in general, is very boring."
He later explained that as a working man he did not count himself wealthy, but that only made his misstep worse. President Cardoso's $6,000-a-month base salary, along with his pension, puts him in the top 2 percent of Brazilians who make more than $2,100 a month, according to Government statistics.
"I'm one of the bums," announced Milton Peixoto, 64, a retired bus driver, adding that there was no way he would vote for President Cardoso. "Last time I voted for him, but this time, he can go to hell. My life's only gotten worse."
The Real Plan tamed inflation but has done little to redress Brazil's startling inequalities. According to the Brazilian Institute of Applied Economic Research, the country's income distribution is the most unequal in the world, with the richest 10 percent of the population collecting 50 percent of it. Nearly 70 percent of Brazil's voters have less than a primary school education, and half of them are considered barely literate.
But many Brazilians see Mr. Cardoso as the only candidate capable of taking the country forward. For example Licinio Franco, a representative for a check protection service here, confessed pride at the figure that his President cuts overseas. A consummate charmer, Mr. Cardoso speaks languages including French, English and Spanish, and sometimes greets foreign visitors by offering their choice of language.
And Mr. Franco said he stood a bit taller upon hearing that a German counterfeit gang was caught making 10- and 50-real bills.
"Now they don't want to counterfeit the dollar, it's the real," he said. "Our money is worth something."
Rosely de Faria Lemos, 50, who runs an advertising agency, said she considered Mr. da Silva "full of good intentions" but ill-prepared to run Brazil.
"He's a guy who's kind of from another era and space," she said, "who has no experience managing anything. He wasn't even mayor. How can we give him the country to run? In one way or another, Fernando Henrique can ease this crisis."

INTERNATIONAL 3-17
 
Crisis-Striken Nations Gather for I.M.F. Meeting
Finance ministers of the world's largest industrial nations agreed tonight to explore President Clinton's proposal on Friday to change the strategy of the International Monetary Fund and allow it to intervene earlier in propping up economies that are at risk of being swept into the global financial turmoil. 1 

Brazilians Vote for President
With their country facing economic collapse and with a $30 billion rescue package in the balance, Brazilians are expected to re-elect President Fernando Henrique Cardoso today and to reject the candidate of the left, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. 8
 
Pope Beatifies a Croat
Pope John Paul II beatified Alojzije Cardinal Stepinac, the World War II archbishop of Zagreb who was later imprisoned by the Tito regime as a Nazi collaborator. The Cardinal is a national hero to millions of Croats, but to many others he is regarded as a sympathizer of a Nazi puppet regime that killed tens of thousands of Serbs, Jews and Gypsies. 13
 
Mongolian Democrat Killed
The President of Mongolia appealed for calm after the killing of a prominent democracy leader deepened the country's long political crisis. Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, 36, a Minister in the governing Democratic Coalition and a possible candidate for Prime Minister, was axed and stabbed to death at his home late Friday. 16
 
Australian Leader Holds On
Prime Minister John Howard of Australia appeared to have narrowly clung to power in nationwide voting after calling an early election on the issue of tax reform. 6
 
NATIONAL 18-38
 
White House Described As Place of Intrigue
Secret Service testimony shows the White House as a place not just of grandeur and high purpose, but also of intrigue, sometimes juvenile, and of mordant humor about the President's private life. One overwhelming impression from the newly released documents is how little privacy the President actually has, his movements traced almost by the step from his bedroom to his office. 33
 
Former President Gerald R. Ford suggested that the most fitting punishment for President Clinton would be a rebuke in the well of the House, a recommendation that could prove beneficial in Mr. Clinton's effort to short-circuit the impeachment process. 33
 
Religious Thrillers
"Left Behind," a series of four books of apocalyptic fiction describing the return of Jesus Christ to take the genuine Christians to heaven, made publishing history in September when all four of the books ascended to the top four slots on Publishers Weekly magazine's lists of religion best-sellers in hardcover and paperback. The "Left Behind" phenomenon, scholars say, is one indication of the public's fixation on the millennium and the widespread anticipation that the year 2000 portends some earth-shattering event. 1
 
Fugitive May Be Charged

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1407 words

HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTERS AGREE TO EXPLORE CLINTON I.M.F. PLAN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Finance ministers of the world's largest industrial nations said tonight that they would explore President Clinton's proposal to alter the strategy of the International Monetary Fund, so that it can intervene earlier in propping up economies at risk of being swept into the global financial turmoil.
The lukewarm endorsement of the White House initiative came in a vaguely worded communique tonight, following an all-day meeting here that appeared to break little new ground on how to quell the financial turmoil circling the globe. The session opened five days of scheduled talks among leaders of the major economies, as well as many from smaller, shell-shocked countries trying to keep their economies from being carried away in the storm. 
 As the sessions opened, the Administration was facing unusual challenges from Europe, Japan and emerging-market nations, each of which is arriving with different and even contradictory strategies for stabilizing the global economy.
The clash of approaches began to play out this morning, as Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin sat down with Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa. And it carried through the meeting this afternoon of finance ministers and central bank governors of the Group of Seven -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan -- and it reflects the extraordinary tension and the behind-the-scenes power struggles under way as the I.M.F. and the World Bank open their annual meeting here.
After months of market plunges, currency devaluations, bank failures and bankruptcies across the globe, governments are searching desperately for some kind of coordinated approach that can halt some of the most virulent economic turmoil in half a century.
But it will not be easy, officials concede. As the meetings opened, Mr. Miyazawa announced a $30 billion Japanese program to aid stricken countries throughout Asia, a scaled down version of a program the United States sunk last year. The Japanese aid program includes government loans, the purchase of bonds issued by Asian countries and guarantees that private bank loans will be repaid. While Southeast Asian countries hailed the move, the Administration's response was lukewarm. Mr. Rubin said on Friday, even before the announcement, that Japan's action was "constructive," but that getting its own banks in order and its huge economy restarted was "by vast multiples more important."
Mr. Miyazawa, a former Prime Minister who has 40 years of experience dealing with the United States, shot back today that Mr. Clinton's proposals for new strategies for how the I.M.F. could choke off crises before they start "would not be very convincing unless the United States' commitments to the I.M.F. are lived up to." He was referring to the refusal by Congress to approve $18 billion in new money for the fund, an issue that Senate and House conferees will debate next week.
At a news conference tonight, Mr. Rubin said that at today's meeting "there was a strong expression from a number of members about the importance of the United States fulfilling its commitments." He appeared to be attempting to use the condemnations to push passage of the I.M.F. funding, and to suggest that if Congress refuses it will imperil American global financial leadership.
Mr. Clinton, attempting to bolster that leadership at a moment when his ability to lead is under intense scrutiny, will take the unusual step of taking part directly on Monday in a crucial meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from 22 countries. And on Tuesday, he will speak to the entire I.M.F., which represents 182 countries, in his second major speech on the world economy in three weeks.
The President set the urgent tone of the meetings on Friday, when he declared that the world was on a "financial precipice." But Mr. Clinton, who last spring was resisting advice that he become far more publicly involved in dealing with the world's financial chaos, insisted that it was not too late to act.
A dramatic initiative to stop the financial contagion may come within days as the fund, the Treasury Department and Brazil's Finance Minister, Pedro Malan, complete a package of $30 billion or more to stabilize the Brazilian economy.
Mr. Rubin met with Mr. Malan at the Treasury late Friday, and there was considerable speculation that the package could be announced as soon as voting is completed on Sunday in Brazil's presidential election. The vote is expected to result in the re-election of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso. Administration officials say they fear that a financial meltdown in Brazil would take the rest of Latin America and Mexico with it, and bring the crisis to the United States' borders.
Nonetheless, the cacophony of competing ideas suggests that it will be very difficult to get agreement on a common agenda from countries facing a varied array of problems -- deep recession and mass unemployment in Southeast Asia, political paralysis in Russia and Indonesia, huge bank failures in Japan, an incipient currency crisis in Brazil, but continued prosperity in Western Europe and the United States.
The United States, for instance, is insisting that there be no backing away from a decade-long move toward freer and more open financial markets around the world.
But the Japanese and Southeast Asians are talking about "capital controls" that would re-impose government regulation to prevent investors from moving billions in short-term investments from one country to another with a few taps on the computer keyboard.
The French, meanwhile, want to increase the power of the committee that oversees the monetary fund, a proposal that seemed to leave Mr. Rubin distinctly unenthusiastic tonight. But, like President Clinton's ideas for the I.M.F., it was included in the vague communique, which touched on almost every major proposal to address the crisis without expressing particular enthusiasm for any.
The communique did include an unusually critical assessment of Japan, saying that its "challenges have intensified significantly in recent months." It specifically waded in to the hottest issue in Japanese domestic politics, calling on Japan to find a way to pour taxpayer money into viable Japanese banks "in sufficient amounts."
Meanwhile, Russia is threatening to default on its loans unless it is quickly given billions that the fund suspended when President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed his team of economic reformers and violated the terms of his accord for Western aid.
A senior fund official said last week that Russia's threats were "a form of blackmail," but that the enormous turbulence set off by the Russian financial debacle last month gives real teeth to Russia's threats. Two Russian representatives joined part of today's talks.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Rubin met again this morning to formulate their own strategies to calm the financial markets and keep the worst effects of the recession from hitting American shores, where exports and corporate profits are already badly affected.
The most immediate of those strategies, described by the President on Friday, would permit the fund to use its finances to help fundamentally healthy economies ward off global economic contagion.
Currently the fund intervenes with billions in emergency aid only after disaster strikes and investors are fleeing. But by that time, the country's currency is under attack, and a bailout can cost far more and often involves austerity measures -- from budget cuts to high interest rates -- that lead to soaring unemployment and political backlash.
So Mr. Rubin and Mr. Greenspan proposed a newer, faster-moving mechanism for pumping money into countries that Mr. Rubin said today were "being hit primarily by contagion," rather than punished for bad policy. The White House indicated earlier in the day that Mr. Clinton's proposal had already been agreed to by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Jacques Chirac of France, but diplomats said there were still reservations from Germany and Japan.
The Group of Seven sounded less enthusiastic. But Mr. Rubin said "there was a shared view that while this crisis began in countries that had substantial problems, now the contagion is affecting countries that had strong reform programs." Investors do not seem to care: Many are withdrawing money from all emerging markets in a flight to low-risk investments.

HEADLINE: It's Time to Regulate Hedge Funds

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Only by giving hedge-fund transactions the necessary oversight will we reduce the possibility of systemic risk to our economy (front page, Oct. 2). The crux of the problem is the lack of disclosure required from counterparties to trades and the clearing members who ultimately process these transactions. 
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is rightly concerned that too much regulation would send these transactions overseas to countries with looser regulations. But at what price do we give traders the luxury of making bets without oversight?
That oversight exists on the floor of our major stock and commodities exchanges, and this gives investors and traders the comfort of knowing that an exchange is insuring that positions are being properly margined for risk even after losses start piling up.
 
ANDREW FURMAN
Maplewood, N.J., Oct. 2, 1998
 
The writer is a commodities trader.

HEADLINE: It's Time to Regulate Hedge Funds

 BODY:

To the Editor:
One thing that cannot be allowed to happen is the support of players who fail. Long-Term Capital Management should have been allowed to collapse (Op-Ed, Sept. 30). The Federal Reserve Bank of New York's involvement in the bailout greatly increases "moral hazard" -- the risk that other institutions will continue behaving in the same profligate manner. This idea that, whatever happens, someone will help out is what brought the Asian tigers to their knees. 
 Investors realized the tigers were paper and fled; economic collapse followed. Nothing is more "paper" than the derivatives that Long-Term played with. Losers in this game should not be allowed to continue playing.
 
PETER M. GATES
Brooklyn, Sept. 30, 1998

HEADLINE: Sept. 27-Oct. 3;
Fed Cuts Interest Rate

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
For nearly a month, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had hinted that the global financial crisis might force the central bank to put aside its concern about inflation and cut interest rates. On Tuesday he acted, leading the Fed to cut its key interest rate by a quarter point, to 5.25 percent. 
 The move should give a small boost to the domestic economy by reducing borrowing costs a bit for consumers and businesses. But with concern growing that the global crisis could spread and endanger the long American expansion, Mr. Greenspan mainly wanted to send a message that he was on the case. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: COLLECTING;
A Cup Of Charm

BYLINE: By Dulcie Leimbach; Dulcie Leimbach's last article for the Home Design magazine was on the resurgence of wallpaper.

 BODY:
You'd have to be an ogre to deny the charms of children's china. even a hard-biled chief financial officer with zero time for frivolity wouldn't be able to resist eating from a plate that depicts boys jousting and says: "Thump away Jack -- Take care of his head./Tis all in good fun. Now hit him hard, Ned."
Not all children's china captures childlike sentiments with such humor and resonance. But most of the china that has been produced for children since the 1790's, when the industry was born, has remained universally endearing. Children's china speaks to everyone; it's one of the few objects that can make you believe for a moment that you're still an innocent, no matter what business you're in. 
 As Sharon Gater, a research assistant for the Wedgwood Museum, in Stoke-on-Trent, England, says emphatically, "Children's china is very much wanted by everybody."
Luckily, its sweet-natured quality has made it impervious to fashion and trends. Highly collectible, children's china brings prices that aren't staggering, though they do make you blink. A 19th-century Staffordshire cup with a popular name like Joseph can cost $300 at James II Galleries in Manhattan, while a plate with a cute saying, circa 1840, can be as much as $625 at Bardith, an antiques emporium on the Upper East Side. At the Country Dining Room Antiques, in Great Barrington, Mass., alphabet plates, always in demand, are $150 to $275 apiece.
"The rarest things are fetching $1,000," says Richard Dennis, the pre-eminent British expert on children's china and the publisher of "Gifts for Good Children," the definitive book on the subject, written by Noel Riley and Maureen Batkin.
The two-volume book, distributed in this country by the Antique Collectors' Club in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., aids both novice and experienced collectors by documenting in detail the advent of children's china in Britain and, by export, in America.
Most children's china is earthenware, also known as pottery; consisting of plates and cups (or mugs), it was meant to be functional. Porcelain pieces, which are rare, were mostly bought by the wealthy as baptismal gifts. Yet some experts wonder whether plates with elaborate borders were actually meant for children or for decoration, and whether plates with prints that might appeal to grown-ups were intended for both generations.
What is certain, though, is that most children's china over the centuries has been produced in Britain, thanks to its robust ceramics industry and, some have argued, its attitude toward children. Although Japan and France only dabbled in this type of china, and Germany produced it mostly for export, Britain was apparently more sympathetic toward children and saw the economic value of catering to citizens eager to buy gifts for their little ones.
Production may have begun in Britain in 1790, but very few pieces were made that early, and even fewer have survived. But as the economy prospered, and the culture became more benevolent toward, and fascinated by, the very young, the use of transfer printing for ceramics coincided with a marked increase in the publication of children's books. Soon, many prints from these books, particularly nursery rhymes and the alphabet, were appearing on plates and cups. Supper in the British household would never be the same.
"This was the first obvious evidence of sentimental prints involving children being used on cheap pottery," says Robin Hildyard, an assistant curator in the ceramics and glass department of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. "I think these things were used in cottages and farmhouses, not bought by people with a lot of money." Small mugs adults used to drink strong beer may have been used by children as well, he adds, noting that fancy tableware for the young was unusual.
In "Gifts for Good Children," however, Riley writes that when decorated pottery started, it was "a luxury available only to the wealthy and ends when developments in mass production enabled cheap ceramics to find a place in the homes of the working classes." Early wares, she observes, tend to depict elegantly dressed children, while mid-19th-century china scenes have more universal appeal, with not as many children riding ponies.
Letitia Roberts, senior international specialist in European ceramics at Sotheby's in New York, agrees with Riley. "You would have to have had a certain level of wherewithal to have such china for your children," she says.
No one factory dominated the children's china industry. Minton, Staffordshire and Wedgwood were only three of dozens in the business. The early wares, issued before the 1850's, are generally considered superior. Everyone concurs that by the mid-19th century, the prints on the plates and mugs became sloppier, reflecting a more rapid, higher-volume production. Overall, the 19th century yielded a huge array of designs heavily focused on the family. These plates and cups became icons of sociability, conveyors of morality and tools for educating.
"All the humanitarian things that went on -- reforms and acts that banned small children from working in factories," Hildyard says, created feelings toward children that had not been evident in earlier centuries.
In the 20th century, the world wars slowed the production of children's china, and in the 50's, plastic began to overtake earthenware as the primary material, eroding the ware's overall value. Yet some of this century's china is as collectible as the previous century's. Early Mickey Mouse and Beatrix Potter designs are feverishly sought after, as is the work of Eric Ravilious, who was a designer for Wedgwood before he served as an official war artist and was killed in 1942. Nursery ware by Susie Cooper, a British ceramic artist and modernist known for her flamboyant colors, is also prized.
Whatever their provenance, ABC plates and mugs with names on them are mostly available in the United States and in Britain, although the Japanese are very avid buyers. In Britain, the source of most material, the market is particularly active.
Richard Dennis says there is plenty of children's china about. "You just have to spend time looking for it, being inquisitive," he observes. "An awful lot was made; an awful lot was damaged. But a lot is still surviving." On the other side of the Atlantic, however, you hear different views. Stuart Slavid, the director of fine ceramics for Skinner, the Boston auction house, feels that such china is no longer as plentiful. "There were good deals 15 years ago," he says. "It's not a secret anymore."
At Sotheby's in New York, children's china has not been auctioned since the 70's, probably because prices are still not high enough to warrant business. "We haven't seen a big group of mugs in years," says Letitia Roberts. Yet she says that children's tableware is "collectible at an affordable level." It can be found, she adds, "in antiques shops and out-of-the-way places."
For the collector, a Benjamin Franklin maxim on a 19th-century plate may offer the best advice: "Plow deep while sluggards sleep; and you shall have corn to sell and to keep."
Robin Hildyard suggests that collectors interested in an investment find pieces that haven't been "bashed and broken and chewed." Dennis, on the other hand, says collectors shouldn't be completely put off by damage, since these pieces were subjected to heavy use.
"Buy what you like; that's always my advice," says Edith Wolf, the owner of Bardith.
"Gifts for Good Children" is a solid source of information on the almost endless categories that make up children's china. They include flora and fauna, mottoes, religious morals, school lessons, country life, animals, children's stories and nursery rhymes, caricatures and cartoons, occupations and trades, games and pastimes. Then there are secondary design considerations, like borders, swags, raised daisy images and florets. Color is another asset: the more colorful the piece, the more expensive it is. Yellow ware, also known as canary ware, is highly valued.
Other enhancements -- raised decorations, enamels, hand-painting and the quality of the transfer printing -- are more clues to a ware's importance, says Slavid. "All the little things change the interest level or sophistication," he notes.
A manufacturer's name has little bearing, most specialists say. "There's nothing wrong with being unmarked," Slavid says. "You can get a marked one that's poor quality and a superior one that's unmarked."
What ultimately leads buyers to children's china is a purely visceral reaction. On a plate, the scene or the saying is what captivates a buyer. For a cup, the name it bears may be the big attraction. "Everyone wants Mary or Sarah or Elizabeth," says Barbara Munves, who owns James II Galleries. "Hannah or Martha are easier to find." For boys, George and Henry are easy to come by, but Robert, she adds, is rarer.
Still, as Sheila Chefetz, the proprietor of the Country Dining Room Antiques, puts it, "The English made something for everyone." Including Ruby Davis, an interior designer in Providence, R.I., who has been sifting through flea markets and antiques stores seeking that special fragile cup or plate for 40 years. "I have collected by color, by sentiment, by what it says," she notes. "Price means nothing."

HEADLINE: Getting the Big Picture;
The Film Industry Started Here and Left. Now It's Back, and the State Says the Sequel Is Huge.

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
MERYL STREEP came to Maplewood for "One True Thing." Scott Rudin brought Kevin Kline to Montclair for "In and Out." Harrison Ford stalked through Newark City Hall in "Presumed Innocent." Nicolas Cage and Matt Damon stormed Atlantic City for "Snake Eyes" and "Rounders," respectively. Jim Jarmusch is in Jersey City now, for "Ghost Day." Woody Allen worked at the Jersey City Armory for "Deconstructing Harry" and in Atlantic City for "Celebrity"; he is planning to cross the George Washington Bridge again this month for his next project. Norman Jewison will be here, too, to recreate the story of the boxer Hurricane Carter.
They're all filming. 
 In gracious, leafy suburbs and glitzy casinos, in gritty urban streets and cavernous armories, the bustle of movie making is back in the state where it all started. In a West Orange laboratory a century ago, Thomas Alva Edison created the technology that put moving images on screen. His inventions spawned an industry that did much of its early filming in Fort Lee. Even the word cliffhanger has its roots in New Jersey: early action movies took advantage of the dramatic crags of the Palisades.
By 1920, for several reasons, the action here had virtually ceased. But over the last two decades, New Jersey's share of the vast flow of filmmaking dollars has grown from almost nothing to more than $53 million annually, money spent on everything from lumber for building sets to rentals of hotel rooms and office space to salaries for local crews. The projects embrace big-budget Hollywood productions, television projects, music videos, documentaries, commercials and independent films shot on a shoestring. A Production Services Directory for the state, published this year for the first time, lists 120 pages of services for filmmakers, from animal training to antique-car rentals to entertainment law offices. About 80 percent of the state's 566 municipalities have designated film liaisons. The New Jersey chapter of the Association of Independent Video and Filmmakers is just over a year old, and vibrant at its monthly meetings. Several small film festivals keep alternatives to mainstream Hollywood fare alive.
"It's worked out better than I hoped," said former Gov. Brendan Byrne, who has a law practice in Roseland. It was under his administration, with his backing, that the New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Commission was created in 1978.
"Filmmaking isn't getting big in New Jersey," said its longtime executive director, Joseph Friedman. "It is big."
In fact, New Jersey has come so far that the questions facing it now are of a high order. Can the state establish itself within the film world as a center in itself, something more than a place that can absorb Manhattan's overflow -- something it never was, even in its filming heyday? Even now, few of the scores of pictures made here are actually set in New Jersey. And can filmmakers do what Bruce Springsteen did in music: create an acme and epitome of homegrown character?
Perhaps. One much-rumored development -- the creation of an international film festival -- is under way, with a tentative agreement between its organizers and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark to schedule the festival for next Aug. 5 to 8. David Marciano, a Newark-born actor, and Bernard Gluckstern, a West Coast businessman, said they were choosing a board and raising a $10,000 deposit to rent the arts center. Such an event could provide a needed springboard for the state's filmmakers. Kevin Smith of Red Bank, for example, had to take his 1994 hit "Clerks" out of state to the Independent Feature Film Festival at the Angelika Film Center in Manhattan, then to the Sundance Film Festival in Utah, before Miramax picked it up.
Another crucial step remains to be taken. Plans have stalled this year for two huge production centers: a 30,000-square-foot complex in Paterson and an even larger studio in Harrison.
"We have a very successful transient business," Mr. Friedman said. "And we've always envisioned an industry here. But you need a studio."
 
In the Beginning, There Was Edison
Even if New Jersey gets neither studio nor festival, it is still benefiting more from the industry than it has in about 80 years. And surprisingly, some of the responsibility for first leading the industry out here, then driving it out, falls to the same man who created it in the first place: Edison.
Although Edison created his inventions in New Jersey, the first flowering of film companies occurred in Manhattan. There, the companies could find booking agents, actors, vaudeville performers, and costume and set designers. Edison opened a permanent studio on West 21st Street in 1901, said Richard Koszarski, a professor of film at Rutgers University and the former curator at American Museum of the Moving Image, who has been working on a history of East Coast filming for 20 years.
Around 1908, film companies started doing more location work to satisfy an audience that had rapidly become too sophisticated to accept painted backdrops, and Fort Lee was the location most accessible to New York. Business offices remained in New York while the studios -- big glass constructions similar to greenhouses, since artificial light was not yet reliable -- began clustering on the Palisades. D. W. Griffith, Mack Sennett, Edwin S. Porter and many other major filmmakers worked there.
Edison, who aggressively defended his patents, formed a consortium of film companies that agreed to use only his machinery, Mr. Koszarski said. Those that couldn't afford the patent fees were the first independents, including Centaur Film Company in Bayonne business, which made some of the first westerns. Violent enforcement of the patents was not uncommon, Mr. Koszarski said.
Eventually, Edison's Patent Company was broken up, Mr. Koszarski said, and the competition took over. By the early 1910's, he said, some film companies were already building the studio equivalent of summer houses in California. Then they realized the western studios worked better, thanks to California's year-round sunshine, cheap real estate, few unions and lack of patent disputes.
The most serious blow to the East Coast industry came just after World War I, when studios couldn't get the coal to feed the generators to make the electricity to run the machinery. "Three-quarters of the film companies just shut down and said, 'We're going to the summer house,' " Mr. Koszarski said. "Most of them never came back."
The flu epidemic of the era also hurt the industry, said another historian, Paul C. Spehr, who created an exhibition and a book about New Jersey's film history for the Newark Museum in 1977. "Thousands of movie theaters had to be shut down," since they were exactly the sort of places where the highly contagious disease could spread, he said. "And if you read Variety of the era, you see that people in the industry were dying of the flu -- sometimes 10 a week."
The Marx Brothers added an interesting coda to Fort Lee's swan song, said Robert Farhi, a Fort Lee writer who checked out a local legend with several Marx scholars. In the fall of 1920, while performing at a vaudeville club in Fort Lee, the brothers made their first feature film, "Humor Risk." Reportedly an abysmal failure, it was either turned into guitar picks, lost in a taxi or burned.
 
Slights, Camera And Finally Action
More than three decades passed before the next real attempt at New Jersey filmmaking, with "On the Waterfront" in Hoboken in 1954. But the widely acclaimed film created no momentum. The turning point came in the late 1970's, as New Jersey headed into its worst recession since the Depression. Governor Byrne was looking for ways to attract business that would not add to the state's pollution problems, as well as ways to improve the state's image.
He had lunch with Sidney Kinglsey, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, who had been to Mr. Spehr's film exhibition at the Newark Museum and happened to be married to Madge Evans, a former child movie star who had worked in Fort Lee.
"We were discussing the potential of New Jersey, the fact that the industry really started here, that it was a natural," Mr. Byrne recalled. "We discussed how the ambiance would be better in New Jersey than in New York. It would be easier to mobilize things. Labor problems weren't as difficult."
Kinglsey, who died in 1995, became the first chairman of the motion picture commission. Since 1978, film-related spending in the state has totaled about $500 million, estimates the commission, whose own annual budget is less than $300,000. With a staff of four, it helps filmmakers with everything from location scouting to negotiating with neighborhood groups.
Neil Machliss, a producer who filmed "I.Q." with Meg Ryan, Tim Robbins and Walter Matthau in Princeton in 1994, said the commission had been extremely helpful.
"We needed to do some filming in the town of Princeton, and we had to appear before the City Council," he recalled. "They came up with a strategy of how to approach them. And if we wanted to shoot somewhere that was owned by the government, they were very helpful. If I could do a movie in New Jersey, I'd do it in a second."
Even small-scale filmmakers receive help. Marylou Tibaldo-Bongiorno studied under Spike Lee at New York University's film school and made "1967," her thesis film, in her native Newark. Set against the riots that tore the city apart, the film, which she hopes to expand to feature length, is the story of an Italian-American draft dodger from the Ninth Ward.
She said the motion picture commission was very helpful, especially in dealing with the city government. "For one scene, which is a big vigilante response to the riots, we needed to have people with rifles on the streets of Newark," she said. "It went from 'You couldn't do it' to 'Well, we did it.' "
New Jersey, historically known as the "barrel tapped at two ends" by New York and Philadelphia, is now a creative market tapped at two ends, by New York and California. But the work of a few widely known Jersey filmmakers points to something like a state character. They include John Sayles, who put Hoboken on the independents' map in 1982 with "Baby, It's You"; Mr. Smith, who followed "Clerks" with "Mallrats" (1995) and "Chasing Amy" (1997), and Todd Solondz, who directed the 1995 "Welcome to the Dollhouse" as well as "Happiness," now playing at the New York Film Festival.
And many more artists are making films in and about the state. April Allridge, who lives in Highland Park, is making a digital video documentary about women who served in World War II. John Schnall, an animator, started a new film on Wednesday in his home in Belleville. Emily Hubley, another animator whose films has been shown at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan, works from her home in Maplewood. And Ken Rodgers, who studied film theory in Rutgers Cinema Studies Program and earned a degree in film production at the University of Southern California, said he was hoping to return.
"So many people think of New Jersey as the turnpike," he said. "I want to tell the stories that reside off the exits."
These filmmakers are nurtured by the New Jersey Film Festival and the Super 8 Film and Video Festival, sponsored by the Rutgers Film Coop; several programs put together by Projected Images of Hudson County in Hoboken; the Newark Black Film Festival; the Black Maria Film and Video Festival (named after Edison's first film lab), which travels the nation; the New Jersey Film Series in Secaucus, and a few private theaters.
But will it add up to a New Jersey school of film? Mr. Smith, for one, said even the idea confused him. "I've heard people say 'Clerks' and 'Chasing Amy' were very New Jersey films," he said. "I was never quite sure what they meant."

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 2; Editorial Desk
