HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Exiting Medicare is not a sure solution for H.M.O. woes.

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim 

 BODY:
THE managed care companies that unloaded 250,000 elderly Medicare customers last week will have healthier financial statements to show for it, starting in the first half of 1999. But many Wall Street analysts said that dropping Medicare units in dozens of unprofitable markets would not be enough to pull the health maintenance organizations out of a three-year earnings slump.
Health care costs are rising, and the H.M.O.'s cannot be sure that big employers will fully accept the large premium increases for next year that the companies need to turn around their earnings. 
 Many of the biggest H.M.O.'s announced that they would close their units in areas where the Government payments were too low to cover rising costs, including suburbs north of New York City, the Washington area and rural Northern California. Some H.M.O.'s are also leaving places where they had a relatively small presence; the United Healthcare Corporation, for example, is closing its Medicare unit in Dallas.
But Roberta Walter, a health care analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that those H.M.O.'s that kept a big Medicare operation would continue to suffer, even though earnings were rising on nongovernment business. "It is conceivable that improvement on the commercial side could be offset by deterioration on the Medicare side," she said.
The remaining Medicare units will not lose money, she said, but they will not grow robustly. And if the H.M.O.'s raise rates and reduce benefits, they will not sign up thousands of new members as they did in past years, when Government payments were rising 6 percent to 10 percent a year and the companies could offer generous benefits and still turn a handsome profit.
Congress has placed a 2-percent-a-year ceiling on increases in the rates the Government pays, and Federal officials have so far rebuffed requests to let the industry postpone compliance with new regulations and cut back some benefits offered to H.M.O. members.
H.M.O. executives are "livid" with anger, said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. The Federal Health Care Financing Administration required them to set their benefit package for 1999 last May and then announced regulations in June that will add to the cost of doing business. The agency rejected a request last week from the industry to reopen the benefits issues. "It was a double cross," Mr. Abramowitz said.
Federal officials insist that they are promoting both Medicare H.M.O.'s and traditional fee-for-service H.M.O.'s. But Mr. Abramowitz said he thought that the Federal financing agency "regards H.M.O.'s as competitors; it's like asking the Post Office to set rates for Federal Express."
Medicare units cost United Healthcare $120 million in reduced earnings and cost Aetna Inc. $60 million, Mr. Abramowitz said. But he said there would be "money to be made next year," when the impact of the pullbacks in the Medicare units becomes clear. He predicted that United Healthcare, Aetna and the Cigna Corporation would be the first to attract investors, after the companies report their first- and second-quarter earnings.
Ms. Walter was more cautious. She recommends a handful of managed care companies, largely because they do not have a big stake in Medicare. Her picks include Wellpoint Health Networks, Cigna and Trigon Healthcare, a publicly traded Blue Cross plan based in Richmond.
In the New York region, even though Oxford Health Plans announced it was dropping 26,600, or 17 percent, of its Medicare members, Ms. Walter said she had kept a low rating, "neutral, neutral," on the stock. She said that Oxford's turnaround plan faced "a very tough industry environment, with costs rising," and was "predicated on a number of assumptions, most of which have to go right for the plan to work."
Edward Keaney, an analyst at Volpe, Brown Whelan & Company in San Francisco, said Pacificare Health Systems, which gets most of its revenues from Medicare, "would be a beneficiary of everybody else's pullback." Although Pacificare dropped 20,000 members of its Secure Horizons Medicare division in Northern California, it has been adept in most places at shifting financial risks to physician groups. The groups are typically paid a set fee for each Medicare member, and it is up to the doctors to keep costs within budget.
Mimi Willard, a health care analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said some buyers were attracted by the low prices of H.M.O. stocks, many of which are near historic lows. Also the companies do not have to worry immediately about problems in Asia and other foreign countries, and they are "perceived not to have exposure to potential problems in the economy," she said.
Some traders were encouraged when insiders, headed by Dr. Norman Payson, the chief executive, recently bought Oxford stock. But Ms. Willard agreed with analysts who said the intermediate picture was still uncertain, especially for Medicare H.M.O.'s.
"These are treacherous times for the H.M.O.'s," said Joyce Albers, who follows managed care companies at Deerfield Management, a health care investment fund. "This is certainly not an area for widows and orphans," she said.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Using Biting Humor to Attack Pataki's Record on State Finances

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:

Here are two 30-second advertisements for B. Thomas Golisano that went on the air on Monday.
 
PRODUCER -- Jay Advertising of Rochester
ON THE SCREEN -- In the first spot, four guys speaking in Brooklyn accents lounge on a brownstone stoop, one of them telling a story as the others express disbelief. In the second, a man in shadow, his back to the camera, talks with a bank loan officer, who ostentatiously wipes off his hand after shaking the other man's hand. 

THE SCRIPT -- In the first advertisement, one of the men on the stoop says: "So Georgie says to me, I'll pay you back Thursday. I say, 'Where you getting the money from to pay me back?' Georgie says, 'I'll borrow it from Jimmy.' I says, 'You owe Jimmy already.' Georgie says, 'I'll pay Jimmy with what I borrow from Tony.' I says, 'Whoa, whoa, whoa, what are you trying to pull on me, a Pataki?' "
Mr. Golisano: "This kind of thing happens every day in Albany with borrow-and-spend Pataki."
Announcer: "Let's hire an independent governor. Tom Golisano."
Four guys on the stoop, singing: "You say Pataki, I say Pataki, let's call the whole thing off."
In the second advertisement, the man in shadow says: "Hello. I'd like a $20 billion loan, please."
Banker: "Ho, ho. That's a pretty hefty number. And what's the loan for?"
Man in shadow: "So I can say I'm showing a surplus even though my business is billions of dollars in debt."
Banker, in an incredulous tone: "What's the name of this business you run?"
Man in shadow: "New York State."
Banker: "Oh. Nice to meet you, Mr. Pataki."
Mr. Golisano: "This kind of economics can't be explained away. You have to vote it away."
Announcer: "Let's hire an independent governor. Tom Golisano."
Banker: "I'm sure we can come to some arrangement."
ACCURACY -- The advertising campaign turns on Mr. Golisano's contention that Mr. Pataki has increased state debt by $20 billion in less than four years, and that only by borrowing has the Governor been able to both cut taxes and increase spending. The Governor's office has challenged the $20 billion figure, but its accuracy depends on what is counted, and either way, the truth is not flattering to Mr. Pataki. Debt supported directly by state taxes and fees has grown $8 billion, to $35 billion. Debt incurred by public authorities, like the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and repaid with user fees like subway tolls, has risen by about $20 billion, to more than $90 billion. There is considerable overlap between the two categories, but the total is well over $20 billion.
SCORECARD -- The message is the same as in Mr. Golisano's first round of advertising, but the style is vastly different, and much more effective. The new advertisements -- four in all, with eight more promised -- use humor and sarcasm where the earlier ones just featured the candidate, earnestly reciting facts and figures. The spots hit at Mr. Pataki's claim to be a fiscal conservative who has got the state's finances under control, but it is uncertain whether an attack on that record can succeed when state spending is up and there is a surplus. While the Golisano ads could soften the Governor's support, with just four weeks left in the race and Mr. Pataki far ahead in the polls, they are unlikely to affect the outcome. RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

HEADLINE: More Fallout From Long-Term Capital's Crash

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The near-collapse of the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management L.P. continued to reverberate yesterday as Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. disclosed its exposure to hedge funds and emerging markets and Moody's Investors Service downgraded the rating outlooks of five of Europe's largest banks.
Lehman Brothers, which has been battered for weeks by unsubstantiated speculation of financial collapse, said that the most it could lose from exposure to hedge funds and emerging markets was $236 million, less than 5 percent of its equity capital. 
 Lehman said it had $72 million of loans with hedge funds not backed by collateral, including cash and Treasury and agency debt. It has $164 million of exposure, including derivatives, in emerging markets that is not covered by collateral.
Lehman expressed concern that speculation about its collapse came from investors interested in driving down the price of Lehman's shares or bonds, a person close to the situation said. Shares of Lehman fell $2.375 yesterday, to $26.625.
Lehman invested $100 million in the $3.5 billion acquisition of Long-Term Capital, based in Greenwich, Conn. Its exposure to the hedge fund is $32 million, backed by $41 million of Treasury securities.
Meanwhile, Moody's said yesterday that it had downgraded the rating outlooks of five European banks on concern that investments in hedge funds and emerging markets could hurt their ability to pay their debts.
Moody's reduced the outlook for the long-term deposit rating and the financial strength rating of Deutsche Bank A.G. and Dresdner Bank A.G. of Germany, Paribas S.A. of France and ING Groep N.V. of the Netherlands to negative from stable. It reduced the outlook of Barclays P.L.C. of Britain to stable from positive.
Paribas, Barclays, and Deutsche Bank were among the banks that agreed last month to take over Long-Term Capital. Dresdner has written off about 240 million marks, or $146 million, because of exposure to the fund. ING said last week it would dismiss 1,200 workers at its investment bank, the result of shrinking profits from emerging markets.

HEADLINE: As Incumbents, Republicans Hold Advantage in 18 Races for Governor

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 5

 BODY:
With elections next month in 36 states, including the 8 most populous, this year's campaigns for governor will determine whether the Republicans maintain their remarkable hegemony in the nation's statehouses or the Democrats rebound from their catastrophic losses of the last four years.
The outcome rests with more than a dozen fiercely competitive races, including those in California, where the lieutenant governor, Gray Davis, is trying to break the Republicans' 16-year hold on the state's top office, and here in Georgia, where Guy W. Millner, a businessman who lost two previous tries for statewide office, hopes to become the first Republican governor since 1868. 
 In a year when the economy remains fundamentally sound and polls show that most Americans approve of the country's direction, the Republicans begin with the advantage of running 18 incumbents, compared with 6 Democratic incumbents and one independent, Gov. Angus S. King Jr. of Maine.
And at the moment, polls show that Republican candidates hold leads, some seemingly insurmountable, in seven of the eight most populous states -- Texas, New York, Florida, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Ohio and Michigan. The exception is all-important California, where Attorney General Dan Lungren, the Republican nominee, is thought to be trailing Mr. Davis by a slim margin.
The status of those races has given Republican strategists confidence that they will at least maintain their current count of 32 seats and possibly pick up a few more.
"I think it's safe to say that Republican governors may rival the National Park Service after this election in terms of their sheer control of land mass," said Chris Henick, a political consultant and former executive director of the Republican Governors Association.
But Democrats are running unexpectedly strong races in states like Alabama, New Mexico and South Carolina, and if a few significant races break their way they could still reclaim a share of the turf that was ceded in 1994. "It was a disaster for Democratic governors four years ago, so clearly we'd like to pick up some seats," said Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, the immediate past chairman of the Democratic Governors Association. "The rebuilding process is long and difficult."
In the 1994 elections, the number of Republican governors soared to 30 from 19, the party's largest one-year gain since 1938. The Republicans lifted their tally to 32 in 1996, when they took control of governorships in Louisiana and Arkansas. Only once this century has the party exceeded its current count, and that was in 1921-22, when it had 34 governors.
The party has made similar gains in state legislatures and controls both houses in 18 states, an increase of 10 over 1994. Democrats have two-house majorities in 20 states, and each party controls one chamber in 11 legislatures. (Nebraska's legislature is unicameral and nonpartisan.)
In the last four years, with support from a devolutionary Congress, those Republican governors and lawmakers have left an unmistakable imprint on taxation, welfare, criminal justice and education. And if the Republicans hold or expand their trove of governorships, their dominance could become self-perpetuating after the next redistricting.
Each of the governors elected on Nov. 3 will have veto power over the drawing of district maps after the 2000 census, giving those governors influence for a decade over the partisan makeup of the United States House of Representatives and of their own legislatures. The outcome of this year's races for governor could also affect the organizing strength of the parties in the next Presidential campaign.
Some Democratic strategists said that their party was suffering because it did not build its second string when it dominated gubernatorial politics.
"The Republicans have done a much better job developing the so-called B-team," said Harold Ickes, an adviser to the Democratic Governors Association. "I think we got sort of fat and lazy."
The party must also contend this year with uncertainty over the turnout of its base voters, who could be demoralized over President Clinton's troubles. Studies show that turnout in non-Presidential election years typically drops anyway, a phenomenon that tends to favor Republicans because their core supporters vote more reliably.
Strategists in both parties said that most races for governor this year were being waged on local issues, with candidates parrying over tax cuts, education reform, managed care, gun control and juvenile justice. But some Republican operatives are convinced that the White House scandal is preventing Democrats from gaining traction.
"There's got to be a reason for it, and I think it's Clinton," said Clinton E. Key, executive director of the Republican Governors Association. "Not in a specific sense but just as a general malaise."
The ethical questions surrounding Mr. Clinton have clearly influenced strategy in California, Maryland, South Carolina and Georgia, where candidates have been prompted to emphasize character.
Here in Georgia, the Democratic nominee, State Representative Roy E. Barnes, has been televising an advertisement that attacks Mr. Millner on ethical questions, including being fined for failing to report contributions to a previous campaign. "This year more than ever, character counts," the advertisement concludes.
Mr. Millner has fired back with an advertisement that criticizes Mr. Barnes for, among other things, getting in a shoving match with a prosecutor while defending a client. "If character is the question, Roy Barnes isn't the answer," it says.
Robert S. Kahn, Mr. Barnes's campaign manager, said he probably would not have opened the war on character were it not for Mr. Clinton's travails. "It's certainly on everybody's mind," he said.
A poll conducted for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution last week gave Mr. Millner a lead over Mr. Barnes of 47 percent to 41 percent.
Republican incumbents in the strongest position include Governors George W. Bush of Texas, George E. Pataki of New York, Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania and John M. Engler of Michigan.
In the contest for Florida's open seat, a recent poll showed Jeb Bush, a Republican who lost in 1994, with a 15 percentage point lead over Lieut. Gov. Buddy MacKay, the Democratic nominee. Mr. MacKay has had to contend with demoralizing defections from prominent black Democrats. And his campaign manager, Robin D. Rorapaugh, complained that her campaign could not break through the press's obsession with the White House sex scandal.
"It puts so much clutter in front of voters that it's hard for a local candidate to talk about local issues," Ms. Rorapaugh said.
Top Republican strategists, speaking on the condition of anonymity, say the Florida race is all but over, and leading Democrats acknowledge it is very uphill.
"Florida is, ugh, we have a major challenge," said Gov. Pedro J. Rossello of Puerto Rico, chairman of the Democratic Governors Association. "It's doable but time is running out."
In Illinois, where Gov. Jim Edgar, a Republican, is retiring, the Republican nominee, Secretary of State George Ryan, has held a constant lead of 20 percentage points or more over his Democratic opponent, United States Representative Glenn Poshard, for more than a month. In Ohio, where Gov. George V. Voinovich, a Republican, is retiring to run for United States Senate, the Republican candidate, Secretary of State Bob Taft, has a lead of just under 10 percentage points in the most recent public polls over his Democratic opponent, Attorney General Lee Fisher. Democratic strategists maintain that the race is tightening.
Republicans are also heavily favored to maintain governorships in Arizona, Arkansas, Connecticut, Idaho, Iowa, Kansas, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Tennessee, Wisconsin and Wyoming. In Massachusetts, where the Democratic nominee, Attorney General Scott Harshbarger, has struggled to maintain party discipline, a poll released last week showed Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci, a Republican, with a lead of 11 points. Democrats are expected to keep control in Alaska, New Hampshire, Oregon, and Vermont.
In addition to Mr. Bush in Florida, Republican candidates lead in several states where Democrats govern, including Hawaii, Nebraska and Nevada. Conversely, polls show that the Democratic candidate in Minnesota, Attorney General Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, is ahead in his campaign to reclaim that state for his party.
But many major races remain neck-and-neck and are likely to stay that way until election day. In Maryland, for instance, polls show the incumbent Democrat, Parris N. Glendening, in a dead heat with Ellen R. Sauerbrey, the Republican legislator who lost the 1994 election for governor by a mere 6,000 votes.
In New Mexico, the former Albuquerque Mayor, Martin Chavez, a Democrat, is waging a spirited campaign to wrest control from the Republican incumbent, Gov. Gary E. Johnson, in a race that strategists expect to be close. The same is true in Alabama, although a poll taken late last week showed Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman, the Democratic nominee, with an expanding lead of 13 percentage points over Gov. Fob James Jr., a Republican who has become a national icon for school prayer advocates.
The most surprising Republican vulnerability is in South Carolina, where public polls show that the Jim Hodges, a Democrat, has cut the lead of Gov. David Beasley to 9 percentage points from 15 in the last month. Mr. Beasley is chairman of the Republican Governors Association, a job typically given to a governor who has few re-election worries.
Other close races can be found in Rhode Island, which features a rematch of the 1994 campaign between Gov. Lincoln Almond, a Republican, and Myrth York, his Democratic challenger, and in Colorado, where State Treasurer Bill Owens, a Republican, faces Lieut. Gov. Gail Schoettler.

GRAPHIC: Photo: One hotly contested race for governor is in Georgia, where Guy W. Millner, left, is trying to beat State Representative Roy E. Barnes to become the first Republican governor there since 1868. (Michael A. Schwarz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

2 Hospital Companies Sued On Charges of False Claims
The Government sued Columbia/HCA Healthcare and Quorum Health Group, contending that they had defrauded Federal health programs for more than 14 years through a scheme involving bogus expense claims. 
 The suit comes after an investigation into allegations of fraud at the companies. It contends that the hospital giants routinely overstated expenses in reports to the Government to increase their compensation from Federal programs like Medicare. Page A1.
 
Stocks Fall Sharply on Global Unrest
Technology stocks fell, leading the stock market lower as the troubled world economy seemed to undermine investor sentiment. The Nasdaq index, which is dominated by technology stocks, plunged 78.29 points, or 4.85 percent, to 1,536.69. Cisco Systems was down 13.3 percent after it was disclosed that the Federal Trade Commission was investigating whether it held illegal conversations with Lucent and Northern Telecom about dividing up the networking market. C10.
 
President Clinton made a direct appeal to a group of the world's top financial officials to come up with a unified attack on the global economic crisis, after nearly three days of debate produced a near-stalemate over immediate cures. A1.
 
Sales at G.M. Fell 3.1% Last Month
Sales of General Motors cars and trucks fell 3.1 percent in September, less of a drop than analysts had expected. Ford Motor saw its September sales climb 4.1 percent. C5.
 
G.M. plans to combine its domestic and international auto operations in a shake-up expected to be announced today. C5.
 
AT&T Buying Vanguard Cellular
AT&T agreed to acquire Vanguard Cellular for $900 million in stock and cash. C2.
 
Latin American Officials Want More
Angry at what they consider the lenient treatment that Russia received in its $4.5 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund, Latin American officials and economists warned that the programs offered to protect their countries were too paltry. A13.

Lehman Exposure $236 Million
Lehman Brothers said that the most it would lose from exposure to hedge funds and emerging markets was $236 million. C5.
 
Analysts See H.M.O. Slump Lasting
The managed care companies that dropped 250,000 elderly Medicare customers last week will have healthier financial statements, but many analysts said that the move would not be enough to pull the health maintenance organizations out of a three-year earnings slump. Market Place. C9.
 
Commission Sues Josephthal
The Equal Opportunity Employment Commission filed suit Oct. 1 against the regional brokerage firm Josephthal, seeking punitive damages for what the commission called "malicious" conduct at its Washington office. C3.
 
Carlson and Thomas Cook in Deal
Carlson Companies plans to merge its leisure travel business in Britain with the worldwide travel operations of Thomas Cook in a deal valued at more than $1 billion. C9.

Veritas Acquiring Seagate Division
Veritas Software is acquiring a unit of Seagate Software in a $1.6 billion stock swap. C2.
 
A New Absolut Campaign
Simon Doonan, the creative director at Barneys New York known for his unusual window designs, is the subject of a print advertisement in the series of pitches for Absolut vodka by TBWA Chiat/ Day. "Absolut Doonan" presents heads, hands, arms and legs of mannequins assembled in the familiar shape of the Absolut bottle. The Absolut assemblage was produced by Mr. Doonan and his display team for the ad and photographed in a Barneys New York window. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C8.

HEADLINE: In First Debate, Kennelly Faults Rowland on Child Care

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 5

 BODY:
United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly used the opening debate of the Connecticut gubernatorial race to go after Gov. John G. Rowland with a stick rather than a sword today, setting a dignified tone for the closing month of a campaign in which polls show the Governor holding a huge lead.
Governor Rowland had to answer for some of the less rosy parts of his record, including what Mrs. Kennelly considers laxness in the enforcement of environmental and child-protection laws. But her criticism was limited mostly to asides as she described her plans to bolster public education and give new rights to patients insured by health maintenance organizations. He, too, seemed to be pulling punches, barely mentioning his differences with her eight-term record in Congress. 
 Mr. Rowland was so confident that during his standard nod of appreciation to the sponsors at the close of the hourlong debate, he even thanked Mrs. Kennelly for coming. He said he would focus in his next term on spreading prosperity to the downtowns of the state's largest cities but proposed no new plans. "I think Mrs. Kennelly sees Connecticut's glass as half-empty," he said. "I see Connecticut's glass as half-full."
"And if you look ahead, the question becomes, 'Why would you run again?' " he continued. He said that after talking to his wife, Patricia, "We decided that the real future of Connecticut is how we turn our cities around."
Speaking to an audience of 500 business leaders from prosperous Fairfield County, Mrs. Kennelly suggested that much of the Governor's political fortune stemmed from the economy rather than his policies. "The years leading to the new millennium are too crucial to waste by complacency or political posturing -- too crucial to spend patting yourself on the back about accomplishments that you didn't have much to do with," she said.
Castigating Mr. Rowland over his record of enforcing environmental laws, she said, "A scandal a month is not good enough for the state of Connecticut, especially since so many of your companies came here because of the quality of our life." Mrs. Kennelly accused the Governor of an election-year conversion on the regulation of health insurers, saying of a Connecticut law creating an appeals process against H.M.O.'s, "You signed it because it was veto-proof by the time it passed the Legislature, but I am glad that you did sign it."
Joseph D. Courtney, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor and Mrs. Kennelly's running mate, explained her strategy after today's debate, the first of four. "The voters are not going to respond positively to a hammer-and-tong attack," Mr. Courtney said. "The way we win this election is to draw the contrast between her message and the Governor's message."
The two candidates' contrasting styles were shown most sharply when they were asked whether the state's death penalty law should be rewritten to be tougher and more workable. Connecticut last executed someone three decades ago. The candidates both said "yes," but in very different ways.
Mrs. Kennelly, a Democrat, 62, said the law should be tougher and clearer, adding, "Once again, I think we have to get those lawyers in the room and make sure that we write a law that works." Mr. Rowland, a Republican, 41, drew laughter when he responded: "The last thing I want is lawyers in a room figuring this thing out. That's why we've got this mess. If anything, get the lawyers out of the room. Then we can get down to brass tacks."
Since Mrs. Kennelly represents the Hartford area in Congress, today's debate served as her introduction to many of the audience members and television viewers from the New York City suburbs. The debate was broadcast live over radio and cable television. The questioners were newspaper editors, and the sponsor was an association based in Stamford, the Business Council of Southwestern Connecticut.
The candidates differed most markedly on tax cuts. Mr. Rowland, who years ago abandoned his 1994 campaign promise to end the state income tax, was asked whether he planned to phase out the tax in a second term.
"There's always that possibility and that opportunity," he said, pausing for laughter from the crowd, which realized the idea was long dead. Mr. Rowland then acknowledged there was little appetite for it in the Legislature.
Mr. Rowland said taxes had been cut $1.7 billion during his term, including reductions or credits for the income, gas, property and inheritance taxes. "We plan to do it over the next four years as well," he said.
Mrs. Kennelly has proposed a 10 percent reduction in property taxes, which she would accomplish with a state rebate to the cities and towns that impose and collect the tax. "I would hope that the Governor would say today that he would forget that promise that he keeps making and never, never does it -- that he says get rid of the income tax," she said. Mr. Rowland denounced Mrs. Kennelly's proposal as "nothing more than a spending plan, a shell game."
The issue that has dogged Mr. Rowland most consistently concerns the killings of children who were being monitored by the state's Department of Children and Families. Mrs. Kennelly said: "It really is very tragic when a child has to be taken out of his birth home because of neglect and abuse. But it's more than tragic when a child under the care of the state has something happen to them." She said workers were inadequately trained and social workers' caseloads too large.
Mr. Rowland said he had increased spending, staffing and training for the department. "With all due respect, Mrs. Kennelly's facts are entirely wrong," he said.
In the afternoon's one reference to President Clinton's troubles, the candidates were asked to what extent a Governor was entitled to a private life. Mrs. Kennelly signaled for the first time that she planned to vote against impeachment, saying that the overwhelming response of constituents since the broadcasting of Mr. Clinton's grand jury testimony had been: " 'Censor him. Punish him. But for heaven's sake, Barbara, don't vote for impeachment.' "
Mr. Rowland said people wanted Congress to act and move on. "Lets get it over with," he said. "Let's have finality. And, by the way, all people should have a private life, including politicians and including candidates."

HEADLINE: Schumer Says Clinton's Acts Were Wrong but Not Impeachable

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
In his first detailed remarks on the Lewinsky matter, Representative Charles E. Schumer said today that President Clinton's lies about his extramarital affair were wrong and possibly illegal but did not warrant impeachment. He called instead for some lesser form of punishment, perhaps censure or a rebuke.
Mr. Schumer, a Democrat from Brooklyn who is running for the United States Senate, also questioned the impartiality of Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel, accusing him of having "seriously overreached" in his investigation and of presenting "flimsy evidence" in his voluminous report to Congress. 
 "It is time we move forward, and not have the Congress and the American people endure a specter of what could be a yearlong focus on a tawdry but not impeachable affair," said Mr. Schumer, offering one of the more ringing defenses of the Clinton Presidency among members of the House Judiciary Committee today.
As Mr. Schumer made his comments today, his campaign was preparing a major fund-raising event featuring the President in New York City next Monday, providing further evidence that even when wounded, Mr. Clinton remains a popular and potent political force in New York State. The full House is scheduled to vote on whether to begin an impeachment inquiry of the President on Friday.
Reading from a prepared statement to the committee, Mr. Schumer said important issues, including education and health care, had been pushed aside in the wake of the Lewinsky scandal.
"The world economy is in crisis and cries out for American leadership, without which worldwide turmoil is a grave possibility," Mr. Schumer said. "This investigation, now in its fifth year, has run its course. It's time to move on."
Mr. Schumer, who is known for having once theatrically waved an assault weapon at a Judiciary Committee hearing, but whose attendance this year has been severely truncated by the demands of his campaign, left soon after making his statement to meet with reporters, even as other committee members remained to listen to their colleagues' statements.
The President's problems have hung like a dark cloud over the New York Senate race all year, leaving strategists for both Mr. Schumer and the Republican incumbent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, unsure of what course to take. As a result, neither candidate has said much to defend or criticize the President until today. Mr. D'Amato has said he will not take a stand on whether the President should be impeached and removed from office until the issue goes to the Senate.
The President's problems most clearly posed a problem for Mr. Schumer, who has been a strong supporter of Mr. Clinton and whose evident desire to recruit the President's help in his campaign may have been hamstrung by his seat on the Judiciary Committee, which would oversee any impeachment process.
Mr. Schumer said today that his decision to oppose impeachment unequivocally had liberated him in a way. "I made up my mind yesterday and I slept like a baby last night," he said to reporters.
Mr. Schumer said he felt that the average person would receive no punishment for lying about an extramarital affair, even under oath. But because Presidents "should be held to a higher standard," he said Mr. Clinton should receive a "significant punishment" short of impeachment.
Asked by reporters today if there was not a conflict of interest in his sitting in judgment on a President who was giving him campaign assistance, Mr. Schumer emphatically said no. "I think New Yorkers are fair and they are going to judge what I said based on the merits," he said. "We'll have to let the chips fall where they may politically."
But Mr. Schumer's advisers clearly believe that the chips will fall in their favor. They contend that Mr. D'Amato will now feel pressure either to defend the President, which could anger Mr. D'Amato's conservative base, or to defend the Republican leadership pushing for impeachment, which could infuriate swing voters who like Mr. Clinton, or at least his policies.
Mr. D'Amato displayed some concern about the issue in remarks to reporters today following a Manhattan campaign event at which he received an award for helping direct Federal mass transit money to the New York metropolitan region.
Asked whether he would try to make impeachment a campaign issue, Mr. D'Amato said no, and instead accused an unnamed adviser of Mr. Schumer's of encouraging reporters to write about the matter.
"He has this guy who does it continually, puts out these nonsense rumors and things," Mr. D'Amato said. "We haven't done it and I don't intend to do it."
Asked by a reporter who this adviser was, Mr. D'Amato replied, "If you don't know, then he hasn't approached you."
The three-term Senator also said that he was "not going to be critical" of Mr. Schumer's remarks on impeachment, adding that he would not offer his own opinion because he might be required to vote on whether to remove or punish the President.
"When it comes to the Senate, then I'll act in a manner in which the facts and times dictate," he said.
Mr. D'Amato also continued his attack on Mr. Schumer's spotty attendance record this year, releasing a new radio advertisement that charges that Mr. Schumer has missed more votes, 110, in the last 12 months than Mr. D'Amato has missed in 12 years. The Senate votes much less often than the House. Mr. Schumer has accused Mr. D'Amato of distorting his record, noting that his attendance for votes during 18 years is more than 90 percent.

HEADLINE: 2 Sides Fight Over a Budget, Leaving Some In the Middle

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
The amount of money represents less than one-half of 1 percent of the $34 billion city budget, yet it continues to provoke a dispute between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council over who holds claim to the title of Most Fiscally Responsible.
Yesterday, some of those caught in the middle of the argument over $150 million in spending -- officials of various nonprofit groups that rely on city money -- held a news conference in City Hall Park to appeal for a resolution to the fight. Standing alongside several Council members and the Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, they laid blame squarely on Mr. Giuliani, who has refused to release money that the Council had set aside for these groups, even though the city is reveling in a $2 billion surplus. 
 They said that withholding the money had affected services to children, the elderly and the poor. To underscore their point, they introduced an elderly man, a foster mother, a formerly homeless man and others to explain the need for the money.
But Mr. Giuliani was not moved. Speaking at his own news conference, he said that he was not about to be persuaded by grandstanding in the park, which he dismissed as the "usual, knee-jerk reaction of New York City career politicians."
"They think it's the same old political game, and they're going to pressure me into spending money that we shouldn't spend," he said. "It's not going to work with me."
As the protesters presented their case outside, leaves fluttered to the ground, a fitting reminder that this dispute began in late spring and has lasted into the fall. It started as a political quarrel between the city's top two officials, the Republican Mayor and the Democratic Speaker of the Council, Peter F. Vallone. From there it escalated into an institutional battle between the Mayor and the Council over who had final control of the city purse strings.
Yesterday's event highlighted the fight's impact beyond the walls of City Hall, where it has caused fiscal headaches or worse for nonprofit groups already operating on tight budgets. With both sides seemingly dug in, this dispute may well wind up in court, as other Mayor-Council disputes have.
At the outset, Mr. Vallone accused the Mayor of holding the budget process hostage because the Democratic Speaker opposed his plan to use tax money for a baseball stadium in Manhattan. The Republican Mayor countered that Mr. Vallone was presenting a pork-rich budget to enhance his chances as candidate for governor.
The Council eventually defied the Mayor by passing its own budget, then overrode his many vetoes. But the City Charter gives the Mayor the right to withhold spending if he thinks it is in the city's best interest. That is exactly what he has done, zeroing in on the Council "member items" -- the Council prefer the term "local initiatives" -- that Council members traditionally have spent on community groups in their districts.
The city's finances remain so robust that tax revenues for the first quarter of the current fiscal year are $200 million higher than expected. Still, the volatility of the global economy has provided the Mayor with the rhetorical reasoning for not spending the money allocated by the Council.
"Maybe back then, in May and June, it seemed like we had all the money in the world," the Mayor said. "But with the world economy and the American economy in a somewhat more precarious situation, I think the wisdom of our saving money is actually going to be seen by everyone."
But Thomas McMahon, the Council's finance director, argued that the Council had passed the "most fiscally responsible budget in city history." And he said that the money being frozen goes beyond the so-called member items; it includes $18 million for expanded day care, $10 million for weekly recycling and $8 million for programs that provide alternatives to jail.
Administration officials insist that circumstances for the community groups are nowhere near as dire as those presented by Council members and advocates.
But Angelita Anderson, the director of the City-Wide Task Force on Housing Court, which helps poor people to protect their rights in the confusing world of landlord-tenant disputes, begged to differ. Because the organization did not receive $263,000 it had been promised, she said at yesterday's news conference, it has laid off several employees and cut back on services.
Theresa Surbeck DaSilva, director of the WEME Mainstream Nutrition and Health Center, which provides 500 meals a day to the homebound elderly on the Upper West Side, said she was worried about having anything left at the end of her fiscal year. "We do need the money," she said.

HEADLINE: In Their Own Words

 BODY:

From the candidates' closing statements at their first debate in Stamford yesterday:
 
JOHN G. ROWLAND
"I think Mrs. Kennelly sees Connecticut's glass as half-empty. I see Connecticut's glass as half-full.
I have spent considerable time over the last four years working on the budget, working to bring hundreds and hundreds of new companies into Connecticut -- a hundred thousand new jobs into our community. 
 We've made investments in higher education. We've made investments in the environment, especially in our open-space programs, that have worked extremely well down in this part of the state.
And if you look ahead, the question becomes, 'Why would you run again?' And Patty and I talked about that long and hard in the early part of this year, and we decided that the real future of Connecticut is how we turn our cities around -- a total focus on turning our cities around.

Today, I ask you to support my candidacy, to help me continue the momentum we've built over the last four years. I commit to you that we will, and we can, do more."
 
BARBARA B. KENNELLY
"I think of myself as a straight talker. I understand government -- local, state and Federal. I've served at all levels. I know what government is capable of doing for its citizens with the right leadership. I know how to bring the best and the brightest in government together with the best and the brightest in business to solve problems. I have committed most of my adult life to making government work.
Put simply, I am running for governor because I don't think this administration has done enough to bring Connecticut into the 21st century. I'm running for governor because I know where we've been, I know where we are today, and I know where we should be going.
Tell me: Have we really done enough to have an excellent educational system for the state of Connecticut? Has the Governor's election-year conversion to H.M.O. reform done anything to forward our discussion on the future of health care for all our citizens? Have we taken our surplus resources and developed strategies to invest in future generations? Have we managed our debt so that we're not going to mortgage the future of our children?"

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: NEWS ANALYSIS;
A First Step With No End in Sight

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Almost every member of the House Judiciary Committee paid some tribute to the Constitution and the Founding Fathers today. Many said portentously that their debates and votes would be remembered for generations. The muse of history was obviously working overtime.
True, it was only the third time that Presidential impeachment has been formally considered on Capitol Hill. But only in that limited sense was the approval of a full-scale impeachment process historic. It was by no means decisive, no matter how much the legislators huffed and puffed. 
 This was only a first step along a rocky road whose length is not known -- not by President Clinton, not by the public and not even by committee members (although the chairman, Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, said this weekend that he hoped the House of Representatives could finish its work before year's end).
"The Constitution provides our compass," said Representative Edward A. Pease, Republican of Indiana. "I intend to follow it." But neither he nor his colleagues could say for sure where it would ultimately point.
Meeting in the same room where Richard M. Nixon's fate was sealed a quarter-century ago, Republicans stressed parallels to that era. This case is about law-breaking, they said, and not about illicit sex. To which Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the committee's senior Democrat, retorted: "This is not about Watergate. It is about an extramarital affair."
That is the fault line, so far unbridgeable, between the two parties.
People in Washington universally assume that the House as a whole will vote later this week to ratify the committee's decision. The Republicans have the votes to prevail. But if only Republicans support the procedural plans set out by their leadership, as was the case in the final vote tonight, the decision will be seen by many in the country as a purely partisan proposition.
That next roll-call will help set the tone for what lies ahead. If only a half-dozen Democrats join the Republicans, the image of trench warfare will be reinforced and the subsequent inquiry will begin under something of a cloud; if 50 or 75 do so, the vote will confer a greater degree of legitimacy.
The more the average voter thinks that the Republicans are ganging up on the President, his strategists believe, the better his chances of surviving.
Of course, consensus or something approaching it may develop later. Only well into the final stages of the committee's 1974 hearings on the impeachment of Nixon did significant numbers of Republican members join the Democrats in concluding that Nixon had committed impeachable offenses. The fact that they finally did led people on both sides to judge its actions fair.
In the other case of Presidential impeachment, Andrew Johnson survived a Senate trial because just enough members of the opposition party broke ranks and voted to back him.
Once this week's votes have been taken, attention will shift to the mid-term elections on Nov. 3. The conventional wisdom in Washington has shifted rapidly in recent days, from a belief in the days before the release of Kenneth W. Starr's report that changes would be minimal, especially in the House, to a suspicion that Democratic losses would be large, which took hold in the days before the tape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony was released.
Now there is a growing conviction that the Republicans erred by releasing the tape, creating a backlash that could help marginal House Democrats.
Two caveats seem in order, however. While the President's troubles seem less likely to influence Senate races, Democrats were in big trouble in those without any drag from Washington. A number of independent analysts see Republican gains of four to six seats. Major losses in the House are still possible, too, perhaps 20 or more seats if Republican voters turn out en masse and Democrats do not.
"Differential turnouts aren't really very common, you know," said a senior Republican Senator on Capitol Hill. "But this year, Democratic voters seem to be in a sulk, and the Republicans act like they'd turn out even if it snowed on Election Day."
Big gains might embolden Republican legislators in their pursuit of President Clinton. But the political terrain is tricky. After November, both parties will have to play to the 2000 electorate -- larger, spread more broadly across the economic scale, and less intensely partisan -- and that might have a tempering effect on the zeal of the Republicans in Congress.
The detailed terms of the case developed by the inquiry, and how it is developed, will have an impact as well. Unshakeable as the preconceptions of many committee members sounded today, experience suggests that over a long period, some of them and some others in the House will change their minds.
If President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky are called as witnesses, their deportment will certainly influence some Representatives. How they and their interrogators behave will influence voters as well. Mr. Clinton is a formidable persuader, and any attempt to break down his testimony would run the risk of alienating people who would sense disrespect for the Presidency.
A foreign crisis -- a genuine foreign crisis, as opposed to one that the Administration would be suspected of inventing -- could radically change the context of the inquiry, too. Republicans might find themselves under fire for distracting the Commander in Chief from important security responsibilities.
And what of the topics other than Ms. Lewinsky that Mr. Starr has investigated? Mr. Hyde insisted tonight that the independent counsel was still pursuing the original Whitewater matter and other controversies; one of the committee's ranking Democrats, Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, insisted that no more would be forthcoming from Mr. Starr. Ambiguity keeps the pot boiling; wrapping up the other cases would take some of the steam out of the House inquiry.
All of those ideas, all of those possibilities will be in the air as the House debates impeachment in November and December. Depending on how they coalesce, the Republican leadership might or might not be receptive to a compromise, either before a committee vote or after a committee vote to approve articles of impeachment, before ratification by the House as a whole.
At any time, of course, Mr. Clinton could change his mind and decide to resign. Nixon's decision to quit came after the committee had voted. But it was motivated by the emergence of new evidence more than the vote itself, plus the belief he could not win in the Senate.
Mr. Clinton's aides say he would rather be a second Andrew Johnson, surviving in the Senate by a tiny margin, than a second Richard Nixon. As things now stand, he would appear to have a good chance of getting the 34 votes he would need (one-third of the total plus one) to win a Senate trial.
But that is not chiseled in stone, either. The Republicans could have 60 seats by the time the case reached the Senate. In that case, if they lost none of their own partisans, a switch of only seven Democrats would doom Mr. Clinton. A remote possibility, certainly, but then so much of what has happened so far in this case seemed highly improbable until it happened.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Retreats 58Points and Other Gauges Also Decline

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Technology shares fell sharply yesterday, leading markets lower as the troubled world economy seemed to undermine investor sentiment.
From Japan came the news that some officials believe their big banks are in much worse financial shape than previously thought. From Washington, where the world's financial leaders were gathered for the twice-a-year meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, came no reassurance that world leaders would be able to act quickly to turn the situation around. 
 "It doesn't look like enough is going to be done fast enough," Jeffrey M. Applegate, chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers, said.
Three of the major stock gauges fell to within easy striking distance of their Aug. 31 lows.
Foreign stock markets also ended lower, with Japan's Nikkei index down 2.08 percent to its lowest close in nearly 13 years. At the midday break today, the Nikkei was up 1.42 percent, or 183.94 points, to 13,132.06. Brazil's Bovespa index was off 4.5 percent, despite the apparent re-election of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso. How fast Mr. Cardoso moves to cut Government spending and work with the I.M.F. on a backup rescue plan will be watched closely by investors, who fear that an economic collapse in Brazil would lead to a recession in the United States.
As investors were shunning stocks, they were rushing again into bonds, pushing yields even lower. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond plunged to 4.72 percent and has now fallen four-tenths of a percentage point in just the last week.
Although stocks finished lower, a sharp, end-of-the-day rebound in the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks staved off a much steeper decline. The Dow, which was down almost 233 points during the day, finished off just 58.45 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, at 7,726.24. The S.& P. index was off almost 38 points before rallying to close down just 14.04 points, or 1.4 percent, at 988.56.
The Nasdaq index, which is dominated by technology stocks, plunged 78.29 points, or 4.85 percent, to 1,536.69. Cisco Systems fell 13.3 percent, Dell Computer was off 8 percent, Intel fell 3.95 percent and Microsoft declined 2.82 percent.
Part of the selloff was touched off by a report in The Washington Post yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission was investigating whether Cisco had illegal conversations with Lucent Technologies and Northern Telecom about dividing up the networking market. Cisco confirmed the investigation.
Selling pressure also seemed to come from the fear that a slowdown in the American economy would lead to a sharp decline in sales of networking and other Internet and computer products. This belief was probably aided by warnings from several technology companies, including Aspen Technology and Avid Technology, that third-quarter earnings would fall below expectations.
Capital spending, which supports much of the computer industry, has been one of the strong foundations of the economy for the last several years. But there are signs that capital spending is beginning to slow. The recent sharp fall in the stocks of financial companies and the recent reports of their losses will further curb computer investment.
If world leaders cannot reassure investors that they can contain the current financial crisis, investors will focus more and more on the possibility of the American economy finally tipping from slow growth into a recession.
Mr. Applegate is not forecasting a recession yet but said that "there is a growing chance of a pretty significant slowdown." With Stephen D. Slifer, the chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers, he is re-evaluating his outlook and said that "all the numbers are going to be lower." This includes his forecast of 1,150 for the S.& P. 500 at the end of this year.
Lawrence Meyer, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said in a speech yesterday that the Fed cut its interest rate target last week by a quarter of a percentage point because the central bank believed the economy will slow next year. He said the cut was part of a strategy to allow the economy to slow with a soft landing, not a recession.
Marshall Acuff, the equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, argued that "the best case is slow growth next year, not a recession." And if that is the case, the Dow could stay above the 7,400 level. But, he added, the odds for a recession are greater than the odds for a sudden strong recovery.

HEADLINE: Transit Repairs Hurried, Unions Warn

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In the latest sign that a surge in ridership may be straining the New York City transit system, union officials warned yesterday that maintenance work on buses and subway cars was being hurried and perhaps shortchanged as the system tries to get them back into operation.
That warning came amid renewed calls by the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group, for increased spending by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on new buses and subway cars that the group said were needed to accommodate the increased ridership. 
 At a news conference that the group held with unions for the transit system's supervisors and track workers, labor leaders said workers were being pushed to get trains and buses with maintenance problems back into operation more quickly.
"It shouldn't be an ordeal to drive a train or bus or to ride in one," said Willie James, president of the Transport Workers Union of Greater New York, which represents 33,000 of the city's transit workers. "That's why we are joining with riders to demand more service."
Some union representatives said they worried that routine preventive maintenance procedures used for years were being performed more rapidly because more buses and subway cars were in use, and more riders mean more wear and tear.
Safety checks on such things as doors, lights and public address systems are normally conducted on subway cars after each 10,000 miles of use (about every six weeks) and on buses after each 3,000 miles (about once a month). But with more buses and subways to contend with, the officials said maintenance workers have a bigger workload.
"Trains come in and go out more quickly, and you just don't want to hold one up in the yard," said Richard Russo, secretary-treasurer of the Subway and Surface Supervisors Association, a subway and bus union. "When people are being pushed, they might miss something."
Transit agency officials responded yesterday by pointing to large new expenditures they have announced in recent months to increase the frequency of bus and subway service. The most recent expansion, called the largest on record, was announced in September, when the M.T.A. said it would use its 1998 budget surplus to spend $44 million on expanded service over the next year.
The transit officials also dismissed criticism of the agency's maintenance procedures yesterday, saying the complaints reflected a predictable desire by union leaders for more jobs and better working conditions.
"I don't think the raw number of jobs is the issue, but the number of bus and subway accidents," said Al O'Leary, a spokesman for New York City Transit, which is part of the M.T.A.
The union officials attending yesterday's new conference were not able to point out any recent mishaps caused by shoddy maintenance.
At the core of the dispute are converging shifts in mass-transit policy: the Metrocard, with unlimited rides, has combined with an upturn in tourism and the city's buoyant economy to draw more people to mass transit, but that rise in ridership has occurred just as the M.T.A has carried out a five-year plan of fiscal austerity. Since 1995, the agency has reduced its employment levels by about 10 percent.
While the Metrocard has helped draw people to the transit system, it has also made keeping track of ridership more difficult, Mr. O'Leary said. Some of the increased ridership numbers could reflect the fact that more people were transferring to and from buses and subways.
The biggest increase in numbers has been on city buses, where ridership had been declining. In the year that ended in September, New York City Transit said, its buses carried 22 percent more passengers each weekday than a year earlier. It predicted continued growth at a slightly slower rate until at least the end of 1999.
Subways have also attracted a flood of new passengers, with ridership up by 5 percent on weekdays for the latest year. Like buses, the agency has predicted continued increases in subway use through 1999.
To push its call to increase the size of the transit fleet, the Straphangers Campaign yesterday announced an advertising campaign.
The $40,000 campaign, in which 2,280 advertisements are being displayed this month in subway cars, is being paid for jointly by the advocacy group and transit unions. The ads depict snails and sardine cans, as symbols for current train and bus service, and urge riders to complain to city and state officials.

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of the advertisements that are being placed in subway cars by the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group, and transit worker unions.

HEADLINE: Accord Reached on Bill For More Rent Subsidies

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Senate and House negotiators reached agreement today on a bill that would make rent subsidies available to more poor families and allow more home buyers to qualify for federally backed mortgages.
The bill, which seems assured of passage by Congress and of President Clinton's signature, would create about 90,000 Section 8 vouchers, or Federal rent subsidies, for low-income tenants. It would also raise the loan limits on federally insured mortgages to $197,621 from $170,362. 
 "This puts HUD back in the housing business," Andrew M. Cuomo, Housing and Urban Development Secretary, said today.
Mr. Cuomo said both the rental-subsidy provision and the higher ceiling for mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration would have wide impact in New York City and other metropolitan areas, where there are long waiting lists for housing assistance. Mr. Cuomo said the creation of 90,000 rental vouchers was especially important, because no new Section 8 vouchers had been authorized since 1994. Nearly three million households now receive vouchers.
Only two months ago, HUD negotiators had thought they might persuade lawmakers to authorize 15,000 new vouchers. Authorization of the far higher number left housing officials "ecstatic," as one put it today.
Mr. Cuomo said the higher mortgage ceiling would benefit about 70,000 families, many of them members of minorities.
Mr. Cuomo praised the bill not only as "the reflection of Democratic principles" but also as the product of dogged, bipartisan negotiations. He thanked Democratic negotiators as well as their Republican counterparts.
Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island, chairman of the Banking Committee's housing subcommittee, said the House Republican leadership had eased the way for the bill by combining it with the appropriations bill for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Assuming that the HUD portion passes more or less intact, the housing agency's funds for the fiscal year that began last Thursday would increase about $2 billion, to $26 billion.
Democrats had pushed for measures to prevent housing agencies from separating working families from the very poor, and thus fostering racial as well as economic segregation. Republicans had pushed for measures to help the working poor who live in public housing. Mr. Cuomo said the bill met both needs.

HEADLINE: Close Election Complicates Brazilian Economic Reform

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Through the anxious weeks leading up to the national elections here on Sunday, as some $30 billion fled Brazil despite a doubling of domestic interest rates, international financial officials watched for the Government to tackle cost-cutting reforms as soon as the voting ended.
But today, as official returns indicated that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso was barely squeaking through to re-election and governors allied to him were locked in runoffs later this month, the road to reform is looming longer and more complex. Polling groups and television stations that announced an overwhelming victory for President Cardoso before voting ended came under severe criticism. 
 Though exit polls reported Mr. Cardoso taking some 56 percent of the vote, official tallies this afternoon gave the President 51.2 percent of valid votes, with 56.1 percent of the votes counted. His nearest rival, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, of the leftist Workers Party, took 34 percent, substantially higher than the 24 percent polls on Sunday indicated that he would get.
Mr. Cardoso's margin was just 1.2 percentage points higher than needed to avoid a second round of balloting this month.
Ciro Gomes, an up-and-coming former Finance Minister from the northeastern state of Ceara, took 11.1 percent, while Eneas Carneiro, a nationalist who called for Brazil to build an atom bomb, gained 2.2 percent of the vote. Though voting in Brazil is largely obligatory, the share of abstentions and invalid votes reached 30 percent.
Allies of the President did poorly in many of Brazil's most populous and politically influential states, weakening his hand going into negotiations for overhauling the way the Government spends money.
Though Brazil has not yet submitted a formal request, Brazilian officials have been in Washington negotiating some form of assistance from the International Monetary Fund that will probably total $30 billion or more.
The country's failure to cut spending in two key areas -- social security and civil service -- and to simplify and improve tax collection, makes Brazil heavily dependent on foreign capital at a time when investors are fleeing emerging markets generally.
Brazil's budget deficit is exceeding 7 percent of gross national product, and its current account deficit, which includes its balance of trade as well as debt service and other payments, constitutes more than 4 percent of G.N.P.
Government cutbacks of $5 billion and the doubling of inter-bank loan rates to almost 50 percent have slowed but not stopped the flight of capital. Some $300 million had left foreign reserve coffers today as of 6 P.M., and the Sao Paulo stock market was down 4.47 percent.
Investors appear to be watching for lasting reforms from the Government and for signs that wealthy nations will back Brazil.
But the political arena remained strangely silent today, almost suspended. By this afternoon, Mr. Cardoso still had not claimed victory, and Mr. da Silva had not conceded defeat. Sergio Amaral, the President's spokesman, said Mr. Cardoso would wait until official results were completely tallied before speaking.
Newspapers in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo headlined exit polls showing the President doing vastly better than official tallies reported, and in state races, polling institutes by and large played down the strength of leftist candidates, bringing the institutes under attack.
"The nation has watched the most shameful political and electoral manipulation heard of in recent history," said a statement from the coalition of parties that Mr. da Silva represented. It said polling institutes, news media and electoral officials conspired "to influence public opinion and alter the electoral will."
Mauro Francisco Paulino, director of opinion polls for Datafolha, one of the main polling services, denied any intentional manipulation of the results. He predicted that the final results would support the exit polls.
Claudia Santoro, a spokeswoman for Ibope, the other major polling group, said the director would not speak until all results were tallied.
In Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paulo, Rio Grande do Sul, Minas Gerais and Brasilia, opponents of the President, largely from the Workers Party, will be competing for governorships in the Oct. 25 runoffs.
In Sao Paulo, Minas Gerais and Rio Grande do Sul, incumbents who had supported Mr. Cardoso failed to win re-election on a first round. The Governor of Rio, Marcelo Allencar, did not run for re-election.
Congress, with its members out campaigning for gubernatorial candidates, will probably not convene to consider reforms before the end of the month, however dire the international situation. Mr. Cardoso appears to be planning for a low profile in the coming weeks, with a brief vacation in Rio state and a trip to Portugal coming up. He is not expected to openly campaign for any candidates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR TO CUT BACK AT SCOTTISH PLANT

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The National Semiconductor Corporation will close part of a plant in Scotland and dismiss 600 of the 1,000 workers there because of slumping demand for computer chips. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said that it would take a $25 million charge in its second quarter, ending Nov. 29, for the cutback in Greenock, near Glasgow and that it was interested in selling its remaining operations in Greenock. National Semiconductor shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $9, on the New York Stock Exchange. They have plunged almost 70 percent this year.

HEADLINE: CLINTON APPEALS FOR JOINT ATTACK IN ECONOMIC CRISIS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton today urged a select group of the world's top financial officials to develop a unified attack on the global economic crisis, after nearly three days of debate here have produced a near stalemate over immediate cures.
Mr. Clinton spoke tonight at the beginning of a five-hour, closed session with finance ministers and central bankers from the largest industrial economies and 15 nations with emerging markets that have been stricken by currency devaluations, plummeting stock markets and growing unemployment. 
 But the session tonight focused chiefly on long-term ideas for making the global economy less vulnerable to shocks, proposed by the United States and others, despite widespread criticism here that too little attention is being paid to coordinated immediate action.
 Mr. Clinton returns to the arena on Tuesday morning, when he addresses the International Monetary Fund. It is holding its annual meeting here along with the World Bank.
Mr. Clinton tonight echoed a lament heard often these days by politicians who feel whiplashed by the markets, saying that global capital markets "can react swiftly and harshly when countries stray from sound policies." He added, " the markets also can overreact, subjecting even countries following good policies to severe pressures."
Just hours before Mr. Clinton opened the talks, the markets proved his point, continuing their fall around the globe. While the reasons varied, from heightened fears about Japan's banks to concern that it is taking too long to put together a huge package of aid for Brazil, the declines appeared set off by fears that the first few days of meetings here contained more finger-pointing than plans for action.
Japan's stock market closed below 13,000 on Monday for the first time in 12 years -- further undercutting the financial viability of its banks -- and the Dow Jones industrial average also plunged, before recovering much of the day's loss.
A participant in the meeting tonight at a hotel along Washington's Embassy Row said the President stayed for 90 minutes of the discussion, and at various points drew 15 ministers and bank governors into the conversation. Much of the discussion centered on contrasting views of what set off the instability.
Poland's Finance Minister, Leszek Balcerowicz, a favorite of the I.M.F. because he has embraced Western-style reforms, told Mr. Clinton the problem was not that the world's early-warning system failed, but that countries refused to listen to the alarms.
Another proponent of I.M.F.-style austerity programs, Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda of Thailand, made the case that his nation -- the epicenter of the Asian crisis -- was slowly beginning to recover. But that was the only real note of optimism, and outside experts differ on whether Thailand is in recovery or simply not getting worse.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the United States would begin publishing more data about its foreign currency reserves -- a key statistic -- in hopes that other countries would follow suit. But the only action taken by the group, however, was to pass on a series of reports about reform measures to governments around the world, for their perusal.
While officials seem to be reaching some consensus about preventing future turmoil, more fissures opened at today's session over how the world should respond, at a moment when the United States, the Europeans and the emerging-market nations all have different prescriptions.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin directly confronted Southeast Asian nations that have been pressing for -- and in a few cases enacting -- rules that would restrict the rights of investors to move money freely across national borders.
"Misguided exchange and capital controls are not the answer for dealing with the effects of this crisis," Mr. Rubin insisted in a speech to the leading advisory panel to the World Bank.
He was clearly referring most directly to Malaysia, which has not only imposed such controls, but also arrested and imprisoned the country's former Finance Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, an ally of Mr. Rubin's. Malaysia announced today that it would suspend Mr. Anwar's trial, on charges of revealing state secrets and sodomy, while President Clinton visits Malaysia next month for the next major meeting on the global crisis, involving leaders from around the Pacific Rim.
Mr. Rubin also delivered a rare public rebuke to both the World Bank and the I.M.F., institutions created 53 years ago to stabilize the world economy, for their troubles in coming up with common solutions to the crisis.
"It is past time to put aside institutional rivalries unbefitting public institutions with the same shareholders," he said. "The I.M.F. and World Bank must evolve to meet the new demands of the global economy. All of us must work together."
But among the thousands of delegates who moved through the meetings, wending their way from seminars on debt restructuring to glittering embassy receptions, criticism grew that Mr. Rubin and leaders of the other major economies should move more quickly to show they have a short-term plan.
George Soros, the billionaire hedge fund manager, said in a forum sponsored by Foreign Policy magazine today that "the G-7 should be shut in a room and not allowed to come out until they have reached a decision" to extend loan guarantees and other backup financing to countries like Brazil that are "essentially following the right policies."
A year ago Mr. Soros was blamed by many at the I.M.F. and World Bank meetings in Hong Kong for accentuating Asia's troubles by betting against its currencies -- an accusation he denied. But today he pressed his argument that countries have increasingly become slaves to the notion that markets are always right and self-correcting, declaring, "Right now, market fundamentalism is a greater threat to open society than any totalitarianism."
In his public comments at least, Mr. Clinton has stepped around the sensitive issue of how much governments should intervene to contain market excesses. It is a territory where he is likely to bow to Mr. Rubin, a former Wall Street trader who is extraordinarily cautious about any moves that might smack of government efforts to restrict the free flow of capital.
Instead, Mr. Rubin has pressed an agenda of long-term fixes to make the way countries handle their resources more transparent and to establish uniform rules when countries or companies cannot pay their debts.
Today several of those were endorsed in three reports issued by the G-22 -- a group of 22 countries that has turned into a think-tank about future economic crises. One called for the release of far more economic data by countries and companies alike, noting that the lack of such information "exacerbated" the panic that began in Asia last year.
Another report endorsed changes in I.M.F. strategy so that countries that could be hit by economic contagion -- a phrase that was rarely heard at these meetings until the Mexican peso crisis of 1995 -- can "seek early assistance." That is the essence of a proprosal President Clinton made on Friday, but its success depends on the approval by Congress of $18 billion in additional funds for the agency. Republicans in the House of Representatives are overwhelmingly opposed, and there was no action today on resolving the House's differences with the Senate, which approved the commitment to the fund more than a month ago.
A report on strengthening weak financial systems in countries around the world calls for a series of regulatory changes, including bankruptcy laws and established procedures to govern the restructuring of a nation's debt. The report suggested that in some extreme cases countries might be forced to suspend all payments to their creditors. This would in turn require foreign banks and other lenders to work out a repayment schedule and pay a greater share of the cost of bringing the country back to solvency.
Many of these ideas have been in circulation for long enough now that they have begun to develop a momentum of their own. But they do not address the current crisis, and many officials here are complaining that Mr. Rubin and the I.M.F. are focusing on rebuilding the hospital before they have treated some critically ill patients.
But coordinated action is in short supply. The markets have been waiting to hear word of some kind of pre-emptive financial assistance for Brazil, totaling $30 billion or more, but while the details have largely been negotiated the Brazilian government is loathe to announce it until President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's apparent victory in a Sunday election is secured.
And representatives of virtually all the major countries here, especially Asian nations, say they are still waiting for most signs that Japan is ready to deal with its banking crisis. The market drop in Tokyo today, just days after the lower house of Parliament passed the latest bill over dealing with the banks, suggested that investors believe that Japan is still not doing enough.
"It's straightforward," said Kenneth Courtis, the chief economist for Deutsche Bank's Asia operations. "We've gotten from Japan all that we are going to get."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Pact at Pratt & Whitney

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Pratt & Whitney of East Hartford, Conn., and the union representing 6,600 hourly wage earners have reached a tentative contract deal that is likely to help the company whittle down its work force.
The pact is expected to offer an early retirement incentive for the 1,000 employees that Pratt wants to eliminate by spring. If enough people do not retire, the jet-engine company presumably would resort to layoffs. 
 Union representatives and officials said they would not discuss details of the proposed pact until employees saw it. A ratification vote is scheduled for Wednesday.
Pratt says it wants to cut employees because of the recession in Asia, which has prompted several carriers there to defer deliveries of new planes. The company says there also has been a temporary dip in orders for military aircraft.
